Definition: In this task you will be given a review body and tell whether it is positive review or negative review.

First off, this protector is very clear. It does not take away from the gorgeous 10.1 screen. Second, the application was easy. I have a specific regimen for installing screen protectors, and I will let you know how to install them every time, without bubbles OR dust.
Go into your bathroom, preferably the smallest in your house that has a shower. Turn your shower on HOT and let it run until the room is steamed up. THIS IS WHAT HOLDS ALL OF THE DUST DOWN! Next have a piece of scotch tape ready just in case. Make sure your hands are cleaned with soap. Remove the backing, align, and lay down from one end to the other. If you see a bubble, STOP immediately, pull back a bit and depending if it was just air keep going, if it was dust, use the tape to pull it off.
This method has worked for me flawlessly for the past 5 years. Hope it works for you too. Thanks Mr Shield!

I picked this up to fix some connection issues present in the top floor of the house. With this wireless repeater here, I'm now getting excellent connections everywhere, even in places where I was getting below 10% signal. My router is on the bottom floor (I use wired connections in the room it is in), I set the repeater up on the second floor (where the signal is still good) and the previous problems on the third (top) floor are gone.

With the included CD, setup is quick and easy. All you have to do is run the software, plug this in near your wireless router (so it can connect easily) then move it wherever makes sense to better increase your coverage. It couldn't be easier to get perfect wireless coverage in any area.

I give this item five stars for price, ease of installation, and functionality. Reading the reviews and knowing ahead of time that I might need to try a couple of things proved invaluable. After reading all the other reviews, I knew that if it didn't work on the first try then to change the jumper location. It worked perfect on the second try. Many other reviewers said their drives just float unsecured in the enclosure but my 300 GB Western Digital drive had holes that lined up perfectly on the narrow sides (top and bottom). What I didn't know is that a plastic slider conceals the screw holes. I found this by accident. After removing both sliders, I saw the two holes on each side and lined them up with my drive. Now I'm locked and loaded and all data is now backed up thanks to my now-external hard drive.
What can you say about this, it was what it is suppose to be and at a very great price.

I am not a gamer. I purchased this card for photography and video editing, to speed up my system. Nvidia GTS450 series was recommended on another web site as best in its price range for the month. Difficult to find those not factory overclocked. This card's GPU will run at lower temperature than competing products, even at full load. It may translate into longer life, time will tell. Works fine with Linux, being nvidia I was guessing I would get better performance (drivers) than with AMD/ATI card (AMD/ATI Linux drivers need to improve compared to Windows drivers).    I am surprised that no effort was made to exhaust the heat in the back of the PC. This card seems to dump heat in the PC case, despite the fact it takes two slots, one filled with just vents. Fan will throttle up/down with load, but even at full throttle it is very quiet. Verify your power supply will support it before purchasing. I believe before attempting to play with overclocking and overvolting, one would get more speed by looking for the factory overclocked versions of this card (810 MHz, 850MHz & 933 MHz)

The MS wireless laser desktop 6000 is a great product that should make a lot of customers happy. However, it does have a few slight, nagging problems that, in reality, would lead me to give it a 4.5 star rating. But based on Amazon's rating scale, I rounded up to 5 stars.

This desktop set has a lot going for it. The installation of the software was painless. The wireless connection is simple plug'n'play with the USB dongle--the keyboard and mouse didn't even have to be sync'd up, it worked right out of the box. It's nicely constructed and has a pretty sharp looking design. The keys are ergonomic and comfortable for all-day use. There are plenty of dedicated function keys that are clearly mapped out for things like the calculator and media center commands. In addition, there are programmable keys up at the top of the board that let you assign any program or document to them. You just hit the key and it asks you what you'd like to assign to it. And for the ultimate test, I let a very non-techie friend borrow the keyboard for a week and she had zero problems installing it or assigning programmable functions to it. It's a great desktop combo, and I would give it a full 5 stars if I had never used Logitech's Wave Desktop.

So what are the shortcomings of the microsoft 6000? The first thing that's a dealbreaker is the mouse--for lefties. This is a right handed mouse. The Logitech Wave Desktop has an ambidextrous mouse by comparison.

The other minor problems are indeed, minor and somewhat personally picky. First, the mouse scroll wheel glides freely when used. I prefer a scroll wheel that has a click-step resistance so that I can scroll a specified 3, or 6, or 9 lines at a time. Again, not a big deal, and more of a personal preference. The final thing is the space bar. The space bar is soft and has some \\"lazy action.\\" It just doesn't bounce up quickly the way I'd like it to when I'm cruising along typing fast. It's functional and very useable, just not a real 5-star perfect.

So, overall, I'm a little torn. I really, really like this keyboard/mouse and would give it 5-stars. But since I've also tried out the Logitech Wave (you can check my Amazon review on that as well), I have to give that a 5-star rating and my full recommendation--especially for lefties. If you prefer a free-scrolling mouse wheel, or a few more easy to use programmable buttons, then go with the MS Desktop 6000.just not a real 5-star perfect. So, overall, I'm a little torn. I really, really like this keyboard/mouse and would give it 5-stars. But since I've also tried out the Logitech Wave (you can check my Amazon review on that as well), I have to give that a 5-star rating and my full recommendation--especially for lefties. If you prefer a free-scrolling mouse wheel, or a few more easy to use programmable buttons, then go with the MS Desktop 6000.

This is a review of the 2 Pack Mini Book Light LED Task Desk Lamp. I received these lights in exchange for this review.

These things are great! They're impressively bright and easy to adjust. My chair's in a darker corner of the living room and my laptop doesn't have backlit keys. I plug one of these into a USB port on the laptop and after a little adjusting to keep the glare off the screen and out of my eyes there's plenty of light to type and see even the small print on the function keys.

On top of being a good task light on the laptop you can plug these into a portable battery charging pack and instant flashlight! I have a charging pack with dual USB ports plugging both in creates a blinding amount of light. At only 1.2w draw per lamp a good battery pack would last quite a while.

Another use these would be handy for is if the dome/interior lighting in your car was inoperable. You could plug one or both of these lamps into a car's USB charging port for quick and you've got quick and easy interior lighting.

Two features I would love to see added to these lights are a dimmer control the lights are very bright and sometimes you don't need the full output of the lamp. An on/off switch would be a useful if not entirely necessary feature. I wouldn't mind the option to leave the lamp plugged into the laptop when I didn't need light.

One thing of note is on the opposite side from the lights there is a metal heat sink that does get quite warm. I tested the sink for a bit over an hour and while it didn't cause any burns it was warm enough that I wanted to stop touching it so give it a few minutes to cool down before handling or throwing it in your bag or pocket.
For the Price ... Very impressive

I bought this to give to a friend as a gift about a year ago and it's still working flawlessly.  Unlike the comment by another owner, this works with the Motorola SB5120 (my service provide is Cox cable, I tested this on my network before gifting it to confirm it works).  It's very flexible and the two main features to use it for is as a router or a wireless bridge which it does both well.      On it's ease of use, the only problem some people may have is an ip conflict with the modem, so the first thing you'll need to do is log into the router and change it's default ip address (changed it to 192.168.5.1 for my friend and backed up the settings), especially if you use dsl since it seems to have a conflict with the motorola dsl modem (ironically didn't have to do it with my cable modem).      How does it perform?  As a router it's decent and able to stream video but it's range is shorter than my far more expensive belkin n+ and it's lan ports are a tad slower than my older linksys wrtu54g-tm (tmobile branded).  As a wireless bridge I was able to survey about the same amount of wireless networks as the wireless n cards in both my laptop and netbook, and the only disappointment is when I connected my external antennae to it, which didn't provide any kind of range boost to see more networks like my rosewill rnx-easy4n 2t2r router used as a wireless bridge (the rosewill cost twice as much at the time).  When wireless bridging, using this as a lan access point, make sure the router connected to the internet is not setup to auto channel negotiation, otherwise if it chooses a less traffic channel the wireless bridges will periodically disconnect (as a wireless bridge it doesn't automatically change it's channel).  I do get the 150 speed closer to the router and less when further.  It also supports wpa2 when used as a bridge for the security conscious but won't do ddns as a wireless bridge (so the main modem connected router still has to be configured as such).    The manual is poorly written, the router defaults to the easy setup mode which doesn't help most beginner's on troubleshooting, and many of the features it has as menu options lack any details of what it can or will do when changed.  I think most manufacturers should explain into greater details of what some of the menus can do so people can maybe get more out of their router in the future.    Features on this router for the price is great.  The only thing it's missing is an usb port for connecting it to a printer, hard drive, or mobile network dongle.  It does more than most big name routers just because it gives you the option to use it as a wireless bridge and in the future it will be one of the determining factors for my future router upgrades.  Routers like this can hurt the broadband companies as neighbors may contemplate sharing their service since you can use this to connect to another person's network and then have it connected to another wireless router to share the service wirelessly with the rest of the people in that second home by making sure the wireless bridge in in the optimal position to connect to the modem connected router then using ethernet to position the second wireless router for the best distribution.

My Environment:
I live in a 3,000 sq foot home spread over 3 floors plus a basement. We have multiple devices, an ipad, a home laptop, 2 playbooks, a work laptop and work related iphone. I use Channel 11 and have set up both 2.4 and 5.1 MHz options. the laptops and iPad can only use 2.4, whereas the Playbook can use the dual band.

The house dates from 1900, so lots of brick walls, duct work etc. All relevant to wireless connectivity.

My old router (Buffalo) was causing issues, so time for replacement. I tried an offering from ASUS and Linksys, both of which had their drawbacks, before alighting on the WD900. In general wireless reception is excellent throughout the house (not the case with the Asus), streaming on the Playbooks is great (not the case with the Linksys, although ipad and laptop streaming was fine).

One problem is with Skype. We use the video chat alot and it is performing badly, picture freezes, sound is slurred etc. We never had this issue with my old router and it touches everyone we chat with.

I have tried several things but to no avail, I will keep trying with this but may have to return it and try a Buffalo. I prefer not to buy on the internet due to difficulty with returns but Buffalo are hard to come by via any other channel.

There is one flaw that none of these 5-star reviews seem to mention and I wish they did because I wouldn't have purchased the mouse.

When the scroll wheel is free spinning as opposed to the \\"clicky\\" setting, if you move the mouse quickly, the scroll wheel activates ever so slightly, which causes the window your in to scroll (or zoom, depending on what scrolling does).

What does this mean? It means when you're browsing a website and move your mouse down, the page scrolls a bit. When you're modeling something in SolidWorks and move your mouse quickly from one point to another, it zooms in/out. It seems like a minor thing, but it gets very annoying, VERY fast.

The solution is to click the scroll wheel down to get it into \\"clicky\\" mode, but it's the worst scrolling experience ever I've ever had. It's very inconsistent--one click will sometimes scroll me down 100 pixels while the next click might scroll me down 40 pixels. I helped the neighbor set up 4 (two of these 2-PLA kits) of the \\"600 Mbps\\" ZyXEL powerline adapters in a house that has no network wiring and only one cable coax run.    In this case the neighbor has a new 57MBs cable service.  We got 57MBs down and 11MBs up consistently on speedtest.net. I was thinking we could use MoCA adapters but it hit me that those can \\"only\\" go to 100Mbps,  and besides we needed network ports in more places.    I own the 100Mbps versions of ZyXel PLAs and have found them very useful to have in the bag of tricks. Those are a bit lacking when you stream video, but they work and sites like NetFlix eventually get enough data across to have good video quality.    So we chose these ZyXel 600Mbps PowerLine Adapters.    As with the 100Mbps versions, set up is fairly easy but you have to get the user manual on the included CD to see how to add more than a single paired PLA. (Spoiler: Press the Encrypt/Reset button on the first one for 1.5-3 seconds and then do the same on the second within 2 minutes.  They handshake and pair and then exit the pairing mode.)  The challenge is that you can only pair two PLAs at a time so you have pair 2, then pair a 3rd and 4th to one of those in separate steps.    Although the instructions say that you should have an ethernet cable connected on each side, I got the paring to work even by plugging the PLAs into the passthrough sockets of the other! Make sure you check the status lights and see the HomePNA lights are on.    I started out testing with a direct cable to the new router and then switched the link to the ZyXel 600 pair plugged in to separate outlets about 20 feet apart in the kitchen. The first test yielded 30MBs.  Repeated tests after that gave 40MBps, or ~320+Mbps, which makes sense if the claimed 600Mbps means 300Up+300Down full duplex..  NB: It's possible that the performance would be less if the PLAs are placed further apart or on opposite phases of the electric panel.    Consider that if you have devices with \\"mere\\" 100mbps 100BaseT Ethernet ports, like most video sources, the link between the PLAs will EXCEED the wire speed by multiples!    Being I've been around long enough to remember when we thought 1.5Mbps was screaming and Ethernet was 10Mbps, I hesitate to complain about 320Mbps.  It's certainly respectable performance on a (\\"1000Mbps\\") Gigabit LAN interface, BUT we get the full 57MBs with a 802.11n WIRELESS link to the PC nearby!    We don't know as yet how well wireless will hold up all over the house. We're keeping these 4 around to use as the reliable wired network where needed, like to the media equipment.    Bottom line:  If you want a FAST wired ethernet link where you have no wiring, these powerline adapters will bring it.

This product and it's matching adapter along with 8 standard 18 inch SATA cables (4 to connect the bracket to 4 available SATA ports on the motherboard in the PC and 4 to connect the adapter to the 4 SATA6 hard drives in the SATA RAID Silo.) solved a need I had to retrofit an older 4 hard drive SCSI RAID Silo to a 4 hard drive SATA6 RAID Silo and this solution allowed me to come out of my PC as eSATA via 4 standard 6 foot eSATA cables and connect to my newly created eSATA6 RAID 0 Silo.

There's no electronics in the bracket or the adapter to auto-negotiate or slow the data rates down which is good so this bracket and the adapter and standard eSATA cables will pass SATA/SATA1/SATA1.5 = 150 Mb/sec or SATA2 = 300 Mb/sec or SATA3/6 = 6 Gb/sec - all with no problem. I also bought 2 dual Y adapters to convert the older Molex hard drive power connectors in the SATA RAID Silo to SATA hard drive power connectors from Radio Shack. The job looks like a professional or factory installation.

The seller was very responsive and helpful when I discovered I ordered two of these brackets but I really needed one bracket for the PC and the matching adapter for the RAID Silo. They did the exchange and did not charge me shipping charges the second time to send me the adapter and were very nice about everything.

Retrofit costs:

Older 4 hard drive SCSI RAID Silo on Craig's List $15.00, Internal to External eSATA 4 Port PCI Bracket and matching Internal to External eSATA 4 port Adapter with shipping $44.95, 8 standard 18 inch SATA cables with shipping $10.80, 4 standard 6 foot eSATA cables with shipping $23.99 and 2 Molex to SATA dual Y power adapters $12.99 Total: $107.73 - Not bad! Now the cost of the four WD Caviar Black, 750 GB, SATA6, 64 MB Cache, 7,200 RPM hard drives inside the SATA6 RAID 0 Silo is a totally different story. Fortunately I got mine before the Thailand floods. :-)

This was the first stylus I ordered to use on my iPad and occasionally on my iPhone (fat fingers), mostly for gaming. The microfiber tip worked pretty well and seemed responsive, although occasionally using it to select something on the screen took a couple of tries. The part I didn't like was the tether, which I found pretty useless. First, the plastic nub that supposedly fits into the headphone jack is a pain. It's either too big or too stiff, or both because it's a struggle to get the dang thing in the jack. Then, it's a pain to get it back out again. I found myself just abandoning it and dropping the stylus in my pocket. It also concerned me that the microfiber tip was totally exposed to lint and other possible contaminants in my pocket, although I lost it before I can say for sure that would have been a problem.

Bottom line: for a stylus you keep on the table or desk until you need it, this guy is reasonably priced and works pretty good. Sapphire blue color is cool, too. Had I not lost it, that's what I would have done - AFTER I cut off the annoying tether. I ended up replacing it with a pair of New Trend styli with retractable tips, which I like a lot better.

This has been my latest waste of money in a long line of 802.11n routers that just don't work. Some overheat and crash, others (inexplicably) don't support UPnP, and then there's the DIR-655: every hour or two of moderate use, the network cuts out, and nothing but rebooting the router causes it to come back. It's not overheating - it doesn't even feel warm. The network just vanishes, interrupting the movie, game, file transfer, or whatever I'm doing at the time. And since it's using the latest firmware, the problem can't be solved with a simple firmware upgrade.

Save yourself a headache - look elsewhere. This thing's less-than-impressive feature set isn't worth the stability problems.

I installed this SSHD about a week ago in my main desktop PC (Win 7 Pro) in the hope of improving boot speed. During that interval I have made sure to boot a LOT, multiple times every day. I also use a stopwatch to see how far along it is at the various stages. At this point I must say I'm NOT impressed. The boot time with my old HDD was about 5 minutes, and the boot time with this new drive is, well, about 5 minutes. Yes, this is a pretty busy machine with lots of drivers, cloud connections, and etc. But really, I've seen no appreciable difference.

That's not to say that I've had any problems with this drive, and if you told me it was a nice HDD I'd agree with you. But as for speed improvement, I don't see it yet. Perhaps it will come with time, and if it does I will update this review.

For now, this experiment has served to make me want a true 1tb SSD.

Your mileage may vary.

12/25/2014 Update: Santa brought me a 1tb true SSD (Samsung 840 EVO), and after a few hours to clone from the SSHD to the SSD, here's the result. Boot time from cold, same stuff with EVERYTHING loaded including cloud, scanner, you name it (drumroll please) went from over 5 minutes (SSHD) to just a hair over one minute (SSD). Comments seen below notwithstanding, this nails it for me. I have nothing in principle against SSHD hybrid drives, but they're only marginally (and in my case almost undetectably) better than a standard old 7200 HDD. This is now the second older PC that I've upgraded with a true SSD, and the results are the same on both -- it's given new life to machines I was ready to trash. BTW the 1tb 840 EVO was on sale for a brief moment for $350 at Amazon, and when the prices drop that low again I'm going to similarly outfit my wife's computer. And YES you CAN absolutely measure this with a stopwatch. You could almost measure the difference with an hourglass. (Sorry, being a bit cheeky on that last comment). Of course all of my apps and (for some reason) web pages are much snappier now. True SSD is the right move, particularly now that prices have come down to Earth!f my apps and (for some reason) web pages are much snappier now. True SSD is the right move, particularly now that prices have come down to Earth!

I ordered this kit two weeks ago and I really love it. The shipping is amazingly fast. The original package shipped a few wrong items but the seller kindly made a quick replacement. After exploring the kit for one week I would say I really love it.

- The cloned kit gives a quick start on arduino. Yes it does not include some of the electronic parts offered by official kit, but it's far cheaper (1/3 of the official price).

- With these items you can test a lot of ideas. Many sensors (include Light Sensor (Photocell), Temperature Sensor) helps you to realize your task, preliminary. When in need, it's easy to extend the kit. The seller has a lot of sensors/extensions for sell. you can look into that.

- It's a good starter kit to learn new things. With this small kit in hand, you can get all benefits from the open source arduino, including software, board design sheet, source code, tutorials... These are all compatible. (The seller has a mini/micro starter kit at even cheaper price. But there're more documentations of uno. So if you are new to arduino, I still recommend this kit). Within one weekend, I already figured out how to develop programs on this microcontrollers, and familiar with every corner of arduino software internals. By the end of last week, I can already program this kit without using arduino library, but with raw avr libc to optimize the performance/energy consumption ratio.

- Yes there's no instruction (well, the seller provides link to an ebook if you want). But who needs it? With abundant online information, it's easy to get familiarize with the circuit design. When in doubt, just google it.

- The quality is good. Well you cannot compare this to the official arduino uno board design and manufacture, but it just works!

This is a truely amazing product at very low cost. I also had a very good time talking to the seller. He's a nice guy, and solves quite a few my requests/problems.

My two cents are

- just write "made in china" on the board. There's nothing to shame about. China factories do produce good products (such as your iPhone)

- Check before ship can save both time and money:)

The MXS10 is a great all around machine that truly shines if you are interested in TV/Video and audio/music functions. Not only can you watch TV on your monitor with the built-in tuner you can also record video directly to the hard drive using the integrated Personal Video Recorder (similar to Tivo). The MX also has S-Video out and Optical out to watch that same video on your home entertainment system.
Have a digital camcorder? Import and edit your video using the built-in firewire port, Even better once you are done editing burn your results to DVD. The DVD-RW that comes standard will record a DVD-R disc that is playable on most (read sold in the last 12-18 months) consumer home DVD players. (...).
Like Music? Not only does the MXS10 include CD-RW capability, a PC card slot and a memory stick slot it also includes a Mini-Disc Audio drive. Copy and create you own MD discs. MD is a high quality portable music technology pioneered by Sony. The MX also has an integrated FM receiver for listening to the radio.
All this and a great looking package that includes shelf size speakers.

I bought one of these less than a year ago and suddenly it quit accepting my user password and the admin password. Same passwords that had been on the device since I first set it up.  As a result I lost everything that had not been backed up. With the reliability of disks these days, I am not too conscientious about doing backups so that was quite a bit of data.  Usually you have to worry about a disk going bad, but with the Padlock you also get to worry about the Padlock firmware malfunctioning too.  Support could not help, and the only recourse was to reset and reformat it.  Bottom line: Be aware that all the data on the Padlock could become inaccessible at any time.  I was able to reset it and it is usable again now, but I lost everything that was on it. I will never be able to trust it again.

I have been a customer at Amazon since it first started and have bought hundreds and hundreds of items over the years, but I have never, until now, written a review. I absolutely have to write this one because this product has so exceeded my expectations. This is the first technology product I have ever acquired in my thirty years of being in the technology field that has worked flawlessly in the first ten seconds of use. I don't read manuals anyway, but in this case, no one has to read anything - you just plug these devices into the wall outlets and you are good to go.

I needed to extend my very fast Internet connection beyond where it comes into the house and didn't want to take the time to set up and properly secure a wireless network. I decided to try these devices based on a review by Walt Mossberg in the Wall Street Journal of a similar device by NetGear. He said it was easy, but this was so easy it's astonishing. Step one: I removed the device from its container, plugged it into a wall socket, and removed the cable connection that went from my cable modem to my laptop and plugged it into the device. Step two: I took my laptop downstairs, removed the second device from its box, plugged it into a wall socket, plugged my laptop into it and there it was - my Internet connection with the same speed I had originally. And I didn't even have to reboot!

If all of technology were this easy, we'd be a lot further ahead!

I too didn't have enuff juice to apply this correctly on my xoom. ONLY IF YOU HAVE ENUFF JUICE. Luckly I had a similar product for another device and it came with more than enuff juice (pack rats rejoice) which I used to redo the whole installation.  It would have been happily ever after if I had spent more time keeping the screen clean during install, so a dog hair made it near the corner, I lifted the corner, removed hair and rejuiced and sqeegi'd the corner down, now there is a line where I pulled the cover back to.  then I tried to pull the cover half way back (I was running out of juice) I was left with a line halfway down the screen and another one by the corner.  I gave up and didn't even use it with the toilet as a practical joke.  Make sure if you get this do it right the first time and use every drop or get more juice.    -a

The enclosure looks very nice, matches the iMac, MacBook aluminum finish and style. The firewire 800 interface is fast. I recently replaced the internal Hard Drive of my Mid 2007 iMac with a Crucial M4 SSD. Used this enclosure to convert the old internal SATA drive into an external drive. Since the SSD is relatively small (256 GB), this external drive will be permanently attached and will contain my large iTunes library, movies and other stuff. The Firewire 800 interface will be very useful because it is by far the best option that I have on this old iMac. So far so good.

There was a minor issue. The screws that come for attaching the plastic feet of the enclosure are of very bad quality. No matter how careful you are, they get stripped. Luckily, I found a couple of screws that worked. No problem with my screws, with same screwdrivers that stripped the original ones, so definitely the original ones are of bad quality. Some other reviewer reported the same problem, so Macally, it is a shame that your otherwise very good product gets lower reviews due to such a minor, cheap, easy to fix detail.

I recommend the product, but you may have to get your own screws for the (optional) bottom feet.

The cable is well made, the "head" is not too big, the concept behind it is great and it really will charge faster on a less powerful charger or port.  If there was a replacement guarantee I'd rate this better but who knows how long you have before it craps out?  Its a gamble.  Edit: So I am updating the review to 4 stars from 2 because there is a 1 year warranty although I don't see it mentioned on the amazon page.  They made it pretty easy to get a replacement with a photo of the old cable destroyed (cut in half).  I still don't think I can give the 5th star for a non-certified cable even though they don't advertise it as certified, I will have to wait 1-2 weeks for the replacement which means you need a spare cable if you use this because it will inevitably stop working.

July 12, 2017 Dead at two year mark, again!  I owned a Linksys EA3500 which only lasted two years. I really liked the Smart Wifi app so I upgraded to the WRT 1900 thinking I would have better luck. Dead at 2 years, one month.  At first we had 1-3 minutes where the WRT  fell off cable modem, but it came right back up.  I assumed it was the internet coming into the house. Comcast came out, dug new line in yard, replaced the gateway. I reset my WRT and the next day the same thing.  Within a couple days it stopped working altogether.  Time to look into another brand. Original Review below:   I had owned a Linksys EA series router and decided to upgrade bc (1) the number of devices in our house has increased dramatically in the last couple of years and (2)there has never been good signal in our master bedroom, which is the furthest away from the router. On the old one I especially liked the parental control feature and the iPhone app.  So, after a bit of research, decided this WRT was the way to go. I have not been disappointed: super easy installation, love the windows based screens as I am not much of a command prompt user and the 5g AC wifi is super fast.  Amazon delivery was also surprising fast.  But, I did call the customer service about 4 days after installing it as I had a problem and didn't know what to do. I called the number on the box that was provided for initial help. I was very disappointed that the person who attended my call told me this was a very complicated router meant for a business application and tried to sell me a different router for $100 more.  I was very upset and told him I was calling for help not sales. He gave me another number where the gentleman helped me through a very simple solution.  This is the only reason I can't give the product 5 stars.

One of the things I had heard a lot about was the PowerBook's long battery life, and they weren't kidding. While 5 hours is a bit high, for normal use 3 to 4 is a very rough range. Even so, 3 hours is a long longer than some PC laptops gets, such as my old Compaq Presario 2195US. Even more so than the long battery life, though, which in itself is amazing, is the seamless transition from running from the power adapter and running from the battery. Unlike the Compaq I mentioned before, in which XP would switch to the battery settings, dimming the screen and slowing it down (and even when I set it to maximum performance it still seemed slower) everything stays the same. No kidding. Unplug. No difference. Plug it in. The same thing. While trying to setup my wireless network, I forgot to plug it in, running off the battery the entire time without even knowing it. When I finally did, I was amazed that I wasn't running from the wall: it was exactly the same experience as when it was plugged in. So for that 4 hours you get the most amazing experience due, in part, to Mac OS X.

In terms of power--RAM, CPU, etc.--I am impressed. The standard 256MB RAM that comes with the computer is simply not enough, and I've had a few slow-downs even with an extra 512MB installed (for a total of 768MB RAM). Albeit I was running a dozen large applications, the point is that extra RAM is a must and that maxing it out is the best thing you can do, so long as you have the extra money to spend. It really makes a difference. As far as raw processor power goes, I found it a bit slow at first (though much faster than a 1.33GHz PC). My experience here is sordid, though, because I at first owned an 867MHz Rev. A PowerBook for about a month or so before trading it in for this Rev. C beauty. Regardless, whatever slowdowns I experiences at first are all but gone--or I've grown used to them. Either way, this thing runs like a Ferrari.

I can't really comment on its size and weight, as I have yet to carry it around with me much, but I will make a note of the screen size: despite it being merely 12\\"--quite smaller than the 15\\" screens I have been using on laptops for the past year--I was accustomed to it almost immediately. I remember using my mom's laptop at one point a week after buying this that looking at her 15.4\\" widescreen was just.. I was thunderstruck at how large it was. Afterwards, I went back to my laptop, and saw a normal-sized screen. I was incredulous before making my purchase, people who said the screen was fine being quite unconvincing, but I have to say that they were absolutely right. You get used to it in an instant, and everything else is, well, huge in comparison.

And how quiet it is! I've never been one to be bothered by the sound of computer fans--though the ones in my old desktop were outrageously loud and annoying--and thought my old laptop to have been quiet, but after using a PowerBook for two months, I know better. I would classify my old Compaq as not loud, as it truly wasn't, but definitely not quiet. Quiet is this, my PowerBook. More than a few times I've made a reach for the power button, and even begun to press it, before I realized that it was asleep, usually brushing against my mouse and awakening the computer, the screen glowing as it came to life. That is quiet.

I simply must mention Mac OS X, even though it isn't a hardware part of the PowerBook. It has made my experience exponentially better. Though odd at first--I had to relearn how to make line breaks in IM clients, how to use the Command key as often as the Control key, and even learn the combos (Command+Shift+Letter, for instance)--it really has made computing more fun. I know it sounds corny, and at first it wasn't that way, but having grown used to it, seeing some of the applications out there, using them, etc., I couldn't be happier. On top of a different way of obtaining most apps--that is, paying for them via credit card and simply buying the CD key, then downloading the trial software and unlocking all the features--there is such a diverse selection to choose from. For instance, there's iComic, which, using Perl scripts, allows you to view [web]comics from within it, and even download them to your hard drive automatically. I don't know of any PC program that does this. As opposed to doing everything with one program, you have multiple, smaller, more efficient applications. For instance, instead of using Photoshop to slowly and painstakingly fade the ends of my images out to a white, I can simply set a template in, say, Yellow Mug Software's EasyFrame, drag all my files into it, and it'll do the same thing automatically. Which brings up arguably the best part: the widespread use of drag 'n' drop. The most basic and amazing use being that, when you want to open a file in a non-default program, instead of right clicking, going to Open with..., etc., you can simply drag the file to the application in question and drop it on it, automatically opening it in that application.

Overall, my experience with this PowerBook, and its OS, has been nothing short of stunning; amazing; the greatest computer experience of my life. Not only is it fun, but the OS is unparalleled and it finds the balance PC laptops can only dream of achieving: being portable without sacrificing performance.

I ordered these batteries to replace my old originals in my APC unit. They came packaged securely and looked like the originals. I simply slide out the original batteries, connected up the replacements, and buttoned the unit back up. Took about 5 mins and works great.

I did notice that the run time was not very long but this is not a problem with the batteries but I had to do a calibration on the UPS unit. From the APC website, it says to apply a 30% load to the UPS (non-critical)with the computer/monitoring software turned off. Then pull the plug and let the system shut off by itself. This recalibrates the CPU in the UPS for the new battery. I did this and my UPS run time went from 2 minutes to 25 minutes.

Michael

Ordered the KDM 270W power supply from eboxdirect and a seller sent me two of the Kentek KT-FATX250 power supplies instead. They were was supposed to replace a SPI FSP200-50PL-B 200W power supply that had failed, and the second one was intended to be a spare.

The SPI 200W power supply that failed is used to run a a custom security equipment setup which includes a LCD monitor, finger print reader, RFID reader, a camera and a a couple of other items. A total of 22 SDI power supplies are used in an identical setup, and they have been running for almost 5 years already 24/7, racking up about well over 40.000 hours of run time. The first one just failed, so I figured replacing it with a power supply with a higher rating shouldn't be a problem, with a smaller load factor, it might last even longer.

Set this Kentek power supply up running the same exact equipment, didn't work. The LCD monitor would not turn on. After doing some modifications to how the distribution board was set up, the LCD monitor finally started working. Not sure how long this thing will last.

It appears that this power supply simply can't handle the load and is poorly regulated, as there is a severe voltage drop on the 5V and 12V lines under load. Note that the setup only uses the 5V and 12V lines. The 200W SPI is rated 5V-15A and 12V-12A. The 250W Kentek is rated 5V-15A and 12V-13A.

Despite being rated higher, it was struggling to regulate the output, and I had to do some load balancing to make it work, vs the SPI runs the equipment completely stable without any issues.

This power supply appears to be poorly designed, over rated at 250W and generally not worth its weight in scrap metal. Returning the unused one and ordering a real KDM from a different supplier.

I currently have chosen to have these keys double as back and forward buttons in my web browser. This makes surfing much easier, as I don't have to move the mouse up to the top of the screen each time I want to go back or forward in the browser.
In addition, these extra buttons are essential for gaming! Since you can program what the buttons do as often as you'd like, you can change the settings around depending on what game you are playing. I like to use one of the extra buttons to reload my gun in shooting games. That is just one of the possibilities of it however.
Overall, the functionality of this mouse is excellent. It has worked perfectly ever since I got it. It is definitley worth the extra few dollars.

Tracks fine and all but the buttons on the sides aren't "gaming" buttons. They don't do what they're advertised to do and they have to be programmed and only one function advertised, rapid fire, can be programmed. The sniper button is merely a back button. I wouldn't be so bent out of shape over this if it was so falsely advertised. Yeah it's a nice price and has LED, but it's a hoax. Even the representative from Etekcity acknowledged it doesn't do what it's advertised to and nor can it even be programmed for one of the functions.

Hi Beau,
Thank you for contacting us. I am sorry to hear about the issue with your mouse. Here's a link to download the software for this mouse: http://www.mediafire.com/view/8vbv51hcxbjt5ek/T-142_Software.zip

Also, we've unfortunately found that the product documentation and description for this mouse was incorrect. The sniper and rapid fire buttons are actually just standard mouse side buttons, and as such function as back/forward navigation by default. While the software allows customizing the buttons, it doesn't seem that there's a way to enable the sniper mode as advertised, while setting the right side button to a double-click can somewhat emulate the rapid fire function. We've since revised the product listing and user's manual, but I apologize for any inconvenience caused by our mistakes. If we can help with anything at this time, please let me know. Thanks.

-Tyler
Etekcity Customer Support

Everything seems to be working OK now, but the installation of this card was problematic.  Here's why:  After installing the EVGA GeForce GT 520, I lost the onboard audio to my HP desktop (running XP Pro).  In the sound resources of the Control Panel, the NVIDIA High Definition Audio became the default and my Realtek High Definition Audio disappeared.  Solution: If the onboard audio is set to \\"Auto\\" in the BIOS, the motherboard will automatically disable the onboard audio if it detects another audio device (in this case the NVIDIA) in your computer. If you change your onboard audio setting to \\"enable\\" this will not happen, and you will get your sound back.  I did have to reinstall the Realtek driver. A couple of years ago I bought a big deal laptop with a 60 GB hard drive. Worked fine with cameras of the time that generated 3 MB image files. Then I bought newer cameras that generated 15 MB files- whoa! I started working with Photoshop. It can generate 30 MB files. Layers, you know. Wow! I filled that laptop very quick.    What to do? I bought this portable hard drive. Formatted it right out of the box as other reviewers suggested. It acts just like another drive with a different capital letter (F:). Moved about 20 GB of images out of my computer's HD in about 20 minutes-- Roughly--. Now I have room to work on my laptop, yet keep all of my image files, at the ready. I'm not a computer geek, but I think the image files move on and off this portable hard drive at a similar speed as they move on and off the laptop's internal hard drive. For $125+ or whatever, I have the space to keep on taking photos for a much longer time. I love this portable Hard drive!

The product works, but it did not work for my setup. We are upgrading one of our XP computers to Windows 7. We have a program installed on both computers called Libra Gen 3. I could get the key to read in the old computer using the 25 pin parallel port, but when plugged into the adapter using the USB port, and allowing the driver to install, the Libra software could not find the software key. I have now purchased a 25 pin parallel PCI-e card. It was worth trying for $4.

This adapter is clearly of higher quality and the plug where the cable goes into the adapter is thick but flexible and shows no sign of wear after a few months of use.  The price was reasonable, though obviously higher than the cheaper adapters out there...guess you get what you pay for.  The one thing I would note here is that the USB option for the adapter is not really useful for me.  I have the cord on the floor next to my bedside table, I just want the adapter to work and charge my laptop and its easier to plug my USB cords into the laptop or a dedicated plug.  There is nothing wrong with having it on the adapter or its functioning, I simply don't see it as having much value...maybe a different story if I traveled more with it.  In any event, this is the best adapter I have purchased for this 6 year old laptop and it has already lasted longer than its 5 predecessors and I am very happy with it.

I'm a film production student and use a USB drive every semester that I can carry with me and tote files around with. I ordered this one because it was red and looked fashionable compared to others I've owned. When it arrived I truly fell in love with it, so much so that I ordered an extra one in blue for a friend!

After using it for A WEEK I noticed one day that the whole thing was gone off of my keyring. I was SO sad and figured it may have randomly fallen off when taking it out of my jean pocket, so I ordered another one.

A WEEK after owning the second red one I was having lunch and it just feel off of the chain! Apparently the chain can get torn pretty easily, and with this second one the little ring that holds the jeweled top to the chain pulled apart slightly and allowed the usb portion to just fall off. I squeezed the ring back together but then noticed two days later that the ring was bent again and I lost the USB drive once more.

Now I'm left with a blue one that I can't take anywhere with me since it could become lost. I've owned several keyring usb drives in my school years, and this is the ONLY brand that has ever fallen off... EVER. It's disappointing because the read speeds ARE quicker than average, but what good is that if the chain breaks easy and the ring that holds it to the chain bends apart easy? Losing school related data is a serious bummer, and one that simply can't be tolerated in a USB drive.

What this is not. It is not an IPS screen made for color accuracy. You can read other reviews regarding lack of height/rotation adjustments but it works just fine for me without them as this monitor is replacing my dying CRT.

GAMES: I needed a monitor that could be fast enough to replace my 19\\" Samsung CRT (which I had since CS 1.2) to play my favorite FPS games: Counter-strike, Team Fortress 2, Left for Dead 2. And for FPS games you can't have any lag. I was a little afraid that I would feel the lag, but thankfully I can still get my one shot Deagle HS kills on my rushes. Sweet!

MOVIES: Having lived with CRTs and a DLP projector in my living room, I just can't stand ghosting lags for movies (or fast sports like Ice-Hockey, Go LA Kings!) and I have to say I'm quite satisfied. Connected through HDMI, 1080p blu-ray movies look amazingly sharp, and I can enjoy my Ice-Hockey without much ghosting. I said \\"satisfied\\" because I can still tell there's a little ghosting compared to my DLP. But it gets the job done.

HDMI and Sound: This monitor doesn't have speakers but it has an SPDIF Optical line and 3.5mm line out so you can connect external speakers to it. When you select the HDMI, the sound routes out through the line out. When you switch to the DVI the sound shuts off automatically.

My other monitor is a CINTIQ 21UX which is an IPS monitor (worth about $1800) and of course this PX2370 doesn't compare when it comes to color consistency and brightness from different angles. Compared to my IPS screen, it was a little odd how the screen got brighter or darker depending on the height I looked at (just by moving up or down 6 inches). But my IPS screen at 12ms is horrible for Games or Movies.

If you're afraid of switching from a CRT to an LCD for games, I can assure you that this monitor will be good enough for your FRAG FESTS, and you won't have to haul around a 40 pound monitor!utomatically. In my opinion, this is simply THE BEST ventilated case for its price on the market today. This is because it is the closest thing to a metal cage ever manufactured for use as a PC tower. Basically the entire upper-back portion of the case is a steel grating. Everything on your motherboard WILL be breathing fresh air at ALL times, and plenty of it. A big part of this is because the PSU is mounted on the BOTTOM, and thus isn't blocking heat from rising up and out, so instead of having a giant, hot electrical box on top of all your heat-generating components, you get two giant 140mm vents. Your drives will be getting plenty of air too with the 140mm blue-LED fan on the bottom and the fully ventilated optical drive ports, but I've never been hugely into cooling drives. Last but not least, it just looks sexy. This is a no-nonsense case in every sense of the word, however, because with all that air passing in and out there comes a lot of noise. All your fans will be heard loud and clear by anyone within fifty feet of them, and so if you're really up tight about noise (which I'm just not... at all) you should either prepare to pay an arm and a leg for super-quiet fans or get a case with some kind of noise-dampening features.    So in the end, it doesn't have plexiglass plating so you can spend your time staring at your motherboard's flashing RAM sticks, and it doesn't have giant, strobing LED lights all over its back parts, and it isn't rainbow colored with bright orange polkadots, but it has a thorough mastery of the fundamentals. Its simple, cheap, and just works and does its job WELL.

I received the Kindle Fire as a Christmas gift and decided to invest in a screen protector. I searched through various screen protectors and reviews on Amazon before deciding to purchase this product. It arrived today and was super excited to apply it since I couldn't stand all the fingerprints and smudging on its currently-bare screen (purchased stylus pens also and those help a bit).

Anyway, I took one of the two included protectors out of the packaging and noticed it had a long scratch on it. I put it aside and decided to apply the other one instead which was fine. I read the instructions on the back. After using the included cleaning cloth to completely wipe away any fingerprints and dust, I gently peeled the first layer down about an inch and applied to the top of the screen, slowly peeling the rest off as I worked it down to eliminate any bubbling (reviews on these things prepared me for the bubbleage that was to be expected). Things seemed to be going well until the last part of the application:

There was quite a long bubble in the last corner of an otherwise perfect application, and so I checked the packaging for the \\"soft card\\" that the directions say is included. It was not, so I folded the cardboard packaging itself and used it as a makeshift de-bubbler. This failed me in every way possible and I could just not get this forsaken bubble out! I cleaned my screen so well before application that I think it was cleaner than it was once I took it out of the box for this first time. Confused and bewildered by this defiant bubble, I removed the thing and proceeded to apply the second protector that had the scratch. I had one or two tiny bubbles that irritated me (I'm a perfectionist and want ZERO bubbles) so I tried to smooth them out with my makeshift de-bubbler. This failed yet again.

Maybe there was a tiny speck of dust that I missed but I doubt it--that mother was clean as heckfire. Even if it had applied flawlessly, it would have looked terrible because of the scratch. Needless to say, my night is now saddened deeply. It's like waking up Christmas morning to a new present, opening it and feeling all excited, then having it ripped out of your hands with Santa laughing as he says \\"just kidding\\". I honestly don't know what I did wrong applying it--I was extremely careful and methodical about it. I was disappointed that there was no bubble-smoother included as stated on the packaging and that one of the protectors was scratched. I gave this product two stars instead of one because had it applied the way I wanted it to, it looked like it would have been a good quality protector with a nice matte finish. But for now, I am using my Kindle without protection.rible because of the scratch. Needless to say, my night is now saddened deeply. I struggled for years with spotty video streaming. Our house is about 5000 sq ft and the wireless router is in one corner of the house. The TV is on the other side of the house, separated by many walls. Our wifi input to the TV was through my son's Wii. I have been frustrated with stalled video streaming from Netflix and Amazon Prime, frequently being unable to see the entire movie, and usually having to sit through reloads every 5 -10 minutes. I searched the internet for solutions, moved the router, turned off other devices, changed router transmission channels, bought devices to boost the signal further to the far reaches of the house, called my ISP who told me to upgrade my old modem to Docsis 3.0, had a cable technician come out to the house and try to fix the problem, and other solutions that I've now forgotten. Nothing reliably worked, until I purchased these Powerline Adaptors. They were truly "plug and play". Following the quickstart instructions I plugged the 1st adaptor into the wall socket nearest the router, then plugged the 2nd adaptor into the powerstrip behind the TV. (They recommend using the wall socket because some powerstrips can block the adaptor signal but I wanted to try it as the wall socket was used by two powerstrips for all the components of my entertainment center.) I connected the ethernet cable into the LAN receptor on the back of my Sony Blu-Ray DVD player. I went back to the 1st adaptor and all 3 lights were on, went then to the 2nd adaptor and all 3 lights were on. This was truly "plug-and-play".There was no need to press and release any buttons in sequence. I turned on the DVD player and it immediately sensed the internet connection and setup was simple.
Last night we streamed a movie in HD without a hitch. I am so thrilled that a solution has finally been found. It couldn't have been easier, and the cost is very reasonable considering the hours of time spent on inadequate solutions. Bravo!!

I've been a fan of Apple/Mac since forever and have had my eye on the Mac mini for over a year now to set up a home theater system, and as a newer system to support my old G4 that's maxed out.    The Mac mini is built with HDMI for HDTV & all the apps for the internet. That's what it's made for. So if you want the internet tv shows, movies and your email and regular internet available on your HDTV, this works with awesome results.    If you read reports about problems with the audio getting through the HDMI cable, be aware that your HDTV or sound system may not support the same audio that this Mac mini outputs, especially if these components are older. If you get no audio after set up with an HDMI cable, there are 2 solutions. One is to use the Audio Out jack on the Mac mini and get a cable to bring the audio to your system. The 2nd solution is to open the \\"Applications\\" folder, \\"Utilities\\" folder, then the \\"Audio MIDI Setup\\". Change, lower the parameters here to match what your TV or audio system can use. And also check the \\"Sound\\" set up in the Apple menu \\"System Prefs\\" to make sure that your Mac can see your HDTV at the end of that HDMI cable.    Other than this audio issue that a few are experiencing, (and I struggled with for a day), my new Mac mini is the best for what I needed. And I own (still) 5 old Mac systems that still work. It's the best system made for my money.

No need to dissolve the cilia in your ears - great sound you can hear, with no rattle. The rubber feet work great in keeping vibration at bay and preventing the satellite speakers from 'walking' around your desk. Whether you decide to put the subwoofer on the ground or on your desk, the sound is still awesome and the subwoofer is attractive enough to be on your desk... not the typical 'black box' many choose to hide in the bottom or back of their desk, which results in muting some sounds. Altec Lansing always does a great job at making great sounding speakers, in attractive, affordable packages that are much more competitively priced than those they compete with in the same class. I highly recommend these speakers.

I plugged this into an older laptop and instantly got faster wireless speeds! Setup is virtually nonexistent; just plug it in and you're pretty much good to go.

The Actiontec USB Network Adapter does what it's supposed to do easily and seamlessly. So there's not much to say there, other than it's nice to be able to connect faster wirelessly with little effort.

Cosmetically, I do have a couple quibbles. I don't like USB devices with removable caps. It's just a pet peeve because I'm always worried I'll lose it. I'd much rather it was attached in some way or if the USB plug was retractable or something. And I do agree with another reviewer that it would have been cool if this could double as a USB flash drive. I'm all for carrying as few things as possible and having this double as a USB drive would have been sweet. Other than that, it's a bit large for my taste but now I'm just being nit picky.

I did appreciate that this came with a USB extension cable. This is good if you want to use this with a desktop computer but don't want to contort behind it every time you need to plug it in. It's also good for laptops if you'd rather run the cable behind your laptop and keep the USB adapter out of sight. As I said, it is a bit large and having a USB extension sticking out the side of my laptop is more appealing to me than this huge thing.

Bottom Line: this is an excellent high speed USB network adapter. Easy to use and easy to setup. It does what it's supposed to do and does it well. But I docked it one star for design and personal pet peeves.

I used this hard drive for six months and the USB port broke internally.  It didn't fall, it didn't get any rough treatment, it just sat on my desk for six months.  I unplugged it at the end of the day after a backup and \\"snap\\".  The USB port had broken inside of the enclosure.  I tried to send it to WD to get it fixed, and I was offered a replacement w/ none of my data.  Long story short, I have now lost over 10 years of designs, photos & video projects.  NOTE: Before you get on me about data redundancy, I had all of my data on my computer at work (which i had to move the data to the external hard drive for a Win 7 upgrade) as well as I had it on a hard drive at home (a 500GB WD MyBook hard drive that got accidentally wiped by my xbox 2 weeks prior.)  I do not fault anyone for a nearly \\"perfect storm\\" type of situation.    My only problem is that any other external hard drive that I have owned has been able to be removed from it's enclosure and put into any of the multitude of hard drive enclosures available commercially without missing a beat.  Now I have to sit, scratching my head at how there can be no way to get any of my data back off of this drive while the drive itself is in perfect working order.  In researching online, it seems that this drive's hardware encryption makes it impossible to be read by any other means than the exactly as it is sold so if any vital part of the MyBook fails, the whole of it is lost.  The drive gets 2 stars because when it did work, it worked fine to my standards.  The SmartWare that comes with it didn't do what i needed from a backup solution.  It is unable to be removed from the drive but you could just not use it.  The hardware encryption was what made my data unable to be recovered.  All because of a small, flimsy USB port.
Too many problems they do not have their act toguether three times they tried to get my order right and still is wrong. Will never do business with them again.

There are so many good things about the kindle, but I feel it is let down by the clumsy interface.    If you do little else but read novels and the occasional sync for new purchases this is a great device. It has a great form factor, it's light-weight, the battery life is fantastic, the text is clear, and it is quick and easy to get new books.    However, if the content of what you read has diagrams or unusual formatting, the results are not so great. The text pagination can confuse the flow of the text and diagrams are often nowhere near the references (and it's unlikely to be on the screen at the same time). If you compare the kindle to the kindle reader applications you can get for the desktop or iPad, you can see a large gulf between was is and what could be.    A word about support of other formats. PDF is supported, but it's implementation is basic, which means you get to see a full page which is too small to read or very coarse zoom levels that give no flexibility for content. The kindle ticks the box on supporting the feature, but only just in my eyes.    In addition to formatting, the interface is the other let down. In a world of touch screens, the four-way cursor and menu system feels archaic and time consuming.        I have and iPad and a kindle. I use the kindle for reading when traveling (bus, train, plane), and the iPad for all other times. Purely because of the interface.    I guess Amazon isn't too worried about kindle sales, as it has provided lots of reader apps for more capable devices. But if you are thinking about buying a kindle - ask yourself what you want out of it. If it matches the benefits I've listed above, great! If there are any doubts, I would leave it until something better turns up.

Pros: Bought this to replace my G500 (awesome mouse also, won't take anything away from it). This mouse is really amazing. It's pure plug and play, there is no software required. It is pretty much a barebone mouse, but it delivers quite heavily on performance. Used this with CS1.6 CS:S and CoD4, and the results have been amazing. I was doing great with the G500, I'm doing even better with this thing. Also has a really low lift off point, I was pleasantly surprised by that.    Cons: I wouldn't recommend this mouse to anyone who loves a lot of buttons and flashy gimmicks on their mouse. If you are someone who heavily customizes their mouse to meet your demands, this is not the mouse for you. There is no software at ALL, and you cannot customize anything.    There also only 3 DPI settings, 500, 1000 and 2000. I think this is perfect because I have rarely seen anyone who uses more than 1600 DPI. Those 3 DPI settings are all sweet spots that cover almost every gamer on the spectrum. However, if you like customizing your DPI settings, you're out of luck here also.    The DPI button is under the mouse, so you won't accidentally pressed it in-game.      Other Thoughts: Aside from all the cons, the reason I gave this thing 5 stars is because of the performance. This thing is better than any mouse out their right now, optical or laser, in my opinion. The tracking and everything is ultra smooth, and this thing is exceptional on my Zowie SpawN GT-F(another great buy from Zowie). I would recommend this mouse to anyone. You may be turned off by the lack of features, but the performance is too good to ignore.    Zowie EC-1 was recommended to me by another pro CS player.

Been shopping around for a more permanent solution to connecting my large collection of SATA hard drives, and this one is the perfect solution. I had been swapping drives using a simple SATA-to-USB adapter, but it only works on 2.5-inch drives, not larger 3.5-inch HDDs. Since I have both a laptop and desktop, I have many of both on hand. This one unit accommodates both without hassle. It's simple but attractive and fits well on my desk, and can easily be portable if necessary. Solid as a rock and, barring some unforeseen malfunction in the future, should last a good long time.

My only suggestion to the manufacturer is to consider adding some USB 3.0 ports to the unit (it has plenty of space for at least 4) to add even greater value and versatility. Also, the power adapter cord could stand to be about a foot longer, but this is a minor quibble.

And oh yeah, it supports eSATA connections and comes with really nice cables for both eSATA and USB 3.0.

The only down side of the free scroll wheel is that it is easy to hit it accidentally and set it off. But I'm getting used to that.

Additionally, I have found that it works well through my iPad's plastic screen saver, which also appears to mitigate the noise of the tip against the glass that many have reported. The cost is a bit high and I wish there were either a pen clip or more options for attaching it to a standard size iPad, but over all I am very pleased with its performance.

Item exactly as described. This is a PCI-E USB3 adapter for consumer OS's only. This will NOT work in any server OS, even if they use the same underlying driver model as their generation's consumer OS. Specifically, even though WinXP and Windows Server 2003 use the same drivers for 99% of hardware, this will not work in Server 2003. It is almost as if the manufacturer explicitly blocked driver installation on Servers. I can understand not wanting to certify as server compatible and not support it, but taking the option away from folks willing to go unsupported sucks.

So this works perfectly fine within the constraints of what is described. Just don't try to use it in any other way.

I bought the PNY GT640 model VCGGT640XPB when it was onsale (sweet)! This version is a Kepler GK107 based 384 core GPU (28nm fab, clocked at 900MHz, and TDP=65W). The card is a full-size card and would occupy two-slot space.
However, by replacing the bracket with a 1-slot low profile bracket (borrowed from an old PCIe graphics card), the height is now the low-profile sized card. With this arrangement, you won't have the VGA output.
If you further take out the cooling fan assembly, the card is even thinner, but its heat sink will still run into the next slot (greater than 1-slot thickness). If your SFF chassis happens to have enough space to fit this card and the power supply fan can also blow into GT640's heatsink, it would be ideal.
BTW, OSX ML 10.8.x now natively supports this card. IMHO, it's a Price/Value leader.

After all of the hype about this case and it always being out of stock, I finally lucked out and got one of two left from one of the Apple stores here in Denver.

If there had not been so much hype, I may have liked this more, but overall, I was not impressed with this case.

The case is flimsy and gets dirty and scuffed up really quickly. The microfiber seems to attract and hold dirt and scuff marks.

If you plan on removing your iPad from the case, which I prefer to do at times, you'll have to give it a good fight to remove it from within the case. It's incredibly difficult to do. The iPad is so beautiful and artistically crafted, I don't want to always have it all covered up inside the case, so this became a huge problem.

Also, supposedly this case allows you to stand the iPad up in the optional charging cradle/dock that you can buy for the iPad, but the iPad needed about another 1/4 inch to be able to recognize that it was docked. So I was never able to get it to dock with the optional cradle while in this case - despite what they may claim at the Apple store.

What I DID like about this was that it could stand up in landscape mode in two different positions and angles while in the case, which was nice. Standing up vertically was a bit wobbly and I didn't feel comfortable leaving it that way. I'm not sure it was advertised to do this, so I didn't ding the review rating for that.

My goal now is to find something more durable and protecting of the iPad, which will hold the iPad at different viewing angles, and most importantly, will allow quick removal of the iPad when I want to enjoy it in all it's glory. :)

The first thing I noticed about this router was that my internet download speed was about 2700 Kbps when connected directly to the router but dropped to 1200 Kbps when operating wireless.
That's with link quality of 100 and only one other computer on the network with no applications running on either computer (aside from the one browser window required for the test). Both computers use DLink DWL-520 Wireless network cards.
To solve the problem I updated the firmware to 1.02. That didn't improve the data rates, but it did make the router's HTML-based menu screens load so slowly that the browser usually timed out.
Following industry standards, DLink apparently mans their first echelon phones with technical illiterates who while capable of following a scripted check list, haven't a clue what's causing your problem or how their sequence of steps might might solve it. For example, to solve the slow menu problem they had me reset the defaults on my browser even though I had no trouble bringing up any other web page I tried. And it made no impact on them that the router menus wouldn't come up any quicker with Netscape.
So, after numerous calls, multiple case IDs, and never talking to the same person twice, I decided it was best to cut my losses and give up before they reconfigured my computer to the point where it wouldn't work at all.
If you surf the web a lot or do internet gaming, stay clear of these products. Stick with a reputable name and save yourself the aggravation and wasted hours trying to make cheap junk like this work. The money you save isn't worth the headaches.

Arctic Silver was great back in 1999.
The keyboard is a little too awkward to use for an extended amount of time.  It is encased in rubber, so don't expect a decent tactile feel.

Pros
====
Pen writes great. (+ 1 star)
The stylus is very responsive (+1 Star)
You can obtain refills for ink from places such as Office depot! (+1 Star)

Cons
====
When you are using the pen, you can not cap it on the back pen of the pen! With my luck, I'll probably lose my cap later. (-1 Star)
I might have a defective cap, When I place the cap on the pen, I have to press the chrome dome on the top of the cap, or it to snap onto the pen. If I forget to do that, it'll fall off and again, probably get lost. (-1 Star)

Other Comments. (Does not affect star rating)
====================================
It's short. I usually like to use pens that are about 5 1/2 inches long. This pen is only 4 1/2 inches long! (Without Cap)
The pen feels light. I tend to like a heavy, a more solid fell to my pens. (This pen feels very cheapy.)
The packaging is a transparent unlabeled resealable plastic bag. (very cheap)
I feel this pen is only worth $4.99.

When I first held this in my hand, the buttons did not feel as nice as the original SNES controller. Especially the D-pad felt loose and rolly which was my biggest fear with getting a game pad for 2D games (even with 3D games the D-pad should not be rolly). I have a Windows 7 machine and the game I wanted to use this for did not recognize it. The instruction manual is in Chinese or something, but I doubt it would have helped even in English. I tried to find some free software to map the buttons to keyboard buttons, but I had to buy some instead. I searched for free software that would do this for quite a while and I am really good at finding truely free software and configuring it, but nothing worked. I ended up using Xpadder to do this which you are supposed to pay for. Setting it up with Xpadder was not as easy as it should have been, but for a geek like myself it was simple enough. Once I actually got it working and used it with my game, the controls are perfect! My concerns about the D-pad were unfounded as it does not control like a loose or rolly D-pad. Each direction is distinct and diagonal is not a separate button but a combination of two. The controller is very responsive. When I mess up, it never seems like the controllers fault. So now that I made it through all that, I am fully satisfied with this game pad. The end result is a 5 star experience while playing games, even though the product as a whole is a 5 star product for how difficult it was to setup. Also, even though I say the playing experience is 5 star, it is not quite as nice as the SNES controller I remember, but that was to be expected. I would have given this five stars if it came with an English instruction manual with directions to do download configuration software from their website and if such software worked on Windows 7 and allowed you to map buttons to the keyboard, ensuring it would work with any game or program.

Let me begin by saying I love the new Kindle Paperwhite. I bought a standard Kindle from a local store, but it was broken out of the box. I was pretty disappointed about that, but I decided I would give Amazon one last try and bought the Paperwhite. No quality control issues out of the box, which is great. The product itself has its ups and downs though. Here is my shortlist of what works and what doesn't (everything else has been covered in-depth by other reviews).

PROS:

The light is the biggest draw for this product. The standard Kindle works well if you are in an extremely well lit room or outside in the sun. If your lighting isn't perfect, you will notice yourself squinting to read. Even with an OttLite next to my bed, I found it difficult to get enough light on the standard Kindle. With the paperwhite, this isn't a problem at all. You can read in any lighting condition. No need to move lamps around or angle your hands so there isn't a shadow. Furthermore, I didn't experience any of the uneven lighting that people complained about, which leads me to believe Amazon fixed the problems with the early units.

Also, the lack of 3G really isn't a problem, unless you don't have the foresight to download a book when you are around wifi. With all of the free hotspots these days, paying a huge premium for 3G capability is crazy. And don't think you will use the \\"experimental\\" browser in this thing. Its basically unusable for more than playing around.

CONS:

1) Price... It is really, really hard to justify paying $129 for a Kindle that has so many ads when a Nexus 7 is priced at only $199. Granted, a tablet will never be AS easy to read as an e-reader, but they certainly do a whole lot more. I think Amazon would be better off pricing this around $99 or they risk losing all but the most hardened e-reader fans. People who are just casual readers won't have a problem reading on a tablet, and would probably be happy to pay $80 more for a device that does 1000x more things.

2) The Ads... Okay, I understood what I was getting myself into when I bought this, but seriously Amazon, the ads are ridiculous. I don't care about the ads on the screen when I turn the Kindle off, but I really care about how 1/2 of the home screen is taken up by ads, and there is only one row dedicated to the books I bought. When you have a bunch of books, it is a colossal inconvenience to have to keep scrolling through to find what you want. Put a small banner ad at the bottom and give me a few more rows for my own books. It makes no sense to take up an entire row with books you suggest I buy.

3) Font... Compare a Paperwhite display to a standard Kindle display and you will see that the Paperwhite's font is much thinner. If they could take the way the text looks on the standard Kindle and combine it with the light of the Paperwhite, it would be amazing.

4) No Physical Buttons... big inconvenience for me. I like to get under a blanket on the couch and read. I have to have my hands outside of the blanket to turn the pages, since it won't register unless a finger touches it. (I refuse to buy a Snuggie, FYI). Also, anything dirty on your hands gets on the screen. Lotion? Better not touch the stuff hours before you pick up the Kindle. Unlike a regular tablet with a \\"glass\\" screen, the Kindle has a matte plasticy screen that is nearly impossible to just wipe off.

OVERALL:

If you want the perfect e-reader, this is the ticket. It comes with the amazing Kindle store and Amazon's great customer support. This thing is near perfect, and with a few more little tweaks, they will have it!

P.S. Amazon, please, please make a Paperwhite DX!

I have had work-issued laptops for many, many years... I am really hard on them... I work long hours, run a lot of applications, etc.

They last maybe 2 years on average. After about a year, the fan runs pretty much all the time and then it's only a matter of time before the poor thing just gives up.

This latest one, it's a Lenovo thinkpad - I think 15" - well, the fan has been running and running and it feels hot all the time and I started to worry and I just don't want to go through the bother of replacing it once again... so I did a little investigation and learned about these lovely external fan cooling pads!

It's great!

I was using books and cardboard under the laptop, but this pad is fantastic! It's super lightweight and airy and I'm finding that I seldom even have to run the fan - just having this under the laptop works great! When I have to use the fan, it plugs into a USB port, but it has a passthrough port, so I can still plug something else into it and I don't lose a port!

It's quiet - I can hear the fan, but it's about the same noise as the laptop fan - maybe quieter?

I did read the reviews that it mightn't last long, but I'd SO much rather replace the pad than replace the laptop!!

Win!!
