Where should I begin? Well for starters I bought this in September last year(2010). It was my first Headset I owned and I was amazed by the sound quality,comfort,and weight(I actually looked at other reviews prior to buying this). Actually without this headset I would have never listened to as much music as I do now. It also made many of my gaming and browsing experiences memorable and enjoyable.  - Comfort: 4/5: I would have these on for hours and after taking them off my ears would be a little sore but it goes away after about 3 minutes. But if you only use them for a couple minutes it is quite comfortable due to the pads.  - Sound Quality 5/5: As I addressed above I was amazed by the sound quality. I could literally hear any sound within 360 degrees of my position when gaming. When listening to music every lyric and instrument is crystal clear. I fell in love with this thing due to the sound quality it produced.  - Mic: 4/5: It's detachable, can be rotated at 360 degrees, and is flexible enough to be bent to a desired position so it is closer to your mouth. Your voice is crystal clear and with Voice FX it can be disguised to your likeness.  - Durability: 1/5: The very thing that brought my piss to a boil. HAVE MERCY. First off the volume and mute control buttons broke this August 2011. I emailed creative about the problem but that they weren't very helpful ,plus it was just a minor setback so I just shrugged it off. Unfortunately the white plastic connecting the left earpiece and the arc also broke, when I was only taking them off. Luckily there's a wire that connects to the right ear piece so I used a rubber band to attach the two phones to my ears.   For those wondering how long I owned this before it broke it was about 1 year and 24 days and it was brand new when I bought this. I think I paid about $160 but I'm just guesstimating. For a headset to cost about $100 and break within a year is just highway robbery. I feel like I paid more for the Software than theHardware. It's in the garbage right now because my chubby bunny just chewed the wire for the audio. Now I gotta find a new headset that won't break on me 9 months after use hopefully with sound quality on par with this product.

I would say that the efficiency of this extender definitely depends on the quality and placement of your router. I bought a new router last year and because the modem/cords are in the living room, I got hardly any wifi in my bedroom. When I placed the extender in the bedroom, I could connect easily but the signal was quite low and the internet was pretty slow. However, when I moved the extender closer to the router (about halfway from the living room) the signal was much better and I could easily video chat/stream things without the connection getting interrupted. It isn't foolproof- there are some days that it doesn't pick up the signal so great or days when I have to turn off my wifi and restart it, but it's definitely a solution to wifi range issues in the household. I would definitely recommend it!

So I've had this laptop for about 2 months now and overall, the laptop is one of the best purchases that I have ever made.
Now lets get into the pros and cons.

Pros:
-Perfect bulk for a laptop. (I've been using Qosmio laptops which are pretty hefty and also macbooks)
-USB port that is always powered
-Graphics card can play recent games at high frame rates on medium settings and above. (Skyrim can be played on ultra)
-Back-lit Keyboard
-Nice carbon fiber looking finish.
-In general it is a FAST computer

Cons:
-Mouse pad isn't TERRIBLE, but it takes a lot of getting used to. A mouse is advised and I assume any gamer will use a mouse
-The frame is made out of a cheap plastic. Though it doesn't look to bad, I'm worried about it getting damaged. 1 year warranty is nice...
-Under average battery life
-Being critical, I feel like the frame is a little too large. It's like having an ipad as a screen.

Arguable Cons:
-The screen is not 1080p but that's what the y510 is really for. A good thing is that you can run some games with a better frame rate.
-Windows 8 isn't fantastic for a laptop like this. SOLUTION is to put windows 7 on your hardrive and restore data.
Only 1 USB 3.0

Benchmarks:
League of Legends -Max Settings- 84-120fps
Skyrim -Ultra- 34-64 fps
Battlefield 3 -High/Ultra- 48-80fps
Minecraft -HD Shaders- 29-114fps (average of 53fps)

Conclusion:
For the price, the laptop is definitely worth it. The laptop has the power of mid-range gaming PC's (arguable) but don't expect it to play the newest games at anything more than high settings unless you modify it. The temperature build up is average and the battery life isn't much of an inconvenience as long as you know when the laptop is about to reach it's limit.
1080 would be great but that's what the y510 is for.

Hope this helped!

I purchased this keyboard to use with my Thinkpad Win 7 notebook for school. I really like its size, it is small enough to use on a text book (I can use it to underline lines of text as I write notes) and the keys are large enough to be effective.
I also like the fact that the power switch and Bluetooth connect are on the face of the keyboard, not on the underside.
Connect time is a bit slow, and I have to use connect each time I want to use the keyboard. I also use a bluetooth mouse that connects immediately when it is powered on, so I do not understand the delay with the keyboard.
My BIG concerns are the lack of a Delete key and a useful “Home” and “End” keys which are really necessary for word processing. The Function Home / End changes screens or windows sizes but are ineffective in word processing.
So I cannot give this the highest rating, but I won’t return it either… it does 80% of what I require, and has additional assets that I enjoy.

This product actually came recommended by another IT Professional such as me, so I thought it a safe bet even though I never used a Buffalo product before.  The feature set was impressive as was the price.  The model I got was not exactly the same as the one my friend had, but it was the next model up, so in theory it should be better.  Clearly that was not the case.  Out of the box, I tried to attach the stand which was a joke.  It sort of just sat on there, rather than snap into place.  Now I know this may seem petty, but this is an upright router by design, so if even a slight nudge sends this thing slamming into my hard wood entertainment cabinet, then this is not good.  I read about the complexity of the web interface configuration before buying it, but I figured I could handle it if my partner could.  This is not by any means for a novice computer user, but the interface was not bad at all.  I just think that it is packed with a lot of features which overwhelms the average user.  I got everything configured without a hiccup, but wait, just one problem.  It is not running at any better a speed then 56 Mbps, and I have a room with a dead spot in the house.  Now granted this is a two story house, and it used to lose bars in this room on my old Linksys WRT150N, but a complete dead spot?  As if this was not enough, it could not connect to my old HP DV1000 laptop's wireless at all.  I called tech support and after wasting an entire Sunday and I do mean entire, without resolution.  They did explain that I would need a dual band USB wireless adapter to benefit from the 5.0 GHz band, but my Dlink wireless dongle used to get at least a 100 + Mbps on the 2.4 band by the adapter icon on the task bar.  I know that this is not an accurate rate, but it does show that it is generally increased in speed and not capped.  So I conducted speed tests between my old Cisco router setup and the Buffalo, and the old Cisco won out after multiple test form different areas.  Now I'm sureif I continued troubleshooting I could find the answers to make this work well, with or without the help of tech support, but I felt it prudent that I should not have to.  A wireless device should not be this complicated to get these most basic of functions working.  My WRT150N did just as good and in some instances better than this one.  I still wanted better coverage in that one room so I later purchased another Cisco device that has met all my expectations thus far and at a third less in price.  The difference gave me the money to buy the dual band USB wireless dongle, to take full benefit of the dual band.  By: King's iRate

I think this may be the first product review I write in Amazon, and I am doing so because I am truly pleased with these speakers. Mind you, I'm now playing music every dinner just to enjoy them and I had not done so for years.

I was a bit hesitant to order them at first due to some of the bad reviews I read here, especially the ones that mentioned poor quality at the low-frequencies and the feeling of "tinned" sound... but I do not think those comments are fair. These speakers sound great for their price. I am actually surprised by how the low tones sound. (This is actually the reason I'm grading them: to offset those bad reviews.)

One thing I was looking for was for "heavy enough" speakers so that they would stay in place. I previously had a couple of Logitech S120 and got rid of them precisely because of this: the speakers were too light, and the cables too thick: so any unintentional movement in the cable would cause the speakers to move.

I respectfully suggest that that in place of ad hominem attacks comments reciting more recent experiences with the M73 would be more constructive. I cannot say enough great things about the Kindle Fire. It has become my go to gadget. So easy to access e-mail, do web searches, facebook, the list goes on and on. All I can say is everyone should have one.

I bought this to replace my dying LCD monitor.  The description really makes it sound like a monitor with a TV tuner slapped to it so I was a little hesitant on the TV aspect.  Comes with both VGA and DVI ports; VGA runs at highest resolution allowed on my NVIDIA 5500 card without any problems. The box included both a VGA and DVI cables. The picture quality of the monitor is great, no dead pixels (yet).   The TV aspect works great as well. The tuner picks up over the air HD channels very well and if you have cable, includes the HD channels as well. My only complaint is that it seems to get stuck on a channel (only happens on the first programmed channel) and you basically have to key in the next one to move up. The 'touch of color' is barely noticeable so if you can save money by buying the standard black one, do so. The sound quality is decent though I really didn't expect Bose quality out of a 22'' TV (that's branded as a monitor). All in all, it's a great little monitor/tv.

I've owned a version of every generation of Kindle e-reader. And, I'd tried many different cases to protect them. I decided on Omoton because it functions as well as the best Kindle branded case with a greater variety of interesting cover graphics/colors and with, at least, equal functionality. Once I pop a new Kindle into an Omoton case I never remove it, and never use the on/off Kindle switch -- no need to. The passive magnetic on/off switch of the Omoton turns off the Kindle. The Omoton case is so light, thin and strong that I am still able to shove my Kindle Voyage into the back pocket of my jeans with no trouble -- and sit on the Kindle with no damage. I've dropped my Omoton protected Kindle on hard bathroom floors many times with no damage to Kindle or case. The case has baked in Caribbean suns, been doused with beer, coffee and wine -- all easily wiped off, and looks almost as good, now as the day I received it.

- Purchased 5/2011 from the Egg - $314 at time of purchase

--- Pros ---
* Still working (2 yrs)
* Stable 4.5ghz like nothing
* Cold (with aftermarket cooling) 62C / 143F under load

--- Cons ---
* None

--- Thoughts ---
* I bought a 2600k and Asrock Extreme4 back in 5/2011. With experimenting I was able to overclock it to 4.5ghz at 1.385v. Idles at 35C, Load at 62C. To this day the overclock is still running solid. Used with Arctic Silver and Zalman 9700.

ONE IMPORTANT TIP BEFORE MY REVIEW:

Go to your windows control panel, find your microphone settings, and activate a MAXIMUM boost (+10.0 db I think) of your microphone input or else people will not be able to hear you clearly in games or Skype unless you raise your voice. On top of that, you'll want to pretty much max out your game's VOIP settings.

ON TO THE REVIEW:

Since picking up this clever microphone I have noticed that people in online games can understand me much better. In games where communication is vital to success this will give you a winning edge. In games that promote socializing, you will find that your friends will hear every nuance of your voice as if you were in the room with them more or less. Fifteen dollars is a freaking steal. The mic stand design of this mic makes it very unobtrusive and intuitive. If someone else is next to you while you're gaming, they can chime into the mic without leaning awkwardly close to your face. You also don't have to wear a geeky headset and you may even feel like a comedian or something talking into this little gizmo XD.

Being a peripheral fan, I've been subject to a lot of different mice as I try new ones every 6 months or so.  Well the G9 was a pleasant surprise and a thankful addition to my permanent mouse collection of two.  First things first, this thing is really a quality item.  The buttons click with ease and are not noisy.  This gives them a really smooth and expensive feel to button clicking, making overall mouse usage a pleasure.  The additional grips and weights are a nice touch for those who want the most from their mouse but what I've noticed and liked most is the shape and low profile of the mouse.  At first this was a bit awkward since I was used to bigger full sized mice with high arches to support the palm of my hand.  However, those mice made my hands sweat all the time and the heat and moisture always left me less than comfortable.  With this mouse, my palm does not touch the mouse but rather hovers over it.  This was odd at first but after getting used to it I prefer it.  Now my hands never sweat and it actually takes less effort to move the mouse.  There are also some other outstanding features to the mouse, notably the microgear hyper scrolling feature that I cannot live without now.  All in all, highly recommended.

You can also buy them through third-party vendors, right here on this product page; there's really no need to pay full price for one of these.)

I really like this cover on every level except one -- it puts your Kindle to sleep, but does not seem to allow you to actually turn the Kindle off. Evidently Amazon assumes that no one ever actually wants to turn their Kindle OFF. But with my busy schedule, I read for fun in starts and spurts, and, sadly, can go weeks without opening my Kindle. There doesn't seem to be a way to turn the Kindle off or keep it turned off with the cover. I power down with the button, and when I open the cover later, I can see the sleep screen and/or my Kindle springs to life as if it's been only asleep (not off, no startup screen), and, if weeks have passed, my battery life has been eaten down to a nub. The last time this happened, I \\"powered down\\" (or put it asleep) with half of the battery life, and when I opened it again, the battery was almost completely drained. (And this was in airplane mode; I keep my Kindle in airplane mode pretty much all the time, except when I'm downloading books or backing up to the Cloud.) It doesn't matter if I power down with the cover open or closed. With it open, I can see that it's actually powering down, but it doesn't matter. It wakes up again later as if it's only been asleep. If someone knows of a way to fix or work around this problem, please respond. It's a bit frustrating. Otherwise, I really love the cover and the Kindle that fits in it.

I loved my original Kindle (which I only used for reading books and listening to audiobooks) but considered the Fire because I was also looking at a tablet. I knew I would want a keyboard and would need a case, so tried this one. It is great. It closes the Kindle down when you close the case and is sturdy. It feels like it will last a long time, is a great color, and the keyboard works well. I only have to charge it every couple of weeks (I do turn it off when I am not using it.) As others have said, it took awhile to get used to the keyboard (key placement) and I still struggle with the different characters because they are placed differently, but that is minor.

It will sit nicely with the back support on the table or easily in my lap (like now). The only criticism I would have is that it is a little heavy - but then I realize that is also what makes it so protective for my Fire.

Highly recommend.
Great quality for the price no problems fits perfect and as expected would recommend especially like the stand feature for watching videos
Good mouse. Would buy again

I'd give it 4.7, but not 5 because of the switch. I know I'm being picky, but the push button switch on the bottom bugs me. Not the location or function, but the actual button itself and the feel. I'm used to Apple's design esthetic and this device feels - not cheap, but mediocre.

On the plus side: it's easy to read, easy on the eyes, light, fits in cargo pants pockets, holds enough books, the interface is adequate (which is massively better than any other e-reader I've tried), battery life seems good, etc.
I love my Kensington keypad and the leather cover is very nice.  I'm glad I found a cover that was a good quality leather and in the color I loved.

We purchased this in September, and by November it no longer worked.  We tried unsuccessfully to contact customer service by phone and finally was able to reach tech support over the internet.  Unfortunately, he was unable to make this work...Something about us having the wrong software (which doesn't make sense-we used what came with the unit). We were utterly frustrated...It was a waste of money!

No problem installing or problems with add-on software.  Video quality is very good under various lighting levels.  Microphone audio quality is really good.  Plenty of configuration options too.  Software updates are easily downloaded from Logitech through the software.  Keyboard hotkeys for the \\"privacy shade\\" (muted audio and no video) would be a nice to have feature that is not there.
Comes with a USB wireless receiver making it the perfect controller to use for PC games.  Especially if you are used to using an XBOX controller anyway.

These speakers are great. The only concern that I didn't care for is the speaker to speaker wire is very short. Other than the extra $$ I put out for an extension wire I have no regrets. They sound wonderful.
I ordered this for use with a Gigabyte GA-MA785GMT-UD2H motherboard.  So far so good.  I have NOT tried overclocking at all.  Construction, and quality are first rate.
This product is good

I was not sure that I needed something like this for my Xoom, but now cannot imagine being without it.  Everything is of the highest quality, and the function is perfect, no matter how you are orienting the Xoom for viewing.  All of the accessory ports are available.  I have used it now for several months, and can recommend it very highly.
Fan is fast, quiet, and keeps the temperature in check.  No complaints.  It does what it says.

This case cover fits perfectly my Kindle 6'. The grey synthetic leather is very good looking, even if at first it didn't smell very good.
This product is simple and essential, but does its job great.

I needed an inexpensive SSD for a family member's laptop that was running slow. I figured moving from a 5400rpm traditional drive to an SSD, plus a fresh install of Windows 7, would speed things up. I researched many reviews to see if this could be wiped and used for a main drive, and decided to go with it given the price.

I installed the new drive in the laptop, started the Windows 7 install from a disc, deleted any partitions that were on the drive, and created a new blank NTFS partition for Windows. No confusing steps for the install, and the laptop runs better than ever.

This was my second attempt at getting a standby power supply for my Zenbook. The last adapter (from a different supplier) caused issues with the built-in touch-pad that made the laptop impossible to use (so was returned). This adapter is really good and the same kind of quality as the original ASUS one with the laptop. The inclusion of the different plug adapters (Aus/US/UK/Europe) is an excellent bonus that will avoid the plug adapters on trips overseas too.

Note that not all Zenbooks are the same it seems and some of the advertised power adapters will not work with all Zenbooks - so read the small print.

This review is for the Genius GX-Gaming SW-G2.1 3000 Black/Gold speakers:
These 2.1 speakers caught my eye with the cool design on the subwoofer and the funky looking satellites.
The system came nicely packaged. Within five minutes of opening the box everything was hooked up. The speaker wires are long enough so you can separate them a decent amount. The control box is conveniently located on my desk allowing me to adjust volume, bass and power at my fingertips.
The satellites do a good job of reproducing high frequencies, and the sub puts out lots of bass although a bit boomy.
Video games and bass-heavy electronic music sound good on this system.
All the speaker cones are exposed which looks neat but makes them easier to damage. Having said that, it's fun watching the high excursion subwoofer pounding out some Bassnectar!
Recommended for a back to school stereo:
1: Affordable
2: Easy set up
3: Relatively light weight(approx 10 lbs)

Very happy with purchase.  I bought this because I needed a portable computer to use around the house. I find myself using it in bed a-lot instead of having to go to the computer room.  It's small and compact, I purchased a small mouse to go with it.  My husband has used it a few times too because it's so lightweight and simple to pick up and access.  The battery life is very long and I only need to plug in overnight so I'm happy with this.  I do wish the screen on the computer was bigger, but that was one of the main reasons I purchased this computer I wanted something very small and easy to use.  My husband did not understand why I wanted such this small computer with no DVD burner (or other major features), but now that he sees that I just want to surf the web and check FB and e-mail... he understands.  So he's happy that I'm happy.  I love when he picks up my computer and uses it sometimes, he's very savvy about computer gadgets so I know he likes my little computer too.  My only complaint is that I did not purchase the pink colored computer... but overall I'm very satisfied with this purchase.  My other complaint is that the computer came with a lot of unnecessary programs that my husband had to uninstall before I started using the computer so it can go faster.

Overall, this case is good.  I used it for my Dell Inspiron 15 (3521) and the top cover fits well.  As others have said, the bottom part functions more as a tray rather than a case.  Also, the color is not as brilliant as depicted.  As the cover is slightly transparent, the color is dulled by the black color of my laptop.  However, the case did arrive very quickly.
The mouse is, hands down, the best bluetooth mouse on the market for Macbooks. You certainly will not be disappointed.

It's still good after over a year use. I originally paid $70 including shipping for the 1tb back in July 2011. Haven't had any problems, but I outgrew the slow usb 2 data transfer rate. This pen has traded fantastic features that you couldn't find anywhere else for something more akin to writing on your ipad with a stylus and also recording the audio.  Obviously the pen no longer stands alone, it requires an electronic device to record. However, this means you can no longer tap on a part of the page where you are unclear what was going on and hear the content at that point. There is also no feature in the app that allows you to select a part of the page you would like to listen to, only a standard scroll bar like you would find in an mp3 player.  The app has bugs and limited functionality. For instance, the app froze the very first time I tried to record audio. The only way to review notes with audio is to watch them like videos at standard speed --- no speed adjustment! There is no reason to ever look at the notebook again because you can't access the audio from the notebook.  All that I want from Livescribe is a pen that is smaller and more classic in appearance. If they can do that, I will happily upgrade.  As far as this product, you would be better off using that fancy iPhone to record audio while you write with pen and paper, then scan the your notes at the end with the phone.  Why the three stars? It's completely unreasonable to give this product fewer than three stars. It works most of the time, it looks pretty, its just overpriced now that its competing with a pen and paper and a Sony digital recorder.

CONs
some sliding in the leaning position
clip can get in the way of typing in landscape mode

I bought this for use with my xbox 360 and am extremely happy with the purchase. I put a lot of time into researching a bunch of different drives to use as a backup to my HDD and decided on this one. It's been great. It doesn't look like it in the picture, but there is a red light inside the plastic to show when it is in use. Also, it has a nice compact size, meets the xbox 360 speed requirements when tested by the xbox, and is cheaper than most other 16gb flash drives out there. I also plan to use this to transfer data between hard drives when I upgrade to the 360 Slim model, which for only a few more dollars than the data transfer cable this drive retains usefullness after the data swap.     I've never written a review before, but when I was researching various drives for use on a xbox 360 I found very little info as far as other customer reviews on this drive. I wanted to add my experience because I was a little wary pulling the trigger with so few reviews but am very happy that I did. I'm thinking of buying another for my PS3. Great drive at a great price.

It does seem the pattern may come off at a later date, but that's off little matter to me, it has a slight plasticky feel to it.  I didn't notice any strange smells or tears. The charger does its job, taking care of the power needs of my Dell Studio laptop. Nonetheless, it should be noted that Dell pops up a warning that an incompatible charger is in use. I don't think the charger impacts performance; I just think Dell uses this message to deter consumers from buying a non-Dell charger. That said, after I cleared the warning message, I couldn't detect any untoward performance.

The USB plug is the bonus I looked forward to most, and it works well. My only beef is that it is an extra dongle to cart around (and misplace). I think Targus could have done a better job on the design of this product by simply including the USB connector on the transformer box itself. Otherwise, it's a good product for those needing a replacement or spare charger.

I bought two of these to augment the 4 SATA3 ports on my motherboard. I'm replacing a RAID server, and adding capacity at the same time. The latest drives are 6Gbps, so you need a wider PCI-Express connction than just 1x or PCI like some of the other boards. I now have 10 3TB disks in a Linux server running an Ivy Bridge i5-3550 in RAID 6 configuration. With a bit of tuning this baby can sustain 300+ MBps transfers, read or write, or copying within the array. And the peak rates appear to be at least twice that, so I'm happy as can be. It easily maxes out a couple of Gb network connections. And the whole system runs on a bit less than 200 watts at full load.

Four stars because the price seems a bit high to me, as others give you full RAID support at the same price. But these guys get the job done and I wasn't interested in hardware RAID after having a couple of controllers fail, leaving the array unrecoverable due to proprietary formats. Now I stick to software RAID, at least for home media servers.

This is quite a cover -- the rubber is an excellent grip in the hands, and it is solid / thick / cushiony enough that should I drop it, most likely ways of landing are going to be absorbed by the cover rather than the device.  The front has enough of a lip sticking out that the screen almost certainly won't ever touch the drop surface, and I can lay it face down without any risk of scratching the screen.  Most importantly (or close, at least), this cover doesn't appear to interfere whatsoever with the wireless Qi charger that I've bought for the Nexus 7 2nd Gen.  This was a concern as the cover is quite thick and protective.  That does not, on the other hand, made the device feel much bulkier.  Somehow it still feels *reasonably* slim and remains easy to hold -- if not a bit easier since it no longer is begging to jump out of my hands as I always figured it was wanting to do with no protection and with the smooth / super thin unprotected tablet.

I am a seasoned road warrior with almost 20 years under my belt and have gone through many laptops and bags. I really stressed about buying a bag >$50 given that my last favorite bag was a $50 Swiss Army bag. I am glad to say that after 2 months and 12 flights later I am very happy with this Everki.

Highlights:
-I am a technical professional so I carry lots of cables, external hard drives, etc...and as advertised this bag has a ton of storage slots that completely organizes my gear
-I was skeptical of the 'checkpoint friendly' claim, but have since used this at DTW, MCO, SEA, SAN, DEN, and SFO checkpoints without issue
-The bag fits perfectly under the seat in front of me...which was a concern because the dimensional specs on this bag were larger than my previous one
-The bag is very lightweight and comfortable on my back...the weight distribution across my shoulders is very good

The only complaint I have is that the padding on the back (part that tests upon my back when wearing the bag) is not as good as my previous FUL laptop backpack. That had an abundance of padding and was very comfortable.

easy to use...makes both my PC laptops print wirelessly now. I have a wonderful Cannon Pixma 530...last model made before they went wireless. Since I really only started using the printer frequently about 4 months ago (after owning it for two years), there was no need to replace an otherwise terrific all-in-one. A prior reviewer stated problems with both the thickness and the cut of the product- #1 - The description clearly describes it as a decal (I'm not sure about others, but I knew what this meant) #2 - The description also informs the purchaser that while it does fit 15.6 laptops, it may need to be trimmed to fit -- Not all laptops are made the same, and although many do not have straight corners, some do. It would actually be improper if the product were NOT cut to the larger specifications... This allows the buyer to simply take the step of using scissors, prior to peeling the decal off of the base, to downsize the product.

IF you find yourself unhappy with the size/shape, as stated above, I had no problem peeling/reapplying the product more than once, and if you still have problems, the customer service left me quite happy, so I'm sure they'd be willing to help.

UPDATED REVIEW  -   Initially I was very pleased with this keyboard with the only real drawback being the lack of the numeric pad found on larger keyboards.  I have used this keyboard and mouse for several months (nearly a year).  The major complaint is this keyboard often misses keystrokes during normal typing.  You will type a word completely and correctly and occasionally a letter will be missing.  I write invoices about 5 to10 times a day and this occurs in nearly every invoice.  If this keyboard were a few years old then I would understand but it's less than a year old. I have been dealing with this since about the 2nd month of use.  I have tried changing batteries, relocating the USB dongle to different ports on my laptop/docking station (even moved offices but not for this reason).  Nothing improves performance.  Now I'm not saying this is junk.  On the contrary....for light to moderate use this keyboard is awesome.  I would highly recommend this for travel as the size is perfect.  As for using in an office for daily use.....well it just barely misses the mark.  I wanted to keep my desk free of clutter, looks like I'll be searching or a different keyboard at some point in the future.  I'll keep using this for now.     ORIGINAL REVIEW  -  The keyboard is very quiet as described.  The spacing of the keys is similar to a standard keyboard while excess plastic and trim has been removed.  Type just as you do on a standard keyboard without missing keys. The mouse is very small but perfect for travel.  The mouse covers a little less space than a credit card making it ideal for cramped locations.  They keyboard and mouse use two AAA batteries.  The keyboard is raised by the battery compartment providing a comfortable working angle.  Both items are very slim and easily stowed for travel.  When not in use, the USB wireless receiver can be stored in the battery compartment of the mouse (and arrives this way when purchased).  This review is to help those who are lookingat this product for its size.  This product has not been used extensively enough to offer any advice on reliability.  Product operating on a laptop using Windows 8.1.

I was extremely reluctant to try e-books, being a die-hard, committed reader of hard copy books. Since I don't like doing any extensive reading on my computer screen or tablet, I assumed I would have the same negative reaction to the Kindle. Not so. Although I still thoroughly enjoy a traditional hardback or even paperback book, I quickly became comfortable with reading from the Kindle and there is absolutely no argument that it is MUCH more convenient, especially if one travels extensively. Now I no longer need to pack two or three heavy books in my suitcase for a two week trip. Also, it is easier to read than hardcopy -- adequate lighting is no longer an issue and I honestly believe I experience less eye strain using the Kindle. The only downside I can see is you can't put the book on display on your bookshelves and the "page" is smaller so it seems like you are "turning the page" more frequently.

I am sold -- although I will still purchase hardcover books for the authors I want to "collect", everything else will be an e-book if it available.

My 5 1/2 year old Dell PC finally bit the dust, and since my family all have Macs and rave about them, I thought I would take the plunge. Wow, am I glad I did! This thing is amazing. Gorgeous, sleek, fast, and did I say gorgeous? I bought the 27\\" 2.9GHz for $200 less because it was the model Amazon had in stock. I was a little afraid it would not be powerful enough for my needs, but it turns out it exceeds them. I am using it for amateur photography needs, and just basic home use and internet use. I bought an external \\"Apple SuperDrive\\" at $75, a pair of 8GB memory cards \\"Crucial 16GB Kit (8GBx2) DDR3 1600 MT/s (PC3-12800) CL11 SODIMM 204-Pin 1.35V/1.5V Memory Modules For Mac CT2C8G3S160BM\\" at $85, and a \\"Seagate Backup Plus 3 TB USB 3.0 Desktop External Hard Drive for Mac\\" to back up my photos at $137. I also bought the $169 Apple warranty. Though I have been told Macs have a rep for not going bad, if they do, an Apple Tech told me the cheapest repair is $800. So, I got the warranty for peace of mind. Anyway, back on the performance of this Mac....it has more than exceeded my expectations...I am glad I saved $200 and got the 2.9 since that money helped pay for the other items.

Note that some bad reviews were over this super thin model not having a built in DVD/CD drive. What is the big deal? You can live without one, but if you do want it, just buy the Apple Super Drive for $75; it plugs into the back of the iMac via USB and is very thin and small. It sits on the iMac stand and is the same color as the stand, so just blends right in. Or if you prefer a blu-ray, there a black Samsung Bluray read/write external drive. So, adding an external player is NOT an issue. Actually, I think it is an advantage to have it as a peripheral, since dying DVD/CD drives have been an annoying problem in the past with PCs. With it being an inexpensive peripheral on this iMac, I can simply buy another down the road should it go out.

Note also that the1TB internal Hard Drive and 8GB of memory should be PLENTY for almost all needs and I found the standard configuration to be very fast and efficient as shipped. I bought the external drive as added protection for my photos, and the extra memory because I use Photoshop and work with a lot of memory-sapping RAW images. But unless you are into photography or heavy graphics, I do not think these additions are necessary at all...and actually a waste of money.

You could just buy this iMac without warranty, external DVD drive, extra memory, external Hard Drive and save yourself almost $500. I guarantee you will be very happy with this awesome machine as shipped and you probably will not have need of the warranty in the first 3 years anyway. These tweeks depend on your point of view and your personal needs.

Overall, I could not be happier with this iMac and highly recommend it. The display is stunning and the machine is powerful and glitch free.

P.S.
I was hesitant to purchase this from Amazon vs directly from Apple (not sure why...I guess because Apple has traditionally been the exclusive seller of their products)...but had no problems or issues at all in doing so. It shipped via UPS with signature required....arrived in two days packed in a very heavy and form-fitting outer box. It's delivery was no different from my experience buying online from Apple, with the exception that Apple usually uses FedEx. Of course, if you buy from Apple, you can configure your IMac a little bit...but adding memory from Apple is very expensive (even if you buy from Apple you should buy your memory separately and install yourself. It is very easy to do). And buying a larger internal HD is not necessary either if you get an external. The external is better anyway in that you can use Time Machine to backup your computer in case a calamity hit your desktop.

I would have given 5 stars to this product up until 31 Jan 2014 - when the surfeasy VPN network crashed - it was on this day that Surfeasy's ability to rectify problems was seriously tested and unfortunately they have fallen short of the mark. In their haste to create a software fix to restore the surfeasy usb they failed to consider the fact that existing users who had already registered their surfeasy usbs on the network could not re-register their restored surfeasy usb with their existing and registered email address. Furthermore, a brand new out of the box surfeasy usb would not connect to the surfeasy VPN network, which suggests that whatever occured on 31 Jan 2014 has rendered the surfeasy software shipped on new surfeasy usbs unable to access the network. It is likely that any new user of this product will have to go through a process of downloading the surfeasy usb restore software and run it on their new device before it will function - this software runs slower than frozen molasses. Most annoying is that there is no evidence of 24 hour support from Surfeasy or even support on weekends. Having bought 4 units for myself, friends and family - I am very disappointed.  1 Feb 2014 - Surfeasy confirm that new customers will have to download and run a surfeasy restore program on their brand new device before it will work. The link to get the updated surfeasy restore software is  [...]update but when you run this software make sure you press the restore option and not the reset option - and then find something else to do for an hour because the program runs so slowly.

UPDATE 1/5/13
I've used this for over a year now and have had no problems of any kind.

There has been no need to recalibrate.

The plastic levers were hit by my chair with no damage.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The quality of the build is much better than I had expected.

After reading ALL of the reviews I do have some observations to make;

1) The USB cord is 4 feet 3 inches long. That's fine for most people. But if your computer is on the floor it may be too short. I've ordered the [[ASIN:B003Z4G3I6 Plugable 7 Port High Speed USB 2.0 Hub with 3A Power Adapter]]. Trust me, you'll want a powered USB hub later anyway for other game controlers/panels.

2) I've read complaints about the potentiometers (electrical thingies attached to the levers inside the box) going bad. This is not uncommon with potentiometers and can easily be fixed by using \\"contact cleaner\\" sold in any electronics store, even Radio Sh--k. I took the bottom off (watch where the screws come from, as there are 6 screws in 3 different sizes. IF YOU HAVE TO PRY THE BOTTOM LOOSE THEN ALL OF THE SCREWS ARE NOT OUT.) and could see that there is another assembly that needs to come out so that you can spray the contact cleaner on the pots.

3) There is a complaint that the stems coming out of the box are plastic and may break. This unit is not an arcade controller. You WILL NOT be slamming the levers around. Don't worry about it.

All in all, I can highly recommend this item. The only possible problem is the relatively short cord.

A special thanks goes to the review by \\"SEATAC\\" on July 6, 2010;

\\"As I moved the aforementioned all the way up and down, they would only register from about 21% to 79%, so I could not get the full range.\\"

\\".... in FSX, Controls, Calibration, set the Sensitivity for all three levers all the way to the right and set the Null Zone for all three levers all the way to the left.\\"

That solved the only real problem I had.the way to the right and set the Null Zone for all three levers all the way to the left.\\"

That solved the only real problem I had.

I also have the previous version [[ASIN:B007PJ4Q4A Logitech Anywhere Mouse MX]]. The old MX is still a great mouse, especially at the reduced price it's selling for now. It does have a few shortcomings though; for instance: I'm loathed to buy AA and AAA batteries for anything in my house anymore (I don't understand why everything isn't USB rechargeable) and it only works with Logitech's Unifying dongle. So when I upgraded laptops to one who's manufacturer thought a single USB port is plenty (Ahem, Microsoft) a few months ago, I purchased the [[ASIN:B00DR8LA6U Logitech Ultrathin Touch Mouse T630]] to keep in my laptop bag. The advantages were two-fold; first the T630's Bluetooth pairing meant I didn't have to dedicate my only USB port to a mouse full-time, and secondly, it was USB rechargeable, so I knew if it was ever out of power I could just charge it, rather than having to go on a quest for more AA batteries. This didn't work out quite as well in practice though. While super-portable, isn't exactly comfortable to use for hours at a time, and it was a bit tricky to get the gestures to work on a surface that also moves around. Also, it only paired over Bluetooth; it didn't work with Logitech's Unifying receivers at all, so that's something to keep in mind. Finally, the USB charging port is on the bottom, so it's impossible to use while charging. It only takes 10 or 15 minutes to get a day's use out of it, but this was still annoying.

The MX Anywhere 2 is the best of both worlds, plus some. To start with, it's the same size, shape, and feel as the old MX, with the exception of the rubber grip strips on the sides. The old MX has small uniform dimpling, while the MX 2 has angled textures which I like both the look and feel of much better. Some may find it on the small side for a primary mouse, but I find it quite comfortable in both the right and left hand (important for a lefty) for all day use, and it's still small enough to throw in the laptop bag without adding too much bulk. I certainly notice the bulged in the bag now, unlike the super-slim T630, but it's definitely a trade-off worth making for the added comfort and functionality. Secondly, the MX 2 is USB rechargeable, with the port right in the front so it can easily be used while charging. This means I can just leave it plugged in and use it all day at my desk, then take it with me on the go, and it's always topped up and ready, or if I need to I can charge it from my laptop without interrupting my work. Finally, the MX 2 pairs with up to 3 separate devices in any mix of Bluetooth or Unifying dongle, and switch between them with the push of a button. This is fantastic for laptops and tablets which often include only a paucity of USB ports these days, as well as Android devices (though apple still doesn't have basic cursor support for ios; tisk, tisk...).

The only negative I've found in the MX 2 is a pet peeve of mine. Included in the package is a Unifying dongle, which is great. In the old MX, there was a slot in the battery compartment where you could store the dongle when not in use so it doesn't get lost. The MX 2 doesn't have a removable battery, so there's no battery compartment, and Logitech didn't think to put a slot somewhere else to store the dongle. That's it, that's the only thing I can find that I don't like about this mouse; you have to keep track of that little Unifying dongle on your own.

I highly recommend this mouse to anyone, though the old MX is still a worthy option for about half the price. ..If buying AA batteries once in a while doesn't offend you, and you have a USB port to spare, or are already using a Unifying receiver for other peripherals.t adding too much bulk. I have a MacBook Pro which had the original drive in it but had 16gb of ram.
I was researching SSDs for it and was thinking about just doing a Fusion drive for cheap but fast storage.
When doing my research I found this. And it seemed like it would work.
There is a little bit of work to get this running.
I followed this guide http://dwn.alza.cz/manual/1026 for everything except the instal of the operating system (I wanted a clean instal) so I did an Internet recovery. Took longer but worked.
I set it up as a fusion drive and it works great! My computer boots a lot quicker than it did with the old one. And now the apps are quicker as well.
I run windows 7 using parallel and it is quick too.

All in all great! It won't be as quick as an ssd only but great price for the storage and speed.

The only con to it is the setup. It took a little bit of time but great that there is a guide to instal it.
I had no problem installing the card and it works just as it should.  Highly recommended.

I purchased this monitor for one thing and one thing only: gaming. And boy does it deliver. gaming in 4k resolution is the future, and it is an incredible experience. I have played multiple games on this monitor, and they all look fantastic. Color reproduction is not quite as good as an IPS panel, but the fidelity is still quite accurate and strong. The clarity the 4k resolution gives to games is breathtaking. I was expecting a jump in quality, but nothing this wonderful. My single 780 ti hits 60fps on less graphic-intensive games so long as anti-aliasing is scaled down or turned off. I can hit 30-40fps on Battlefield 4 with anti-aliasing disabled. Dark Souls 2, Dishonored, Borderlands 2, and Hitman give me a consistent 60 fps across the board. The 4k image is so life-like that the picture on this looks three dimensional. If you are on the fence as to whether or not this monitor is worth it, I recommend you go ahead and buy one. I doubt you'll regret it.

This WD 4TB internal drive is currently as close to a dream hard drive as you can get. The high capacity does require a compatible BIOS or UEFI (that's the modern replacement for BIOS), but once you have the mobo support, Windows 8 makes it easy to install a 4TB drive, with just a quick trip to the Drive Management utility.

Compared to large-capacity Seagate drives I've used, this WD is quiet. Speed-wise, it certainly feels like a champion, helped in part by its 64MB cache. Compared to a previous WD internal drive I used and reviewed, waking up from sleep is speedy on this drive. Really, I have nothing negative to say about this drive's performance.

Of course, beyond performance one's main concern is reliability, or how long a drive will last. I've owned over a dozen WD drives, internal or external, and none of them has ever failed, going back as early as circa 1997, maybe even earlier (before 1997, when I built my first system from scratch, I had never paid attention to drive makes). I hope this will last a long time, too, especially since I use it in an informal server environment.

The best bits of advice I read in the reviews after trying all afternoon to get this work:
1. Read more recent reviews as products and Internet service providers' (ISPs) policies change
2. If you have an AirPort Extreme, this device will not work well (basically you will have to restart the modem and the router more times than you wish to imagine with no guaranteed formula for success)
3. If you have even the slightest interruption in service (which happens daily), this modem will stop working until you restart it.

I live in Boston and called Comcast/xfinity right away to get the device registered and activated. While plugged into the computer directly via Ethernet, the modem provided connection; but when I went to connect it with my router (an AirPort Extreme), the router had a green light indicating it was working, but in airport utility there was an amber light indicating no internet connect was available wirelessly. I don't fully understand all the issues (something about double NAT?) but I decided to take the advice of fellow reviewers, bloggers and apple community forums and go with the Zoom 5341J modem instead.

Get it and you will not be disappointed.
OH AND BY THE WAY... speaking of better audio, remember that the QUALITY of the audio file you're playing will have a profound effect on your sound. Especially when you're playing it loud. Try to play 320kbps files or better yet a lossless file such as FLAC!

Finding balance between a good gaming system and portable notebook is a difficult endeavor. There are plenty of 15.6\\" or 17\\" screen systems out there that are able to pack the highest performing components inside, but leave your shoulder/back aching. On the other side of the spectrum, there are a number of sleek, ultra book class notebooks that are easy to carry, but leave you wanting more performance. I needed a high performance notebook that allows me to multi-task and game a bit while away from home. The MSI GE40 is a nice compromise between the two categories with a few caveats.

Design:
Weighing in at 4.4ish pounds, the GE40 is quite light for what it packs inside. The palm rest and lid are a brushed aluminum. The lid has eye-catching red LEDs in the form of \\"dragon eyes\\". The rest of the body is comprised of your standard glossy plastic that attracts finger prints, but isn't handled all that often in everyday use. There is more flex in the palm rest and keyboard than a full aluminum chassis, but it doesn't scream poor quality.

Screen:
My main issue with the GE40 is the quality of the screen. While it does feature a high 1600x900 resolution for a 14\\" screen, it is an average TN panel with OK viewing angles. This evaluation is quite subjective although I personally think the vertical viewing angles are poor. You will need to view the screen dead on or the image will be washed out. This left me a little frustrated trying to watch netflix on my bed.

Performance:
With a high wattage Intel Haswell Quad-core 4th generation processor, it chews through everything quite quickly. The lower wattage CPUs in ultrabooks are primarily designed for battery longevity and much lower thermals with decent performance. The difference between Apple's latest generation Macbook air with it's 15W Dual-Core CPU and the GE40 is very noticeable in the programs that I use (namely Acrobat Pro, Photoshop, transcode applications). The dynamic overclocking of the CPU also allows lightly threaded applications to take advantage of higher clock speeds whilst putting the unused cores to sleep.

The graphics duties are shared between the integrated intel HD4600 and a dedicated NVIDIA GTX 760M. The switching is handled with NVIDIA's optimus tech. The integrated graphics are powerful enough to handle the Windows GUI acceleration, Flash, and movie playback to conserve power and reduce heat generation. The GTX 760M kicks in when you launch a full screen 3D application, allowing you to take advantage of a large performance increase. The GTX 760M did a great job of providing acceptable frame rates at the native resolution in the games I play. For specific numbers, look up the GTX 760M on Notebookcheck.com

This version of the GE40 has a 128GB solid state drive and a 750GB hard disk drive (occupying the bay where the DVD-ROM is on the cheaper version). Out of the box this notebook is much faster, but you should ask yourself if that is enough room for your OS and programs. Personally, I think a 256GB SSD is the minimum size, but you can always put your steam folder and larger games on the mechanical drive if you're willing to deal with longer load times.

While the GE40 has 8GB of DDR3-Low Voltage memory installed, it is a single DIMM. This is both a plus and minus. With a single DIMM, you drop your effective bandwidth to 10GB/ps for the CPU and integrated GPU. You'll be hard pressed to see a noticeable drop in performance, but this is supposed to be a high end system. On the other hand, if you were planning to go to a total of 16GB of RAM, you won't have to buy x2 8GB DIMMs. Just grab 1 8GB DIMM and you'll get your dual channel memory performance.

Preinstalled Software:
Windows 8: You either love it or hate it. I personally like Microsoft's new OS due to the faster performance and support for new hardware technologies. I'm not a fan of the Start Screen, but that's easily remedied with a third party start menu replacement. The product key for Windows is integrated into the UEFI BIOS of the system so you won't need to enter a key during Windows setup. Just activate once you've reinstalled the OS.

As I mentioned before, Norton and other trialware is preinstalled. You'll be greeted with a number of desktop cluttering icons and background services taking up system resources. It isn't nearly as bad as some, but again, this is a gaming system that shouldn't have junk preinstalled to begin with.

I personally reinstalled Windows 8 after installing an extra 8GB DIMM. Be prepared to download the wireless LAN drivers beforehand as Windows 8 doesn't come with them out of the box. There are also a plethora of other drivers that need to be installed to restore full functionality (Bluetooth, WLAN switch, ETC).

Noise/Heat:
In normal operation, the notebook is a bit warm to the touch and the fan constantly runs at a slight hum. The fan is audible, but not overtly or annoyingly so. When gaming, the notebook does get hot. It's not unbearable, but it isn't super comfortable either. The fan kicks it into high gear and is very noisy. I was able to hear it every between explosions in game with my headphones on. Both the heat and noise levels are to be expected, especially with the amount of performance packed into such a small chassis.

Overall evaluation:
The MSI GE40 is a great notebook that fills my needs well. The balance of portability and performance allows me to finish my work quickly to get a little bit of play in. If you can cram your programs and games onto a 128GB SSD, you'll find more value in the upgraded version of the GE40. Otherwise both notebooks can stand to have an additional 8GB of memory and a clean install of Windows to maximize its performance and your enjoyment.

Update 7/10/2013:
I was curious if I could get the thermals down a bit, so I opened up my notebook again to see what kind of job MSI did with the thermal paste. As I suspected, they put way too much on which was hindering the heat transfer from the CPU and dedicated GPU to the heatpipe assembly.

Dis-assembly was not that difficult; 8 philips screws and the fan and heatpipe was easily removed. I cleaned up the factory paste and wiped the CPU/GPU and heatpipe with some isotropic alcohol. I then applied a thin layer of artic silver 5 and put it all back together. Subjectively, the notebook runs cooler. The fan spins slower at idle and comes back down from 100% quicker after playing a game. The palm rest and WASD keys were also a bit cooler. I didn't record before and after temperatures, but there are a couple youtube videos detailing this modification and the tangible results.

If you are comfortable performing this procedure, I wholeheartedly recommend doing it. Your left palm and wrist will thank you.edied with a third party start menu replacement. I received a ReadyNAS 104 through the Netgear Friends and Family Program.

I planned to use this unit as a backup for pictures and media, but found it versatile enough to serve as a basic server for streaming media.

Opening the box, the ReadyNAS was packed well for shipping, and was fully assembled. I first set it up with a single [[ASIN:B008JJLXO6 WD Red 1 TB NAS Hard Drive: 3.5 Inch, SATA III, 64 MB Cache - WD10EFRX]], and created a ReadyCLOUD account. That was simple and straightforward, and allows the user an interface to access the ReadyNAS from virtually anywhere. I also installed the free ReadyCLOUD app on my android (HTC One (M8)), and then mapped a couple of network drives to locations on the ReadyNAS. So far so good.

I started by transferring a couple of files over by dragging and dropping, and found the drag/drop feature through the interface tends to freeze fairly often, particularly with large files. With patience, the system would unfreeze and continue as normal, but I found that somewhat annoying. However, I did not experience system freezes when drag/dropping between a local and the network drive I mapped to the NAS. Speed was unremarkable, with a read/write speed of about 11.5MB/s. However, this could have been bottlenecked by my own system/router.

Next, I plugged in two more 1TB WD Red drives, and let X-RAID take over to create a RAID5 configuration. The rebuild took about 12 hours, and I was back in business. This time, I had a read speed of 66MB/s, with a write speed of 43MB/s measured with CrystalDiskMark 3.0.3.

I set up Genie Timeline to use a networked location on the NAS for its new backup location, and kicked off my backup. While that was running, I installed PLEX through the Apps tab on the NAS interface, and transferred over a few movies, not expecting much. However, found I could stream MP4 movies with ease. It was literally as simple as turning on my circa 2011 Panasonic Viera TV, navigating to the DLNA app, then selecting the PLEX server I had installed on the NAS and choosing a movie to watch. Movies stream instantly, and seem to be more responsive than even Netflix. I can stream movies to my phone as well through the ReadyCLOUD android app, but cannot stream in a web browser on my laptop as HTML5 is not supported.

While my original intent was to use this exclusively as a backup device, I'm sufficiently impressed that I've renewed my project of ripping DVDs and Blu Rays. While the ReadyNAS 104 cannot serve as an end-all media server - it's well-documented that you won't be happily transcoding anything with an ARM-powered NAS device - it works well enough for streaming media, and excels as a storage or backup device.

At the ~$250 price point, you won't do much better.

I thought I had finally found an alternative to Apple's Magic Mouse. I love the feel of the Magic Mouse, but its erratic jumping around the screen in certain programs (anything from Adobe and Microsoft) drives me crazy. The M510 is a lot fatter, but not uncomfortable. Out of the box it worked pretty good with Mountain Lion. I'd say it was almost as accurate as the Magic Mouse, but not quite, except when it came to scrolling. That's where the M510 shines. Since Apple removed scroll bar arrows, it's really difficult to scroll through lists, especially Adobe's little palettes in Photoshop CS6. But the ratcheted scroll wheel lets you easily move from one Pantone color to the next with no problem. And the scroll wheel rocks right and left for sideways scrolling of big images, almost like the Magic Mouse. Sadly, the accuracy of the mouse declined after about a week. Using a mousepad helped a little, but then the M510 started clicking on its own, making dragging and dropping files impossible. Finally, I installed the Logitech driver, but it doesn't work with Mountain Lion so I could never try out the side buttons.

PROS: Comfortable, very accurate track wheel, batteries supposedly last a long time (I couldn't test this)

CONS: Clicker went nuts after only a week, accuracy is iffy, wireless dongle hogs a USB port (Apple's Bluetooth is built in), hard-to-open molded plastic packaging, old school design could go on a diet, driver doesn't work with Mountain Lion

[[ASIN:B0012X5766 Kingston 8GB DataTraveler USB flash drive - High Speed USB]]

In terms of meeting it's function, this Kingston Data Traveler seems very good so far, certainly as good as the other smaller capacity ones I own. And the 8 GB capacity on this guy makes it very useful for a lot of large file backups or USB storage and transfer. There are a few things to keep in mind but overall this is a solid product.

Pros:
+ Kingston brand is well deserved
+ Reliable performance
+ Nice capacity of 8 GB has you future proofed as smaller USB drives start to disappear
+ Durable body and NAND memory stands up to a lot of abuse
+ Compatible with old and new Mac and PC Operating Systems (XP, Vista, OS X)
+ Very light
+ Rear bar to connect a lanyard or keychain
+ USB 2.0 connection is backwards compatible for older computers
+ Very quickly mounts and stops
+ Less scum-ware and needless apps than some other drives
+ Easy to format and enable encryption to protect your data

Cons:
- Cap comes off easily and can be lost; inferior to retractable designs
- Lanyard or extender accessories not included
- Doesn't have the good looks of some drives like the Sandisk Cruzer Micro
- Still somewhat slow speed in copying large files, limited by USB transfer rate
- Same old body is larger than it has to be
- Keychain / lanyard attachment bar is too easily broken
- Pricing here doesn't change to reflect when this item goes on sale elsewhere

This is the same design that Kingston has used for these Data Traveler USB drives since the 1 GB I got quite a while ago.

Transfer speeds are comparable to other drives, but still slower than one would like. Load ups are fast and stops are only a little slower.

In order to enable encryption, there are a few ways but the best may be to use another tool to encrypt the drive after re-formatting it. This way you can test the drive as well as use the encryption you prefer.

The main real competition is from Sandisk, whose Cruzer Micro has a tab to retract the USB connector [[ASIN:B000UZN2ZK SanDisk 8 GB Cruzer Micro USB 2.0 Drive with U3 SDCZ6-8192-A11 (retail packaging)]]. That way there's no risk of losing the cap, but there is more chance of getting dust in it. It is more expensive though.

Kingston produces some retractable ones as well.
[[ASIN:B000TZ5WSG Kingston DataTraveler 100 - USB flash drive - 8 GB - Hi-Speed USB - black]]
[[ASIN:B000TXEE14 Kingston DT100/8GB Data Traveler 100 8 GB USB 2.0 Drive]]

Conclusion

This is a nice capacity in a small USB drive. Just watch the price and make sure you're getting it on par with prevailing prices

Just watch the price and make sure you're getting it on par with prevailing prices Enjoy!

I've been using this Logitech Bluetooth Keyboard & Mouse for several months now. I have it connected to my laptop when I'm using it at home. When the mouse works, it's very good. However, the Bluetooth connection is not consistent, and I constantly need to reconnect the mouse by turning it off and on. This happens at least once a day, sometimes more frequently, and it usually happens while I'm moving the mouse pointer. Once disconnected, the mouse will reconnect if I turn the mouse's power switch off and then on again. However, this is a hassle, and it takes 5-10 seconds for the mouse to be recognized again.

Before using this Logitech mouse, I've been using a Dell Bluetooth Mouse. That mouse didn't have this frequent disconnect problem, and usually lasted several weeks or more between disconnections. I've also had a Lenovo Bluetooth mouse, which disconnected more frequently than the Dell one, but still much less than this Logitech one. In my experience (and most other Bluetooth users' too), Bluetooth mice have a tendency to disconnect, so I don't think Logitech is completely to blame. However, disconnecting on a daily basis (often more than once per day) is unacceptable, especially when other mice can work much better on the same laptop.

Other than the disconnect issue, the mouse is well built, feels comfortable, and the extra buttons work well. The buttons are customizable, but with some limitations (Logitech's SetPoint software gives you a limited list of functions to choose from). The Hyperscroll function works well too, but may take a bit of getting used to. The laser sensor works well on most surfaces (including my desk where my optical mouse didn't work too well). The battery lasts about 2-3 weeks for me, which is adequate, but I would probably prefer user replaceable batteries instead, so I could get longer battery life, and also not have to deal with the extra charger on my desk.

The keyboard does not have the same issue as the mouse, and I haven't experienced any disconnections from the keyboard yet. The keyboard does get a bit laggy when the mouse spontaneously disconnects, but it is resolved when the mouse has been reset. Also, it takes a couple seconds for the keyboard to connect when turning on the laptop. When it gets to the Windows login screen, I can type my password and press enter, but it will take a couple seconds for it to register on the screen (not a big deal though, and I'm sure it's the same for all BT keyboards). The keyboard itself is very easy to type on, and the keys sound like they are slightly dampened, so it isn't very loud. I wouldn't say it's very quiet either, but at least it doesn't make annoying loud clacking sounds. There are many function keys that can be customized, and the LCD calculator function is quite convenient too (you can have the calculator button go to Windows Calculator instead if you don't like the LCD calculator). The media keys also work well. I haven't had to replace the batteries yet, so I can't comment on the battery life.

Overall, this is a good product from Logitech, and since there aren't that many choices for Bluetooth keyboards & mice out there, I decided to keep this set even with the mouse connectivity issues. Some users may not experience the same disconnect issues, and for those users, I'd give the set 5 stars. However, for those that have the disconnect issues, the product is probably only worth 1-2 stars. That is why I gave it an average 3 star rating. If you want a good Bluetooth keyboard & mouse set, and are willing to take a chance with the connection problems, then order this product. Amazon is very good with returns anyway, so if you find that the mouse doesn't work well with your computer, you could always return the product.

-Keys Quietness 4/10 (0 being makes no sound, and 10 being unbearably loud)
-Connectivity 9/10
-Battery Life 8/10 (estimated)

MOUSE:
-Comfort 8/10
-Functions 7/10
-Connectivity 1/10
-Battery Life 5/10

I first learned of the Nokia N800 by accident just looking at PDA sights on the Internet.  The more I learned about it the more I wanted it.  A newer model (the N810) came out so I compared the newer and the older models and the older one won hands down.  Like the Iphone and Ipod touch, this offers a full internet browsing experience not just mobile sights and the clarity of the screen is stunning.  Also it is an internet radio with presets from all over the world so you can use it as a radio.  Also, hidden inside the radio but not mentioned in any Nokia Literature, the N800 has a hidden FM radio receiver (the N810 does not have this).  With a few commands you can activate it and you use the earphones as antenna - but you can listen thru the speakers. You can also watch videos on You Tube with no problems at all.  You can download the latest software that comes with the N810 for free from Nokia.   Speaking of downloads, ACCESS has made Garnet (Palm OS) available free for download so you can download Palm programs to the machine.  This is a Linux machine but don't let that put you off.  I had never used one and have found it easy.  Plus there are lots of free software like FBRreader available which lets you make the N800 a digital books reader.  They've also just released a program for free which completely simulates a Star Trek PADD from the Next Generation.  Whew!  Is that enough for you?  Oh did I mention that all this is a little over $200 - half of what you pay for an Ipod Touch and you get so much more.  PS there are 2 memory chip slots so you can put in as much as 32 gig on cards purchased separately.  The N810 only has one micro memory card chip slot.  Oh and the battery is easly changed - it is a Nokia battery available at any cellphone supply store unlike Apple where you have to send in the whole unit when the battery runs out.  All in all, this is a winner you will not regret.

I'm an advanced amateur photographer who takes photos mainly for my own pleasure but I've also sold some prints and I also do some paid assignments. Anyway, trying to calibrate my monitor to achieve accurate color has been a difficult, seemingly impossible, sometimes almost futile endeavor.  I've used manual (eyeballing) software tools such as Adobe Gamma without any success.  Adobe Gamma got me whole lot closer to my ideal of a perfect color match than my factory default unadjusted monitor, but it was still off... the colors were a little too warm and the gamma a bit too high.  Then I decided to order a hardware calibration tool.  Enter the Spyder2Express.  This thing is amazing!  It was very easy to install and set up.  About 10 minutes later my monitor was perfectly calibrated!  Now my prints match what I see on the screen with amazing precision.  I should have ordered one of these things a while ago... it would have saved me tons of headache and wasted prints.
