The ventilation slits on the bottom are rather helpful since the Mac tends to heat up on my lap. The CD slit as well as the other outlet openings are easy to access. The keyboard skin fits perfectly. The package did come with a screen protector, but I didn't use it since I'm not a fan of them. It is wrapped well though to ensure it won't get wrinkled or dusty. This product does the job perfectly.

If you can live with the Call of Duty graphics instead of the plain black, you get this G9X gaming mouse much cheaper than the standard version. Same great mouse. The weights are nice and lets you adjust the mass of the mouse to "feel right" for you.

Have had it almost a month. Good size, good power, and good storage. I used it daily until it got knocked off my night stand and the screen shattered. I guess I will be able to review how easy/hard it is to repair.

I purchased this on the recommendation of a friend and used it for about two weeks, after owning my iPad for a month and getting increasingly paranoid about screen injury and not really liking the fingerprints.    Bottom line, this is a well-made product that will be up to the personal preferences of the user.     It is fantastic at reducing fingerprints. When the screen is off they are barely perceptible. It isn't hard to install, just PREP the area - canned air, wash hands (I wore disposable surgical gloves), go slow - and you'll be fine.    The only reason I removed my screen after two weeks was that I could tell there was a significant loss of clarity when viewing pages or using the Kindle app. At first I tried to ignore it, but after a family member visited and I used theirs, sans screen, I felt like I was viewing a HiDef BluRay DVD after watching an over-the-air lo-res cable feed.     The product is otherwise built really well, and I stored it in a ziploc in case I ever sell it, but having lived without it for a week-plus now, I don't miss it at all. It's much easier to keep a small piece of the screen cloth tucked into the iPad folio cover and wipe down the screen every so often.
The price was great and the product meets my expectations - the quality is good..  I would remcommend this item.

I decided to buy this drive for one purpose - a boot drive for my HTPC. I was originally was just going to get a 8GB SSD, but the performance on those was only slightly better than a typical hard drive. I decided to up to the 64GB model and put my the OS on the SSD drive as well.

First off, putting this in the machine was trivial, thanks to the included 2.5\\" -> 3.5\\" adapter. Most people who are using these in a desktop wouldn't have a spot to mount it otherwise, so kudos to Corsair for including it.

Now, onto the drive. It is FAST. I did some tests on it and was actually able to get very close to the reported read/write speeds. I got 140MB/s on a write, and was able to read at 240MB/s. This is a performer. Additionally, the motherboard I got 18 months ago works perfectly with this and recognized it with a hitch.

The inclusion of trim is a nice touch as well.

Overall, I am quite pleased with this SSD, and can't wait for the price to come down even more.
Great little case!

I like the color & size...I got the tablet on monday  today is friday & I stil cant access the Internet ....I tried accessing both email & gmail accounts ...failed...tried registering the tablet also a failure...I have my own wi fi....only reason I bought this tablet the price was right & it uses wi fi..can somebody pleaseee help me :((...have no use for it if I cant just use my wi fi will return it.
My Kindle Fire is my new best friend, it is always with me and the ability to protect the screen from scratches is very important to me

This was my first experience in making my own external harddrive from one of my old laptops....and to my surprise...with this case it was a piece of cake!!! It was so simple to use and the instructions were very clear to follow...Thanks for such a great product....this 61 year grandma will not hesitate to buy this again!
This router was super easy to set up for this \\"Networking and WiFi Challenged\\" person.  So simple.  I was online in a matter of minutes with security features.
This is perfect for the price, love the color as well, I would highly recommend, I will be ordering more colors as well...
It's a great product and fit very well for my Pro15

The sticker itself is very cute and exactly as shown in the picture but after a few hours of it being on my laptop it started to peel off on the edges. Only way its sticking on now is because i have it pressed under my laptop case rather than it being on top.

using this so I can have a usb hub next to the couch for easy access, especially so I can plug in my Droid for music and video transfers. Everything works fine and I haven't noticed any difference in transfer speed. I'm probably going to buy another one so my wife can move the printer in her office wherever she wants it (don't feel like buying a new one just to get wireless printing and those wireless adapters are overpriced, imo)
I chose this rating because it was the quality I had hoped for in spite of the very low price. I was exactly what I wanted and hoped it would do.

Yes this fits the iPad.  Yes it protects your iPad, but it definitely was not designed with the iPad in mind.  It's slightly too roomy to be an iPad only sleeve.  It really fits my wife's netbook nicely but I'm dinging this thing down to 3 stars because it's pitched as an iPad sleeve.

This is the third cover I purchased and I couldn't be more pleased.  It opens like a book, but if you wish you can snap the left side in the back of the right side.  The kindle is secure and doesn't flop around.  All buttons are fully exposed and are accessible.  The cover is light, doesn't add much bulk.  It is a classy black, looks professional, and protects my precious kindle. There are vents on the back that are enclosed with a fine metallic mesh.  It looks really good and feels good in my hands.  I love this cover!

Cheap, efficient but noisy--too noisy for me to use at night--I'm used to a logitch wireless keyboard. While using this at night I kept worrying about waking my roommates while typing on this.

As a student with roommates that often finishes typing up assignments late night/early morning, this would not be my first pick.
We use this for our ipads, fits comfortably inside and padded enough to prevent damage, good quality.
Very durable and worth the price! I would recommend to anyone. Great material and clearly workable. Hopefully more color themes and extras can be created.
I bought this for the Intel Next Unit of Computing DC3217BY Kit and haven't had any issues. Price was very reasonable. I would have liked 16GB but I settled for 8GB to save $75 on the project.

I had previously tried 2 other SATA extension cables which were very poor quality. [[ASIN:B003WFBFZY NSI LK-13526 7-pin internal SATA Male to SATA Female Extension cable - 7 pin SATA M/F - 20 inch (50 cm)]] and the [[ASIN:B0022WRMIC 1.5 FT (0.5 m) SATA Male to Female Extension Cable]]. These 2 appear to be the same item and are very poor quality. One arrived with the male end tab broken and another broke after a few uses. The item being review is much better. The only thing that prevents me from giving it 5 stars is the lack of a metal clip on the female end. This would make it hold a little better. The cable measures 12.25\\" tip-to-tip. I bought 1 for evaluation and based on that I ordered 4 more but the item was first back ordered but now is not available.

I have never written a review on anything before. That is how disappointed I am with this product. If I had known that the screen was going to stop working within 2 years I would have returned it. I definitely wouldn't have spent $60 on a fancy cover.. Amazon offered me a very small discount on buying a new one. No, thank you.

The E2414Hr version does not come with a DVI-D cable, whereas the E2414H (non-r) should; note that this should be a DVI-D (dual-link) cable and not simply DVI. Per the user guide -- \\"DVI Cable (E2414H only)\\".

Driver support for XP users (which MS supports until 2020) is incomplete and non-functional causing driver installation errors, and using the generic Plug-n-Play monitor setting may be dissapointing. Also, it is beneficial to have a video card that can support the monitor's full range of 1920 x 1080 @ 60Hz, but lower settings are supported at higher frame rates (70-75Hz, etc.).

The video appears to be somewhat washed-out and Word text seems to be pixilated and a bit ragged, although attemps have been made to adjust the color temperature along with brightness, contrast, and other settings. The black adjustment buttons on a black frame can be difficult to distinguish, and I would prefer the buttons were of a contrasting color such as silver or chrome.

There is no vertical (height) adjustment or the capacity to swivel right/left with this monitor, but it does have a forward/back tilt mechanism.

It is overly easy to assemble (three pieces not including display or cords) and no tools are required, with fairly good cord managment to the rear.
What a large fan!  I thought this was a window unit at first lol.  All jokes aside, very well made and awesome design.  I would recommend this fan in a second to anyone wanting to upgrade case fans.

I bought this because I thought my Kindle needed it.  In fact, it did not need it at all. I installed it less than a minute and it has been working great.  No frills are needed.  The fan connects to a USB drive and starts working immediately.  The blue light looks cool but you really can't see it once the computer is set on it.  I found the highest setting a bit too much slant to be comfortable but I've been using it without setting it up so high and have not had any issues.  I'm happy with the purchase.

The product worked well and charged nicely until the return-policy expired. It just randomly stopped charging and shuts the computer off in the middle of work, so hours of work can be lost. Now we are getting better at saving our work frequently, but this is a huge hassle, now. Take my advice: save up for one of the better batteries. This is a waste of money.

I just peeled off the nylon sticker band attached to the feet and used my own glue. installation takes only a few seconds if you unscrew and take the bottom case off your mac.

800- number is a joke. It just tells you to visit a website or call 310- number.

Bought this in May of 2014, it worked pretty well... for about 6 months, then the velcro holding the outer cover to the inner tablet case stopped being any good at holding on because the fabric for the inner case seems to be very plain fabric, much unlike how velcro pairings usually go; on the inside the flap that holds the tablet inside of the case properly has two matching velcro surfaces; if there was a similar "strip" on the back of the tablet case to attach where the velcro is on the inside of the outer cover piece then this would not be an issue, but as it stands the tablet is now prone to "fall right out" of the case since there is pretty much no "grip" anymore.

To make things much worse, what the heck is with the price? I bought this for ELEVEN DOLLARS, right here on Amazon, just SIX MONTHS AGO! In six months, a product which is apparently only good for six months, has managed to skyrocket by 2.5 times the price it previously was?! That's ridiculous! Based on the quality and longevity that this product has, to even THINK of raising the price at all is in and of itself ludicrous! But to more than double it? Ahahaha... yeah no, for $25 you can get GOOD tablet cases, bluetooth keyboard cases, hard-shell covers, stuff that LASTS... don't waste your money.

I ordered the Full Body kit, wanting to protect my entire device. I got the front and back sides on alright with no issues. The buttons were a little tricky. The edging...oh what a pain in the ass. Being so thin and small, they were difficult to place without moving around (for any that wish to try, I recommending doing 1 edge at a time and letting it dry for a bit before tackling the next one). I couldn't keep the small pieces moist long enough before they quickly dried up. Eventually I started tor run out of solution and used the extra solution for a kit I bought for my phone. No such luck, the dryness continued.

I said eff it and pulled off all the edging. Also had one of the button tabs turn slideways and slide under the back piece, lifting it up and allowing air to get under. I removed the button tabs as well and attempted to fix the back piece with a quick reapplication. Hopefully the back piece stays on.

Unfortunately, when the product arrived the plastic casing around the screen was partially opened and the screen itself was out of place, showing metal around the perimeter that you shouldn't see.  Oh, and the buttons didn't work.  I managed to get the screen in place (never mind the casing still looked busted, but hey, function over form in this case).  But to top it all off, when I set everything up it didn't even work!  I contacted the seller to explain the issue - told them I'd like to return, but if they even had any other monitors for sale I would still be willing to purchase from them.  Well, no response from the seller!  So this seller A) sells broken merchandise and B) is completely unresponsive to issues.  WOULD NOT RECOMMEND BUYING FROM THIS INDIVIDUAL.  Oh, and as for the brand itself...I tried to troubleshoot some stuff from the I-Inc website and it is terrible.  Looks like amateur hour, and their help line is clearly outsourced to someone just answering phones with no real product knowledge.  Wish I would have looked into the company, too, before I decided to purchase.  Bummer

Love this speaker. Very loud, and recovers quickly if completely submerged  in water. Also is very easy to cut a pool noodle, wrap around edges, secure with rubber band, and voila, it floats. Doesn't look as cool with all that stuff attached, but it works pretty well. The Bluetooth connectivity is simple, and connection is very strong. The band on the back is strong, attaches securely, and really expands the possibilities of mounting on pool floats, rafts, etc.

I like the external unit because I don't have to hunting for sound ports on the back of my PC. It is easy to hook up and delivers excellent sound. It is a great work around if your PCI ports won't take anymore cards. I love that I can reach everything on the sound appliance so easily. Love it! It is upgrade compatible to the best speakers on the market.
Good all around iPad mini case. Does the job with out breaking the bank. I would buy from this company again.

With computer mice being a commodity, it takes some explaining to my friends why I spent so much.  (I use this mouse at work as well - Solidworks is about 90% mouse-driven).  The benefits?  It is very comfortable to use and very fast and accurate, but for me, the pinky shelf keeps me from dragging on the mousepad, which normally would slow me down a lot.  The natural angle of tilt makes it very comfortable for the wrist.  Also, this mouse is larger than other mice I have used, and fits my large hands better - I don't have to curl my middle finger as much when running the wheel.
The memory card has 400kb more than advertised, and works perfectly for free mcboot and backup saves.  Also looks like standard memory card which is a plus

Bought this to use as an wifi range extender. My current wireless router wasn't strong enough to effectively reach my entire house (1500 sq.ft.). There were spots that would either get a really weak signal or sometimes no signal. After installing the Securifi Almond, I have better internet connection in the whole house. There is not a spot in my house now that I do not get a wifi signal, although in one spot it gets a weak signal.

Very easy to set up!
My son wanted this for the wireless computer needs for his entire house and he said it worked perfect for what he was looking for.  It was packaged nicely and arrived promptly.

the zoom feature in PDFs have been improved, even though it is still not perfect.

Recently grabbed a TP-LINK N300 wireless router at the ridiculously low price of under $20. The packaging and accessories (RJ-45 cable included) was as good as anything you would find from the leading brands. Design is pretty sleek, modern and good-looking, the only miss is the inability to mount/stand the router vertically. You can either lie it flat or hang on wall.

Pop in the cd or go into web interface and configure with help or manually. Overall just as easy and has plenty of customizable options Performance seems perfectly fine based on wired and decent on wireless connection. Overall I'm pretty happy in terms of value, design and function on the TP-LINK N300...

I have owned three Kindles and all have been protected by an Otterbox. I have a tendency to bump into things and the otterbox has kept my Kindle in like new condition. It does add a slight amount of weight to your tablet, but for what it does to protect your tablet makes it worth a little more weight. I would reccomen this to anyone who wants to protect a major investment.
Well designed, sturdy, good adaptability, and of course sexy at $23. My only mistake was not looking at the SFX power supply requirement. D'oh!

This is toooooo small for a ipad and does not measure 8 by 10!!!
very disappointing.

I have owned two G Tablets for about 6 weeks.  I have become addicted.  I use mine primarily for web surfing, video streaming, monitoring my email, and as an ereader.  The available android browser and email software (aka Apps) is not as good as that on my laptop,  but it is good enough. I prefer the Dolphin browser, MailDroid for email. Actually, my laptop is getting lonely and jealous of the amount of time I spend with the GTablet. (of course, I am writing this on my laptop.  When I need to answer an email, I go over to my laptop. Then I go back to my recliner or couch and the GTablet.)     I would not have gotten this much pleasure from the GTablet if I had not installed a third party ROM to replace the stock ROM that comes with the GTablet.  I went through Tnt Lite and Vegan which are Android 2.2 and give you full access to the Android market.  Now I am using Vegan Gingerbread (Android 2.3) and am looking forward to upgrading to Honeycomb (Android 3.x) in the next few weeks.      The viewing angle is indeed not great.  But only when watching videos.  For anything else, it is, at best, a nuisance, hardly noticeable.  But when streaming a video or movie, I notice it.  That said, I watch a lot of streamed videos.  For me it is an irritant, not a deal breaker.    Wifi is more than adequate.  I am frequently at least 50 feet from my wifi router. It is located in the basement. Last night I watched three episodes of a TV show with no problems.      The battery is amazing.  Eight to ten hours.    The Acer Aconia and the Asus Transformer are attractive, but reading their reviews, they also have issues you have to learn to live with.  Plus they are more expensive.  I got two GTablets for the price of one Xoom. The Acer cost 50% more, but I don't think I'd get 50% more value. I don't need a back facing camera.  An HDMI port would be nice, but I have only used the one on my laptop twice over a year.  I've got the same processor as the Asus, Acer, and Xoom.  I'll be gettingAdroid 3 soon.     If you absolutely have to buy a Tablet today, the Gtab is an excellent choice.  If I wanted to spend $450 to $600 dollars, I'd wait to see what comes out during the Christmas season.      Support from Viewsonic is worthless.  But the support from the community of Gtab owners and programmers is priceless.  People get a lot of problems solved by knowledgeable community members on sites such as XDA developers, and slatedroid. I have directly benefited from this community when I ran into problems installing a new ROM. Of course not every problem gets solved.  But I think the odds are in the Gtablet owner's favor.     The bottom line is that you must decide what you are comfortable with, how much you are willing to pay, and how long you are willing to wait.      I understand the features and advantages of the newer tablets on the market today.  But I don't seem them as a superior value to what I've got.  I know that the Gtablet will serve me very well for a long time.  I reserve the right to change my mind 6 months from now.  But as of today, having had these Gtablets for six weeks, I'm very happy with what I've got.

Backlit Keyboard is awesome. Free xbox 360 is great as well. Reasonable price. Laptop Arrived promptly. Slow to boot up at first, but some programs were uninstalled and now it is much better. Black color looks good. Battery life seems reasonable so far.

This mouse is just what was needed.  I used the Microsoft tracball for years and years and it just broke.  This mouse for a fraction of the cost replaces the tracball and I am back on the computer again.  Thanks to God for this mouse.  The thumb model was beginning to hurt my arthritic thumb.  this with the fingers moves smoothly and fast.
Works very well. NO complaints.  Jim K.

I love my Comfort Keyboard. The product description is totally accurate, and I no longer experience the debilitating CTS pain that I used to have with normal ergonomic keyboards. Basically it's the best thing since sliced bread!

I have purchased more expensive models of this cooler in the past. They were rugged, no assembly required, but a bit more. When I could not find the other model I bought this one instead. I "lucked out" in that the component I needed in this kit of 4 objects was the exact fit for my 1st gen ipod, namely the AC wall charger..  However, the USB extension cable included in this kit does not have the same configuration as my 1st gen ipod.  Not a problem since I still have my original in working condition but it would have been a disappointment if I had needed to replace all the components.. This is not a problem created by the seller. It is a good pad and I'm still using it (still works pretty well) after all those years. The only thing I don't understand is that no calibration feature is provided in the Nostromo Array Programming Software and its included driver (in Control Panel). The auto-calibration feature, if present, does not work well sometimes.    For those of you having calibration issues, uninstall the Nostromo Array Programming Software, restart your computer, center the D-PAD sticks as best as you can, then install the Nostromo Array Programming Software again.    Of course you can also use 3rd party tools to calibrate it.

Just received the Belkin QODE Thin Type Keyboard and I absolutely love it.  Quality is fantastic.  Very solid.  Bluetooth connects fast.  Body is aluminum.  Key buttons are plastic with nice tactile response.  When iPad Air is placed into slot not only does the keyboard activate but the ipad is awakened as well.  Ipad sits well in landscape or portrait position.  All the keys work well; placement of keys is great.  Besides all the dedicated IOS shortcut keys on the top row, there are three keys on the top row (in position 6, 7 and 8 from the left) that are used when ITunes Radio is open.  Key six with the star means you can \\"like\\" the song.  Key 7 with the X means you do not like the song.  Key 8 with the + means you want to add it to your wish list.  Well worth purchasing and the wait.  Love it!  It weighs about 12.5 oz.

This worked fine charging my HP 1000. The new charger cord is not three prong (grounded) and is shorter that the original charger in length. AC side is 45 inches long,  charger side from plug to converter is 47 inches VS the original HP charger whose AC side is 71 inches long, three prong (grounded), thicker wiring and from plug to converter is 59 1/2 inches. The new charger does have a a filter near the plug, the orignial does not. Total length is of cords is new-92 inches vs original- 130.5 inches, these measurements are approximate and do not take in account the actual converter box, so there is roughly a 38 inch difference in length, the original has thicker wire and a three prong plug. All in all it functions properly and is a good price, it just bothers me that something meant to be used with a computer does not have a grounded plug. I will update upon some usage to see how durable it turns out.
This is a great product and I can't imagine not having it for my husband's Kindle.  I would highly recommend it to anyone who purchases a Kindle and wants to keep it protected.

Very portable.  Fits perfectly in laptop case.  Helps to keep laptop cooler than if it is sitting directly on your lap and prevents sliding with rubber pads.  Room for use of minimouse on the side.  Very convenient.  Recommend to others.

I have a 7 year old desktop where the Ethernet port is apparently going bad, and the built in wireless is only up to the b/g standard, so it is slow.  I inserted this device into the USB 2.0 slot, and Windows 8.1 installed it so quickly I didn't even see it happen.  Now my download speeds are back up to nearly 100 Mbps, which is better than what I expected with USB 2.0.  I opted for this device because it will also offer a wired Ethernet device for my Netbook for situations where wired is available, like hotels.  Anyway, setup with Windows 8.1 was virtually non-existent.  I did go into the device properties to change the settings so that it couldn't wake my computer from sleep.  It did have more options in device properties than the original Ethernet port, but that's probably to be expected with a device which is over 7 years newer.  Edit:  Installation on a newer Netbook running 8.1 wasn't as smooth--perhaps because netbooks might not have as many drivers pre-loaded????  Once installed though it gave me my fastest speed test ever--120 Mbps.

If you are using a NAS configuration I highly recommend these WD Red drives! They are working great with my DROBO-5N!!
The "Red" HDDs are made for NAS / RAID configurations and have different parameters for anotating bad sectors and protecting your data as needed.
I've heard horror stories of people using "green" drives in a RAID and not know that one or more drives had encountered a bad sector and no action had been taken by the drive to note the problem. Only to find out later that their data could NOT be "rebuilt" when they replace a failed HDD.

I just purchased the XA1 model and out of the box I was having a few issues (backlight/function keys not working and cdrom drivers being iffy.)  The first thing I did was create the backup discs.  One nice thing is if you happen to delete the application that creates the discs for you, it can be found on the driver disc that came with the laptop.  Anyway, after a day or so of freaking out, I used the backup discs and restored the system (yeah...  a day after cutting it on for the first time.)  Took almost 2 hours to reinstall Windows with all the added junk, but the laptop works perfectly now.  Haven't had an issue since.      One thing I was worried about with an i7 laptop was heat, but Asus designed the rear fans very well.  It runs SO much cooler than my old Toshiba Satellite.  CPU temps are running around 40 or so, going up while playing games (WoW, CoD, L4D2) to about 55 or 60.  Battery life is... normal compared to what this beast has under the hood.  On the first charge it only lasted around 2 hours, but creating and burning the ISO images for the backup CDs seemed to hog some major resources.      I'll update after a week or so and give a better review.  It's running great now, but it is a little odd having to reformat the 2nd day I've used the thing...

I have a Mid 2010 iMAC running Windows 7 (The application that I use runs on Windows only, but I like the iMAC hardware).  When I tried to reinstall Windows 7 to the MiniPro SSD, it tells me it is not supported (a quick Google search confirm that).  So now I am just using this as a data disk. The interesting thing is; I also measured the IO speed of this external SSD disk and the internal hard disk of my iMac with CrystalDiskMark. This external SSD disk clocked in at approx 86 MB/s and the internal hard disk clocked in at 111 MB/s. This means there is no incentive to look for extra-ordinary method to make Windows 7 boot from the external SSD drive. It is not going to be faster anyway. I later found out that 86 MB/s is petty close to max wire speed of FireWire 800. The take away from my little experiment is this; It is possible for a external SSD to be _slower_ than a internal hard disk. You have to also consider the speed of the connection technology.

I am a new Kindle user and it is not up to my expectations. I'm reading Aristotle's Ethics, but both editions I have looked at are cluttered with meaningless references to footnotes that aren't present. I've tried to read Newton's Optics, but the integral figures are not included in the edition I'm reading, making the text useless. I really was looking forward to a wealth of public domain culture being available to me on this device, but it is really difficult to access it since the Kindle store is not really set up to facilitate searching for this type of material.

The browser is awful. It's not just that it is buggy or unfinished (it is \\"experimental\\" after all), but it doesn't refresh the screen like it needs to and the menu system is poorly designed. Wikipedia is usable, but clunky. Google News is nearly inaccessible, and news subscription services sometimes charge more for Kindle access than other forms of delivery.

Finally, the touch interface takes a little getting used to. I'm used to using iPads and iPhones, and it takes a little while to adapt to Kindle's touch technology. It isn't too bad, though.

With my lack of satisfaction with this product so far, I am not eager to begin paying money for more recent books. I've only had my Kindle for a couple of weeks or so, but my expectations are low for that part of the experience.

While I live near some great libraries and have ample access to a lot of reading material, I was hoping that the Kindle would instantly revolutionize my reading lifestyle with easy access to books, especially free or inexpensive public domain texts. I was also hoping for a device that would allow me to browse Wikipedia and access news on my device. So far I am disappointed.

Nice price, functions well, but only reliably to about 8 meters, not the full stated 10 meter range.  Do not use on a metal TV tray as the metal will block the signal.  Occasional spurious signals/commands crop up: e.g. the unit thinks the mouse wheel is being scrolled when it is not even being touched.  So if the mouse wheel advances you through pages, you may find yourself suddenly twenty pages down the line.  The remote units go to sleep rather quickly (to save batteries), so if you have been using the mouse for a while, and then need to enter a keyboard command, you will likely find the keyboard will take one or more key presses to wake up, and then another press for the intended signal to get through.    These flaws make this equipment unsuitable for detail work (fine brush strokes or tracings in image editors) or software that cannot be backed out of spurious or unintended commands.  For that, you should stick to hard wired equipment.  But for general knock around keyboard and mouse work on a PC connected to a huge TV, it is fine.

First off let me say that this is a great CPU. I did a ton of research before I bought this and It has paid off. My only problem with setup and install had to do with the fact that my mobo( biostar ta990fxe) I bought isnt very condusive for overclocking. When I tried to overclock the board and the cpu I had system restarts, which indicates the board reseting. I have gotten it stable just running regular factory settings and the speed is incredible. Even on factory settings I can run multiple programs at once without a hitch. I reccommend that if your going to purchase this chip, please make sure your mobo is compatible and dont take the cheap way out like I did on the board, buy a good solid board like ASUS or Gigabyte. Make sure its AM3+ socket compatible. Also, the stock cooler is ok but if your going to oc make sure you get a good aftermarket cooler, and with coolers make sure they fit in your case and on your board as I ran into problems with the cooler master hyper cooler not fitting on my cheap board.

Overall- 4 out of 5 only because the stock cooler is shit and useless for overclocking and AMD knows its shit,
But the speed and performance is impressive and the price is terrific as well.

This laptop is very convenient and does what it has to do. It looks and feels classy and work grade. I use it for school, work, and home, but mostly school and work. No flaws from a technical standpoint. It works just like its price range is going for.

BUT! There are a couple severe flaws, and this is where it really hits the fan. The trackpad is GOD AWFUL. It registers presses so poorly that half the time will be spent fidgeting around trying move the cursor. It is not smooth at all, and most of the time it will stop dead in its tracks even if you continue moving your finger. This is because the trackpad is somehow registering two or more presses. I can prove this because it will show arrows indicating you are either scrolling or zooming on a page. I have had cheaper laptops with better trackpads, and trust me, this is nowhere near what I have experienced. For me, its not very convenient carrying around a mouse as I rather prefer using the trackpad more.

Another thing to talk about is how it sleeps. You would assume that once you close the display the probook goes into hibernation, which it does ... half the time. When it doesn't, it only turns off the display but keeps the computer on. There will be times I stuff my fully charged probook in my case, and come back to it several hours later burning so hot I could cook an egg on it, not to mention with a near dead battery. I fear that the battery will be short lived and so will my probook.

And on a side note, upgrade the RAM. 4 gbs is just not enough. Fingerprint scanner works but is not very efficient half the time. How this probook is $750 on Amazon is beyond me. You can find it at any retail store for around half the price.

Final verdict: Good laptop, but expect flaws and buy it somewhere else.

I've used this RS-232 Serial converter for connecting to Cisco networking devices and various other networking equipment that utilizes a console port. This device was able to connect to all of them flawlessly. It was able to auto-detect the baud rate to apply for the connection and whether or not flow control was needed, which was reflected on the LEDs for each device connection. I also used this cable to xmodem a IOS file to an old Cisco Catalyst 2960 switch. This is a genuine FTDI chipset used in this device, http://hackaday.com/2014/10/22/watch-that-windows-update-ftdi-drivers-are-killing-fake-chips/ this link listed the drivers that affect fake FTDI chips. I updated my adapter to use the latest version that would "brick" the device and it is still detected and functions perfectly. I also made use of this adapter in linux using putty and cutecom and it detects perfectly as well, no need to modprobe usbserial vendor=0x???? product=0x???? it is plug and play.

I wasn't sure when I ordered it whether or not this would work for me, but it has everything I wanted in a case for the Nexus 7 and more that I expected.

Some of the best features:
- A holder for my stylus pen. [My stylus has a standard pen clasp, which keeps it even more in place.]
- It fits the New Nexus 7 perfectly, including holes for ports, cameras and speakers.
- The case is stiff, but "squishy" enough to distribute impact or drop force.
- It is extremely versatile as you can open it completely and use the strap to aid in hold it, or open it partially to act as a stand.
- There is a magnet in the front cover so that when it closes, the tablet knows it and automatically locks the screen.

The case is even form fitting enough that a zippered sleeve that I have from another tablet purchase can be put around it on occasion for extra traveling protection. Overall, this was an excellent choice in cases, and I have no complaints whatsoever.

-In-line Volume and microphone mute works great and has a smooth volume dial operation, unlike what other reviewers have said.
-Cord is long enough for me to move around the room
-Cool snap-cover colors

Cons:

-No lapel clip. I would like to have had a lapel clip so I can keep the cable close to my body instead of having it dangle in front of it
-Flex-boom microphone only comes 2/3rds of the way to the mouth. While the microphone is sensitive enough to pick up the sound of your voice anyway, I would have like to have had the microphone stop in front of the mouth. Especially for those moments where you'd rather whisper into the microphone without others around you hearing.

This adapter worked well for approximately 4-5 months, as is the consensus with most other reviews of this product. However, after not using the adapter for a few weeks, I plugged it in while running my ASUS net book. After about 20 minutes, the power notification on the monitor was changing from AC to Battery... back and forth. To my surprise, the box on the cord was melting. I immediately unplugged it and let it cool down. I took the advice of other reviews and only charged the netbook when the power was off or it was hibernating. That seemed to resolve the issue. I also think if the adapter starts to melt or get too hot, it's also due to where it is... mine was under a blanket... of course it would melt. Be careful with this one.... so hot it can burn through the plastic.

This is a great product, I'm not sure what those other people are talking about, the setup was extremely easy, it even detected the latest Firmware for me, no searching required.

Remember you are getting WN2000RPTv3 not WN2000RPTv1, meaning the firmware is different in numbers, the latest for v1 is 1.0.1.24, while the latest for v3 is V1.0.0.24, it can be confusing at first, since the box it came with had instructions proclaiming it to be just WN2000RPT, it didn't say which version you are getting, you figure out once you are in the control panel website, but you should not complain, you are getting a overall better version.

Wireless Performance: Definitely better than dealing with 1 bar dead zones, my router is pretty far from my bedroom, my router is located in my living room which is on the other side of the house, I had 1/2 and rarely max 3 bars on my iPhone, I could not watch youtube videos because it kept on buffering and giving me errors, I love to watch 30 minute to 1 hour videos of documentaries, and that was nearly impossible since it kept stopping, and giving me error of "Video could not load", With this extender, that all fixed, I can also watch Twitch live streaming in HD without it skipping or stopping.

Ethernet Performance: Yes, this DOES work with Ethernet, and I love it for my gaming, and uploading my youtube videos, it's extremely fast, Let me tell you this. I had 10 mbps download and 20 mbps upload on Wifi, with Ethernet, I got max 60 mpbs download and 40 mbps upload, This was a test on my Laptop, I'm on Optimum ISP, this could be different for you, or even better. depending on your ISP, but I am satisfied with it.

PS3 on Ethernet: It boosted my DL/UPL by 10 more MBs, I used to get 5 Mbs DL and 2 Mbs Upl, but now its 22.1 MB DL and 11.2 Upload.

On Wii U: I had about 2 MBs DL and 1 MB Upload, with an Ethernet Adapter I get 6 MBs and 2 MBs Upload, This is definitely critical in games like Super Smash Bros for Wii U, because lag could ruin you badly, and this helps a lot.

I rate it 4 out of 5, because I'm happy with it, it gave me problems in the beginning because they kinda confused me with the versions, but once I figured it out, it was all good.ike Super Smash Bros for Wii U, because lag could ruin you badly, and this helps a lot.

This tablet is for folks who want a single purpose tablet or are on a budget. There are some surprising features, like an HDMI port, a relatively decent camera and a very fast processor. On the other hand it lacks bluetooth, but does have a 3.5mm headphone jack. I am not going to regurgitate the product specs, which are clearly spelled out in the product description. I will provide some highlights that I found interesting on the review sample that I received:

DISPLAY: vivid and easy to read. I set mine for maximum brightness and larger fonts since my eyes are not what they use to be.

SPEED: actually faster than my Samsung Tab 3 10.1 tablet, so while this is a stripped down tablet, it doesn't skimp on CPU power.

EXTRAS: ships with an OTG (On-The-Go) cable that connects to the micro USB port. This allows you to plug in the also included USB Ethernet adapter for directly connecting to hubs, a keyboard or even a multi-port USB hub. It also ships with a 3.5mm cable.

POWER CONSUMPTION: it takes about four hours to fully charge this tablet after it falls into the 10% remaining battery range. I got six solid hours of use between charges, which is an hour more than the product specs claim. That was a pleasant surprise.

OTHER: the camera function is not spectacular - it's not as good as the one in my Samsung tablet or my Note 3 phone, but it still takes relatively decent photos and video. The issue I have is it's a little touchy when you slightly move when taking still photos or in lower light conditions. If that feature is important you will probably be disappointed.

This also would not recognize any SD card over 32GB that I tried with it. For me that is not an issue because other tablets I have owned have similar limitations. I am mentioning this to set your expectations.

DISLIKES: I do not know why this tablet requires a non-standard charger. You get a wall wart with a barrel connector that plugs into the charging port. I almost subtracted a star, but when I considered the price for the tablet I let it slide. The documentation is not that great either, but if you are an experienced Android user you won't need any.

I mentioned that this is great for single-purpose use. I am donating this one to my bandleader who is legally blind. She has some vision, but is challenged when it comes to reading music and other visual tasks. [[ASIN:B006LR6K14 MobileSheets]] will address that issue, and also [[ASIN:B006C67NP6 iReal Pro - Music Book & Play Along]] for practice and backing.

Bottom line: the key things missing are bluetooth, which can be worked around, and better documentation for folks new to Android. I am still unhappy about the power supply, and would give this 4.5 stars if I could solely because of that. However, this has a lot of pluses and for the price is a bargain.when I considered the price for the tablet I let it slide. Never ever ever ever going to buy Samsung products again. The tablet itself was nice, at first. Then after only using it a few times, it started to freeze and the screen had flashing horizontal white bars across it. I spent over 2 hours on their online FAQ section and service area. I performed every restart and reset possible, and it still locks up after only a few minutes of being turned on.

Now, I am sure it is just a defective device, which is fine, it happens. But what I cannot understand is why the person at the other end of the phone in their customer service department almost refused to do anything except tell me to reset the machine or to take it somewhere where a technician can reset it for me... really? I have been using electronics for my entire life, I think I know how to follow a few directions on resetting a device. I was one of those people in the eighties who could set the clock on their VCR properly, so it is a little insulting that they assumed I was completely clueless.

Their products may be fine, but based on the service alone, I will never buy another product of theirs.

I hope this helps others to make a more informed choice when looking for a device. Don't just look at the cost, look at the service. That is why I normally spend a few dollars more on higher-quality products backed up by more responsible parent companies.

There's really not much to say about a flash memory card except that this product comes with an SDHC reader which plugs into USB 2.0.  That's great because I had no other way to download SDHC data into my laptop except through the Sharp video cam's USB port which I don't enjoy.  Oddly enough, the Transcend 16MB Class 6 is available with and without the reader for virtually the same price.  I'm just lucky I found the Amazon ad that had the reader with the card before I pushed the button to finalize my order for the one without reader.    I also wish Amazon's system would have recommended Class 10 SDHC cards because I wasn't even aware such a thing existed until a week after my order arrived.  I would have sprung a little extra for a little faster, whether I need it or not.  The Class 6 is doing just fine but I always like to buy cutting edge when possible.    My recommendation is to be extremely careful about choosing the card you need for the device you're putting it in or you'll have a mess.  SD, SDHD, SDHC, miniSD, microSD, and others can get confused easily - especially when Class numbers are added as a specification.

The title is by no means a knock on this case: more of a jab at some other reviewers.

The Review:

I opened the package and was happy to see the product looked exactly as pictured. The second thing I noticed was a smell. While in hand reading, I don't smell it, but when close it's there. Is it the worst ever? No. Would it turn off some people? Probably, but I hope not. The leather (real or not I can't tell) is very soft and very comfortable to touch. The interior padding, while grey against the brown leather, is very thick and soft. I would feel comfortable dropping the case on the floor so I'd say the build and protection is good. I think the case sets itself apart from other cases and I like that. I like having an extrodinary piece of technology wrapped in a vintage leather looking case. The band that keeps it shut, while serving it's purpose, also adds to the overall look. The way the case builds in the kickstand is nice, but I don't read like that. If you like to read with your kindle on a flat surface then this feature is meant for you and works as advertised. Overall, I like the case a lot. It's has the look, the features, and protection I was hoping for. Afterall, you won't find anything else like it in the 25 dollar range. Go ahead and buy without fear.

PS I hope you weren't buying this for the reading light, because if you were too bad. I threw it away the moment I laid eyes on it. But I didn't care about getting the light, so it doesn't matter to me.

Pro: Adjustable fan speed and doesn't need to be plugged into a USB port to run. It comes with a power chord. Looks really good and the mat finish on it complements any laptop. Its made out of metal and the fans aren't super loud (but still audible at the highest setting. Nothing out of the ordinary.)

Con: I had the same issue with the little legs breaking just a few days after purchase that many other users reported having. The fans seem to have problems getting enough air especially without the extra extension legs. if I turn the fans up as high as they go they can't lift a piece of paper up in the air (not enough air pressure) but if i lift the cooler a few inches off the table, the piece of paper flies right off. Another thing is that the cooler doesn't create good positive air pressure where the fans are. The reason is that there's a pretty good distance between the fans and the top of the cooler and there's a big opening in the front of the cooler which makes all the air vented up by the cooler eject through the front.

Conclusion: If you're looking for something that looks cool and not much performance, this is the cooler for you. if you want to cool a gaming laptop or an old machine that overheats, look somewhere else. This is more of a piece of furniture and doesn't significantly cool anything. The fans are good but the design isn't at all.

I have been comparing my new kindle paperwhite to the touch this morning and found some things I wanted to share. I noticed that when you turn the light all the way down, it never really goes off. At first I didn't like that, but now I don't mind because it gives you a very slight glow that is helpful in a darker room but not so dark that you need more light. I also noticed that with the light down as far as it will go, the screens are two different colors of gray. This doesn't matter, I just noticed. Also, with the light at any brightness--low or high--the screen is not white but almost blue. Again, this doesn't matter but I hate calling it a paperwhite when it isn't white. Just my OCD coming through.

Some things I absolutely love: the light of course, that was the whole reason for getting it. It also has a really great feature where you can see how long it will take you to finish the book or the chapter you are in, based on your reading speed. I love that because two of my previous kindles had dots at the bottom that told you if a chapter was long or short and you could judge about how long it would take you to read it. The touch didn't have those and I missed them. With this feature on the new kindle, it \\"watches\\" you read, times how long it takes you to read something, and calculates how long it will take you to read each chapter and ultimately the whole book. You can set it to glance down at any time and see how long you have left in that chapter. I LOVE that! A lot of people talk about how much faster it is than the touch, but I really can't tell a difference. However, there is more room on the touch than this one, giving it more room to work. Books may download a little faster to the paperwhite, but not enough to make a huge difference. As far as page turns, I found them to be exactly the same. Same with opening a book from your home page. One thing I do like is that you have to mean to turn the page on the paperwhite. On my touch anything would turn the page--a leaf falling onto the screen for instance. I know it is due to each kindle using a different type of touch screen. You can feel the difference too--the touch is smooth while the paperwhite is slightly rough feeling. I like that there isn't as much room between the screen and the casing because my touch stays dusty in the corners unless I get a Q-tip and wipe it out. The paperwhite has less distance between the two so that when you wipe the screen you get the corners too.

Some things I don't like: The fonts are different. That shouldn't matter, but it does to me. For one thing, I had to increase the font size by one in order to make the letters the same size as they were on the touch with a smaller size setting. I know that isn't a big deal, but I just didn't like it. Also, I had to set the line spacing further apart. In my opinion the fonts seem to show up bolder and more crisp on the touch than the paperwhite. The light seems to take away some of the contrast, but only a little. Even with the light all the way down, the touch seems bolder and more crisp. Of course, though, the light could not be beat in a darker room. Some other things that bother me: 1) You cannot swipe up and down to go to next or previous chapter. 2) There is an extra step to turning off wi-fi. Rather than just hitting menu and choosing turn off wi-fi, you now have to hit menu, go to settings, then select turn on airplane mode. This turns off wi-fi. 3)I miss having text to speech even though I don't use it that much. 4)No one mentioned that the black spots along the bottom were normal because the lights are located there.

I know I have only worked with it a short time, but AT THIS POINT, if I had to choose which one to keep it would be the touch. I want to read on it for a while in different lighting conditions and see how this light affects my eyes before I decide if I am going to send it back.

This is the best laser pointer I have ever seen in person.  I live in Maine, where there's not that much light pollution, and at night this thing is crazy intense.  I mean, I don't usually go star gazing, but I use any chance I can get to shine this thing at night.  ITs like a lightsaber, you can see the beam going up and up as far as you can see.  You can easily see the beam hitting targets miles away, no problem.  The casing isn't the best, (the pocket grasper thing popped right off for instance) and sometimes there's some sort of battery contact problem and you have to tap the laser pointer or screw on the bottum part tighter, but for a 20 dollar green laser pointer that's fine with me.  Shine this off your teeth onto the ground and it makes awesome organic, alien like curves and parabola designs on the ground (same for your tongue), shine it through water or the faucet man its just so sweet to see this in action when its dark. I purchased this system to remote a Directv HD DVR, which only has an ethernet port so a Wi-Fi adapter is not the most straightforward choice.  I was hoping this would be a plug and play system, as advertised.  I plugged one unit into the wall and then into my DSL router.  The other unit went into the wall near the DVR.  It is very frustrating to determine what is going on with the system.  It does establish a link but it seems to be intermittent and is not good enough to download movies into the DVR.  It wouldn't be so bad if there were some diagnostic software that I could use to determine what is happening but the Asoka software doesn't seem to do anything.  And as mentioned in other reviews, the Asoka tech support line just connects to an answering machine with no call back.  The email support comes up as a non-deliverable mail address so there is no way to contact them for help.  I have searched in vain (probably not looking in the right place) for a piece of shareware software that would allow me to just go directly between two computers and measure link quality but there doesn't seem to be anything out there.    Bottom line, it may work for you but if it doesn't make sure that you have a way to return it for a refund.  It is probable that I simply don't have an outlet available that is free of interference, but the system appears to be very sensitive to that issue.

The construction of the plug at the L joint (where the plug goes into the laptop) seems much more sturdy than that in the replacement adapter as well as in the original adapter (which stopped working at around 14 months). The thickness is good since this seems to be the chronic failure point. The wires inside detach from the plug at the solder points, and the cords stop working. I don't know how long this one will last, but I'm hopeful to get at least 6 months out of it. If it stops, however, I'm probably ditching Acer and moving to a different computer brand. The adapter came with a 12 month warranty that I hope to try out if it stops working within that timespan.  I will update this review if the adapter stops working soon. As of today, it has been working for 10 days without fault. However, I have begun to notice a slight deformation in the yellow plastic at the tip of the plug, which makes me worry about its longevity over time. There seems to be some overheating, which could be due to my computer or due to the adapter. Whatever the reason, it sometimes makes the adapter difficult to remove from the computer. This will likely be the adapter's undoing soon.

\\"Very basic and not very sturdy\\" is something I note in context of the current price of this item -- there are several good points to this cover, but there appear to be better values out there.

I already have a cover for my HDX, which is an [[ASIN:B00DQZPAF6 OtterBox Defender Standing Case for Kindle Fire HDX 7\\", Green]]. The Otterbox is Fort Knox sturdy. It's bulky. It's near kid-proof. It's fairly costly. Oh, and it's dayglo green.

The Belkin Chambray in Blacktop, by comparison, is the epitome of sleekness and good taste. It's compact. It belongs on a stylish desktop or business environment. It would last about 4 months in my handbag, I estimate, before starting to show signs of wear. The plastic is thin and appears to be brittle. The fabric is a nice touch, but also likely to be a stain magnet - FYI to those who might break out something on the Kindle to read or watch with lunch. Obviously, how you are going to feel about this depends on how you are going to use or abuse your Kindle.

As for ergonomics and features: No magnetic closure/sleep function, something other users have touched on here. This cover was clearly built for propping the kindle up to view video or email, vs. holding in the hand, but the notched easel assembly won't stand up to much screen poking (as in the case of game play, for example), without collapsing on itself. I didn't have a problem with accessing the charge port with the cover secured, so perhaps they fixed that feature. I also wasn't able to come up with a program that wanted to display \\"upside down\\" as the cover and kindle within is oriented, but of course any program displaying in portrait mode will display \\"sideways\\" on the easel.

I'll still be looking into a second (well, now third) cover, hoping my story plays out like the proverbial 3 bears and I can find one that is \\"just right\\". I might try the [[ASIN:B00EX9JAGO Poetic Slimline Case for New Kindle Fire HDX 7 (2013) 7inch Tablet Black (With Smart Cover Auto Sleep / Wake Feature) (3 Year Manufacturer Warranty From Poetic)]] -- besides being more economically priced than many HDX covers, it touts a 3 year manufacturer's warranty. (I can find no warranty information here on the product page for the Belkin.)

This cover, I would provisionally recommend for some users, but not at the price offered at this writing.ch Tablet Black (With Smart Cover Auto Sleep / Wake Feature) (3 Year Manufacturer Warranty From Poetic)]] -- besides being more economically priced than many HDX covers, it touts a 3 year manufacturer's warranty. (I can find no warranty information here on the product page for the Belkin.)

This cover, I would provisionally recommend for some users, but not at the price offered at this writing.

We have been buying drive carriers and using drives purchased on Amazon in our HP servers for years. Now with the \\"new\\" HP gen8[9] propaganda and scare tactics, we were fearful that we would be stuck paying for the ridiculous HP drive markup - nope!

Here's what you get:
A quality drive carrier that fits in HP \\"genX\\" servers and has all the same LEDs/signalling as HP branded SmartDrives.
To pay for the actual value of the drive instead of a ridiculous brand name mark-up.
To receive the drive manufacturer's full warranty (5+ years for enterprise drives).

Here's what you don't get:
The little sticker that shows the drive size.
HP's stripped down (1-3 year) drive warranty.

Drive selection is important. Make sure your drives are SMART spec and enterprise class (I've only tried SAS). You may have heard stories about POST errors, error lights on the carrier, and fans spinning at max. (I think) These problems are caused by using cheap consumer-class non-SMART drives, or drives that only partially conform to the SMART spec - not the carrier. We have successfully used Intel SSDSC2BA400G301 (and other sizes of same), and Seagate Enterprise Capacity drives with no issues.

After many, many, weeks of researching, I chose this mouse, this fine Anker Precision Gaming Mouse. Although Anker is a relatively new company, with little to their name, people are often skeptical, even though their products are spectacular quality and well-priced. After purchasing a series of different mice, including both wired and wireless, gaming and non-gaming mice, I have finally found the best one, of them all.

Anker's Gaming Mouse has many amazing features. Besides the outstanding 2000DPI (up to 4000DPI by software), the mouse also offers a great variety of built-in LED light colors, a well-built structure and a well-designed ergonomic feel. Whether you're a gamer or not, this mouse is well made, creative, colorful and guaranteed to stand out and awe-inspire your friends.

I use Anker's Gaming Mouse to do many things. These things include: Surf the web (casually), play FPS (First Person Shooter) games on my PC, a variety of other non-FPS games, and accurately edit/create digital design on Photoshop. Only on this mouse, is my experience 100% flawless, with no jittering, solely what my hand does. With as high level of accuracy as this mouse has, the possibilities are beyond imagination. You can do everything you do with your current mouse, but most likely better!

Pros:
1. Low priced.
2. Sturdy plastic design.
3. 2000 DPI, and up to 4000 by software.
4. Easy to customize \\"profiles\\" for certain sensitivities and DPI speeds for select games.
5. Fresh LED lighting.
6. 7 Programmable Buttons.

Cons:
I haven't found any yet.

Regardless if you're in the market for the new mouse or not, I would definitely suggest purchasing this mouse (even as a spare if you're not in the market for a new mouse). Don't bother spending $50+ on a mice from another manufacturer, instead, pay a lower price, and get nothing but a higher quality experience.

Their customer supportis outstanding as well! I myself have not had to contact customer support (being everything has gone so well), but I have seen the responses by their customer support team, on other reviews on their products. I must say, I wish other tech-companies had as reliable customer service teams as Anker.

Outstanding buy! Anker is officially my favorite brand for any gaming peripherals.

10/14/15 - FOUND MY MOUSE!!! Sharkk SK2541 MMO Laser Gaming Mouse - does EXACTLY what I want and feels great! $40 too :)  6/30/15 PM - received reply from tech support. the software and mouse does not support click and hold at all. they did not offer any alternative. i now have a $65 paper weight - but its still staying on long term storage - the mouse hunt continues.  6/30/15 - revised down to 1 star ... i got my new RAT TE mouse replacement and even though the cursor does not float away, it squirrels with small movement = not accurate ... so i lament that my Corsair M65 RGB does not support press-hold in any form. this is a software design that i wish Corsair would implement. I just read another persons post on the Corsair forums that pretty much sums up what i also require... seems that a lot of us do, but apparently not enough for Corsair to rewrite software for. Alas. http://forum.corsair.com/v3/showthread.php?t=141442 ... in the future - if they do integrate this feature, i will use the mouse immediately. until then, it's in a long term storage box. i'll check the site and forums periodically to see if it becomes a feature.  6/12/15 - revised down to 2 stars from 4 ... the mouse still works - but the software or what it does not allow is what everyone needs to be aware of. the mouse and software does not support any-key press and hold. this completely kills using push to talk or any WASD assignments for strafing, etc. Again, the mouse is accurate and very responsive ... but this lack of press and hold - even with macros - is nearly a game breaker ... i am hoping for a software update in the near future from Corsair to implement this.  6/6/15 - just got today as a replacement for the failed 'Mad Catz R.A.T.TE Tournament Edition Gaming Mouse for PC and Mac' (see review on that page). The M65 RGB is accurate, precise, and instantaneous on my maxed out win7 pro 64 HP 17 Z-book. Once i dialed in the software, it was perfect. buy this mouse ... i will be quite upsetif anything fails within the first year. 4 stars as i have to wear a wrist brace (been doing computer design and stuff for over 20 years) ... so this is not an issue if you are not wearing a brace, but it is about 1/2" longer than i would have liked. without the brace, it fits my XXL hands perfectly - easy octave-and-a-forth each hand on the piano.

Best router I've ever owned... once I installed the third party Tomato firmware.    I've had this router for well over a year now.  I didn't use it much until recently though.  When I first got it, it would work fine for a couple days then have to be reset multiple times a day when the conenction just died.  I recently found out about the third party Tomato firmware from another reviewer (thanks by the way) and decided to give that a try as my regular router was on its last legs.  I had difficulty getting Tomato installed; the router didn't want to accept it as valid no matter what I tried.  I finally found a different third party firmware and different firmware installer program that came with it.  Using the other installer program Tomato finally installed correctly.  Since then the router works great!  It doesn't need to be reset and the overall speed seems higher than the previous Belkin I was using.  Both wired and wireless connections are strong and stable.    Great buy but only if you want to put some time into installing a different firmware first.

The UE Boom is exactly what a Bluetooth Speaker should be! I've owned a number of portable BT speakers before this. This is replacing a TDK A33 - what a massive difference!! The TDK was all bass, everything else was muffled. Accurate high & mid frequencies matter (to me) - a lot.
The UE Boom DELIVERS on all fronts - low, mid and high freq's. Light years ahead of the TDK speaker - they're not even in the same league. The UE has nice, accurate high and mids, and enough bass for me. We also have a Fugoo speaker which my wife uses a lot. The UE is similar in sound to the Fugoo, but the UE can play louder. Both are good, quality speakers. If I had to do it again, I'd probably get 2 UEs instead of a Fugoo and the 1 UE. That's how much the UE has impressed me, and I've only been using it for a few hours. I really like the shape of the UE - easy to grab, and the cylindrical shape makes it easy to put almost anywhere. It really does have "360" sound as well. If you want a high quality, excellent sounding BT speaker - the UE Boom is it.

What a great laptop! Shipping was pretty fast (expedited), took roughly 3 or 4 days.     Pros: Pretty good deal for the price, VERY powerful (to say the least) and has a battery life of 1-2 hours. Has 2 switchable graphics (Intel and Radeon), even though the Radeon is a 6770m and can handle almost anything out there, the Intel is still useful because it still is able to handle games like Bad Company 2 at low-medium settings and medium resolution.     Cons: The graphics aren't switchable initially, one has to first download and install an updated BIOS, THEN go into the bios and configure switchable graphics. Then finally you're able to right click on your desktop and actually switch the graphics. If you do not do this, the laptop will always use the Intel card, even though it will claim that it is auto-switchable.     Overall this is a great machine, but it does come with a lot of crap-ware and needs the BIOS updated to use the Radeon 6770m graphics card for gaming. Price is alright, and is a reasonable deal for what you get. Can handle almost anything you throw at this beast.

Very pretty!!  I prefer to use my Kindle out of a case and this keeps my Kindle protected from scratches.  Was very easy to install.  Tiny bits of dust aren't really an issue with this type of skin.

BACKGROUND

I have had this item for approximately 18 months so I can provide feedback with operating experience.

I have a Linux workstation with two dual-core 3.0 GHz AMD Opterons. The system is cooled via a Swiftech extreme water-cooling kit with two CPU waterblocks and one GPU waterblock. I wanted the option of checking that my water loop was functional when the case was sealed with its side panels. I planned to use the CL-W0033 for that purpose

EXPECTATIONS

[1] Successful mating with my 1/2 ID water loop
[2] High-temperature alarm to alert me when there is a temperature anomaly
[3] High quality material for product longevity
[4] Sufficient wire length for monitor installation in drive bay

RESULTS

[1] I use PrimoChill PrimoFlex tubing, which is a thicker tubing. Although the CL-W0033 comes with an attachment for 1/2 ID tubing, the PrimoFlex was too thick for that adapter to work. I improvised by using a zip tie to secure the tubing to the 1/2\\" nipple. The 1/2\\" nipple is not exceedingly long, but the zip tie has worked. In 18 months of continuous use, I have not experienced a leak.

[2] Once I was working on my system and I forgot to reconnect the power cable to the circulation pump. I powered on the system and the CL-W0033 sounded its alarm. I immediately powered off the system and performed an inspection. The CL-W0033 had saved my very expensive CPUs.

[3] The sensor body appears to be high quality, but also lightweight. It is easy to mount with zip ties and is quite sturdy. I disassembled the unit when I flushed the system (FluidX created particulates) and noted the fine machining and tight tolerances. The sensor body is of excellent quality. The display box is plastic, but it meets my expectations. There are only two mounting screws on the half width mounting bracket, which is okay, but I would have prefer a full width bracket so that I could use four mounting screws. The display is bright and the sampling frequency adequate.

[4] My chassis is a Lian Li V2100, which is a voluminous chassis. The included wiring between the sensor body and display box is adequate for my chassis, which means that it will be adequate for any chassis.

Afterthoughts: There are two modifications that I would make to this item: (1) sleeve the power cable to the display box. Currently the power cable consist of a red and black relatively large gauge wire with sufficient length to accommodate a large chassis. Given the length and thickness of the power wires, they are disruptive to an orderly wired/tubed chassis. I removed the power connector, trim the wire lengths for my chassis, and sleeved them. (2) a small mount for the sensor body. I made a mount, but it would have been nice to have one included.

SUMMARY

I am 100% satisfied with this product. It has met all of my expectations and saved my CPUs from overheating as a consequence of the circulation pump not being powered. The components are all high quality and are expected to have a long life cycle. I would highly recommend this comment to a colleague.cy adequate. [4] My chassis is a Lian Li V2100, which is a voluminous chassis. If you are looking for this tablet, it means that you are looking for something in the $200 price range.  As some of you already know it, the Kindle Fire costs only $199 with IPS capacitive screen, duo core and 8GB.  So if you can get this tablet under $200, you get a pretty good deal if you want something decent with a front camera for video call.  Otherwise, the other good bet is MID 7022 which has a capacitive screen.  -----------------  Ok, there are a lot of things to be said about this tablet.  Some other reviewers have rated this tablet as bad as it could be (e.g. freezes, and etc...).  True and not true.  I have a Toshiba Thrive 16GB.  Comparing a 16GB 10\\" screen Tegra 2 with 1GB of RAM to this little toy seems unfair, but this tablet is not bad.  You just must know how to fully utilize the Viewpad 7e.  The PROs:  - white case  - small form factor (i.e. 7 inch screen)  - front and rear camera  - Android 2.3  - microSD slot  - 4 buttons below screen  - sound  The CONs:  - limited 4GB storage  - 512 MB RAM  - single core  - screen resolution  ------------------  I was able to install Google Market.  It's really not that hard when you make some research on how to install it.  BUT I've found it useless because it's not the up-to-date one.    The 1Market and the Appstore pre-installed in the Viewpad 7e are good enough.  You just have to make yourself as a SuperUser.  Also, the device is already configure for the user to be able to move installed applications to the SD.  Or if you want you can install App2SD for free.  ------------------  Knowing that you have only 4GB, a single core, and 512 MB RAM to play with, you must know how to work with what you got.  The key is to clear any unnecessary program when not in use, not to use the 3D Launch (a.k.a. SPB Shell), and definitely NO Live Wallpaper.  It may sound easier said than done, right???  Well, there's a free app for that's called Gemini Taskiller Widget program.  After installation and setup, all you need to do is to shake the device so that it would clear your RAM every time after you close a program to open another one.  My 8 year old girl can do it.  Why can't you?  ----------------  With QQ Player installed, I can even play RMVB!  MKV can also be played for animation episodes.  This is all a cool and cheap tablet that can do it all with restrictions of course.  Overall, for something under $200, it is a nice tablet. I got mine for $170 during Black Friday.    The other thing I want to mention is the screen.  It's more resistive than capacitive.  It also means that it is not as hard as gorilla glass of course.    I was a little put off by it, but I eventually get use to it.  It is not that bad.  It's like in a Nintendo DS, if not better.  It is acceptable.  Although the resolution is not that high, it is really acceptable when watching NON-HD episodes.  Let's face it!  Who got enough bandwidth and time to download HD episodes regurlarly???  I was one of them, but then if you car recommended fuel is 87, why pay/waste for better grade?  On my Toshiba Thrive, when I play RMVB episodes, the pictures are very blurry because of the lower resolution format.  On this baby, it looks more acceptable on a smaller screen @ a lower resolution.  --------------------  The other downside is the Wifi.  I have really good reception.  I have good signal even when I am in another room with closed door.  The problem is that it seems to go to sleep even when I have set up Wifi to never go to sleep.  I have also set my device with static IP, and the trouble still persists whenever the device is left unused for a while.  No problem.  The solution is to reset the Wifi, and to find an easy way to do it. Just put a Wifi toggle switch as a widget in different pages, and flick it off and on whenever programs stop seeing any network connection. This usually happens after the tablet has been left unused for a while (e.g. charging).  Of course, in my more expensive Tablet (i.e. the Thrive), I do nothave this problem.  Hopefully, there will be an update soon to fix this problem.  But then again, I know my way around it.  -----------------  The sound on this tablet is pretty impressive.  I did not expect it to be that good.  The Toshiba Thrive has stereo speaker.  This Viewpad 7e only has one, but it sounds better than my Toshiba Thrive!!!  How so? Acoustic design. The Toshiba Thrive stereo speakers just throw sounds straight from the bottom. The Viewpad 7e resonates through the tablet nicely with only one speaker to make it more lively (kind of like a tube TV in hand)! Simply amazing! And with a white case, it's just class (with restrictive power).    - But as a Toshiba Thrive owner, I really have some hard time swallowing this. Yes, a bit mad indeed about what the Viewpad 7e can throw in the sound department. -  -----------------  Also, after installing programs (then move them to SD if possible), don't forget to reboot, then test the program.  The battery is adequate.  You just have to tune down the screen brightness, and lower the volume whenever you can.  My daughter just crams the volume to the MAX, and she still gets some good kicks for about 3 hours.  Good enough for me! I don't want her to be in front of the screen too long.  -----------------  Like I said, once you know how to operate this baby, for the price it is a steal if you can find it close to the price range of a MID 7200.  At least with the Viewpad 7e, you can still use Skype or other programs to do video call.  The Kindle Fire can't.  Also, the Viewpad has expandable microSD storage that you can total up to 36GB (4+32).  But it is no duo core, nor does it have IPS screen.  It is what it is.  It just depends what you want for something close to $200.  Otherwise, save your money, and buy an Iconia A100 for more $$$!

This laptop comes with a 1 yr warranty.  My son's laptop warranty was expiring in 10 days when I contacted Acer regarding the non working charger.  They gave me a case number and promised me I would receive a replacement within 3-5 days. Nine days later I called again because I had not received the charger and found out that my claim had been closed and Acer did not notify me of this.  On that date they apologized for the mistake, gave me a new case number and promised me that I would receive a replacement in 3-5 days. I asked to have expedite shipping and they said it was not an option. I asked for a confirmation e-mail and was told I would get one but never did. I didn't receive the charger either. I tried to contact Acer again but at this time my warranty had expired and I was unable to get through because their automated system recognized my phone number and said \\"Your item is not under warranty therefore we are not able to assist you, good bye\\" and the call will drop.  I tried to chat with Acer online but when I entered the laptop SNID number I got a message stating that my laptop was out of warranty and they couldn't help me.  It was really frustrating to know that Acer did not comply with the warranty and waited until my warranty expired.  Acer is not responsive and makes promises they don't deliver.  I feel this is disrespectful on their part.  I would not buy any more products from Acer.

I had a 24" LCD Dell monitor for a while that treated me well. From everything I've read and experienced, I'm a believer in Dell monitors. This new LED monitor is no exception.

The image is bright and vividly clear. It's such high quality, in fact, that it makes the age of my older monitor (now owned for 6 years) very apparent. The old monitor has that sepia effect creeping in, and the new monitor has made that so clear that it's really starting to get under my skin.. Dell's evil plot to get me to order another one? Maybe..

Needless to say, this is an excellent product. Dell monitors are long-lasting and reliable, and this one provides the sharpest image I've ever had with a computer. I think that LED technology makes a big difference with text, so websites really pop on this monitor.

Considering my old 24" LCD Dell Monitor cost me $650 at the time, I'm quite happy with my investment in the new Dell UltraSharp LED. I'm also really happy to finally be on the dual monitor train. As a guy working behind a computer screen for eleven years, it's astonishing that I haven't yet. Already it's making a significant difference in my productivity.

At this price, this level of image quality and Dell's reputation of building stellar displays, I don't see how you could go wrong. Order it now!

I use my new Bluetooth headphone every day now. For a great price and great usability, I would give this little device ten stars if I could!!!
