I recently built a new computer, and wanted an internal card reader. Most of the newer, more expensive units use a USB3 header off the mobo, which seems silly considering that most boards only have 1 USB3 header (if they have one at all), and that's taken by the front USB ports on most towers.  Furthermore, most can only read one card at a time.  This unit uses USB2, which is plenty fast for most people's uses (simple file transfers) and there's usually several extra headers on the board. It reads SDHC (SD cards over 32 gigs), can use read from multiple cards at once, and is generally great.  Cons: The blue LED light on the front is absurdly bright. That isn't an issue for me because my case has a door covering the drive bays, but it's something to keep in mind.  The other thing to be aware of is that it reserves a drive letter for each card type. This allows the user of multiple cards and is a great feature, but you may have to go into disk management and reassign drive letters. My external drive wasn't plugged in when I installed it and it somehow overwrote my previously reserved drive letter (E:).  It messed up some file paths until I reassigned everything. It's a 3 minute fix, but is annoying if you aren't expecting it.  Also, don't make the same silly mistake I did and forget to order a 5.25-3.25 inch bay adaptor of you're sticking this in below your DVD drive. I had to wait 3 more days to install.  All in all, this is an amazing value. It's cheaper and better for my needs than other products.

Let me start off by saying, I really wanted a tablet I could play Civilization V on. This Tablet wont play my FAVORITE PC games, but it does everything else I wanted it too. The battery life is great!! this Tablet will last me 8 hours ATLEAST, and that's with continual use. I use it mostly for my job as a network administrator, I like to access my network drives wherever I am, and be able to log into my server when away from my desk. I never liked carrying around a laptop, even a netbook was kind of awkward, I would rather be able to stand, then have to sit down to use my portable device.

The only issues I have had, is with the digitizer pen. It's not perfect, and re-calibrating it doesn't seem to improve anything, but at least there is a crosshair that shows on the screen when you get the pen close enough, so even if it is off a little, you know where your going to press by looking at the crosshairs. Lenovo's pre-installed software/apps are nothing special either.

Other issues I have had:
Firefox likes to crash occasionally
The display will sometimes go dim, then brighten back up for no reason.
Digitizer isn't perfectly accurate
My 1Tb external USB 2.0 hard drive wont connect. (I have read similar reviews stating the same thing. I read another review where someone was able to get there 500Gb external to work, maybe its just on 1Tb and up.
Atom processor isn't the fastest, but from what I have read, its better than the ARM. You can actually run x86 (32 bit) programs on this device.

Things I love about this Tablet.
Its weight, I have no issues holding it all day, and I'm not what you would call a physically fit man.
The battery life is amazing.
Its form factor is really sleek
Digitizer pen (although not perfect) really comes in handy when trying to navigate thru windows explorer/desktop.

Oh and more thing, I can actually run Civilization IV with no issues :)

The rooCase is a tight but easy to remove hard leather-like sleeve sitting inside a hard leather-like case. The velcro on the back of the sleeve allows it to attach itself securely to the case when using it as a viewing stand.

THE GOOD THINGS
- Hard, protective leather looks pretty cool too.
- Detachable sleeve that can be used independently from the portfolio case.
- Everything that needs to be accessible (charging port, USB) can be accessed.
- Soft microfiber lining will not scratch the Nexus.
- 100% of the screen is exposed and can be touched.
- The case can be used as a viewing stand.
- The sleeve attaches itself to the case with Velcro.
- There is a stylus holder.
- Supports the Nexus 7's smart cover capability, turns it off when closed, on when open.

THE NOT SO GOOD
- When the case unfolds as a viewing stand the half that's supposed to lie flat on the desk doesn't but that may improve in time.
- The Velcro that holds the tablet in place when in viewing stand mode is likely to degrade the inside cover.
- When wrapped around the Nexus it makes it significantly thicker and heavier.

In real life I'm using the case more to store the Nexus than as a viewing stand because the Nexus can really stand just about anywhere but I can see myself using the case as a stand when traveling for as long as I'm watching a movie.

Overall, I am happy with the rooCASE. It's not perfect but it's the best there is at this price point. Probably can get 'better' if willing to pay more.

This is one of the greatest budget "Keyboard and Mouse" combos I have ever seen on Amazon! The backlight on both the mouse and keyboard is really neat. The combo itself feels more expensive than it actually is. Lets start with the keyboard.

Cons:

The only to options for the back light are ON and OFF

Scroll lock triggers the backlight, so having scroll lock on could interfere with some programs such as Microsoft Excel

Media keys feel a bit cheap, but its not too bad

Rating: 9/10

Now for the mouse.

Left and right click feel very nice, not cheap

Rubber side grips are very nice

Mouse has that same rubber-plastic feeling

DPI switch comes in handy during the middle of games.

Optical sensor very accurate for this price point

Cons:

Two side buttons feel very cheap

SQUEAKY MOUSE WHEEL. Very annoying.

The back light cannot be turned off, but is not all that bright.

Mouse light will stay ON when computer is in "sleep mode".

Rating: 7.5/10

Overall: This combo set goes really well together. I would definitely recommend this to a friend, just remember to get some lubricant for the mouse wheel.

So, much like many of you, I agonized for many days and nights about which tablet to purchase: iPad 2, Nook Tablet, or Kindle. I read multiple reviews on each, WATCHED video reviews on each, and talked to 2 or 3 IT professionals to get their impressions/thoughts. I went to countless stores to play with each device (repeatedly), and I came away with the following verdict: there is no 'winner' and each device CLEARLY has distinct advantages.

iPad: I love Apple products. They're elegant, simple, reliable, and (in their own way) works of art. I already have a desktop and a laptop, so I wanted something VERY portable (i.e. could fit into my handbag)... granted, if I had a BIG handbag, an iPad would fit, but truly the size makes it a bit cumbersome. PLUS at $499, it was way more expensive than the other two options. (Two strikes against the iPad.)

Nook Tablet: I love my local Barnes & Noble. It's one of the last great 'brick and mortar' bookstores. There are few things I enjoy more on a rainy Sunday than wandering the stacks at B&N. Plus the advantages to the Nook: there is more 'onboard' storage space than the Kindle. You can go into any B&N and read any of their titles for 1 hour per day (free). Last, there's always a human at the B&N who can answer your questions and help you.

Kindle Fire: (the eventual winner). First, amazing price tag: $199. Really? Is that a typo? No, seriously, it's $199. It's portable, sturdy, I can hold it in one hand, put it in my handbag, AND it does everything I want it to do. Does it make phone calls? Nope, but hey I have a smartphone. Does it take pictures or videos? Nope, but hey I have a little point-and-shoot digital that works just fine thank you. What I CAN do with my Kindle Fire is surf the internet, check Facebook, send emails, watch instant videos (you get 1 month of Amazon Prime free with purchase, and TRUST ME, you will love this...) and READ to my heart's content (and boy do I love to read...) You can read magazines, newspapers and books. Oh yes, you can listen to MUSIC too. And of course, there is the app functioning and gaming stuff you can do if you're so inclined..

A couple items of note: 1) the 'reading' screen: I've heard mixed reviews on this; however, I love the screen. You can change the font, point size, brightness of the screen, etc. You can also read 'portrait-style' or 'landscape-style'. You can highlight, make notes, and use bookmarks. It's great.
2) the on/off button. Apparently there are folks out there who have accidentally hit the off button. OOPS. There's an easy fix, Einstein. Just flip the Kindle 1/4 turn to the right or 1/4 turn to the left and - VOILA - problem solved. The on/off button is no longer a potential problem. (Really, this is such a non-issue I'm surprised people are bringing it up.)
3) LAST (and this was the BIG clincher for me)... there are soooo many free and really cheap books at Amazon. When I compared e-book prices between B&N and Amazon, there was a BIG difference. Now, for people who don't read much, this might not be an issue, but if you read a lot, and B&N prices are $2 - $4 more PER book... that will add up.

Bottom line: each device is different and has pros and cons... make sure you really investigate, take the time to play with each one, and purchase the best one for you and YOUR needs.

Regardless, the technology we have access to now is truly amazing! Enjoy!can read magazines, newspapers and books. Oh yes, you can listen to MUSIC too. And of course, there is the app functioning and gaming stuff you can do if you're so inclined.. I purchased two of these (8GB) in January to be a boot drive for a NAS (one is a spare). They were intended to be used in a 24x7 environment.

Pros:
- Cheap.
- Relatively speedy for the price.

Cons:
- Longevity. The first drive failed in April and the second was dead by September. Both drives have bad sectors or a failing controller that don't seem to be able to be repaired, even with Patriot's low-level format tool.
- The slider design is flimsy. Despite careful handling, one of them is bent and sticks when retracting.
- Blocks nearby USB ports. This is a challenge when they're set close together (i.e. with the ports on a motherboard).

While it's possible that I'm having bum luck from heavy usage, the consensus of other reviews I've seen seems to be that longevity is an issue with these things. Patriot may be pretty good at pounding out RAM, but I'm hesitant to give their flash memory another chance.

Logitech's Z-3 speakers are a quality set of basic stereo-plus-subwoofer speakers for use with a computer, game unit, or small near-field (close-up) audio setup. They are quite pretty, with faux-wood cabinets and brushed metal accents, and despite their small size are quite heavy. While the set is not exceptionally loud for its rated power, the subwoofer provides substantial bass (perhaps too much at higher settings), and the stereo mid- and high-range satellite speakers offer smooth sound, an attractive and functional design, and solid metal bases for stability. The wired remote, with its simple power button, large analog volume knob, and funky blue LED power light, is an especially nice design.
I purchased the Z-3 speakers for use with a digital stage piano in our living room. Logitech includes a wired-in male mini-stereo plug (the kind that connects to a computer, portable CD player, or other mini-headphone jack), as well as an adapter that converts the mini plug to two female RCA jacks, which plug into standard left and right RCA cables used by stereo systems. I needed additional adapters (which I had, fortunately) to convert those RCA connectors to 1/4" mono phono plugs on the musical keyboard, but that was to be expected, since the Z-3s aren't aimed at musicians anyway.
Wiring up the system was straightforward: the power plug is part of the subwoofer, so you don't have to worry about multiple power cables snaking around-which also means there's no way to run the satellite speakers alone, without the subwoofer. Oddly, you must separate the main cables (which connect the subwoofer to the satellites and remote in a bundle) by peeling the wires away from each other, like licorice strips, to get them to the length you need, which is something the otherwise-good (and very short) manual fails to mention. As shipped, the free cables are too short to reach either side of a computer monitor, never mind a piano. Some might be wary of doing any wire-separating without anything in writing to make clear that it's safe (which it is, since you're just peeling off some rubber). The satellites are very nicely designed, with two stable cast-metal feet and removable soft speaker grilles that protect from poking fingers but don't seem to colour the sound significantly.
The volume remote is worth a mention on its own. Some PC speakers provide all sorts of doodads on the remote (or just put the controls on one of the speakers), and they often use little clicky buttons to control the volume. The Z-3 gives you just the basics, and is better for it. There is a power switch (which doubles as mute-just turn the power off!) and a very large, smooth-feeling old-style volume knob. There is a standard mini-headphone jack, slightly recessed, which could be awkward if your phones have a bulky plug, but none of mine do. The LED power button is a trendy blue, and perhaps a tad bright if you use it in a dark room. The remote itself is plastic, but feels solid and well built, like the rest of the set.
Although the Z-3s are rated at 40 watts total power (17 for the two satellites, 23 for the subwoofer), they don't seem to have much more overall real-world volume than my old Yamaha YST-M7 computer speakers, which lack a subwoofer and are only supposed to put out 10 watts total. That shows how meaningless wattage ratings really are for these kinds of speakers. But it's good for me, since my young daughters tend to turn everything to 10 if given a chance, and when 10 isn't that loud, it can be a relief. If you crank up the Z-3 subwoofer (it has a separate bass knob on the back), you can get room-shaking bass, of course, but at the expense of being able to hear much high-end articulation from the satellites. Apparently, if you have a hotter source signal than the piano I used, turning the Z-3s up yields too much high end in the sound, but I didn't find that in our setup.
With the stage piano, I found a subwoofer setting just a few notches above minimum to work best. The high keys give a realistic tinkle, while the lowest ones vibrate the keyboard authentically, and the midrange is rich and lush. Overall, the Z-3s beat my old Yamahas for overall richness and evenness of sound. Audiophiles might disagree, but they'd be spending hundreds or thousands of dollars for speakers, while the Z-3s barely break three figures in Canadian dollars. It would be nice to have some equalization control for the midrange and high end, but few computer speaker systems offer that, and it's always possible to add an external EQ unit between the sound source and the speakers if you insist.
There are less expensive "2.1" PC speaker systems, as well as more powerful and better-sounding ones, but if you want a set of speakers that look good in addition to sounding just fine for most near-field, low-volume applications, the Logitech Z-3 might be your ticket. For my application, they're great.

I chose this model, based on other positive Amazon reviews. I wanted a H.D. with a little more capacity and speed than the original Western Digital 320 GB one from Dec 2009 that had developed 42 MB of bad sectors on it. This computer was bought in late 2010, and I was disappointed that the H.D. was already failing after only 3.5 yrs. This was the first W.D. drive that has ever failed me. I still have ones from 2005 & 2006 that are still going strong!

Replacing the H.D. turned out to be the easiest part---taking off the rear support stand bracket was the hardest. It required a very thin #1 Phillips screwdriver to be able to access the bracket screws. The removal of the computer's plastic back cover was straight forward.

I partitioned the 750 GB WD drive into two partitions using "PartedMagic", which turned out to be fairly easy!
I also installed a jumper on pins 5&6 to turn it into a SATA II drive, to match it to the original 320GB H.D. computer's configuration.

Luckily I had made "Recovery Disks" when the MSI computer was originally purchased in Oct. 2010, so re-installation of Windows 7 Home, 32-bit, turned out to be quite easy, taking about 50 min. I also didn't have to re-register with Microsoft, since the operating system was already pre-registered by the manufacturer. Installing on a larger H.D. didn't turn out to be a problem. Nice! The hardest, and most time consuming part, was re-installing all the latest Microsoft updates. What a hassle!!!

I have not done any speed tests with this new drive, but it seems to be working properly. I ran a quick W.D. diagnostic on the new drive, and everything was fine. No bad sectors!

I would recommend this H.D. for any desktop or laptop that takes a 3.5 inch format drive! I didn't need a larger 1 or 2 terabyte drive, so this 750 GB one turned out to be a nice compromise. 7200 RPM, SATA III, and a 64 MB cache are all pluses!

The only drawback on this case is that it does not have a magnetic close, so you have to make sure to shut off or hibernate your iPad before you close the case or it is sitting there wasting battery. That was enough for me to take off a star since this was one of the convenient factors in a smart cover.

Aside from that, this case is really the best that I've come across:
-The iPad feels secure in the case, and I'm not worried about it slipping out or getting damaged.
-The keyboard is removable, so I can take full advantage of different screen angles with the case.
-The Bluetooth on the keyboard connects quickly with the push of a button. Especially helpful after the upgrade to iOS7, where you can control Bluetooth on/off on the iPad from the shortcut menu to save battery.
-The battery life on the keyboard is excellent- I have charged it once in the past 6 months or so.
-Typing on the keyboard is easy- it has the feel of a laptop keyboard. The only typo tendency I have is occasionally intending to hit the right shift key, but actually hitting the return key.
-There is a loop for a stylus if you use one.
-The red color is great- I wanted something with some style or personality that I could also use at work and feel professional.

What you get is exactly what you see: a sturdy beanbag with a rubberized plastic cradle. For the most part, this product functions precisely as advertised: on all flat and most flat-ish surfaces, it props up an iPad. On most sloping and all crazy sloping surfaces, it does not prop up an iPad. But then, who would expect it to? And who would take the chance it might fail to? Some users appear to have had difficulties balancing their iPads on the ViewLounge. If you're familiar with the law of gravity, and stick to flatter surfaces, you should have no problem keeping your own iPad steadily balanced atop its ViewLounge perch. On balance, ViewLounge strikes me as a useful enough device. But it's not something I'd ever go out and buy. Less one star because it is, after all, a $21 beanbag with a plastic clip.

UPDATE: I had previously given this item 4 stars for the reasons noted above. After using this item some more, I am upgrading my rating to 5 stars. Yes, this is a simple concept. But it's very well executed, and it serves it's purpose to a tee. Being able to prop up my iPad on the arm of my couch or lounge chair is a real boon, and something I'm not able to do with standard iPad stands. So, for that reason alone, I think this is a terrific niche item. And it's quite sturdily constructed as well. Contrary to my previous assessment, $21 strikes me as entirely reasonable. And knowing what I now know, this is definitely an item I'd go out and buy.

Finally, my 2006 macbook has all the multi-touch gestures OS X Lion makes available. The battery life is excellent, and it even works (without the multi-touch gestures of course) with my Dell laptop at work.

My only gripe, and it's a small one, is that the physical click space at the bottom doesn't work if you're mousing on a soft surface. It's a minor gripe, and has more to do with my expectations than it does with the design of the trackpad.

I purchased this Logitech G500 mouse after my Logitech G400's left-click wore out. Suffice to say, I was disappointed, but there is some good about this mouse. For example, the shape is very similar to the G400's, but slightly improved. The buttons are longer and the grips on the sides are better. When I gripped the G400, my fingers would hang over the edges and my hand would begin to hurt after a while - not so with the G500. The new improvements made the mouse a lot more comfortable. Even though it comes off as a bit gimmicky, I did like the dual-mode scroll wheel for moving through long Skype conversations quickly. I also liked the braided cord, which feels a lot more durable than the G400's cable. One of the best things for me was Logitech's decision to move the DPI up/down buttons onto the side of the left mouse button instead of on either side of the scroll wheel, where I would accidentally hit them on occasion when scrolling through documents or changing weapons in games.

Which leads me to the cons of the mouse...

First of all, the sensor is inherently flawed. The Avago ADNS-9500 will act up in a bad way depending on what kind of mousepad you have. With a soft mat, you'll see 5% negative acceleration. On a hard pad like the Steelseries 4HD or Razer Scarab, you'll see small amounts of positive acceleration. It's especially noticeable at lower sensitivities. Prediction has never been much of an issue for me, but acceleration is intolerable. That was my biggest reason for returning the mouse. I also found the weight cartridge to be incredibly useless because of it's placement inside the mouse. The slot for the cartridge is at the back at the mouse, so when you place the cartridge inside, the weight becomes unevenly distributed, which bothered me a lot. I'm also not a big fan of the sensor's placement on the mouse. To make room for the weight cartridge, the sensor has been off-centered, which can result in subtle changes in how the sensor tracks. I found upwards motions to be quicker than downwards motions, which was extremely frustrating in-game.

All in all, if you can deal with the sensor flaws, enjoy the weight cartridge, and love the shape, this mouse is probably for you. But those who want a mouse with a cleaner sensor (such as the ADNS-3090) and don't need features like the weight cartridge, I'd say look elsewhere. The Razer Deathadder, Abyssus, Logitech G100s, and Logitech G400 are all excellent alternatives with prediction and acceleration-free sensors, along with solid customization options.acks. I found upwards motions to be quicker than downwards motions, which was extremely frustrating in-game.

All in all, if you can deal with the sensor flaws, enjoy the weight cartridge, and love the shape, this mouse is probably for you. But those who want a mouse with a cleaner sensor (such as the ADNS-3090) and don't need features like the weight cartridge, I'd say look elsewhere. This is a high functioning product: It is fast, cheap, able to access pretty much anything that smartphones can access, and cute. The marketing pitch: The "kid" (or regular) mode displays items in a very straightforward and clickable manner making it very easy to select programs or functions - quite similar to an iPhone or iPad. There are many pre-loaded apps and games so it's easy to become familiar with the Nabi's capabilities. The "mommy" (or advanced) mode turns the Nabi into a sophisticated computer. In this mode you can pretty much do anything a regular tablet can do. Mommy mode determines the apps and functionality allowed in kid mode. Mommy mode also let's mom or dad use nabi as their personal tablet. My personal disappointment with Nabi is how advanced kid mode actually is. I assumed it would be very basic and easy-to-use for kids, but it's really not. Even just the clicking between screens is difficult and not very logical. For example, I would assume that a back button would be big and easy to use, especially for little kids' awkward inaccurate fingers, but this is not the case. The area to click the back button is in a tiny clickable area on the lower left hand side which is hard to see, illogically placed, and difficult for even an adult to accurately click. The camera function isn't very easy to use, the apps require much "clicking-through", and everything just seems very tiny and hard to click. For something that is supposed to be kid-friendly, I am surprised at how kid un-friendly it is. I would even call this mommy-unfriendly as it definitely takes some practice to figure out the mommy-mode or even how to use the kid-mode. So far, this has been a lot of mommy having to click through the kid mode, find the video that the kid wants, turn it on, and hand it to the kid. Also, it is very annoying that the battery doesn't seem to last that long, and even more annoying that the Nabi doesn't come with a simple stand. I would say mostpeople probably buy this as a graduation from their kid constantly using their parents' iPad, to finally having a version of their own. But I think it can become more of a burden than a solution. I wonder if there might be something else that works better.

If you get these during a Black Friday or similar sales event, you can pick these ASUS Chromebooks up for around 150-ish. For that price this computer is amazing.

There are only 2 things I really wish were different, both of which aren't likely to happen unless there is a significant price increase: backlit keyboard and double the memory.

If you like to use a computer in bed, or watching TV, chances are it'll be pretty dark. Unfortunately the letters on the keyboard are small and not bright on this Asus Chromebook, so the brightness from the screen may not be enough to see the keyboard clearly.

The other issue is memory.
This Chromebook comes with 2 Gigs of memory and you can't upgrade. This is fine for basic browsing but depending on how many extensions you have installed, 2 Gigs may sometimes not quite be enough to get a really smooth experience out of it. I found that installing Adblock extension helped bring down some of the excessive memory use at times but it's not a universal fix by any means and my observation may well be incidental. One example is Facebook. FB has tons of trackers and ads pulling away resources at all times. Loading FB pages (not through apps or extensions, just regular webpage) can take a long time on a low memory machine. I find that Adblock cuts this down by at least half. Engadget is another one on occasion. The Gmail app canbe pretty memory heavy if you have a lot of emails in your inbox. The same is true for many other sites that go nuts with their ads and trackers. I find that this has gotten worse. This Chromebook, and most other Chromebooks, were conceived at a time when 2 Gigs was fine for basic online use. Over the past 2 years, however, many sites have dramatically increased their tracking and ad serving mechanisms, all of which tend to hog more memory. If you think this is BS, time load times on a regular Windows machine with and without ad blocking enabled. See what I mean?

The more extensions you have active, the more resources you'll need. It's true that most extensions use a very small amount of memory running in the background, but they do add up. If you have lots of extensions, and frequent ad-heavy sites, 2 Gigs apparently isn't enough sometimes. I've experienced several low memory crashes ("He's Dead, Jim"- screen on Chrome). Disabling extensions to the bare minimum helped. If you're comfortable with the terminal you could mess with zram (swap enable) but if that's not your bag, and you need those 50 extensions running at all times, expect the occasional hiccup.

Why do I keep harping on this? Because Chromebook is incredible with extensions. There are a LOT of things you can do with the right app or extension. But again, the more you have, the more memory you need. And since you can't upgrade you want to really think about this limitation.

The battery lasts a surprisingly long time even with moderate use, anywhere from 8 to 10+ hours in my experience. The sleep function helps. It charges up quickly, too, the supplied AC adapter does a great job.

The screen quality is acceptable, nothing more. Don't expect to judge color accuracy on photos with this. Videos looks a little washed out and HD videos on Youtube sometimes look pretty bad. But again, for casual use this is totally fine.

The trackpad, while quite large, isn't great. It's not very accurate but should do fine for basic use. You can always pair a mouse with this if you need to have accurate and more comfortable control over the cursor.

The C300 is very light. The specs claim a bit over 3 pounds but somehow it feels lighter. The somewhat cheap feel of the plastic probably helps with the illusion, but I like it.

You already know that you can only install extensions and apps made for Chromebook. And while the selection of extensions and apps is very extensive, some notable options are missing. If you don't want to or can't use Gmail as your sole email client for your non-Gmail accounts, you'll be looking for a decent third party email client extension or app. Let me know when you find one because as of May 2015, there aren't any good ones. The ones that are there are severely limited, often don't work with MS Exchange, or have some other limitations and bugs. It's a bit weird, actually - you'd think something as basic as email would be taken care of by now. For most users, the Gmail app is fine. You can use third party emails through Gmail but it's a hassle, doesn't always work smoothly (emails sometimes come in late), and Exchange doesn't work at all.

FTP is also an issue. There are very few FTP extensions/apps available as of right now, and the one least worst one you need to pay for. It's like 2 bucks or something like that but the point is that your options are limited. And none of the FTP apps right now are really good. They're buggy, seem to disconnect randomly, sometimes don't connect at all, delete stored FTP credentials randomly, have a very limited feature set, and so forth.

This is not a heavy productivity machine, none of the Chromebooks are at this time. For example, there's no Photoshop available for the Chrome platform, and no real alternative is available. There are some basic photo editing extensions, and they tend to be ok for cropping and minor adjustments such as brightness and contrast. But anything fancier than that isn't happening right now. Wouldn't matter because the C300, like almost all Chromebooks, just doesn't have the power for heavy photo editing.
Forget video editing completely, even basic cut n' export jobs. Not happening at this time.
This Chromebook works perfectly fine for moderate spreadsheets (via Google Docs) but it may choke on some large corporate level Excel sheets with lots of formulas.

I was surprised how well this Chromebook handles playing HD videos on Youtube (besides the aforementioned visual quality issues due to the limited screen specs). I've not experienced any stuttering and it just doesn't seem like the machine's processor is overwhelmed playing videos, even after doing this for an hour or so straight. On a 2011 Macbook Air, the fans go absolutely nuts when playing 720p or higher videos, and it heats up quite a bit. The Chromebook stays quiet and cool. In fact, there is no fan that can kick in. This is part of the reason why performance is limited - it had to be in order to keep the processor cool and omit the fan.

If you rely on Dropbox, note that you cannot install a Dropbox folder on this and expect it to sync with your Dropbox account like it works on Windows or OS X. Dropbox does offer an app but it's really just a shortcut to the Dropbox web site. (Some third party extensions claim they can create a virtual folder on your device and connect it to your Dropbox account but security concerns prohibit me from testing these). Google really wants you to use Google Drive. If you do, you're all set - the C300, like all Chromebooks, connects and works nicely with your Google Drive account.
Side note: if you see the ad here on Amazon claiming you get 100 TB of free storage from Google Drive for 2 years...that offer expired January 2015.

Chrome OS currently cannot connect to network drives. If you use a USB thumb drive or NAS connected to your router, don't expect to be able to access any of its contents from a Chromebook, including the C300. Again, this may change by the time you read this review.

Chromecast. If you need Chromecast, this Chromebook does the job...kind of. It doesn't always do it very well though. Videos tend to be somewhat choppy (even if they play fine on the C300's itself) when cast over to your TV. Colors look weird, not sure why that is. The machine does appear to change the look of the video somehow when it casts it to a TV. It points to a problem with the Chromecast extension itself, not necessarily the C300.

Skype: Microsoft/Skype really needs to make a proper extension for Chrome but as of right now they haven't. If you rely on Skype, you only have one realistic option: Outlook. Install the app, and sign in with your Outlook email account. You can use a very crippled version of Skype through the Outlook email app, but there are no proper notifications, and you can't search for or add new contacts. But it's fine for basic use.

That's the gist of it - Chromebooks are for BASIC use. This includes the C300. It's good, does the basics fine, is light, lasts a long time on battery, wakes up from sleep very fast. Its limitations come mostly from Chrome OS itself and they are the same with every Chromebook. The Asus isn't alone in having only 2 GB of memory and no backlit keyboard either. So if you get a good deal on this (under 200 bucks), and are in the market for a Chromebook anyway, absolutely get this one.

If you need more info, go ahead and read the other reviews here, most of them are really good and spot on. I close with saying that if you haven't been using Chrome as your main browser, aren't familiar with how extensions work, and don't really know about Chrome OS limitations, do check out a few online resources about Chrome OS before you decide to buy this or any other Chromebook. I will say that those reviewers who say "it's great for X" may be right in regards to how THEY like to work on "X", but your personal workflow and style may or may not be accommodated by Chrome OS.

For me, the C300 is wonderful for basic browsing, emails, doing very light Word or spreadsheet work, and checking social media accounts and watching some Youtube videos.

+3 Firstly, I love Logitech's universal receiver and actually seek products out that use it.  Great bit of gear.  Note that you don't have to use  Logitech's SetPoint software to use the universal receiver.  I'll note why that's important later on.  +/-  The wave shape is a bare change from regular form factor unlike the main competitor, Microsoft's Natural (Elite), which is a full split keyboard.  The latter certainly takes more pressure off of the wrists and, if carpal tunnel syndrome or related repetitive stress injuries have troubled you in the past, you can feel the difference within minutes of typing on the Wave.  On the upside, the lack of split gives the Wave a much lower profile than the Natural series did; the Wave fits under your desk on most sliding keyboard trays where the Natural bumps most.  -2 Keys are stiff, mushy and crowded in depth.  After buying the Wave I actually came back to positive reviews here to see if I had misread them.  The key presses are terrible; there is no indication of when the press is complete and you can release for the next stroke which makes for an necessarily long key press.  Moreover, they are stiff.  A quick typist is going to be considerably delayed by this keyboard.  -2 There are no indicator lights for CAPS/NUM/Scroll/Function locks.  With SetPoint installed, toggling each status gives you a brief on-screen indicator of your change.  There are plenty of game, video card settings, multimedia players and the like which completely conflict with this indicator so you frequently have no idea what status your keys are in.  Even if you're just typing, you more often forget your various statuses.  There's no light of any kind to reference on the keyboard.  You have to experiment.  While using it for both writing and gaming alike, checking your lock statuses frequently creates breaks in concentration and this is a critical design failure.  +1 The multimedia buttons are other extra programmables in general are well placed.  However, they require the SetPoint software to really get much value from.  Without it, not all keys are matched to a standard function within Windows 7.  -2 The SetPoint software is on version 6.2 yet remains a calamity.  I've installed and uninstalled probably half of the versions over the years across every incarnation of Windows.  It forgets settings across profiles which renders them pointless, conflicts with Windows settings for mouse sensitivity, and has very limited macro capability.  My biggest complaint, which you can confirm across the Web's related trouble-shooting forums is that it will frequently cause a stutter in mouse movement.  -1 There is no backlight.  A wireless keyboard is as often as not used with a multi-media setup in a darkened room.  Not having lit keys on a non-standard layout is poor design.  Logitech mastered the feature with the K800 wireless so leaving it out of this recent incarnation of the Wave has been lazy.

I had to replace my 2007 Dell quickly after it was fried by a power surge (surge protector I guess was already fried so couldn't help, I'm told).  My new computer, Asus 11AD w/ Windows 7 did not come with an internal modem.  I've been using dial up ISP (Net Zero) for years, these days still d/t very complicated wiring circumstances (I'm in a crazy condo) so needed a modem exclusively to get me back into Net Zero.  This modem could not do it - never connected with Net Zero server, ever.  I spent quite a number of hours using Net Zero help and also their tech support to try to remedy situation without any success. Tech support at HiRO was great once I called, though.  Returned my call promptly (on a Sunday).  Tech basically explained that while this modem type has been tested successfully with Net Zero that many circumstances could interfere including conditions at my site or a defect in modem I received, but that, in fact, either the modem works or doesn't and time spent altering settings in windows or Dial Up ISP is not well invested.  He suggested that I either try a different manufacturer (gave me 2 recommendations) or a new modem of this same type.  I elected to go to a different manufacturer (Zoom 3095) which did work \\"out of the box\\" once driver CD installed.  So, even though this modem was not able to do what I wanted it to, I give it more stars as HiRo tech was truly stellar!  Quite possibly, this modem would have done it's other functions (faxing) without a hitch. It tested fine in Windows Modem Query.  PS:  This modem is a \\"soft modem\\", ie. most of the operating software is run from your computer, not the modem, while the Zoom has the operating software running from the modem which is why it is pricier.  Perhaps, this made a difference in my case.

We have 3 of these packs, my kids think they are the greatest thing to recharge their phones, they use them all over the house so they are not tied to the wall.

UPDATE - 5-1-2014

I have purchased 5 of these, 3 for our own use and 2 for friends who really liked using ours at our home or away from home.

All are working great Ours are used daily by the family to charge iPhones and iPads while not being tethered to an outlet, one is always being charged while the other 2 are being used.

When friends come over they use them to charge their devices while they are over.

Of the three we own, one was bought a year ago, one about 3 months ago and one a week ago.

NOTE - I do not use the included connectors, ever, I have plenty of micro USB cables to charge it and apple cables to charge our devices. I don't think their cable is the greatest, but that is my opinion.

There is an updated model, but the one we just bought this week from Amazon was not the updated model, that came from a daily steal sight as did the original one.

The updated one has a new VAAS logo, comes with an iPhone 5 charger tip (lighting cable), the status LEDs are different (one LED in each vs 2 per bar and they all flash during charging) and the power button functions differently (you have to hold it to turn off where the old style is one press on one press off).

I have been really impressed with these power bricks from Vaas.

I also have had other Vaas iPhone battery cases and bricks, but have been less impressed with the quality of those (the 5200 brick while smaller, has no off button and only a 1A output, and had a 2000 stick that was cheap quality, and some of the battery cases had issues).

I would definitely recommend this item though due to my consistent results with the 5000 brick and the reasonable cost.

This is a good router for the money, for $20 you get a DSL Modem plus router with WIFI & 4 Lan ports.  my unit came used with scratches on the front part but no biggie.  Software was up to date but I did have to reset the VPI/VCI from VPI 8 VCI 35 to VPI 0 VCI 35 I am in AT&T Texas  This unit actually boosted my signal from 768kb to 1.4Mb almost twice the speed compared to my previous DSL Modem efficient Speedstream 5660 also the WIFI reach is a lot better.  The two cons I could see  1 unit is missing a USB port but for twenty bucks ok with me.  2 the wireless security encryption WPA WPA2 sould have all AES TKIP SKA it doesn't  I have a good bridged wireless router WRT54G-TM running DD-WRT with only one option WPA PSK and looks like I can't use it unless I use WEP but that's a no no.    Now if you have a good running router, still get this router as a backup just in case.

I received a Kindle Fire as a Christmas present, but the gifter did not get a cover for it.  I purchased this leather cover and am very satisfied with it.  The leather looks and feels great, looks very elegant and classy.  You can stand the Kindle with this cover, or fold the cover back and use the strap to grip the Kindle.  I find this particularly useful on the bus or train - I don't worry about accidentally dropping the Kindle while reading, especially if the bus suddenly lurches.  I especially appreciated the video about the product, showing exactly how to stand the Kindle up.  My only complaints are: 1 - its such a strong sturdy cover, it adds a lot of weight to the Kindle.  I have, on occasion, left the Kindle home because I was carrying other things and the weight became a factor.  2 - The cover closes, but doesn't zip up around the kindle.  In a handbag, its possible for the kindle to get scratched on the sides and there is no way to carry the cord with it.  That's why I gave it 4 stars and not 5.  For traveling and longterm home storage, I had an old zippered cosmetics travel case that was the right size for putting the Kindle in (with the cover on), along with the power cord, and the stylus I also bought.  This exterior case provides complete protection, as well as keeps the cord stored with the Kindle.

To provide some perspective - I am a CPA with a Big 4 accounting firm. I often work from 8am-11pm and I am using a mouse nearly the entire day. A mouses accuracy, feel, and reliability is very important to me. After about a week of constant use, I highly recommend this mouse!

This mouse works very well and it is a great value at $14.99. The left and right mouse click buttons are smooth and produce a nice sound in terms of volume level and tone/pitch. The tracker ball is smooth and nearly silent. The sides of the mouse have a smooth grip material that has a nice consistency (not too sticky, not too slippery). The nano transceiver is nice, but seems to be a common option on portable mice. The size of the mouse is perfect for my hands and convenient for travel.

The biggest difference between this mouse and other mice is the laser. This mouse users a 'blue laser' technology that is extremely accurate and works on nearly any surface. As I write this, I am using it on my couch. The couch material is microfiber and it is not smooth. The material has a bunch of ridges that are not uniform or consistent. Yet, the mouse works perfectly. I have been using the Logitech M325 for several years now and have really enjoyed it. As of right now though, I believe the Microsoft Wireless Mobile Mouse 3500 is superior to the Logitech M325. I will post an update if my opinion changes.

I consider this mouse a strong buy.

I have not yet given a product a single star, but this one deserves it.  Took a while to setup, but it is a relatively easy process. I kept entering the password that I just created and the router would not accept it, including the original, preset password.  I reset the router and went through the setup again.  An hour later, the same story.  The router still worked and maintained wireless network, but it would lock me out.  I get it, sometimes companies make defective hardware, but this one was disappointing on more than one level.  I purchased the router to improve my network speed and range, because this one claims to be the best in that department.  My Apple airport express has a few slow zones and I was hoping to rectify that issue.  In places where Airport had weak signal, ASUS did not connect at all.  My speeds wend down substantially throughout the house.  I have no idea what the fuss is about.  Yes, the product offers a TON of customization and I also bought it because it had a VPN router functionality, but I would have to be able to access the router to set it up.  Overall this is an inferior product......

I am not a networking pro, but just wanted to use Wireless as I got my office laptop in addition to my personal laptop at home, as I needed an IP splitter anyway. This device, being a combo and at a decent price immeidately caught my attention and I bought it inspite of my friedns' warnings against D-link.

The setup of the base unit was easy but as soon as I installed the card, I figured that something went wrong. After a 2 hours discussion with cust-support, I was told that I would have to use Static IP addresses on both PCs to connect to internet, as the DNS server of the Base unit had some issues. That is fine as long as my both pcs are used at home, but I have to change my network setting everytime (to autodetect an IP address) whenever I have to take my PC out or if someone bring another device to my home. I happened to change my service provider and discovered that the TCP/IP setting of my main PC had corrupted and needed reinstallation.

Other than that, its been working fine since last 2-3 months. Not a single dropped connection. It works at a consistent high speed. I would say its a good value for money if, unlike me, you know how to use it.

I wanted to replace my 5 year old Dell Inspiron and this laptop was good enough. What I liked about the computer was the quick boot up. It took me less than a minute to get on the internet from the moment I pressed the power button. I have never had performance issues with this computer. The graphics on this laptop are good but not great. This laptop is good for watching HD videos on the internet but not for playing  graphically intensive video games on the highest settings. The built in camera is okay but not so bad that I would have to buy an attachment.

I would have given this product 5 stars had it not been for a files permissions issue early on that I have since resolved (see below).    I bought this D-Link DNS 323 NAS about a month ago and I love it. I ordered it with 2 [[ASIN:B001IEZX3G Western Digital 1 TB Caviar Green SATA Intellipower 32 MB Cache Bulk/OEM Desktop Hard Drive WD10EADS]] drives and set them up as one disk, giving me 2TB of space. The first NAS unit I received had a faulty right drive bay (amber light came up no matter which drive I put in and both worked in the left bay), so I returned it to Amazon and they sent the replacement promptly without any hassle. The replacement NAS has been excellent since then. It is nice to be able to back up my files (I know RAID1 would be better due to the redundancy, but I don't want to sacrifice overall space) and access them from anywhere, especially my music, videos, and pictures. I got married just over a year ago and the photographer gave my wife and I digital copies of all of the photos, and the NAS makes it easy to share the full-quality images with friends and family.    The only other problem I've run into was an issue with permissions for files I had uploaded. For many of the first files I uploaded to the NAS I had difficulty in reading them again after a system reboot. I'm still not entirely sure what caused this, but after just a quick search online ([...] - this is a great site for tips on hacking and enhancing the device) I was able to set up a telnet to the machine, telnet in, and change the permissions through the Terminal on my Mac (thank God for Linux-based firmware).    One of my favorite features is the built-in bit torrent client (on the newer versions of the firmware). I am a huge Dave Matthews Band fan and I download audience recordings of the shows, so having a program on the NAS to download and seed the shows without having to keep my computer running all night has been a welcome change for me (especially since the NAS runs much more efficiently than my 5 year old laptop).    If you are looking for a good NAS system, I recommend the DNS 323 to you with no reservations, especially now that it is $110 after mail-in rebate.

I wish I could rave about the Kindle. I wish I could be that fanboy who tries to convince everyone he knows to buy the same device but, alas, I cannot. I was very underwhelmed with this thing.

First, it should be noted that I am an admitted bibliophile. I read all the time and the purpose behind my digitalization of the book was because I got tired of lugging several books with me each time I trudged off to work. I loved the idea of having an near-limitless supply of books at my fingertips. Much in the same way that I have a 500GB Archos for transporting the majority of my music collection, I wanted something to drag around the majority of my books.

The issues with the Kindle were immediate. I'm not going to buy everything from Amazon's eBook store and therefore needed more format support. No problem, I'm told, use Calibre. Except calibre seemed to wonk the format of every ePub book I fed through it. So I either stick with it in the hopes of future ePub support or I resolve to buy nothing but Amazon's wares (or the third option was of course to scour the seedy corners of the interwebs for bootlegged, non-DRM MOBI versions of things but that's not the way I roll if I can avoid it).

Plus, as a technophile I like rooting, Linux-ing and otherwise voiding my warranty whenever possible. So I returned the Kindle 2 in favor of the Nook and couldn't be happier with the decision. (A fairly simple rooting took care of the one issue I had with the switch: the Nook's initial lack of a browser. Plus now I have Pandora but that's neither here nor there.)

Let's be honest though: this is all a personal choice, isn't it? The same way I prefer Archos and you might prefer Zune.

The Kindle does have a nice interface and the eInk screen is insanely clear and easy to read. For someone this'll be the perfect device. Just not for me.

And for the record, Amazon was incredibly easy to deal with and fast when it came to the return process. That was a nice little bonus.

So, despite some negative reviews about chemical smell, I went with the SwitchEasy Canvas, which is the only A-rated iPad case from iLounge: [...]  Here's why this case stands above the rest:  - No chemical smell  - Sturdy front cover with magnetic locking (like the Apple smart-cover)  - Clear screen protector (and plastic inserts for headphone and charging ports)  - Just the right amount of bulk to give you a sense that it will survive a fall or two, but not overly bulky  - Great price for all that's included (read the iLounge review linked above)  - Solid build quality with good feel/texture  - Sturdy in stand mode (works great in your lap, unlike the Joy Factory Smart Suit, which was too wobbly in upright stand [picture frame] position). The Microsoft Surface is perfect.

In my opinion, the vast majority of people who try to knock it down with their reviews are clearly Apple or Google fanboys. Having used the tablet for about a week now, all I can say to them is \\"sour grapes\\". My advice to potential buyers is to spend some hands-on time with the competing Apple and Android tablets and then try the new ones running Windows 8. Once you touch the Microsoft Surface you will know who the winner is.

Windows 8 RT is super intuitive and takes about 5 minutes to learn (nobody running iOS or Android can claim that). The built-in kickstand is an absolute must (nobody else has it). The keyboard/screen cover is fantastic (nobody else has it). You can run Office on it (nobody running iOS or Android can claim that). You can attach peripherals and memory to it via a full-size USB 2.0, a HD video out port and a microSDXC card slot (a few other tablets have these features, Apple's doesn't). The build quality is superb (Apple's is comparable but most Androids are cheap junk). Every time I needed something actually useful in the app marketplace I was able to find it. This is the first essentially bug-free computer I have experienced - ever. To borrow a phrase from Jim Cramer: Buy, buy, buy!
Could be a little bigger.

For $100.00 you can hook up a third monitor only to find out it doesn't work. Call customer support to find out you need a firmware update then apply it and... it still doesn't work. Call customer support back again so they can tell you to send it back. Duh. What a circus. Maybe I'm asking for to much here but I think for that much money the product should work and if I have to fix your firmware fresh out of the box then you should pay me for finishing your work. At least give it an auto update ability instead of having me call tech support to find out what the problem is when you already know. I read many reviews for these adapters (after the fact)and found most people are having to send these back for replacement. Once they find one that isn't broken out of the box they are reasonably happy. Sorry, but if I'm paying this much money for a little adapter then it needs to work the first time without me having to fix or replace it. Overall quality is not acceptable. I have abandoned this idea completely and will simply add another video card to get the third monitor working and maybe a fourth. Display Ports are nothing more than a low quality, cheap(for the manufacturer)replacement for DVI that companies are going to try to sell to you as the next \\" best \\" way to plug in your system.

I recieved the CT14 A0 ultrabook yesterday and have been tinkering with it as much as possible in the last 24 hours. It is very sleek and sexy! So far I Love it.

Pros:
-Beautiful looks! Inside and outside. Somehow the color and the texture was chosen with aesthetics in mind.
-The trackpad is sensetive to light touch. I prefer touch-clicking rather than tapping the button. 2-finger scroll works pretty well for webpages.
-BLAZING FAST ! Boot time : 20 sec to reach login screen. After login, 5sec to fully load the desktop with startup apps, bluetooth connection to speakers, wifi etc . Shutdown time - 10sec. I believe this is possible because of the solid state hard drive.
-No bloatwares! In my opinion , bloatwares are utter garbage and a waste of resource. For every preinstalled program, there are 10 free open source programs out there.
-Vizio has done a fairly classy job with there own logos, startup screens etc.

Cons:
-The trackpad does not respond well at times. It has completely frozen on a 2 occasions. That doesnt bother me too much. The way around this problem is a quick sleep-wake or several taps and clicks.. Its still a glitch
-I miss the Alternate Menu (Right-cick menu) key thats usually near the Right Ctrl key.
-The edges around the palm are kinda sharp and might bother you after long hours of use.
-The 128GB size of the hard drive might come and bite you one day. I have been used to a 500gb HDD for a long time. I'm already figuring out ways to put the old laptop up as a file server.

This laptop is probably the best value-for-money in the ultrabook category. I bet the prices will creep up slowly.

I am not a big screen protector user. I know, not a good habit, but they tend to get messed up or I can't get the bubbles out or whatever, I don't always use them. I Love my Kindle Fire however, and was eager to try the Belkin Protecter pack. One thing I really like about this protector is that it comes with helpers to keep the Fire in great shape. First, the Belkin protector kit has a little cloth to gently wipe the front of the screen to get rid of dust and fingerprints. The protector itself is fairly thick, much thicker than anticipated, making for good, strong protection from scratches. The screen protector is attatched to clear plastic that you peel off and then apply the protector to the front of the Kindle Fire. Secondly, you get a little credit card sized piece of sturdy cardboard to smooth down the clear protector and get all the bubbles out. I've gotten most of them but not all, when I am reading though, I can't see them.

All in all, good protector pack. There are 4 screen protectors with this Belkin pack. They come with two cardboard smoother cards, two cloths and four screen protectors to keep the Kindle Fire's screen protected for a long time to come.

I'm an audio engineer.

I purchased this USB speaker after reading a \\"shootout\\" review on Macworld.com [...]. For thirty bucks or less, you can't beat the quality and portability of the Tritton Sound Bite.

It's slightly larger than a hockey puck, plenty loud, and I love how the tweeters fold down to protect themselves during transport. The cord also wraps into the underside of the unit so it's very neat and tidy.

The audio quality isn't going to win any audiophile contests (what do you expect for $30?), but it's plenty clear with minimal distortion, and it does a great job of actually getting your laptop up to ACTUAL listening levels for DVD's, streaming movies, etc...

The one problem I've experienced with this device (this reason it got 4 stars instead of 5) is that it doesn't seem to work with my wife's Mac Book Pro. I haven't messed with this a WHOLE lot, but it's enough to be annoying, since it worked immediately with my PC laptop. Funny, since I bought this thing because of a review on a Mac website.

UPDATE (March 3, 2011): I still use this device EVERY day. Most laptop speakers just don't put out enough volume, and definitely not enough bass. I watch Hulu/Netflix in the kitchen on my laptop, and this device is a LIFESAVER. I also take it with me on trips so I can watch movies and Hulu in my hotel room. Again, this isn't necessarily for listening to your favorite gold-disc 48kHz special-edition of your favorite hi-fi album, but it's great for getting audio levels to where they need to be for ACTUAL listening without distortion or other typical laptop annoyances.

To qualify my statements, I'm generally not a big Sony or Apple fan for various reasons, but this seems to be an area Sony does really well in...

Comparing this to the Sony VPC-SA series, I couldn't help but notice, that you can get a lot more from Sony at the same price, same weight:

Without being any heavier, Sony adds:
1) Intel i7-2620M Processor, rather than Samsung's i5
2) AMD HD 6630M GPU with 1GB dedicated GDDR3 RAM (this is within a few fps of the Nvidia GT540M GPU)
3) internal DVD writer/reader
4) Much better Screen resolution at 1600x900 instead of the crummy 1366x768 they call \\"HD\\" these days...
5) Fingerprint reader

A chunk of extra cash will get you an internal BluRay writer/reader.

True, maybe Sony's magnesium-alloy plus aluminum isn't as fancy as Samsung's duralumin (whatever that is, exactly), but that comes down to the same type of comparison you have with Macbooks; would you rather have higher-end electronics and capabilities, or would you prefer a spiffy aluminum case carved from a single block? Everyone has to make their own choice in that area...

As for this Samsung, I think the Amazon description doesn't quite do it justice when it comes to the measurements - 2.7 inches thickness seems really unlikely to be true, I bet that's a typo...

The Sony SA series is less than 1 inch thick, and I think so is this Samsung.

So, if you really need \\"dramatic curves\\" on your laptop, by all means, go for this one.. I guess you can tell, I'm a bit tired of all the retarded advertising texters, its insulting. Does anybody read this stuff without cringing? Who are they writing it for? Do they think the earth's population had a collective lobotomy?

Beyond that, I have nothing against this notebook. Its just surprising that Sony could cram a lot more into the same weight (and price), and it gives me the idea that by comparison, this Macbook-Air-wannabe is both over-priced and over-weight.

Ah Yes! Just what the common man, or woman was looking for in a universal hard drive adapter.  A true plug and go, the only note of caution on using the device is the power plug,  You can push the plug in upside down thereby reversing polarity and blowing out your hard drive. (Use care and look carefully at the plug to avoid this Doomsday Scenario.  The company could have designed a better plug input to prevent this from happening, or at least color code the plug adapter to make it "stupid proof".  Read the instructions very carefully before jumping in.  One other weird thing to look out for,  When you are hooking up to older IDE drives the power plug needs to plug directly into the hard drive not the Apricorn Unit.  This was not spelled out anywhere in the instructions which were very sparse on that point.  Other than that, you will find the unit very accepting of almost any type of drive to include laptop drives.  Bravo Apricorn for knocking this one out of the park for data retrieval.

I really love the Das Keyboard so far. It's my first mechanical keyboard and honestly the first good keyboard I've ever used. I hate to admit it, but the last keyboard I had was a $12 Logitech I bought about four years ago. I use the Das for gaming (FPS and RPG's), typing of documents and general web browsing.

It's the "Silent Key" version, but it's still quite loud when I'm typing a document or playing COD. Definitely louder than any membrane keyboard. When I'm playing RPG's I'm much lighter on the keys, so I can actually play totally silently since you don't have to push the key all the way down to actuate it. It all depends on how forceful you are when you type. The switches are Cherry Reds which have a good linear feel to them with a lower actuation force than the Cherry Blacks. I can still rest my fingers on they keys without actuating them, so it's a good balance.

The keyboard is also very well made and weighs about 3.5 lbs. It really looks and feels like a high quality product. The enclosure/bezel has a glossy finish, so be prepared to wipe it off frequently if smudges bother you. They keys are a matte finish with laser-etched lettering. Overall, definitely recommended.

I bought this monitor from Amazon on September 17, 2014, as a second monitor to use with an HP laptop. The laptop is 1920x1080 also the monitor's native resolution. Beautiful panel, very clear, good color, sturdy stand. But in the last two weeks the monitor has refused to wake from sleep when my computer wakes or I reattach the laptop. The power button stays amber and acts as if it is dead -- that is, it does nothing. Unplugging the power cord, waiting for the power button light to go out, and then reattaching the power cord does the trick -- the monitor comes on and works fine -- at least, until the next time I remove my laptop and the monitor goes to sleep. I fear the entire power board eventually will die...  I have written to Planar regarding this problem, asking for a warranty RMA. No response yet, but it has been only two days. Disappointing. Would be five stars except for this power problem.    Update January 2015: I have contacted Planar twice regarding this problem via the customer service form on their web page. No reply. Buyer beware. OK product but, in my experience, no customer support (and, hence, de facto, no warranty). I have developed a workaround: power off the monitor before detaching it from the laptop, and power it on after reattaching it.

We decided on this tablet for several reasons and it has preformed as well as we wanted it to. We were looking for something to replace a DVD entertainment system in our SUV. It would be mounted using a suction mount tablet holder suctioned to the dome light. An IR transmitter would feed the audio to IR headphones on the kiddos, leaving the adults in blissful silence! Alternatively the FM adapter can play the audio through the Excursion speakers.
The tablet needed to included the following:
1. less than $100 - technically right at $100 but within the budget.
2. expandable - yes it does have this capability although it is labeled TF Card. Handled a 32 GB micro SD.
3. 3.5mm headphone jack - handled the IR transmitter and the FM adapter both beautifully
4. 10.1" - the screen was large enough for kids in the back to easily view the movies. We were a little concerned with viewing angle but we didn't seem to have much issue. The tablet was mounted near the roof. The only problem came when the mount would slip and the tablet would tilt down. Otherwise the viewing angle worked very well for us.
5. decent battery life - we got 4 full movies at full screen brightness both going to our destination and coming home

I've owned a Kindle DX for 3 months.  I am very satisfied with it.  I do agree with the reviewers who criticize the Kindle for not having a folder system to organize reading material.  I hope that feature is added in the future.  That said, I am able to read, make notes, and download new material easily and I find myself using my Kindle more than I ever thought I would.      Now for the reason I'm posting a review, since the above is not exactly ground-breaking:  I have arthritis in my left wrist due to a fracture I sustained several years ago.  It makes holding a print book open quite painful.  Reading had been one of my favorite activities but I all but gave it up 8 years ago when I broke my wrist.  The Kindle is, for me, a miracle.  It's given me back the ability to read.  Since I bought it, I've done almost nothing but read.  I understand that many, if not most, like the look, feel and even the smell of print books, but for the small minority of us who can't effectively use print books, the Kindle is a godsend.  That may be a good thing to keep in mind as a present for a loved one who suffers form arthritis or a similar challenge.

The problem start with installation, in order to adjust the shield to the right location on your screen, you will have to keep the adhesive side pretty wet, and once you get it to the right position, you'll have to squeeze the bubble, which is easy to do, but that where the problem is, when you move the water to the edge, there is a good chance moisture will get into your ipad, now this might be being if your ipad is new with the original seal. I originally purchased a Zagg keyboard together with my iPad Air at the Verizon store. But @ $107 I thought it was steeply priced, I didn't need a backlit keyboard, it didn't put the iPad in portrait mode, the power cord was so short I had to charge my iPad on the floor or remove it to charge the keyboard and the manual left much to be desired. So I searched Amazon.com for an alternative and it seemed like this product was the right solution. Alas it almost, but isn't. Because you can read so many glowing other reviews, I'll just state what I find lacking.

1. Don't let the stock photo fool you that accompanies my review; you CANNOT use your iPad without retrieving the arm from the base. Trying to put the iPad at a decent viewing angle otherwise upends the keyboard causing it to tip up.
2. Retrieving the arm from the base is an exercise in delicacy and agility. The way I found to do it is: (a) put the iPad to sleep; (b) grab the button the locks/unlocks the arm at the base of the hinge; (c) while holding this slider button with one thumb, pull the slider with your other hand. It takes some effort.
3. Putting your iPad into portrait mode also requires effort. You'll have to repeat (2) to slide the arm all the way out, rotate your iPad; and place it in the groove on the keyboard table.
4. If you want to take the iPad out of the arm and use it as a tablet, that works OK, but restoring it is a bit awkward. Again, it's best to put the iPad to sleep before removing and restoring it.

Nevertheless, I'm too embarrassed to return this item and re-buy the Zagg after I returned it, and then return the AirBender 2.0. Also, I expect that, assuming its a sturdy unit, I'll adjust to its quirks and use it just fine. After all, the keyboard is better and it has many features I want. For example, the Zagg doesn't have cutouts for the iPad's 2 microphones, the AirBender 2.0 does. Great for recording your instructor in class. Works for me.

Surprisingly good, very pleased:

A friend's iPhone 4 with a heavy duty case does not fit - there's too much rubber to allow the socket to accept the plug...

updates:
- we just changed to summer daylight saving time - however, the clock did not over night, but it did when I plugged the iPhone back in...
- it does have dimming feature, so I corrected the statement above accordingly.
- it's not a travel clock: the batteries are only for back-up, and besides, it's too big (about the size of a VHS Video cassette) plus a power supply built into the plug.
- and yes, it does charge the iDevice while docked.
- and the back-up batteries ensure wake up if power is down, but the display is off when there is no power.

The outside is mostly all leather -- or at least appears to be -- with the inside being lined with black padded material in the computer part and a black shiny-type fabric in the accessories part. The handles and shoulder strap are part leather and part nylon. I think it looks really nice!  Also, Amazon's info gave a delivery estimate of \\"January 9, 2007 - January 15, 2007\\", but I ordered on Christmas Day and it arrived by UPS just 2 days later on 12/27 -- and that was using the free super-saver shipping!  Anyway, I think it is a pretty good deal for the money and am happy with my purchase.
