Back in the early 90s Logitech came out with their first trackball, and things have never stopped selling and for good reason.  To be helpful, I'll go with a strengths vs. Weaknesses approach.    Mouse Strength                       Trackball Strength    ---------------                      ---------------------    Industry Standard-used by            No Cords to impede movement  used by almost every company                                                        No flat service needed  Compatible with just about             everything                           No mouse pad needed    Tremendous Variety of choices        Very short learning curve                                       Optical, so rarely need cleaning      Mouse Weaknesses                      Trackball Weaknesses  -----------------------------         ---------------------------  Long learning curve                  Very intuitive, Short learning           curve    non optical so they                  Optical so only needs cleaning  1 or   often collect dust and must          2 times a month  be cleaned often                                       Cord never stops you from moving   Cord CONSTANTLY gets stuck on        cursor  something impeding you from doig   something quickly, esp. during       EXTREMELY ergonomic and intuitive.  games.    Mouse wheel, if existent, breaks     Mouse wheel has never broken in any  easily                              of the mouse wheels I've had since'91      Non-ergonomic fostering              Very natural feeling with no fatigue       Carpal-Tunnel                      buildup even after 12 hours of playing      I will admit from the first day I ever used a mouse, I hated.  I've always has problems with precision, despite years of use before the trackball came out.  I always was frustrated I would lose a level because the mouse cord got caught on something, or the mouse ran out of room to keep moving in one direction.  The mouse and I hated each other from first sight.  The very first day I saw a Logitech Trackman for sale, I was joining the Army in 1990 and had to have one.  In about 30 minutes I loved it.  Since then they've even corrected all the problems, including sending me new trackballs, when the older ones malfunctioned, no questions asked.  I introduced my 72 year old mother (who hates anything \\"new\\" to the trackball, and now she refuses to use a mouse after having used one for 16 years beforehand).  It should be noted this trackball comes with or without cord.  I buy the cordless version so again, I' not inundated with wires.  If you haven't every tried one of these, do yourself a favor and borrow someones and give yourself a day, especially if you're a player.  It'll seem weird at first, but once you get used to it, you'll never want to use a mouse again.

Throughput was very low.  Don't know why but suspect the transmitter and receiver were on two different circuits. I have no proof but it seems the results are consistent with other reviewers experiences.

Saitek does a very poor job with their Proflight driver software.  The TPM has overlapping switch settings with their Proflight Control Yoke/throttle Quadrant, which is the other Saitek peripheral MOST likely to be used with the TPM.  Consequently, when both peripherals are connected via USB to either FSX or X-Plane 9.6x you will get unexpected commands being issued to the sim software.  The TPM's  nine switches have two positions but can't be programmed to have two functions ( ie one for each physical switch position), and because they send commands that are interpreted as if they are coming from another Saitek device (in my case even with the Proflight Throttle Quadrant disconnected), they are really useless. Saitek support is pretty useless as well.  Build quality is good, but overall not a very good value and quite frustrating to try and integrate into either sim. at this point I've gone back to using the older Throttle Quadrant due to the glitchy TPM software.

I use external drives at home and on the road to back up the various content and work products I create. The external 250 gig Hitachi I used for nearly three years had an interface electronic, not a drive, failure and needed replacement. This round I chose LaCie. Several people in my traveling, data intensive, hot, cold, dusty, bumpy world of wildland fire computing use LaCie external drives.

The drive case is heavy aluminum wrapped in a soft plastic guard. It's bright orange, so I may not forget and leave it behind as I clean up my equipment and leave fire camp. Of course the color and styling also scream \\"LaCie\\" to any passers-by but that's not important is it ;). A cable was included in the package.

LaCie has drive management and back up software installing automatically when you connect the drive. In my case, installation was smooth and product registration easy. You can also choose to reformat the drive, lose the software and run with a straight-up external lettered drive. I kept the software to test the whole package. When I buy the less costly/bottom line dollar drive products, the software included on them gives users less choice in installation. The LaCie software has not forced anything on me I did not choose, like a backup, or a flashing, insisting opportunity to buy an upgrade to get the REAL backup solution. I have not chosen to use LaCie's backup solution yet.

I bought a case for the drive. It's a solid, padded, textured, multi-pocketed case. The length, and width of the drive and case together are a centimeter more than the length and width of my old setup. The thickness is nearly double that of my old external and its sleeve. The weight is about 4X more.

I'll run it a year and let you know how things go. That's what counts for me.

This looks so sick in my system. I love the controls that allow you to adjust the brightness of the lights. Some times I want it REALLY bright when I'm showing it off, and other times, and night its so nice to be able to turn the LEDs down, so they don't hurt my eyes in my dark bedroom. You can even turn them completely off if you want, so you can sleep at night. If you don't turn your computer off.

The product seems very well made, and works perfect. The wire has a black mesh covering that matches most high end TX PSUs. I can't believe how cool this thing looks. I wish I had one for my last computer. It really makes the system stand out, even more than the LED fans.

The little plastic mounting clips that come with it, don't stick very well. They like to randomly fall off causing the wire to fall down. So you just have to avoid using them and come up with a creative way to display the lights. It doesn't bother me, the lights are what I paid for, and they are amazing.

It does take up a slot at the back of your computer though, so be aware of that. It also needs to be plugged directly into your PSU so you'll need an empty 4-pin molex.

I want to get some of the other colors, and try them as well, along with this blue one. The green and red look cool too.

While I love the DX for what it is, I loath it for what it is not. Classic love/hate relation, skewed towards love most of the time.

I am not certain how well R&D tested the screen for use in the sun. When I use it this way (as indicated by Amazon commercials), sometimes small blemishes begin to appear creating a cloudy look. This vanishes when I turn the page, and will pop up again at random times. This never happens indoors. So my advice is: do not use it in direct sunlight. Indirect sun is fine. I believe the product will wear out rapidly in direct sunlight.

My main concern: as a student pursuing a PhD, I was thinking I would use this for organizing my PDFs, and generally making the PhD process more streamlined. Yes, you can put your PDFs into the Kindle document folder easily enough. The problem is, that PDFs cannot be highlighted, unless you go through any number of 'fixes' found on Internet blogs. I have tried them all, and all of them fall short in various ways. OCR, Mobipocket Creator, Calibre, MS Word and every iteration of those in tandem/mixed/jury rigged...

Solution for now: NOOK Study app for students (FREE) can only be used on my PC. However, it does everything I need it to do as a student: Highlights, organizes, I can open multiple books at once, PLUS: I can drag and drop a PDF into the interface, and it automatically transforms into a useful mark-able format that is perfect, just like having a book to mark up. This is the main need for my study habits.

The downside to the NOOK Study app, is that the Kindle is far easier on the eyes. I can read for hours without eyestrain, and this is why I will keep it for some of my research (books that are already in Kindle format). However, if I make the brightness of my computer screen dimmed, it can approximate the look of Kindle e-ink to a large degree.

So for now, I will keep both DX and NOOK Study app. This is a hassle, but I suspect that both companies (Barnes and Noble and Amazon) will make these devices more user applicable as time goes on.

Oh, one thing I love about the DX: listening to books while working out, I can also read while doing a treadmill. I listen to books while driving too! Listen in the dark while falling asleep. Love that. One design flaw here: the volume level goes from zero to a little louder than I like. This can be solved by loosely inserting ear-buds, although I would think the volume control could be more sensitive. The battery will wear down much faster when using ear-buds, so keep that in mind. Text to voice is still a new technology, so expect a small learning curve understanding some of the text, especially if you have academic tomes to read.

I love it enough to keep it, dislike it enough to make this review. I hope Amazon is listening.

Mick Malkemus
PhD Student, Ed Tech, Gamification used for learning

I purchased the drive for my MacBook Pro (Core i7).  Installation was a breeze.  The performance improvement was significant compared to the 7200 RPM drive that came with the MBP.    However, the drive has failed three times already and it's only 42 days old.  Each time, the Apple Disk Utility was not able to repair and required a full re-format/re-partition of the drive.  Thanks to a good set of backup from Time Machine, I can usually get it back running in about 3 hours or so.    As this is my primary computer, this repeated failure is unacceptable.  If you don't regularly backup your computer or need a reliable computer, STAY AWAY from this drive.    I've already opened a RMA with Kingston, so hopefully a replacement drive will be better.  However, from reading other complaints, I doubt it.      Update:  I got an advanced exchange RMA from Kingston.  After just over two weeks of using the new drive, I had to go through the Reformat/Re-partition fun again.  Either these drives are not compatible with the Core i7 MBP and Kingston doesn't tell me about it... or they're just awfully UNRELIABLE!  Definitely stay away!!!

I guess this isn't so much of a review, as a DIY modification.   The pack is excellent. It stores my 17.3\\" notebook, as well as a cooling pad, in the laptop section. It's well sealed, and has lots of pockets. I can fit a 16 oz water bottle (thin one) in the side zippered pocket. There's plenty of room for books in the secondary pouch. It feels very solid, and the straps are well padded.  Ok, so there's my quick review. 5 stars on the pack.  My only issue was that it sounds like a wind chime because the zippers clank around a lot. They're well made; no argument there. They just happen to be rather noisy.  Fix:  1. Buy some paracord. Easily found on Amazon or Google.  2. Remove the metal grab tabs that attach to the zipper (just the part you would pull on, not the part that actually zips). I used wire cutters of a decent build, because these are hefty pieces of metal.  3. Attach the knot of your choice. I used blood knots, because they're fast, easy, and solid.  Done: No more jingle jangle.  Synopsis: Great pack, but noisy. Easily fixed by replacing the pulls with knots. The zippers are excellent, so you shouldn't think this is a downside. They're metal on metal, and that gets noisy, but 10 minutes of your time is all it takes to swap the pulls to knots. If you want to add reflection you can always use reflective paracord, so that vehicles will spot you more easily.  End note: Easily fits a 17.3\\", books, pens, small umbrella, water bottle, notepads, extra battery and power supply for the notebook, and whatever else you're willing to lug along. I carry about 20 lbs in it normally, which feels very light with this pack. I would expect it could lug 40 lbs or more without difficulty, and the straps would still ease the load well. This is a good uni commuter bag for those with a large load.

The unit I received was defective from day one. It had the dropping wi-fi issue other reviewers have noted. It is hard to imagine Samsung keeps seeling a defective product. I called Samsung support and in many different sessions we tried installing updates, wiping the hard drive, and other techniques that did not work. They finally admitted it was a hardware issue and said I would need to send it in for repairs that would take up to 15 business days to complete. I explained it was defective from day one and I can't be without a computer for over three weeks and that I would need a replacement sent or sometype of loaner. They were unwilling to honor that request. I asked to speak with a supervisor, was placed on hold for 20 minutes. I was then told the supervisor was talking to someone else but would call me back at the first opportunity. I received a call about 18 hours later, but only after my wife tweeted to Samsung on their lack of follow through. The supervisor said she had no ability to override their standard policy but someone from the exeuctive team would call me back within 2 business days. As you could guess this call came well past two days in the form of a brief voice mail that said we revieded your case and we will not accomdate you. No attempt to speak with me. I can understand a repair if I had the laptop for a while, but not working brand new....not the experience I have had with other companies. It is a shame because it is a nics machine and would have been perfect for me if it work ad advertised.

Since Samsung is resolving a known issue and had so little respect for its clients needs or time I would strongly recommend a differnet ultrabook.

- Flip switches always rock back to center and can be programmed for up/down presses separately

Cons
- Requires USB 3.0 (It won't work on any USB 2.0 ports on my PC. Only works in USB 3.0 ports, and each part has to be on its own USB BUS. If both the throttle and stick are both plugged in to the same USB BUS, via a multi plug device or a hub plugged into a USB 3.0 port, button presses randomly get sent fairly frequently. Probably a driver issue.)
- I've had the throttle randomly lose power while playing. It doesn't disconnect from the PC (windows still sees it), but the lights go off and none of the buttons work. This is an issue when you're maneuvering to dock and the throttle and thrusters get stuck on. I've never leaped around to the back of my computer to unplug and plug it back in so quickly! (which fixes the issue) This issue is pretty rare, but it's very problematic when it does happen. It's not enough of a problem for me to pursue an RMA though.
- The stick is just a little "sticky" during fine movements sometimes. That's not to say it's bad; it feels good 99.8% of the time. Occasionally you need to give it a slight wiggle to make it smooth again. Really not a big issue though. I'm not flying a real plane.
I hate finger prints and smudges!  This is a complete system for your Le Pan II.  Goes on as smooth as silk and keeps everything clean.
We use it ALL the time with our 17" laptop when working on the couch. Before, our laptop would overheat and the fan would be going like crazy. Now, it stays cool and is comfy on your lap.
Fits perfectly on the Mac.  Almost forget its there since the fit is so perfect to keyboard.  Very good and worth the money.
excellent keyboard

I would like de cable to be a bit longer.
Other than that, I really like it
Very good for the money it cost.

After checking out numerous owner reviews I gave a few of these as Christmas gifts last year and got one for myself.

I purchased two Kindle Fire's for my twin daughters. In one year, I had to exchange BOTH of them THREE TIMES because of a defect in the metal casing where the charger plug is inserted. Thankfully, Amazon extended the one year warranty and told me that they would honor the third exchange because the manufacturing defect was widespread. When I complained that the last exchange did not include chargers and I was required to purchase my own chargers, they quickly called me on the phone and credited my account for 2 new high speed chargers. I alway shop at Amazon first because I know that they have amazing customer service. Thanks Amazon!
Well made what else is there to say?

You get what you pay for, it's true.  Sony is known for quality, at a price.    I bought this memory stick when it came out and it was on sale for $99.  I thought I could save money by buying a knockoff at half price!  Those lasted about a year before it stopped working, incidentally after their warranty expired,  either someone programmed them to break (like computers in the early days) or I was just plain unlucky.  Nope I had several knock off MemSticks and they all cease to work in about a year.    The Sony Memory Stick is still chugging along, after nearly 3 years, how bout that.  Now I have a newer model camera which uses a memory stick at half the length. Now companies are coming out with tinier and tinier cards.  C'mon guys please agree to one size, its like waking up and finding out your new electronics take AAAA batteries that measure 1cm by 1cm.    I gave this product 4 stars if it weren't for the high price.    Now I tell people to avoid sony cameras to save money, and they get decent pictures, plus memory cards at unbelievable prices that make me green with envy :)

It does what is expected and is pretty well built, especially for the price.  Some people don't like that it operates off a rechargeable battery, but, IMO that is mostly an advantage given the purpose you'd usually put a small speaker like this to, so I think that they shouldn't be removing stars for that.  I am removing a star, because it is a bit on the quiet side.  otherwise, though it is quite good, although I haven't had a change to really put the batteries through their paces yet..  it is *VERY* small, but, again, that is a plus given that it is intended as a portable speaker.

Was looking for a good on-the-go USB stick that had a fair and competitive pricing. This was on flash sale and had good reviews, so I decided to give it shot. Cant have to many USB sticks around the house, right? This stick worked for me for awhile, but for some reason it started doing some wonky things. While it works most of the time and does what I need it to do, I sometimes have troubles when copying a lot of files or bigger files lately. It will freeze around the 100mb left, and it did this on multiple computers. I have formatted it multiple times and done other IT tricks, but unfortantely it still hangs up here and there.

I would go another route if I were to get another USB stick in the near future from my personal experience. However, I would recommend this if its on sale, as I'm sure my experience is just an uncommon fluke.

The only complaint I have is the plastic surround at the base of the head band where the size slider slides into, twists and breaks over time. Superglue wont stick to the plastic to repair it and Roccat do not carry spare parts (even though its screwed on)

Do not buy this for your xbox.  It sucks.  The unit was functional (well, not defective) and by 'dialing in' to the unit it was able to communicate (with and w/o wires) with my computer.  The first red flag was when the xbox did not recognize the DWL-G820 as a wireless adapter.  This is normal.  It has to be configured with an IP address, which is ridiculous because the wired router connection is normally plug and play.  However, no amount of configuration in the xbox dashboard would allow the xbox to connect wirelessly.  This was even with the assistance of tech support, which is spotty at best.  The folks are nice enough, but getting through can take a very long time.  I'm okay with networks - all of my other stuff works great - but definitely not an expert, and I could go on and on about the changes I made.  I won't, though.  If you prefer painless set-up it's probably best to match brands when designing a wireless network.  I'll give D-link the benefit of the doubt and admit I was using a router of a different brand, but with all of the configuration options on both ends, this should not matter.  Oh, and I read some of the earlier reviews and I agree that this thing runs real hot.  Who knows what that'll do for the product's longevity because I don't plan to keep it.  If I ever got it to function properly and I had small children, then I'd probably mount it out of their reach.

I love this cover.  I wanted a something a little more spiffy then the cover Amazon sells for the Kindle 2 so I went with this.  As another reviewer mentioned it is a bit stiff at first but does become more flexible with use.  The front bends back nicely so you don't have the front cover to mess around with and doesn't interfere with the reading experience.  The inside is nice and soft.  The mounting system isn't as sophisticated as the Amazon cover but it holds the Kindle 2 in very securely and hasn't slipped out once. The clasp to close the cover can be a little clumsy at times sliding it.  This design could be improved upon.  The charging port is accessible when the cover it closed and it has a built in pocket for the M-Edge light.  Although that still isn't available for purchase, it's a nice feature though. The inside of the front cover has pockets for a memory card and other odds and ends but I haven't used any of the pockets yet, or the pen/pencil holder built into the inside crease.  All in all, it's a stylish protective cover and am extremely happy with my purchase!

First, mine came already opened and scuffed.  That might not have bothered me as much, and I really liked the idea of an integrated case and keyboard and the fake leather is perfectly ok, which I didn't see many or any alternatives for.  But the rubber keyboard is pretty squishy, on top of a squishy case, making for a presumably bad typing experience.  I say presumably, because I wasn't able to get it to pair (bad Chinglish instructions), so I have no idea how it works in practice. Finally, the keyboard itself is poorly glued onto the base.  A return for sure.

I bought the waterproof cover to be able to use the kindle on the beach without worrying about water/sand damaging the kindle. Although I haven't been on vacation yet, I already love this cover! The kindle seems very safe inside, while it is still easy to use the controls (even the power slide). Initially I was planning to buy the unpadded version, but I am very happy the padded version came out just in time, with this cover I am less worried about handling the kindle, putting it down, travelling, etc. I was a little bit worried that the straps and especially the black top would distract me, but fortunately they fold back easily so you don't see them at all when reading. And it is nice to have the option to secure the kindle by putting the straps around your arm/neck (for example while sailing). I definitely recommend this product, I can't wait to go on vacation!

I have had this Playbook case for well over a month now and it has been holding up very well. I also have a car mount for my playbook and sliding the playbook in and out of this case poses no problems to me. I can also mount the Playbook with the case installed but the bottom hangs and doesnt look as clean so I opt to take it off when mounting it in my car. Compared to the RIM leather case (which my wife has) this one has better functionality. I can charge my playbook without having to leave the case open (as with the RIM case). I actually dropped my Playbook once since having this case and the Playbook did not sustain any damage as the corner was protected. Opening and closing the cover is easy too as opposed to the RIM one which has an elastic strap. There was a small thread that started to come undone on the outer stitching of the case but I scorched it with a lighter (the thread) and it has yet to come undone anymore. I give this 5 stars due to functionality and value.

This case is pretty good, it's got good protection for the Mini, and the (important, for me) wake/sleep feature. The one thing it doesn't have, and I know this won't matter to a lot of people, is the elastic handstrap, and it lost a star just because of the absence of that feature. Otherwise, it's a great case cover - well built, sturdy, holds the iPad securely. I just feel like I need that hand strap, and that's because, among other things, I use my Mini as a shopping list. I don't want to try to hold onto it while pushing a shopping cart - I'm afraid I'll drop it, and good case or not, I'm not ready to allow that to happen. The hand strap helps me to hold the Mini MUCH more securely while I'm shopping. Yeah, I know - a lot of people would consider it a pain to use, but I just don't want to take that chance and drop my iPad. So, for me, the hand strap is kind of like insurance - anything that helps me hang onto my iPad is a good thing!

Having said all that, if the hand strap feature doesn't matter to you, this is a very good choice for a very good price. The wake/sleep feature works flawlessly, and I had no problem accessing any of the ports and buttons on my Mini. I would recommend it, definitely.

All that this adapter does is convert Mac's HDE display port to the more common VGA format. After doing so you can connect your Mac to other monitors, televisions, and even projectors! This adapter works somewhat, but the quality is inferior. I first used it to connect my 2012 non-retina Macbook Pro to a standard 17 inch monitor. The display on the monitor kept flickering out. I can't blame it on the monitor, I connected a VGA laptop into it and it worked fine. After that I used it to connect the same Macbook to my television. It worked perfectly there. However, the adapter is very cheaply built. The plastic cover protecting the HDE plug slipped off after a few minutes. Underneath was a crude looking circuit board, which was no surprise to me. No, what annoyed me was that the circuit board was covered in what appeared to be hot glue. I am no electricity expert, but I am pretty sure a circuit board does not perform well if melted plastic is smeared over it. Try another brand and avoid this.

Sure, after treating my laptop as a desktop and leaving it plugged in for months at a time, I was not very shocked when it was unable to hold a charge for more than 45 seconds when I took it out.

Yes, I would recommend this product to a friend.

I bought this laptop from another site in March however it seems to be getting a bum rap here.    I've had no blue screens at all and the laptop survived a 4 month trip into a desert carrying it on 4 different airlines in an unpadded messenger bag. All I've done to the machine is uninstall all the usual crapware that came with it and ran CCleaner.     The GT425M (1GB card dedicated) leaves a little to be desired if you are a hardcore gamer however I was looking for a battery life compromise as electrical power was somewhat intermittent from time to time. I generally squeeze about 3 hours of battery with normal usage and there is an unobtrusive piece of system management software preinstalled so you can hotkey several settings for more performance or for more battery. Starcraft II ran very well as did Sins of a Solar Empire with a fairly large map.    The only issue I've had is the camera cutting out on Skype from time to time, though my internet connection in the travel area may have caused that.

I must admit that I was quite skeptical if this would actually work because I've had bad experiences with every usb 2.0 kit out there. I am happy to report that this works just fine! I have used it on everything from 3.5" PATA EIDE drives to newer 3.5" SATA drives to 2.5" SATA 6 GB/s SSDs. It works both when connecting to your USB 3.0 port directly on the motherboard and also thru a USB 3.0 hub. I also found the transfer speeds to be limited by the type of drive connected but performance was as expected. The only tricky part with this kit is that there is a toggle switch for the power brick that I missed the first time, so I couldn't figure out why it wasn't powering on with everything connecting. (Everything is made with matte black plastic so it's easy to miss.)

I purchased the 2.5 TB version of this hard drive; that seems to be the sweet spot right now to get the best value for your money.  Have had the drive for a few weeks and have been working on ripping my DVD collection to the drive without any problems.  It offers a lot of storage space for the price, it's fairly quiet, and it installed easily and is crapware free.  For those who don't know, it is common for hard drives to fail almost right away if they are going to fail, and if not it's unlikely that they will fail for at least a few years, which is why you see so many one star reviews for this hard drive, and basically any hard drive available.  The good news is that if they do fail right away it's covered and can be easily replaced.  And knowing that, it's always smart to make sure that a new hard drive doesn't have anything of importance on it that is the only copy you have because of the high early failure rate of hard drives.  Back to this hard drive, very pleased with it, and would be another one once I'm in need of more storage space.

I originally had the default Intel cooler on my i5-760. I added a few more drives into my server/workststion (LIAN LI PC-V354B case) and the CPU started to overheat (>65 C for emergency shutdown). I looked into a few options, including the Corsair water coolers. This Noctua system seemed smaller and simpler -- I'm very happy with it. It's small enough to fit in my tight case, cools effectively, and quieter than the case fans.

This is a good, adequate USB Thumb Drive.

As numerous reviewers have pointed out, this IS on USB 2.0 and it IS on slower hardware which means the transfer speed is not blazing. That said, I never had any complaints with transfer speed. Even with 32GB capacity, I seldom transfer files larger than a few hundred MB and I had no problem with the few extra seconds I may have had to wait as compared with higher speed USB 3.

The novelty of the waterproof skin is definitely novel. To test it out, I copied some files to the drive then submerged it in a glass of water for about 15 minutes. I took it out and dried it off and was able to use the drive fine on my computer. (That said, my son had a cheap 1 GB thumb disk go through the washing machine a few months ago and it worked fine afterwards as well...as long as the internal circuitry is protected, you're usually going to be fine).

The rubber skin made the disk bulkier in my pocket and gave it added traction when pulling it out of pockets, backpacks, etc. Not a problem, just an observation. I'm not sure if it adds any "strength" or "ruggedness" to the disk (beyond just waterproofing) but the disk felt sturdy enough.

It has a nice hole for stringing it onto a lanyard/necklace/bracelet/strap/whatever.

The standard retail price is maybe a little high for the USB2 transfer speed and the capacity but the average sale price is about on target with other products.

Overall it's definitely an adequate USB Drive for your pocket sized storage needs. It seems to handle water well enough and has some added durability so if for some reason you're planning on taking it river rafting or camping, this is the drive for you.

The New Trent Airbender 1.0 wireless bluetooth case is a pretty darn good product. As with my other reviews, I will breakout how I came to the star ratings:

We start with 3 stars as a base. I gave the case a +1 star for the ease of use of the product. The case can easily be setup and will quickly connect to the iPad. It only took me around 3 minutes to remove it from the packaging, hook up the power cable to ensure it has enough power to connect, then sync the bluetooth. Pretty great in that regard. I gave it another +1 for the keyboard. The keyboard is not quite a full keyboard, but it is as close as I have ever got with a bluetooth case. Also the keys gave good feed back, and had good finger feel. So we are now at 5 stars. I did give it -1 star for the fact that the plastic enclosure and slide out stand did not feel durable. I mean kid durable. It would probably work well for a business commuter or student, but not great for the home user with kids. Since the iPad is largely a media consumption device I had to take one star off. So now we are at 4 stars.

Good for:
Students
Business Commuters
Travelers

Not Good For:
Kids
Homeuse
Rugged use

One day at work,I saw this person using a device that he inserted into a port on his computer. Well back then let's say my knowledge about computers was very limited. It was no bigger than a pocket knife, but it had the storage power of some hard drives. Of course now when you think of bytes for hard drives and certain files, it's nothing but what it is--BYTES-- Well that was the day I learned about flash drives and how important they can be, especially if you are limited on your hard drive space.  Ever since I have tried different FLASH DRIVES, but I really like the Cruzer the best. It's space designed, lightweight, can be used with one hand and most important it's very reliable with a cost friendly price. I keep several on hand just in case my hard drive crashes or maybe I want to download something to it instead of my hard drive. Keeping your information stored and logged can be a time saver when something goes wrong with your system. I know there are other ways to back up information, sometimes you just might want to carry it around in your pocket and with some backup devices that would be hard to do.It's amazing that something so small can hold so much information.  So my thinking is this---If you are just beginning to learn about computers and want additional storage without having to update your computer then get yourself some of these. They go much higher in bytes than this one, but for me this is just right for now.

I bought two of these to replace two other prior-gen Buffalo AP's. I was single band 2.4Ghz before and nearly all of my WiFi devices are 5Ghz capable now. None of my neighbors are currently running 5Ghz (suburban single family dwelling development) so it's pretty much my spectrum at the moment. The N600's are a huge improvement over what I had. Network performance marks are up across the board. Part of the attraction to the N600's is the out of the box DD-WRT firmware/factory support. I setup my AP's with tagged VLAN interfaces to distribute my WiFi network via copper (saving the bandwidth that would be consumed by traditional WDS). I use 2.4Ghz for better range/penetration and 5Ghz for closer range/faster throughput scenarios. I believe these are also MIMO 2+2.

Are there even more capable router/AP's on the market today? You bet. But these are a great buy for the money and probably more than enough for all but the most discriminating consumer (read: those bent on having the absolute latest and greatest with or without cause).

I've been using this mousepad for a month; here are my findings:

PROS:
-Absolutely no issues with mouse tracking. I have a Logitech G400, for reference, but I'm confident that no mouse will have a problem with the QcK.
-Excellent quality.
-The material feels good to the touch, with a slight texture. It is thin enough to lay flat on your desk without any noticeable raise.
-The logo is not obtrusive at all. It doesn't detract from the attractiveness of my computer setup.
-Perfect size, although this is a subjective opinion. I recommend that you draw out the size of the mousepad onto a piece of paper (12.6 in x 10.6 in) to get a good perspective of how big it is.

CONS:
-It attracts fur like crazy. I have two cats that love to walk all over my desk, and pieces of fur end up on the mousepad each time. It's a little difficult to brush the fur off with your hands, but a damp paper towel works fantastically.

The mousepad is the highest quality I've ever used -- better than the numerous aluminum and foam mousepads that I've burned through. I recommend the QcK fully. It would be great as a personal purchase or as a gift to a PC gamer or any computer user in general.

The Asus tablet is a fingerprint magnet, so this shell case works very well due to it's matte finish, that I like. I also like the color, it's a nice shade of blue. The first thing to do when you get it is carefully stretch the handle and REMOVE it! The shell attaches to the Asus with four very small tabs. Since the Asus is a somewhat heavy tablet for it's size, using the handle just means you're stressing those attach points and just asking for the shell to detach and for the tablet to fall out - it's as simple as that. My handle came off easily and as someone else noted the handle attach points do make for a slight elevation of the keyboard which is nice. I would just like to add that there is very little if any "protection" offered by this shell, the weak attach points mean that it'll fly off if you drop the tablet, so if you're aware of that limitation then go for it. I bought mine just so that I wouldn't have to constantly wipe-down the tablet after use from fingerprints and I liked the color it added better than the slate grey that the tablet ships with. Recommended with reservations.

This review is for the Dell Venue Pro 11 (model 5130) with the Atom Z3770 (aka BayTrail) 2.4 GHz (Windows: 1.46 Ghz) CPU, 2GB RAM (Windows: 1.88GB usable), 64 GB SSD (Windows: 50.3GB usable, 14GB used (includes recovery partition), 36GB remaining), and Windows 8.1. The review also includes the Slim Dell Tablet Keyboard (does not have a secondary battery), but not the Dell Active Stylus.

Background: I am in the IT field, but don't consider myself a guru on the hardware or software side. I do use Windows 7 at work, Windows Phone, and iPad Air. I feel this is important for you to know, since what I use on a daily basis shows what I'm comfortable and familiar with. An active digitizer by Synaptics initially caught my eye too, but as the reviews from DVP8 users started coming in, turns out (so far at least) to be a false positive, the recent software update seems to only make it slightly better, it is Synaptics first generation attempt so it looks like major teething troubles (in fact, between December 2013 up to now, February 2014, Dell has stopped selling it).

Packaging: I will mention the packaging because US carriers are known to drop and sometimes throw packages, so it's important for electronics. Both tablet and keyboard came double-boxed (box within a box), providing good insulation from shocks, though curiously the keyboard's box was almost twice as big as the tablet's. Excellent job Dell on the packaging, I don't think it could have been any better.

PROS:
- good performance/battery balance: from complete power off to login is about 12 seconds, sleep to wake is almost instantaneous, and orientation change takes about two seconds. Passmark scores show 538.2 overall and CPU mark of 1358. Internet Explorer, Skype, and other apps load responsively, you never get a sense that it's slow, although I haven't multi-tasked too much with it yet. Official battery life is about 8-9 hours, for my general/light usage, seems to live up to that. Heavier continuous usage with wifi I see about 4-5 hours. Battery life on standby/sleep seems to drain about 1% every hour, so you're looking at about 3 or so days of standby time. Text-based reference programs (x86) are no problem for this machine, and MS Word 2013 loads to blank document in about 4 seconds. I would guess heavier programs like full Photoshop would struggle.
- 10.8-inch screen indoors: bright indoors, most of the time I have the brightness set to 38%. At 1080 HD (1920 x 1080), text and pictures look sharp, and viewing angles are excellent. Touch responsiveness has also been accurate except the virtual keyboard.
- size/features balance: officially weighing at 1.57 lbs without the slim keyboard and a fan-less design, pretty happy with what they squeezed in physically for that weight: 10.8-inch 1080 HD screen, full USB 3.0 port separate from the charger-USB port, mini-HDMI out, and micro-SD card slot. The full USB has been convenient, being able to instantly plug in mouse, backup drive, and external CD/DVD drive.
- full Microsoft Office Home and Student edition: this means full editions of Word, Excel, Note, and Powerpoint with an activation key. I don't think the i-Core(i3,i5) versions of this tablet come with this
- full Windows 8.1: whatever is lacking in the Microsoft Store, I usually can find a free, powerful version for full Windows. Example: Sound recorder, the standard Microsoft touch app is very basic, with no control on the quality, format, or save location. With full Windows, there is Audacity. Same thing with encryption software - TrueCrypt, or PDF viewer/annotator called PDF-Exchange (this one is not free though), and so on and so on. With the power and productivity of desktop-class programs, the fact that this machine can run both (touch apps and desktop) to me is a large advantage
- consistent and decent-range wifi performance: thankfully have not experienced the wifi issues plaguing some DVP8 devices
- removable battery: I can't think of any tablet that has this (the battery is rated at 4220 mAH). I like this not so much that I would have multiple batteries, but that if the tablet is still alive and useful after several years and the battery starts to fade, I could easily replace it without surgery
- reasonable price considering all of the above pros

NEUTRAL:
- camera: 2MP front facing, Skype video renders relatively sharp and clear, the rear camera at 8MP is just ok, typical for mobile devices - with enough natural light (outdoors), pictures come out nice and sharp, indoor pictures not as a nice - white balance not that natural, blur and high noise from medium to low light (flash would have been nice). Compared to iPad Air in indoor medium/low light, the iPad Air pictures come out better, meaning more natural/detailed and less grainy.
- graphics: Games like Reckless Racing take about 17 seconds to load to start screen, Asphalt 7 takes about 7 seconds, Reckless Racing is relatively smooth but can get jittery, Asphalt 7 bogs down to about 10-15 fps and barely playable. Passmark shows 2D mark of 194.7, and only 2.36 for DX11 and 48.6 for DirectCompute. You'll have to do some research on how this measures up to your requirements, it is nice how you can play full-fledged PC games on this tablet if the graphics can keep up, but I don't care too much about games, you might.
- speakers: the speakers are stereo and there's one on each side of the tablet (along the shorter sides) about 2cm long, but they sound tiny, at medium volume voices sound thin and can distort. The iPad Air speakers are in a different league and have a fuller bass than the Dell, but for general usage and with low expectations for a device of this size, it is ok
- windows capacitive button: I heard DVP8 users complaining they don't have it, but I find I can accidentally press it and wake up the tablet from sleep, I wish it only worked after the tablet iswoken up by the power button. The capacitive button is in the middle of the long side opposite of the power button, and by default it provides haptic feedback on press. By pressing it, you go to the start of the metro view, touch it again and it switches to desktop view
- virtual keyboard: like with other Windows users, I'm experiencing repeating letters using the virtual keyboard, even though the press itself is accurate/deliberate/careful, making the typing experience frustrating. Adjusting the settings in Windows does not seem to help. My Windows Phone does not have this issue, and this is probably more a Windows thing than Dell, which is why this in the NEUTRAL section
- add-on slim keyboard: pricey, although maybe reasonable compared to iPad's smart case. Magnets work well in keeping it attached and the cover on, even when upside down. But curiously the keys are hard/smooth plastic, which does raise concern about screen contact and scratches. I would prefer the keys to have a rubbery coating and back-lighting similar to Microsoft Surface keyboards. Key travel is minimal (1-2mm) but allows fingers to rest on the keyboard, something you can't do with touch keyboards, and the \\"precision\\" track pad, although small in size, is very accurate and responsive. Unfortunately, both the keys and touchpad are not fully sealed, so it raises the possibility of debris getting in and jamming the keys. Lap typing is not a good experience because the keyboard flexes so much, to the point where any key can all too easily press down due to flex pressure. The keyboard experience on a flat hard surface is optimal and almost required. The keyboard has a built-in deactivation feature, where if it swings past ~190 or ~70 degrees, it will deactivate, which is a great idea. The keyboard has come quirks - disabled auto-orientation (locked landscape orientation), and disabled virtual keyboard when the keyboard is swung back. These can be major drawbacks when you think about it- eg. PDF viewing/editing in portrait mode with the keyboard swung back, trying to keep the orientation in portrait, trying to find the virtual keyboard when using touch apps, etc. is an exercise in frustration. Microsoft Surface (regular and pro versions) do not have these drawbacks, so if seamless operation while the keyboard is attached is important, this is something to consider. A representative from Dell in the support forums says the engineers are looking into this.

CONS:
- NEW UPDATE February 2014: un-usable rear camera: using the standard Windows Camera app to take pictures with the rear camera sometimes does not work, instead you just get a gray screen. I know physically the rear camera is not broken because strangely the video and panorama modes work. When the camera sometimes does work, it eventually causes the tablet to freeze or shut-down (crash) that day or the next. Apparently, other 5130 users in the Dell support forums are experiencing the same issue, and BIOS A05 does not fix this.
- quirky stability/bugs: search the Dell Windows mobile forums for all the bugs and stability issues one might encounter. I've experienced the Windows camera app freezing/crashing the system, battery not charging, auto-brightness being too dim, touchpad being slow on wakeup, random freezing, random shutdowns, etc. These are not dealbreakers for me, they are annoyances that mostly have workarounds and hopefully will improve over time with firmware updates. Hopefully.
- 10.8-inch screen outdoors: outdoors the screen is very reflective, also noticeable indoors depending on the light-source and angle. There doesn't seem to be any anti-glare baked into the glass, like with Nokia's ClearBlack and Assertive Display Technology. Add-on solution: 3M anti-glare matte screen protector sold from Dell, does a nice job in diffusing glare hitting the screen, but also diffuses the screen sharpness going the way. A built-in solution is preferrable since therewouldn't be this sharpness/anti-glare tradeoff
- no built-in GPS (although Bluetooth or USB receivers are an add-on possibility, I prefer a built-in option and not have anything sticking out)
- no hardware orientation lock, but you can through the software in about 4 steps
- no camera flash. To be fair, not too many tablets have this either, including iPad, but why not?
- no physical covers for exposed slots: I'm not sure of the long-term consequences of this, and I understand most laptops do not cover their ports either, but as a tablet that goes everywhere, I am a little concerned of debris going into the exposed ports. The only port covered is the micro-SD.

Tips:
- if you see a subtle screen flicker, try the \\"Intel HD Graphics Control Panel\\". Inside this program, there are two settings: Panel Self Refresh, and Display Power Saving Technology, by turning both off, the flicker went away for me
- to install x86 programs from CD, either use ImgBurn or similar utility to create and mount an ISO file, or just buy a cheap USB CD/DVD drive
- be aware that Windows has two levels of lock screens - screen lock and account lock, and both have different settings configured in different locations
- if the screen seems dim, in desktop mode, click on the battery icon in the task bar, then click on \\"more power options\\", then click on \\"change plan settings\\", and then click on \\"change advanced power settings\\". Expand \\"Display\\", and turn OFF Dimmed brightness and Adaptive brightness.
- if you're having trouble with the SDXC card, even if it's brand new, it could be the quality of the card. I purchased a new generic 64GB card and had problems with file and copy corruptions from the start, and formatting to NTFS, FAT32, and back to exFAT did not help. Eventually returned the card, and spent more for the SanDisk brand, which worked flawlessly. In hindsight, saving a few dollars for the cheaper card was not worth the hassle.

Dell sales/service: No Dell product review would be complete without the usual mention of Dell's abysmal sales/service, which seems to be consistently rude across the board, and sometimes (ok, many times) I find them hard to understand, it doesn't help that they get impatient or just hang up on you. I find with my colleagues that have used Dell products, as long as you can stay away from actually talking with someone, or if the request/problem is relatively simple, the experience tends to be better. One commenter said she got better experience going through Dell's small business channel.

Overall: NEW UPDATE February 2014 - overall rating now drops from 4 to 3 stars due to the un-usable rear camera. Overall a decent tablet as long as you can work with the bugs. Dell seems to be aware of and working on some of them, so hopefully things will improve soon. On the OS front, Windows needs some improvement too, looks like some good changes are coming to Windows 8.1 Update 1 and eventually Windows 9. In the meantime, especially on the touch side (live tiles and apps), there could be some frustrations, for example, closing an app by swiping from top to bottom and holding for a few seconds (try that in portrait orientation on this screen) is a drastic step back from the infinitely easier red X of the desktop. This is just one of many examples of possible irritations you might encounter, and combined with the almost un-usable touch keyboard, if touch interaction and refinement is a priority, would lean the review to lower ratings.

UPDATE (7/28/2014)
I've had this pen since May and have some reflections to share:

First, the IR sensor which tracks the pens movement gave out. Livescribe has been very quick and responsive about replacing the unit. If your pen starts missing strokes when you write, make sure it isn't lag and then check in with Livescribe. There is a knowledge base article that shows you how to check to see if you are having IR issues.

Second, while in general I really like the pen and have found it to be very useful, I'm not sure the Livescribe 3 was the right choice for me. I want to share my thoughts so to make it an easier choice for other consumers. I am a student and I use the pen to record notes/lectures. Lectures run anywhere from 50-75 minutes or so. This makes my pen casts very long.

I also want to be able to share the pencasts with other students. Herein lies the problem. The Livescribe 3 pen, which runs on iOS, requires that users who don't have an iOS device (which includes me when I want to replay casts on my MacBook Pro) use the online Player. My files which are > 10M don't play on this and in fact Livescribe recommended that I record 1page at a time. I haven't tried this yet to see if it works, but I'm not sure I want to be thinking \\"Is this a good time to start a new recording?\\" when I'm in class.

If you use the Echo (USB transfer) or Sky (Wifi transfer), this is not a problem as the player is part of the desktop app. Therefore, if you are a student who wants to record pen casts to share with students who may or may not have iOS devices, I recommend going with one of the other models (and from what I've read of wifi model, I might stick with the Echo.

I'm still not increasing the stars to 4, until I get the IR issues straightened out. But I'm hopeful that in a few months I will be able to increase the star rating on this. It has a bunch of potential and I'd really like to see the product succeed!

The ADVC110 from Canopus is a great little device that lets you import all your old analog video into your computer.    Once you connect this device to your computer via the FireWire cable it is seen as a standard FireWire device and is treated just as if you had connected your modern camcorder to the computer. Within your video editing program you capture video just as you would normally, except that instead of the capture program being able to control playback you will need to manually start the playback on your source device (VHS VCR, 8mm camcorder, etc.).     Connecting the unit is easy. Simply plug your analog source into the standard RCA ports (or use optional S-video for the video portion) and then connect the fireWire cable between the device and your computer. Optionally you can connect things in reverse and use the FireWire as the source with the converter changing your digital video into analog (I guess if you want to output your digital video to an older TV). I have not used the device this way.    My main use for the ADVC110 is to import lots of old VHS and 8mm tapes that I had recorded throughout the years into my computer. From there I am simply archiving the video files to external hard drives. This is great because now I can easily review tons of records straight from my computer with instant access instead of searching for tapes, rewinding them, etc. The video files are standard DV format and take up about 13GB of disk space per hour.    So far I have imported about 100 hours of video with this device and it has worked flawlessly!    There are two things that the ADVC110 did not come with that I had to purchase separately: An AC power adapter and a 4-pin to 4-pin FireWire cable. This may not apply to you if you are using a Mac computer or a desktop Windows computer, but for my Lenovo laptop they were required. Why? Since my laptop only has a 4-pin FireWire port I had to buy the 4-pin to 4-pin FireWire cable (Canopus includes other cables in the box, but not this particular one). The problem is that 4-pin FireWire cables do not provide power to the device, so you then need to connect an AC power adapter to the ADVC110 in order for it to turn on. Once you have this setup and working everything is fine, but you should be aware that you need these two extra items if you will be using a 4-pin FireWire port. Also be advised that the AC adapter is quite expensive for what it is (search Amazon to see).    All in all this is a fantastic device if you are serious about capturing high quality video from analog sources.

Really, if you need a lighted cover for your Kindle Touch, this is the only one to bother with. It's certainly the only one where the light is powered by the Kindle battery and that's the whole point of it I think.  It locks your Kindle in nice and tight (it's not going to fall out on it's own) and looks very smart.  It is not poor quality like some other reviews suggest. It is very well made and looks quite streamlined and upmarket.  I guess as with anything, the leather may show some scuffing in time. A leather protectant or periodic polishing may help if you can be bothered. If you want something crazy robust, look for another cover.  The light swings out to illuminate the text adequately and it's neat how it's built-in and powered off the Kindle battery.  I guess it does make the Kindle a fair bit heavier but nothing unmanageable and it would be better if there was a strap or a magnetic closure to keep the front flap shut. If you're concerned about this, it would be a cinch to make a strap to go around it out of elastic.  I went for black, just couldn't commit to a colour sight unseen.  My only real gripe is that Amazon would not ship direct to Australia so I had to use a parcel-forwarding service (highly recommend boxvoyage.com) and literally the day before the cover arrived, I received an email from Amazon saying they now ship Kindle Touch and it's accessories to Australia. I used this mouse extensively for about 2-3 months, by extensively I mean used for gaming on my HP Dv9000z. The retractable cord function is great, and the cost was very low. However, the cable used to connect the mouse is very thin, and after repeated extending and retracting, it became loose somewhere along the line (either in the retraction, or at the mouse, or at the USB port). If you are planning on using this mouse from time to time, its a great option, I'm sure under normal usage just traveling or in meetings it would stand up quite well to the task, however under heavy usage... choose something else. The responsiveness of the mouse and the ease of moving it were great, as I said I used it for PC gaming as a cheap laptop alternative to using my Bluetooth Logitech MX1000 mouse which is too laggy for gaming.

I just purchased this laptop from Best Buy yesterday, and I'm pleased so far with the results. I was a little apprehensive about making the switch to Vista 64 bit, but so far, so good. I've only found one HW item so far that I've had trouble with -  a little $10 USB travel mouse. So far, all other software and hardware has worked fine in Vista 64 (most importantly, my old games).      I haven't run into any issues yet, just the typical bloatware that was installed on the PC by gateway. One other annoyance with the scroll function on the mousepad. The right area is dedicated to the scroll function, and it's not quite as responsive as I'd like, but so far, that's my only complaint about this laptop (one that I'll not have to deal with once I get a compatible USB mouse).     I have played both Titan Quest and Age of Empires 3, with the detail cranked all the way up, and while I had to dial back a couple of the settings, the laptop has performed admirably well. I haven't had a chance to load any FPS games yet, but feel that I'll be able to run those at medium settings.

There are just a couple of things I don't like; one is the mouse pad which doesn't have a separate button so I often accidentally zoom in on google maps (since I have one finger on the "button" and one on the other hand "pointing"). The other thing is I almost always have the audio "headphone" jack plugged into my home stereo, and I am startled by a loud buzz when the book goes to sleep or turns on, or at other times (it happens fairly frequently) and is really unsettling. And I guess a third thing is I do have to limit the number of tabs (pages) open, or I get the "he's dead Jim" message. On the whole though, I'm very happy with it. I use it to read, often when it isn't plugged in, and the battery life seems fine. The screen isn't nearly as good as my 15" laptop, but it's so light and easy to travel with (around the house or out-and-about), I am really glad to have it. The keyboard is fine, only the mouse pad, lacking keys which aren't also part of the pointer surface, is the only thing I'm having to struggle with (and the loud buzz).

I shopped around a lot for the right tablet for a long time. Years in fact, all I knew was that I didn't want an ipad. But in October I finally got down to saying right, time to get one. So I was pretty sure that I was going to get a Samsung Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 32gb but I couldn't find a 32gb on amazon that didn't come with a bundle of some kind. Which might be great for you but the offer I saw I didn't like. Then the other 32gbs were Tab 2s. And the Galaxy Note 32gb was too expensive and I didn't want to spend that much or need all of the processor. In fact I could only find the Tab 3 16gb for 399 and it went on sale for 299. So I had resigned myself to that. Then I found the Asus MeMO Pad FHD 10.1 32GB and it was priced at 299 on sale for Black Friday. It had the same chip and the 16gb Samsung tab 3, but double the ram and the storage. So it started to become a no-brainer. It had the removable SD storage, dual cameras, a Micro USB port and a Micro HDMI. And that pretty much sold it. I checked out some online reviews and the machine seemed like it would be fine and it is. It's my first tablet, and it does what I expected it to do, browse the internet, play a youtube video, connect to the cloud and allow me to read a book. I have not tried to play a movie yet but I don't expect that will be an issue. The speakers are great, clear and loud, good sound. The apps all work especially the ones I wanted. I have no complaints.

I will say that patience in waiting for Black Friday, waiting for android 4.2, doing a lot of reading and reviewer research really helped me to make a decision on this tablet. Great purchase, I would recommend it.

After reading all the negative reviews I was thinking about returning the product before even trying it, but I'm glad I didn't. I have to state that I'm not using the drive for anything else than as an easy way to share data between all my systems. I know that there are lots of cheap cloud storage sites that could do the trick but I like the idea of no monthly cost and no size limit on data transfer. The drive has been great for me. I have two Macs and 3Pcs mapped to the drive and copying data between them has never been easier. My files are large but I'm not backing up my entire drive so transfer speeds are fine for me.   To set it up for my needs I just called customer service and they were very helpful. I just explained what I need and they told me how to map the drives and avoid using the provided software. All in all I am very happy with the drive and would recommend it to anyone who has similar needs.

EDIT: First I gave it a 1 star because of this: When I got my G51JX-A1 everything was ok. The mouse is cool and the backpack looks good too. The computer is awesome, it really is, but after using it for about 5 hours I got a BLUE SCREEN OF DEATH (BSOD), I updated the nVidia drivers and that was the end of that error. About 3 hours later it started FREEZING constantly, but the temp was ok and I had not too many programs open. Everytime it freezed I had to turn it off pressing the on button for like 5 seconds, then it turned on fine... The freezing became more constant and I couldn't even use it for 10 minutes straight, then it came the WORST, It doesn't even turn on now, just gives me a black screen and that's it. One time it turned on fine and I managed to update the BIOS with the latest version, it did it ok, when I restarted the computer I got on the BIOS information and in fact it was the version I updated it to. It turned on fine, got on windows, 5 minutes later it FREEZED AGAIN, that was the last time it worked... I called Asus, they gave me a RMA and I'm going to send it back to get it fixed, however I don't live in the USA and I'm here for vacations only, after they send it back I'm gonna have to pay like 150$ to get it send to Venezuela and that's not on Asus...    Good luck with yours, but give it a try and search \\"Asus freezes\\" or \\"G51JX freezes\\" on Google before buying, that might help you reconsider...    EDIT: My New 5 star review would be after this: I contacted Amazon and in one day I got a replacement laptop for the one that was bad. The one I received worked great... Great Laptop for real! I bought this modem as a 2 for 1 situation.  Previously, I was using a Motorola SURFBoard for Internet traffic and a leased modem for telephone traffic through Comcast.  The leased modem cost was about $7 per month.  So, why not buy a modem with the capacity to do both.  I had researched to determine if the Arris was capable with Comcast prior to purchase.  The modem was easy to connect to existing cables.  However, I had to make a direct connection to the data source in order to provision properly.  Eventually, I used the online Comcast capability to provision and once completed, both Internet data and telephone data were readily available.  It's a bit costly, but will save over time.

Awesome value!

**** 3 Month Update ***

My initial review remains the same. This case is holding up well, as is the keyboard. I've never had the battery run low, I charge the keyboard as often as the iPad, every 1-3 days. The keyboard actual feels better as time goes by, since I get more and more accustomed to the feel of the keys. I would recommend this!

*****************************************************

Initial review:

The keyboard paired easily with my 1st Gen iPad, within 2-3 seconds. Previously used primarily as a media device for music and movies, I will now be adding a touch of productivity to the device. Within the first hour, I found myself reviewing productivity apps to view and edit Office files. And with 4 different corporate emails from 4 different companies, this will make keeping up with emails MUCH easier.

Imagine getting this much use from a 4-year old original iPad...!

The value in this purchase lies in the LOW discounted price,,, $22, if it was priced at it's original cost of $69, I would agree with other reviewers and purchase another item. It's seems well-made, but also inexpensive-made. Only time will tell how reliable this will end up being, but at $22... there is no doubt about it's value.

An advantage is that you only have to log in once instead of separately for each device.

I haven't read a book for enjoyment in years.  I read so much required material at work that by the time I get home or when I'm traveling I find myself not wanting to read.  I've been looking for the right book to inspire me to read for enjoyment again and instead of a book to inspire me it was the Kindle.  It peaked me interest so I started researching e-readers and found that I didn't want a stepped down version of an iPad,iTouch,iPhone, or small laptop, all of which I own.  All the other e-readers out there seemed to be some sort of version of the aforementioned.  I also didn't want anything that reminded me of reading on a computer screen. I wanted something that's only real function is dedicated to the written word.  I decided on the Kindle for that reason and after downloading all kinds of free classics I found myself excited in the books I purchased as well.  I'm finally reading for enjoyment again.      The pages on the Kindle looked so much better by far than any other e-reader I looked at (which is basically most of the e-readers on the market today).  The words on the Kindle seemed to pop off the page without looking like it was a computer screen.  All the other e-readers seemed like it was on a computer screen.  The battery life as stated far surpasses the competition as well and so far it hasn't disappointed me on that claim either.  My friend has a Nook and needs to recharge his battery at least once a week.  I can go multiple weeks without charging my Kindle.  I also bought the leather companion case with LED light in the corner and couldn't be happier with that purchase as well.      Maybe because I can carry a variety of books with me all at once now and have many options is what rejuvenated my spirit.  Either way I couldn't be happier with my Kindle because I have finally found a way to get me a way from the Internet, TV, and other distractions for a little while each day.  I never thought the day would come when I would start reading for fun again... That day has finally come.

This keyboard has a comfortable feel, but I prefer my 7-year-old original Microsoft Natural keyboard, as Microsoft has really fouled up the layout of this one.
The "home" and "end" keys have been moved, the "delete" key enlarged to twice its original size, and the "insert" key is entirely missing. What's more, the F keys have been replaced by Microsoft Office control keys (open, save, undo, print, etc.), and if you want them to act how they're supposed to, you have to manually turn on "F Lock" each and every time you boot--this key cannot be controlled by software! (There is a registry hack for Win2k/XP that can effectively disable "F lock" on the PS/2 version, but if you're using USB or another OS, then you're up a creek.)
It's a shame Microsoft had to add these annoyances to an otherwise good keyboard.

The earpods aren't like the normal plastic but a velvet like cloth material that does a good job of being comfortable and canceling out noise around you so you can hear your team or chat without outside noises interfering.  The swivel earpods are nice for storing them and if wrapped can easily keep your cord from getting entangled.  You can turn on or off the mic by a switch on the earpod. I don't play online games on PC much but when I do I like to keep the mic off until I need to use it so this makes it a little hard for quick on and off function without messing up the game, but if you play with the mic on all the time then this will not be a problem. I watched a movie on them also just to see how well they could be used as earphones and I was pleased makes the movie loud and crisp and keeps outside noise out.  Will be using these for both movies and when I play online.  One last thing I will note because in the past most PC headsets say only PC but will hook up to the PS3 I tried them on Xbox and PS3.  I tried to hook them up and as most headsets will configure to the PS3 this one would not so this is strictly a PC headset.

I purchased this battery about a year ago and have had nothing of problems. Then, after discussing the issue with a friend, I discovered that this battery is counterfeit. The first indication of trouble was the fact that the battery did not fit as smoothly as the original and had to be "forced" into the socket. After fully charging, everything seemed to be fine at first, but I noticed quickly that the capacity did not last nearly as long as the original battery. Often times, this battery would overheat and swell, making it difficult to remove from the socket. After only a few months of use (normally on the charger because of the low capacity), it now continues to charge even after the computers say it is at 100%, and the laptop immediately loses power if the charger is removed. I've been looking online and found that I am not the only one with this problem and that this is in fact a counterfeit battery, meaning that it is constructed of inferior materials and only made to look like a laptop battery.
I am very lucky this battery has not exploded or caused a fire.

There were cheaper Cat5e cables out there, but I liked the thinness of the wire and that it's future proof for 10 GB LAN. The cable slips below my door and it's hard to trip on. So I recommend this cable and $%#%# wireless. PEACE!

The service is ... used just like standard landline in 98% of uses.  Ooma gives the owner a choice of telephone numbers, so I chose a metropolitan number outside of my home region.  The service produces high quality voice transmission and reception.  There are quite a few call handling features including \\"smart\\" options for forwarding to other land lines, cell phones ... how, when, what to and not to forward.  Call blocking has been useful ... a couple calls had be received from acquaintences of the former assignee of my phone number, so I set up a persistent block.  Frankly, I should recover the $140 hub price with ca. 6-months of use.      My rating would be 5-star were it not for the disappointing technical service program.  The people are trained to handle simple setup questions.  In the end, I would have been fine if Ooma offered better setup documention and dispensed with tech support.    Incidental Note: The hub was designed for a direct WAN connection through a DSL modem with dynamic IP address assignment.  Since my subscription employs a block of static IP addresses, I dedicated one address to the Ooma hub, and connected it to the internet via a network switch.

After spending a fair amount of time trying to set up a hub-based USB charging system for two iPhones, two iPods, an iPad, a cellphone, and a Bluetooth headset, I found that the USB 2.0 standard limits the power to any single USB port. Technically, for normal USB 2.0 use, a port cannot supply more than 2.5 watts (5 VDC nominal x 500 mA), a number that barely works for the iPhone series. Thus, no matter how much power I provided through the power input connector for a powered USB hub with seven connectors, the individual USB port circuitry limited it to something that would not charge any of the iDevices. That right: NONE of them.

Enter the XMultiple connectors. These connectors apparently use the little-known specification for \\"charging only\\" USB service. This provides up to 9 watts (5 VDC x 1800 mA) of power by placing a 200 ohm resistor across the D+ and D- pins. (Thanks to Wikipedia for finally making this clear to me.)

The end result is that all of my devices now charge simultaneously off the dedicated multiport powered hub. Power to the hub is supplied through a 12VDC battery source (our off-grid house battery bank) running through a heat-sinked 12V-5VDC regulated voltage converter, which never even gets warm.

There's nothing out there that is commercially available yet to charge multiple devices, but this workaround does the trick. I bought four of the connectors at once. They're well built, match Apple's USB cords very nicely, and simply put, they all work.

I purchased a Toshiba M45-S331 on Feb. 2 at Office Depot for $1299.99 after rebates.  I got it home, and fell in love with it instantly...until I decided to try out the wireless.  I had my power features set so that when I was on battery it switched to the maximum life mode and when I was on AC it was the Maximum performance mode.  I was walking around the house wireless surfing the internet - no problem....until I plugged my AC back in.  The machine locked up hard.  No ctrl+alt+del...no nothing....it was froze.  I called it a glitch and cut it off and back on.  I was working on battery, and plugged it up again while surfing the net and it hard locked again.  I assumed I had a bad laptop, so I returned it to Office Depot on Feb 3.  I took another one home thinking surely that it wouldn't do this....but it did.  I was also able to duplicate the problem on the one on display at Office Depot.  It seems as long as you don't have your wireless turned on...it will do fine going from battery to AC.  As long as you don't plan on wirelessly surfing the net and plugging up to AC at the same time, it should be a great laptop.  One side note - this was the only toshiba model that had this problem that Office Depot had on display. But...I decided to try my luck with Sony so I ordered one today.

Of course, there is no substitute for paper, crayons, paint, etc. to invoke your child's creativity. The touch of paper, the smell of crayons, the feeling of dipping your fingers in paint...Awesome! But when that activity becomes the love of your child's life and laundry becomes a daily activity for you, you need a substitute to supplement that passion!

The Chalkee is a standard stylus in a comfortable to hold rubberized body. Though designed to look like a crayon, the body is thick like a sidewalk chalk. It fits well in the hands of a dainty 3-yr old. The Chalkee is well constructed and will hold up to a child's abuse.

We had downloaded some finger painting apps on the iPad for my 3-yr old niece, but she hardly ever used them. For some reason the concept of virtual finger painting did not seem to appeal to her. But she got hooked on the same apps when using the Chalkee. The Chalkee is precise, sensitive and versatile - she was able to select the right color from the color palette as well as use broad strokes to paint in the picture within the lines. The Chalkee did seem to jump in some small areas, but that was due to some food or other residue on the screen. It worked fine when the residue was cleaned up.

A little pricey at $15 (a couple of free apps can justify this cost!), but worth it for all the time saved in cleanup and laundry!

Pros:
* Good product dimensions enable ease-of-use even for dainty toddlers
* Stylus works! It is precise, sensitive and versatile
* Comfortable rubberized grip
* Durable - holds up to a child's abuse

Cons:
* Slightly expensive at $15
* No included apps
