To be clear, this is a review of this particular laptop and not Windows 8 or the box store I purchased it from (both of which are fine - better than fine , actually). There is a lot of hating on Acer that goes on on-line, and I thought, how can a laptop be that bad? It's got the same Intel processor and Microsoft software as all the others, why not get this one that is so much less expensive and does all I want?

In the interest of fairness, I will say, I wanted so much to love this laptop. It was lightweight, had the cool 360 degree thing all the way to tablet mode, and the touch screen is absolutely the way to go with Windows 8. The problem was that it didn't work, and in subtle ways at first. The laptop was always unresponsive when booting up. It was necessary to hit enter or whatever key several times before getting to the login screen. Then, when switching to tent or tablet mode, the touch screen would become wonky - only letting me type in caps, opening a million new browser windows, or not working at all. Each time this happened, returning to normal laptop mode did not correct the issue, and a restart was required. So after a few days of this, I exchanged the laptop at another location (which was easy to do because I was well within my 15-day return policy period) for a new one - same type. The new one worked okay for about 5 weeks. I say "okay" and not "great" because there were still little issues - the unresponsive keyboard at startup, the "g" key not working properly after a couple of weeks, the issue where I couldn't connect to my wireless router when I returned home from being connected at work and had to reboot to make the computer connect. Finally, these little issues were overshadowed by the touchscreen ceasing to work at all. I had not really been trying to use it in other modes - turns out it's an awfully big tablet and not very appealing to use in that manner - but in simple laptop mode, it would work and then itwouldn't. When it didn't, the driver would disappear completely from the device manager. A chat with Acer support had me update my bios, which made things better for a couple of days, but then back to the nonworking touchscreen and the disappearing driver. Acer support chat had me do a factory reset (be prepared to give up a day to back up your data and then do the reset), and after that, the driver didn't load with the Windows software. After updates, it did load, but then there were the same issues in tablet and tent mode as with the first laptop. They told me I would have to mail it in (with at least a 3-week wait time) for repair.

I went back to the box store (that I believe this model is specifically made for), despite being well past the 15-day return period, and since I had already been in for a touch screen issue, they let me exchange the machine for an entirely different laptop. There's also a lot of hating on the internet for this particular store, but I can only say nice things about their customer service. Anyhow, two laptops both with touchscreen issues, purchased in two different states, no less, indicates that that is an issue with this particular model. Add in the wireless connectivity issues, the flimsy keyboard, and the slow boot, and it's clear that this is not a well-made computer.

I purchased the NextBook tablet because I wanted an e-book reader that did a little something extra. I've had the tablet for a month, and I don't have many complaints. The Wi-Fi quickly and easily connects to my home wireless network. The graphics are good, and the tablet works with all kinds of apps. I was a bit disappointed to learn that the Google Marketplace wasn't installed. However, I easily overcame that problem by transferring apps from my Google G2 phone to the NextBook tablet. You can easily transfer apps from your phone to the NextBook if you have an SD card and the Astro browser app. The tablet also plays YouTube videos. It's not good for playing games though, aside from a few simple card games.

UPDATE: YouTube recently made it necessary to have Flash in order to view the videos. This change happened at the beginning of March 2011. The NextBook NO LONGER shows YouTube videos because the NextBook does not support Flash. This might change at a later date, but as of March 2011 you cannot watch YouTube videos on NextBook anymore.

I first loved this card reader. As a professional photographer, my time is important. Taking forever to download files is not good. Now that I use both CF cards and SD (in my Nikon D7000) and am shooting video as well as stills, this card reader seemed to be the one to get. I have only one issue with the card reader... the SD slot works only once per computer one/off cycle. After that, I either have to reboot the computer, or unplug the card reader and replug it in for each time I insert a SD card. When I sent Lexar an email explaining the situation, they told me to \\"zap the P-ram\\". No problem doing that, and it worked again... once. Then, the same issue. I sent Lexar a follow-up and got no response from them.   Don't get me wrong, this is a very fast card reader, and I really enjoy it. I just wish:  1. I didn't have to go through the hassle of unpluging it and re-pluging it in each time I use it.  2. I wish Lexar would have sent me a new one to see if that was the issue. After having the kindle fire for a little over a year I decided to buy my 4 year old daughter her own kindle. I have not been that impressed with it. The great thing about it is that my daughter has really learned a lot about spelling, reading and sharing with others. I do like the ability to set how long she uses each option. The kindle camera takes pretty good pictures. It doesn't hold a charge as long as my kindle does. That could be because she sometimes leaves it running. While having a year free subscription to FreeTime is totally awesome (it really is) the fact that she can click on multiple apps at one time uses up the kindle memory. So I am constantly having to make room, archive apps or just delete them. As for durability she and her sister have dropped the tablet numerous times on the tile and so far it is fine.

I've had this very long term it was originally bought for me but became the property of the kids it's been dropped slammed around banged around and it always works fine in fact we've only had one problem with them the charging port (amazon replaced them a bunch of times out of warranty) if amazon had put a better charge port it'd have been the perfect tablet way back when. So if you can still get one of these and don't mind it being out of date on everything and if you can get at a great price it be good but don't pay too much because you might end up having to replace the usb port or the whole device as old as it is.

All I can say is wow, this RDA is amazing!! I'm pretty sure this is the real thing, even has all the factory original markings... "MADE IN USA", "Kr" logo, all that! The machine work is on point, and the sliding action for the air breather holes is smooth as butter! I literally ordered another one of these "clones" from another site, and it came with only the "454" marking (as expected) which typical of a clone. This unit is quality material, and quality craftsmanship! I'm running a triple coil with Plat-24 wires (couldn't seem to fit four through the main post to do a quad coil setup), but it works great!! Shipping to San Diego was less than a week, stoked! My only complaint about this 454 clone compared to the other 454 clone I got, is the adjustment screw on the bottom. This one has adjustable screw, the other with "454" only does not. I prefer not having to mess with a set screw, but both work and do the same job. I will recommend this to others for sure :)

I had forgotten how Dell mistreats its customers. I bought the convertible for travel use since it had  enough RAM and hard drive memory to use Photoshop Elements 13 on it. I had forgotten how much bloatware and even malware Dell loaded on its computers. First I had to uninstall Mcafee, which I feel should be classed as malware. It was the usual battle but I got rid of it. Then the Face Access program started downloading itself. When I tried to uninstall it I found it almost impossible (at one stage the only option the screen gave was to continue to install it, there was no cancel or go back button). After searching online I found how to uninstall the Dell Digital Delivery and Face Access. Now the tiles on the start menu don't respond! I can open them but I can't change the order. My only hope is that Windows 10 might deal with some of the problems, especially since Ballmer has finally left (I had never seen a rumor of a CEO leaving drive share prices UP). I will certainly never be buying anything from Dell again/

This router was easy enough to install and seemed to work well at first. I had two computers hooked up hardwire to the router and three computers using wireless. After a couple of days ALL of the computers were showing signs of slowing down and then they all started to lose their signal....including the hardwire computers!!. I was very surprised and disappointed as was my wife. She spends time playing Farmville and it became impossible to play because the computers were so slow and kept dropping the signal. Soooo.. The speeds are livable, absolutely no dropping of signal..... and best of all.... the wife is able to enjoy Farmville again!! Very disappointed with this product.

Typing on an iPad Mini is arduous at best. The virtual keyboard is small and without tactile feedback, trying to type anything at length is very difficult. I know all the cliches about the iPad being \\"designed for consumption of content,\\" but I've done a lot of real work on my full sized iPad with no real issues. Sadly, it's harder with a Mini, especially when I want to touch up a document or tap out an email.

I ordered this keyboard as a way to do just that. It fits very well and I have to say, even though I've had issues with wireless keyboards in the past, this one was reliable for me. However, and this is a big caveat, the dimensions of the keyboard are still pretty small. I know it has to be compact to fit with the form factor of the Mini, but it's still a little difficult for me to type on it. Doing regular typing was out for me, so instead I resorted to finger-thumb style typing. It works, but I'm not sure carrying around the extra bulk of the case is worth it.

That all said, the product is great quality. The keys, though Chicklet style, are enough to give you positive feedback when you're typing. It also does double duty as a stand, so if you want to place your Mini on a table and watch something, there you go.

This is a good product if you simply *must* have a keyboard that fits the footprint of the iPad Mini. I kind of wish the keyboard were a little bit larger, but all in all a good product.

Without this device, we usually get 1 to 3 bars for the wi-fi at most RV parks, difficulty maintaining connections, and poor performance.  With this device, we usually get 4 to 5 bars, a solid connection and acceptable to great performance.  We've had no issues with our Windows 7 laptop.  We've not had good results with our Apple laptop using the latest operating system (officially not supported) which is why I'm giving it a 4.  I'm not sure where the 10 mile claim comes from or what it has to do with anything.  At most RV parks, we are generally within a 1/4 to 1/2 mile from the nearest WiFi source and this works great for that use case.  It also works great if you are in a mall parking lot near an establishment, e.g.  Starbucks or McDonald's, with free WiFi.  Can't beat the price so if in doubt, give it a try before going with more expensive longer range solutions you might not need.

I asked for it for Christmas to replace my Kindle Keyboard that was starting to fail. I just love the new one. It is everything I'd hoped for. It's thin, light, user-friendly, and I was able to get a nice cover/stand for it.

While I, too, have had some problems with this unit, I still believe it is a good value. I had this thing up and ready to go in a matter of minutes due to the plug n play capability. I had the previous software, "My CD", at the time. The CR-R supplied with the burner failed to work, prompting a call to HP. I was getting the "high speed media" error and not too happy about it. With the technician's help (we all agree they need an 800 number) this was solved by simply going into "options" and telling it to NOT perform a write speed test. Then we set the write speed at 1X. It seemed to work, but I was having quite a few disks fail during burning, so I called back. This time checking the system performance was done and the whole turning off all startup menu programs. But I would not deal with a product that forced me to turn off my antivirus software and decided that if it took this much trouble, I would return the 8230. I have since discovered that if I simply reboot my system prior to burning, even with all startup items intact, that I have no problems burning either data or audio CD's. You may say this is not ideal, but I find it to be a small inconvenience for a sure thing, instead of a possible coaster.
Yes, it is slow, but I don't need speed and am totally uncomfortable with installing anything on my computer. Since updating to "Record Now" software, I have not turned off the write speed test or checked the write speed, but have not had trouble with data CD's and I think my son has been burning audios. We use some WalMart bulk CD's with no problem, as well as anything on sale.
For the price (I got mine cheap on a well known auction site) and two phone calls, I still rate it a four.
I returned the item because you can only run programs purchased thru the chrome store.  I couldn't run my work program which was my sole reason for purchasing this item.

At the time (one year ago) this seemed like the best deal out there. I needed a mix of USB 3 ports for external drives and drive caddies, plus a couple of ports for a mouse & printer that I left at my desk.

Problem 1: if I boot with the SIIG hub attached, my notebook's fingerprint reader is blocked. Doesn't even show up in the hardware list. Unplug the hub & power cycle the notebook, and all works well. It's a poor-man's workaround.

Problem 2: Now it's dead. This morning, no lights. Moved it to three different power outlets...nothing. It's not quite 12 months, and SIIG claims it has a 5-year warranty.

Unfortunately, it's not easy way to make a warranty claim. There is only an online form requiring you to look up everything and type it in manually. They can't take the microsecond to print \\"P/N\\" and \\"S/N\\" on the equipment, and leave no clues on the form to decipher the information. I'd call it poor customer service, but I'd also blame manufacturing. What manufacturer would print multiple strings of numbers and letters, but leave no indication of their use?

If yours dies too, the part number is JU-H70112-S1. The number in the middle is the serial number.

I've babied this. It's always plugged into an UPS with power conditioning. The line voltage from the building is always between 119-121VAC. A power supply should last more than a year.

Good news...you'll get an automated acknowledgment of your RMA request within minutes. Let's see how long it takes to actually get a replacement.

I bought this card for one purpose: To put SD TV from my office satellite box in a window in Vista. It works fine for that. But I would echo what others have said: Only after installing the newer drivers from Happauge's Web site. Upon initial install, the unit offered only herky-jerky, unwatchable video. The new driver took care of that.     Since I live in an area with no direct OTA digital or sd tv channels, I'm using it exclusively with a DirecTV basic satellite box. So I can't speak to the efficacy of the tuner, or, for that matter, the remote control, which is superflous to me because I simply tune channels with my sat box. But it does provide smooth, pretty sharp SD TV to my Dell Latitude 2.2 gig dual core with 8 gigs ram and 256 MB ATI video card.    Note that to hook up the unit with a satellite box, your box needs a video out (such as S-video) and audio out jacks to feed into the card. Note also that this card will NOT give you HD channels through a sat box, as it has no HDMI or composite inputs. But I didn't expect that for the price, and HD TV in a small screen window seems sort of a waste.     The WinTV app is a little annoying, but it works OK. I tried to set up this card through Windows Media Center, but the setup wizard would hang everytime it tried to link the tuner to a Media Center remote, and I don't have a Media Center remote. Dumb, with no workaround apparent. The software does recognize the tuner, however, for those of you who do have the full whiz-bang Media Center setup.    Also, the audio from the card through my onboard PC audio system is excellent. Overall, I'm pleased that I can junk my clunky old office TV for fifty bucks or so.

We've been waiting nearly two months to get the power cord replaced!    We bought an Asus EeePc for my 11 year old son in mid-October 2009. He was so excited to have his own computer.    After a week, the power cord failed. We called to get a replacement. It was supposed to come in a week, that turned into another week, and then a month. By then, amazon's one month return had passed because I lost track of the delay.     It's not mid-December, and we still don't have a charger. That's going on two months.    My son asks just about every day when his computer is going to work again. I call Asus every few days. They keep telling me that we'll be getting a new power cord in a few days, but they can't tell me when one will ship or confirm when new power cords will be in stock.     This is my first Asus. And my last. I've had computers at home and at work from Apple, Dell, IBM/Lenovo, Gateway, Sun, and a few other companies. Never have I had a runaround like this. Check out all the other complaints about the power cords for some models. And check out the complaints on the delays.    There are other companies that make inexpensive networks. I'm sure any of them have better support than Asus. I'm sure these work great for some people. But why take a chance that you might get one of the defective power cords and have to go through this hell.

I used to love this router. When it was new, it was fairly reliable for a while, although it was always under a very light load. Typically that meant one laptop, one phone, and occasionally an additional device when I had a visitor.

Now, it is regularly supporting 3 phones, a tablet, 2 laptops, a Nest thermostat, and a WeMo Insight switch.

I'm not sure if it's the load on the device (which shouldn't be overwhelming, at a count of ~8 max) or specific compatibility issues, but I'll say this--I have had such pain connecting the Nest thermostat and WeMo switch to the Netgear N600 (WNDR3700) that I have since added a second router as an access point specifically for the Nest and WeMo. Now I'm connecting an Amazon Fire TV Stick and having similar problems. Switching the Fire TV Stick over to my new wifi access point also (a separate physical router), almost all of my problems have gone away with these devices and their connectivity.

One possible problem here is that I'm connecting these devices to my 'guest' Wifi. I should explain here that the N600 has the ability to separate a primary wifi network from a secondary guest network--in my case, I use the primary to enable connections to my NAS, so the guest wifi cannot access my secure files.

Overall, I've spent enough time trying to forgive this device, because I wanted to like it. However, the poor quality firmware combined with the frustrations with some of these newer devices has me looking for a replacement sooner than I previously anticipated.

Let me start off by saying that I bought this computer to replace my Acer Aspire One D255 Netbook which has a single core Intel processor running at 1.66 GHz and 1 gig of ram. "Annie" my little Acer has served me well but since I am getting back into photography in a big way I need a better computer. What I was doing to edit my photographs was using my Android tablet which has a 1.5 Ghz dual core processor as well as 1 gig of ram. So you can see why I needed a better computer.
Now about the computer................I like it, it is refurbished which makes me feel better than buying one that is used.
The color is Black which is okay, it does have the 3D pattern.
It does have the Intel Pentium P6200 dual core processor, it does have the 320 gig hard drive.
It does have Windows 7 Home Premium 64 bit.
It was advertised has having 4 gigs of ram but.........................came with only 2 gigs.
I had ordered it to be shipped overnight, it came on time despite the horrible weather that hit the Northeast around the time I ordered it.
When it arrived I did a very basic setup (WiFi) and then let the computer update itself, after which I went to bed got up at midnight and spent 9 hours using a Flash drive moving the files I needed from "Annie" to my new computer, it was after that, that I found out about the memory, I talked to the seller (Oh I was so upset) and they did refund me $50.00 and for that I am grateful.
The computer came very well packaged and with the exception of the memory I am very happy with it.
It has a beautiful display, the screen size is just right for me, the keyboard has a nice soft touch, in other words you do not need a 100 lb. sledgehammer on the keyboard to type.
If it was not for the missing 2 gigs of ram I would give it 5 stars.
I already taken it to a computer shop and it will cost me $25.00 to have the other 2 gigs of ram installed which I will take care of next month.
The bottom line is this.....................It is a good computer and despite the 2 missing gigs of ram I am happy with it and I am glad I bought it.
So if you are looking for a good (very good?) computer then this Dell computer might be "your cup of tea" (a little British Lingo there).
Nothing is perfect, you could buy a brand new computer that might die with in a month.
You can buy a brand new computer and find things about it you don't like, so instead of looking at the "empty" glass realize that even the "empty" is not empty it is full...................with air.he bottom line is this.....................It is a good computer and despite the 2 missing gigs of ram I am happy with it and I am glad I bought it.

I bought this system to play music vst's in a live setup and to edit video.   As for playing music this system is plenty powerful - when playing a number of VST modules live there is no latency problem. I use a bluetooth mouse to control it and there are 5 USB ports to go to my audio interface, controller keyboards and dongle etc (without a hub).. the lighted keyboard is useful in low light and the large 17.3 screen makes things easy to see with the computer setting above my two keyboards on my delta stand.    I have yet to edit video on the system but my first tests indicate it is very capable of this task and I edit full HD Blu-ray quality video at 1920 by 1080 resolution which is native to this laptop.     So far the system has been equal or above the performance of my AMD Quad 3.2 GHz desktop system (which is expected from an i7 chip vs the AMD)  I was disappointed that the Raid 0 did not make the drives in this system faster. And the drive speed is the rate limiter on the Microsoft performance rating. I assume this would be a great system after swapping out the two drives for solid state or hybrid drives.  I can't comment on its gaming power but I assume since it does well on music and video tasks it should also perform well for gamers...   Bottom line: Really good powerful system lots of features, excellent keyboard which can handle audio and video tasks with ease at a really really good price point.

I've had my Toshiba for two years now. I have been very happy with it. It's the smallest screen size I've ever had, so that took some getting used to initially, but I can't even tell it's small anymore. As other reviews have said, it has a sharp screen, good memory, and fast processing. Best of all, it has a DVD burner. For the price at the time, I feel this was the best deal I could've gotten. I have had few problems with it, other than the power cord, which goes out on all laptops. Compared to my previous Sony Vaio which costs twice as much as this, I have had gotten way better, uninterrupted use out of this little laptop. (My Vaio was constantly in and out of the shop.) The only complaint I have about this laptop is that the battery didn't last long. It needs a new one but I'm not going to replace it. I recently installed Windows 7, which I am not happy with on this laptop as it runs slower now, so I suggest sticking with XP.

This is primarily used for streaming movies (Netflix, Vudu, etc.) to our TV from our wireless router in another part of the house.  This replaced a Hawking Range Extender, which constantly needed to be rebooted through a cable connection to the router.  The setup was easy: in fact, so easy I thought I must have missed some steps.  It is streaming HD quality video without any problem.  We have had a couple of power interruptions and it reconnects to the router without any special attention (unlike the Hawking).  After 3 months, I would have to say that we are 100% satisfied with this unit so far.

I received a Kindle for Christmas. I am a constant reader and love books so I was dubious about using a book reading device. I am now sold on the Kindle. I take it everywhere and find it easy to use. There are many sites where you can download free books.  Of course these books are really old, out of print or not well written. I am now reading an old Andre Norton and it is entertaining but dated.  The only drawback came when the screen developed a problem.  I contacted the Kindle customer service people and the representitive was great.  Within a few days I had a replacement Kindle with free shipping to send back the problem Kindle. I have downloaded a book while a passenger in a moving car (3G) and downloaded a book in a wifi spot and it is remarkably fast.  I would recommend the Kindle to anyone. It does not have color but neither does the books that I used to read.

The measurement from the rear mounting point of the cage (2.5 to 2 9/16 inches). So those of you with small cases or cases or a lot going on in them now you are able to know if you have enough depth to mount this. You will need another quarter inch or so for the power cables and SATA connectors (right angle). When the HD's are mounted they are flush with the back of the cage. (See the picture I uploaded)

I have this mounted in a HP xw8600 (Dual Quad-Core Xeon) The bottom drive has just enough room to clear the fan on the top CPU. The front cover however is another story. You can mount the fan into the stock face-plate on the xw8600, the springey clips on the fan fit right in. The power contacts are too far apart though. To fix this I removed the contacts and fancy stuff and just hard wired the fan's power. Not as \\"clean\\" as what was intended by the manufacturer but it works.
It does the job and easy to install.

I received the item quickly thanks to Amazon Prime.  I setup my monitor and started to use it, but the control panel seemed to have a slight delay in responding.  I ignored this at first, more excited to try the monitor out.  I used it for a few hours and it looked sharp and the color was nice with movies and games, but then I wanted to turn it off as I left the room and it would not respond.  I tried other buttons, but none of them were responding at all, so I just unplugged the monitor then plugged it back in.  I tried the controls and they all responded accurately and I could use them without any issues.  After I figured things were ok I shut off the monitor and left to do other things.  I came back and then the monitor wouldn't turn on or respond.  I had to unplug the power, plug it back in, then it worked fine.  I watched a few shows, then went to turn off the monitor and AGAIN, the damn switches wouldn't respond.  I got fed up and returned the monitor because this is a major deal breaker for me.  On another note during on of the shows a pixel decided to get stuck on bright green which was rather annoying as well, but not a reason to return the monitor since there needs to be at least 5 pixels before it's considered defective.

Just got this laptop 2 days ago thanks to amazon prime shipping.    I needed a small and light laptop with some juice and purchased this laptop.    Pros:  -Sandybridge CPU, very fast and snappy.  -G520M with optimus. I love this technology, as it saves a lot of battery. You can choose what program to use with the discrete or integrated video card. I've only tested counter-strike source and I got up to 150fps, ranging around 50-70 average on High settings!  -Keyboard looks very nice and clean and feels good to type on  -Not too heavy, something you can carry around with you.  -Build of the laptop is very good, wish they would put the same material thats on the palm rest to the case. (Oil resistance)  -Battery life is VERY good! So far I get around 8 hours (Surfing, Gaming, Install programs, Movies, Brightness at 30-40%)  -Touchpad is good, but clicker attracts oil!!  -Nice and quiet, no vents on bottom, doesn't get burning hot.      Cons:  -Speakers are very dull. No clarity at all, nor its loud. I can live with it but would prefer to have headphones on.  -Resolution is at 1366x768, but it looks fine on at 13\\" laptop. Viewing angles arent great and can't really see outdoor.  -Finger print magnet on the cover.  -Webcam could be better.  -No USB 3.0  -Not 7200RPM HDD like advertised  -ASUS BLOATWARE      So far I'm satisfied with my purchase, battery life is good, moderate gaming when needed, sandy bridge, build is nice and its not too heavy. I plan to use this laptop for some business work/ personal entertainment. If you can deal with the cons, this laptop is for you!

Pros:
802.11AC coverage is fantastic. My computers get great signal through several walls and the bandwidth is awesome.

Cons:
Apple, in its infinite wisdom, decided that SNMP wasn't worth keeping around and removed the feature. This means that technically advanced users can't monitor internet usage or other stats from the access point.

Conclusion:
If you don't need SNMP, buy this router. If you do, buy this router anyway, but keep your old one on hand to use as a primary gateway so you can still get most of what you need.

This tablet mount works ok. i use it to mount my Kindle Fire on the extended arm of a mic stand. I would rate this mount higher if the clamp wasn't so very heavy.

The clamp is long, about 6\\", and heavy. About as heavy as the tablet. I mount the Kindle at the end of an extended arm from the stand.

This means that, due to the weight, to prevent the mic stand's arm from slowly arching down toward the floor I must tighten the grips on the stand to a point where it is difficult to loosen them.

To prevent over tightening the grips I have wrapped one end of a Velcro strap to the opposite end of the extended arm and wrapped the other end of the Velcro to the stand's main pole. This prevents the arm from dropping down.

Not a very attractive solution. But it works.
It has occurred to me that wrapping the tablet with Velcro directly to the stand and putting the mount in a dresser drawer might also work.

The problem is actually much worse! My own case ended with 2 IDE disk start to smoke and burn out as soon as I plug then in this dock. For any one that received the 6pin power adapter version, this will be the same result for you! Do NOT plug any 3.5in IDE disk in this dock. It WILL burn it. There is a design defect that the 12V power is not controlled by the switch, which means if you plug your 3.5in IDE (PATA) drive in, there will be a 12V between the 12v and 5v input! This will kill your drive, and if you leave it in for more than 3 second, there will be smoke!

It's a great little keyboard and mouse, but some of the reviews say it comes with a Unifying Receiver. This is total hogwash. It doesn't come with a Unifying receiver, nor will it work with a Unifying receiver. Otherwise, I would have given it five stars.

I gave this memory one star because I didn't use it.  Why didn't I use it you ask?  Because the friendly folks at Crucial told me it would not work in my newly purchased ASUS 1005HA net book computer. UPDATE: Along the lines of please don't try this at home, it seems this reader is washer-safe. I forgot that I had it in my jeans pocket and put the jeans through the wash. Full cycle including a high-speed spin dry in a front-load washer. I figured it was a goner after I found it, but I let it dry for a few days and then tried it out (with an old SD card that held no data of any value). It works! It's a bit scuffed and smells a bit like Tide, but it still reads and writes just fine. The manufacturer makes no claims about water resistance, and certainly nothing about being washer-safe, but this little guy can take a punch. The cap didn't even come off in the wash!

Original review:

I'm very pleased with this SD card reader. It's very nicely built - feels solid and able to hold up to getting bounced around a bit in my travel bag. Good quality plastic with rounded edges so you don't stab yourself when you carry it in a pocket. I especially like that the cap over the USB port fits tightly so it won't come off unless you want it to. Granted, I'll still probably lose the cap in a few weeks as I usually do, but until then it does the job of protecting the port very well.

There are two side-load slots for SD cards (one for regular, one for micro SD cards).

Installation was non-eventful. Just pluged it in and in a few seconds Windows recognized it. I used it on XP (SP3), Win 7 32 bit and Win 7 64 bit machines without any problems. Although it is a USB 3.0 device it works just fine on a USB 2.0 port.

The speed is excellent. I timed copying a directory of 400+ jpgs with the following results (the camera was a Panasonic Lumix; the same SD card was used for all):

Direct connect the camera to the PC = 1 min 39 seconds
Reader built into my monitor = 1 min 21 seconds
Pixelflash reader = 44 seconds

Excellent speed, good construction quality, simple installation. Can't ask for more than that!

This card is absolutely fantastic. After having to settle on playing nothing but old, dated games on my computer's integrated graphics, I finally gave in and decided to look into getting an actual graphics card for my computer. After an entire day of research to try and determine what would be the best price/performance upgrade I could get, I finally settled on this.

Nothing more was required than a simple unbox and plug-in to my motherboard. This card runs any game I throw at it like a dream and doesn't require anything more than a 300 watt power supply.

I can play literally any game I can buy on steam on max settings at 60 FPS. This card boosted my system so much that I honestly haven't touched my Xbox since the day it arrived. I've just officially canceled my Xbox Live subscription and have happily moved entirely to PC gaming after buying this thing.

If you're looking for a graphics card that uses low power and provides insane performance for a medium-low price range, there's probably no alternative.

First, I consider myself fairly computer savvy, but despite multiple attempts with different cards, I was not successful in getting this card to work consistently with several Linux distros or Win XP.

I saw the average 4+ star rating on Amazon, and was excited to find a card that would allow me to use Puppy Linux 5 and above, Ubuntu 10 and higher, Linux Mint 10 and higher and Win XP Pro wirelessly on my Compaq Presario 2195us laptop (vintage 2004). Many reviews stated that Linux worked great out of the box. The stock Broadcom BCM4306 worked great with Win XP, but failed at the Linux distros. I didn't want to use ndiswrapper, fw cutter, fuss with command lines, etc. Broadcom cards have been a problem with Linux. I have another laptop using an Intel 4965 card, which connects to Linux out of the box. My thought was that there was better Intel support/drivers built in the Linux kernels.

I purchased several Intel 2200bg cards in a package at an unbelievable price with the intention of selling the extras.

Installing the card was super easy. After shutting down the laptop, removing the battery, loosening 2 screws, removing the small back cover, popping off the antenna wires, releasing 2 latches and popping out the Broadcom card, then installing the Intel card and doing everything in reverse, I was ready to go. It took all of a minute or so to replace the card.

I excitedly booted up the computer and tried out several linux distros and later Win XP.

Puppy Linux was a flop. The card was recognized, but it took several attempts to get a connection. I have a couple other desktops and use USB wireless dongles on both, and Puppy/Ubuntu/Mint connect effortlessly. Not with this card. Then, onto Ubuntu 10.04. No luck. My wireless network was recognized, but after typing in the wireless key, no joy. Finally, Linux Mint 11.04. Of all the distros, this connected to the wireless decently, but the connection did drop and I had to reconnect. I did not have this problem with my wireless USB's on my desktops. Overall, my experience with Linux was disappointing.

Next, I tried out Win XP Pro. I downloaded the latest driver from the Intel website, and installed it. Originally, I used Network Magic as my wireless utility. I could not get a connection. I uninstalled Network Magic and used the native Windows wireless zero configuration utility to connect. It worked a little better, but it took a couple minutes to connect. However, the connection was inconsistent, and there are dropped connections. Sometimes, when I put the laptop to sleep and wake it, I cannot get the card to reconnect.

I tried several cards to make sure that I wasn't using a faulty card.

Finally, I replaced the Intel card with the original Broadcom card, and then booted up Win XP. Right away, I got a connection within 10 seconds. The connection has been rock solid. The Broadcom is excellent for Win XP on this laptop.

I'm very disappointed with this card. For linux, I will use a wireless dongle for this laptop despite my preference for a mini PCI card.

First, this product arrived on time and, although roughed up by UPS, worked fine. Packaging was very good and all items were undamaged. Saitek quality is very good and the yoke and throttle quadrant work fine, although it was much more difficult to use than expected. There is no manual supplied with the equipment that is useful and the manual for the SST programming software is useless.  I have another Saitek input device, the x52 fighter stick and throttle which have been in use for a few years along with Saitek drivers and their SST programming software. Being somewhat concerned that I would have a conflict with the older system when I installed the new yoke (they would be used for different sim software and not at the same time) I attempted to contact Saitek tech support as shown on their website. The phone was never answered, the email server was constantly having \\"connection issues\\" and the \\"official forum\\" is closed to new registrations. Support is presumably provided by Mad Catz something or other.  Installing the new software provided with the yoke was a disaster. None of the profiles developed using the other version were recognized, the new software is much more difficult to use, one reason being that none of the button assignment numbers in the software templates match anything provided by Saitek, so you have to guess. I finally managed to create a profile for Flight Simulator 2004 but the program refused to use any of the commands. It also broke my other stick so I had very basic use of that. I wound up removing all the new software and drivers and reinstalling the older version for my fighter stick and got that working again. I then had to manually assign commands within FS 2004 for the yoke and throttle and have that working, but without the programming capability due to the older software not being aware of the newer yoke.  I would buy this product again, but just aware that you are on your own with faulty software and non-existent support from the manufacturer.    As an update, after a week of frustration trying to get this to work correctly and getting no useful information via support email I have returned the unit to Amazon. The throttle quadrant refused to work in FS2004 and I could not get one button on the yoke to program. In addition, doing a calibration within FS would reprogram the entire unit with commands from some source I could not track down.

Giving my 6-yr old autistic grandson a Kindle Fire was worry-free thanks to Square Trade's protection plan. Here are a few tips using the SMC Barricade SMC7004AWBR wireless router and WEP. I have a pre-Airport and pre-G3 Powerbook and an iMac SE. I wanted an alternative (read cheaper) solution than Apple's Airport Base Station.
The iMac came with an Airport card pre-installed and has since been upgraded to Airport 2 in OS X. I also recently acquired a Lucent Technologies Orinoco (formerly Wavelan) Silver PC Card from Agere Systems, which offers 64-bit WEP for my Powerbook.
The most challenging aspect of setting up the WEP security is getting it to work on each hardware device. I'll explain the three steps it will take to get the above configurations working. We're still using Macs, so it's relatively painless once you know how. The steps below assumes you're familiar with the wireless aspects of your hardware and that you're not yet using or haven't figured out how to enable WEP using your SMC router.
Step 1 for the router: Access your SMC router via your web browser on any Mac using a hardwire Ethernet connection and click on the last link in the left pane, "Wireless". In the main window, under Wireless Setting, select a name for your wireless router in the space next to Network ID(SSID). The next item, Channel, can be left alone. The item after that is where you set your WEP Security. In my case, since the PC Card in my Powerbook uses 64-bit WEP encryption, I chose the "Enable IEEE 64 bit Shared Key security" option for the router. Now choose "WEP Key 1" and enter a Hexadecimal string of 10 characters (you can only use the numbers 0-9 and the letters a-f). I try to come up with a nifty pass phrase to help me remember the string, which may prove challenging using hex. In our example, let's use decade2010. Save your changes and reboot the router.
Step 2 for the iMac: In either OS 9 or X, invoke the Airport Setup Assistant. The assistant should detect your SMC wireless router now. In OS X, you'll get an Enter Network Password dialog box where you'll need to enter the hexadecimal string you came up with in Step 1. But in order for it to work, you have to enter a dollar sign ($) before the string. In our example, the network password that will work with your Apple branded Airport card and the SMC router is: $decade2010
Step 3 for the Powerbook: Open the ORiNOCO control panel and click on the Encryption tab. Click on the Enable Encryption check box and next to Key 1: enter a zero (0) and the letter "x" before the string in Step 1. This lets the Wavelan card know you'll be transmitting using a hexadecimal string. In our example, Key 1 will look like this: 0xdecade2010 (don't forget to set the "Transmit using" to use Key 1 and then click on Set to save your changes). If you click back to the Basic tab, you should see Closed Network for Network:, and your router's name for Net Name: which you set up in Step 1.
This setup works flawlessly for me and I highly recommend this non-Apple branded hardware.
The SMC wireless router has a printer server port and a serial port if you want to add your old 56K modem to it. This is good if you have broadband and it goes down. I've only tested this scenario and I pray to the Wireless Goddess that I never need to invoke it! It also bridges AppleTalk, which is awesome for printing to old laser printers that have Ethernet, but don't support TCP/IP and for easy file sharing. The USB Printer Sharing in OS 9 works great too.
The Lucent wireless PC Card is actually an Apple Airport card, but Lucent of course adds the antenna. This card is compatible with any Powerbook with a PCMCIA slot in it (even the 5300 and 190 series!) using Mac OS 7.5.2 and greater.
And best of all, SMC and Lucent support Mac users while many other non-Apple wireless hardware vendors do not.
Have fun in the wireless zone!

I have an HP G62 notebook, nothing fancy, but keeps me in touch.  A couple of months ago, this laptop began behaving in a very peculiar way, not always but a lot.  I could not scroll through on-line pull-down menus, Hulu+ play stuttered and jerked in full screen mode, and even the operating system would not allow me to scroll through some lists of programs, files, etc.  Online research yielded varied results:  some people had re-installed their computer from scratch, others had purchased new mice, Kensington's in particular.  So, I ordered the Kensington wireless mobile with the nano receiver and I called HP help.  When the tech got on my computer by remote, since even he had the same difficulties with the features same as I did, I began to think it couldn't possibly be the mouse, and was wondering if I should even open it.  My current mouse was a Logitech laptop mouse with a nano receiver.  I did the system recovery myself and might have saved myself the time, because, although improved very mildly, the same problems continued to occur and get gradually worse again.  So, when the Kensington mouse arrived the day after, I was very curious to see what would happen.  Lo and behold, the Kensington mouse \\"healed\\" my notebook!  Amazed, I experimented.  As soon as I pull the Logitech nano receiver out of the port, and put in the Kensington, everything, and I mean everything, that didn't work, works perfectly!  As soon as the Logitech nano receiver goes in, problems!  Not all is lost with the Logitech however, it works great as a game mouse.  I just have to remember to take the receiver out as soon as play ends.  Now I think the problems began when I installed an HP game, but even after uninstalling it, the problems remained, probably because as with so many uninstalls, stuff gets left on or alterations made remain.  Anyway, the best part of all this is that I find the Kensington to be an EXCELLENT mouse in its own right; a very functional and stylish mouse, it fits my hand well and it is VERY portable.  Plus, it has a great feature in that it turns itself off after not being in use for about 10-15 minutes, saving on battery drain!  I thought I would be a little mad to have paid a few dollars more for it, but not at all! I LOVE this mouse and will buy Kensington again and again!  Definitely worth every penny and I recommend!

The back screw hole is lined up flush with the heatsink blades, meaning you have to push the screwdriver against the heatsink. Save your money and find another heatsink.

A big plus for me is that this set up is wireless. I am weary of dealing with wires.

The mouse is surprising accurate and comfortable. The blue center button caters to windows 8 by bringing up the start metro menu -- if you're into that.

I don't much fancy the peripheral num pad, I hardly use it. But that brings me to my next point: when you push the keys in the num pad, the whole thing jiggles as if not on an even surface (it is).

The same thing with the keyboard. But if you distribute the weight of your wrists just right, you can get away from the jiggling.

It is ridiculous to have a portable power supply that requires using a 110 volt ac outlet and a proprietary charging cord to be charged. If I have a 110 volt outlet available, I do not need a portable power supply. I returned it and purchased a different brand that is charged using a standard micro SD input plug that can be charged by any USB connection. That means I can charge it while I drive, or a 110 volt outlet, or even my portable solar panel.

Update May 20, 2013

I am using three of these power supplies for different projects. What is of most interest probably is that it is an exact replacement for the Toshiba Satellite C675 S7200 laptop supply. By changing the connector I was able to use one to power a Samson S amp (head phone amplifier) after the power company destroyed the original wall wart.

Finally, I use two to power a very fussy prototype scientific amplifier-synchronous rectifier that measures very low currents around 0.0000000000001 Amps. If something needs 19.5 volts regulated DC at less than 3.5 Amps, try this power supply first before considering something much more expensive. Device to be powered should have filter capacitors as this supply is well regulated but is not fully filtered.

The second and third units were purchased in 2013.

Despite being made in China, they seem well built and don't get overly warm at near full load and are stable at a 35 milliamp load as well.

These run very well on a simulated sine wave inverter. Input power to the 12 volt inverter is less than two watts when the supply has no load, less than one watt for the inverter and likewise for the HQRP supply. Overall 12 volt to 120 volt to 19.5 volt conversion loss is around 15 % on average. Some other power supplies do not function well on simulated sine waves, making this a vital piece of my power backup kit. Ideal for solar power apps.

Our grandsons love the Nabi 2 we bought them for Christmas 2013. During that time it quit working and the vendor replaced it because it was within the One Year Warrantee period. I recently asked if Nabi had a way for grandparents and parents to send/receive messages to/from their children/grandchildren on the Nabi. They do, but it ONLY WORKS for versions AFTER the Nabi 2. The feature is called Nabi Konnect and the parents/grandparents use an app called NabiGator on their smartphones. So, like most products with "planned obsolesence", you have to either buy a Nabi 2S (~$9 more than the Nabi 2) or the Nabi DreamTab (~$40 more than the Nabi 2) to get this valuable "communication capability" (Nabi Konnect).

Therefore, I would recommend that anyone buying now should minimally get the Nabi 2S or ideally the DreamTab if you want a device with pen-stylus drawing capability.

This is my first Fire, so please bear in mind that I cannot contrast/compare to the Kindle Fire (traditional). I have numerous other Kindle e-readers, and work with numerous other Android and Apple tablets on a regular basis.

First impressions - when it arrived today, it looked very sleek. Well-packaged, easy-to-open (unlike reports of the Nexus 7). No power plug, but I have it charging as I write this using a standard USB charging kit. Please note that if you plan on charging this device, you will (preferably) need a USB power adapter that supplies a full 2 Amps of current (or better). Otherwise, the unit will take forever to charge. And by forever, you can just check the FireHD's site out - 13 hours. Yeah. More than all night. No thanks. :) I personally believe that not including such an adapter was a wise cost-cutting move on Amazon's part... many of us already have a 2A charging adapter from other tablets/etc, and it cut $10 off the cost of the unit (or $20, if you didn't buy Amazon's special charger when you ordered the FireHD). By the way, my particular FireHD came charged to 68%.

The size is perfect - it's got a good, solid feel, as well. Not too heavy, but heavy enough to let you know it's not a toy. The back is a nicely-textured matte finish. I don't like larger tablets that much, since it obviates one of the major advantages of a tablet in the first place (mobility). At iPad/Transformer sizes, I start to wonder why the person didn't just have a Netbook or regular laptop.

Setup: The FireHD comes, as all first-bought Kindles should, pre-registered to your Amazon.com account. After power-on, the device asks for a wireless network, a timezone, and (optionally) Facebook/Twitter integration. That's it. Then it gets to the carousel/shelf interface and is instantly linked to your account's purchases. All my latest books, music, and videos were there, even those purchased earlier today, along with a Kindle Fire Welcome Guide. The device automatically updated itself after the first sleep I put it in.

Incidentally, before the device arrived, I had pre-registered to remove the ads, for $15. From what I have heard on other Kindles, the ads are actually not very invasive or annoying, and actually can help pay for the Kindle over time through reduced prices or coupon offers. Me, I prefer an uncluttered and un-advertised-to interface, so I opted out. I think it was absolutely excellent of Amazon to offer this option in response to those who wanted out of that, but I would have been fine with them being there if there was no option to turn them off.

Screen: The screen is gorgeous. Here, Amazon has learned from its competitors, who on their tablets used an application where the LCD panel is laminated/applied directly to the back of the cover glass. This allows the FireHD to have a clear, crisp screen no matter what the viewing angle. When I first powered the unit on, I cringed for a few seconds because it felt like the screen was too small - like I would feel cramped. This, however, was absolutely not the case, once the Kindle was active and into all the content, it was very open and inviting. I can only imagine how big the 8.9\\" would be!

In terms of usability for the touch-like nature of the display, this is the best tablet thus far I have ever used. Even light presses register properly. Many other tablets I've used are very particular about how hard you need to press or linger before registering. And yet, even with the \\"hyper-sensitivity\\" this device has, I have yet to have it register anything false (wrong button pushes), which are another hallmark of other tablets. Bravo, Amazon.

Apps: The fire comes pre-loaded with OfficeSuite (a free version of a larger suite for editing documents), the Silk web browser, a Calendar, and various other supporting apps for things like Email, Contacts, IMDB, and Help. I like that they kept the initial load relatively free of bloatware (MOTOROLA: TAKE A HINT PLEASE!!!). I personally do not like the lack of some applications on the Amazon App Store... for instance, I would have liked to load Firefox or Chrome, but they are not there. Also, a link for Skype is on there but the app is not pre-loaded.

Books read well on this, and this being my first Fire, I like the interface for reading books, though I definitely prefer e-readers for eyestrain reasons. It's nice that the FireHD has text-to-speech, especially since the PaperWhite lost this functionality (which I think was a great move; that device is an e-READER, not e-audibleprovider). The three backgrounds should help users with some of the eyestrain for limited periods of reading.

I have not yet connected this to my corporate Exchange servers, and quite honestly I may not bother. But it's nice to know that's an option. Email for Gmail works well, with an occasional \\"stutter\\" to the interface while it's loading something from the web (see my comment in the next paragraph for Performance). I doubt I will do much email from this device, but again, it's nice to know that it's there, in a pinch.

Performance: The processor is fast. It's not perfectly smooth, but reasonable. The vast majority of the lag, from what I have seen, revolves around network operations. Basically, if a screen has to load an image, or some other content, from the Internet or Amazon, the device can, and will, \\"stutter\\" occasionally. I guess there could be adjustments done to the interface to avoid this, but the fact is that to me, it isn't distracting from the experience. Temple Run and various other games run very smoothly on the device. I know it's about to sound harsh, but I would expect nothing less from an Android 4.0-based device. :)

The storage (I got the 16GB version) is adequate for what I will use it for - mostly media streaming from the Web, plus some locally installed apps, games, and side-loaded books. Anything else will be on the Cloud. If you're a heavy movie watcher and want them loaded on the device itself (perhaps you would use this on a bus or commuter train), you may want to wait until October for the 32GB version; the $50 difference would be worth it, then.

Wireless: Out of the box, Bluetooth is disabled (which is a good thing, don't want anyone hacking our precious new toy, now do we?). Since I have not been able to get Flash, I cannot benchmark the wireless (TWCable and Speedtest.net use Flash). Huh, now I know what it's like to use an Apple product. :) However, all file transfers happen as fast as most other wireless hardware I have around the house, and video streaming of HD looks crisp and clear. Video playback looks clean and the controls are easy to use.

Buttons/Interface: I don't like where they placed the camera on the device. I personally think it should be on the other side, so that the camera is \\"up\\" when put in a case that allows for stand-up (though, this might be my case - but I don't see how they could have easily engineered around it). The camera provides a good, clear picture for video conferencing after a brief Skype test, and appeared to operate fairly well in low light, which is encouraging for me, since many areas in my house aren't adequately lit (hence my additional order for a Kindle PaperWhite :)). The interfaces on the unit are the speakers (which are decent, but don't expect huge bass or amazing sound from tiny speakers), USB and HDMI out (THANK YOU AMAZON! The HDMI interface, ALONE, should sway folks to this platform over other tablets!), the headphone jack (which is well-placed, not too near a corner and not recessed as early iPhones were), and the power and volume rocker buttons.

Quite honestly, the only poor thing about the device is the power and volume rocker buttons. They are flush with the chassis, have little gap between them and the chassis, and are the same color as the chassis (black). This means that, every time I sleep the unit or adjust volume, I'm squinting at the top of the Fire to figure out where the heck the buttons are. While it is, technically, possible to \\"feel\\" your way to the buttons, it's impractical - since the volume rocker buttons have a tiny raised edge which \\"announces\\" their presence, but they are not differently-sized (smaller nubbin for \\"lower volume\\", larger nubbin for \\"increase volume\\"). I think that, in time, the power button will be easier to find, since it's smack-dab-in-the-middle of the top, but for now, it's kind of a hunt, especially with a case on. I would have preferred a raised button. But believe me, this is a very minor complaint on an otherwise excellent interface implementation.

Here's where the \\"religious war\\" starts. First off, I refuse to compare tablets purely on a hardware basis as, inherently, a contest of \\"this one is best.\\" That's a technological no-win situation. Also, I firmly believe that, as a technology, tablets (of all kinds, not just the FireHD), since their inception, have been a solution looking for a problem. They are jack-of-all-trades, master of none. They are neat gadgets, but in and of themselves, they cannot do a tenth of what an average Netbook or laptop computer is capable of, and with current price points for decent laptops in the $400-500 range, it's hard to justify a tablet based on hardware alone. And I'm glad that Bezos and others at Amazon \\"get\\" this - I can't tell you how many friends and family members I know that own tablets, and never use them - because they want a keyboard and mouse.

Here's where the FireHD shines. I think that the perfect niche for a tablet, where it can have a chance to be a \\"master\\" as opposed to a \\"master of none\\" - is in the singular application of being a multimedia consumption device. When a user wants to read a book, listen to music, watch a movie - they want a simple, point-and-shoot interface. And a tablet provides not only the interface, but the mobility.

Conclusions:
I feel that the FireHD is really what tablet users should be looking for. We should be looking at a device that provides easy, mobile access to an ecosystem of rich media, with features and accessibility that make it easy to use and enjoy. The Amazon ecosystem is amazing - having been a Kindle e-reader user for years, and now a Prime member with all the media perks that entails, I love how the media I purchase is available anywhere, on any platform. I think this device is a perfect complement to that experience; especially with the HDMI-out and Bluetooth capabilities, which allow this device to be a multimedia powerhouse at home or on the road.

The only \\"downsides\\" I see in this device are the slightly-difficult-to-address buttons, the lack of an option to remove/disable the carousel, a Collections for Books feature (after 100 books, it's tough sometimes to organize things and find what you want to read), and the ability to set a custom screen background while on sleep. Since three of these four are software-based, I'm hoping they can be addressed in future software. In the meantime, these do not significantly impact my enjoyment of my device.

Anyone seriously considering a tablet, especially one that takes full advantage of the Amazon ecosystem, should be considering this device. It is solid, performs well, and has a rich set of features that a $199 price tag makes all the more amazing. I think that, for $200, you would be hard-pressed to find a better way of enjoying Amazon's content offerings.

(By the way, after finishing the typing of this review, the device is at 92%, which is awesome charging speed. It's great, again, that Amazon doesn't force you to use their chargers, unlike SOME OTHER manufacturers. :))se will be on the Cloud. Great battery life. Bluetooth pairing works seamlessly, even with my Android phone and Ubuntu laptop. You can select the keyboard backlight intensity (3 levels, plus "off") and color (white, blue, cyan, green, yellow, red, magenta). The magnetic alignment of the iPad holder and the keyboard hinge is convenient.

Keys are obviously smaller than a full-size keyboard's; but are comfortable enough for e-mail typing with medium-sized hands and much faster and more comfortable to use than an on-screen keyboard.

Cons: the protective frame is thick (which makes accessing the volume, rotation lock, and mute buttons and charging port slightly awkward). The delete button is much smaller than on other keyboards.

Needed to replace my [[ASIN:B000P6J64K Adesso]] that died. There are few wired keyboard-touchpad combos to choose from, so decided to try this one figuring I could handle the lack of plug-n-play several people warned about. I was mistaken.

The keyboard worked fine after plugging in the first time, but the touchpad didn't work at all. Still didn't work after trying the suggestion to remove other mouse drivers (Logitech and Adesso on my computer). Then googled \\"usb browser mouse driver vista\\" and found a solution to install the generic microsoft driver for it.

So the touchpad worked, but only for a brief time before acting erratically then becoming completely unresponsive. I tried plugging it into all USB slots but still unresponsive.

Will be returning this and use a stand-alone touchpad plus regular keyboard.
Hard to get on completely smooth.  Peel up too easy and are therefore unaffective after a couple uses.  Wish I'd never wasted my time or money.

I got this screen protector and i was not happy initially because there were some smudges on the screen. The company informed me that there were two cover slips that needed to be removed one before putting it on and one thereafter. They even offered to send me a replacement unit. I tried what they suggested and it worked very well. People complain about the bubbles but putting on the screen protector requires steady hands so if you have issues i suggest you ask someone to assist you. These things are fantastic if installed right. In any case i had to return the kindle because it had some issues and Tech Armor representative refunded the entire amount of the purchase. This is exceptional customer service and i will be buying screen protectors from them in future. All in all i recommend the product and commend the vendor for being responsive to customer needs.

This is a good cover for an iPad. Reasonable price with nice features, i.e. stand to hold iPad at an angle.  Don't really need the strap and iPad doesn't seem to shut off completely with the cover closed.  But the cover is very good and substantial.

I got the Fire HD 7 as a Christmas gift and I love it.  I like that I can read books anywhere, play games with family that live far away, look up things in any room of my house. I don't know everything I can do on it yet but I am learning! So far nothing negitive.

Leather doesn't last for ever.
touch screen is a little glitchy when trying to use a stylus It is probably due to too many processes running in the background as is typical of Microsoft operating systems.

I really like the illuminated keyboard.  I chose the setting that illuminates as your hand nears the  keys.  Saves energy and still very useful. The mouse  works on  almost any surface and is comfortable in my hand.  There just isn't anything that  I dislike enough to downgrade from five stars.  Given that there are lots  of cheap keyboard alternatives this combo may be considered expensive. It seems like good value for the money in my opinion.

Nice, compact, solid little desktop which is small enough to be mounted out of sight. Seems to be perfect for and HTPC but we have implemented three of these as workstations on our network for users who don't need a powerful computer.  I am not saying that this computer wouldn't have been sufficient for a power user-  I haven't used it enough to be able to say how or if it's performance suffers under heavy processing loads or when the ambient temperature is warmer, like it is in summer.  But we have many users who only use the computer for very basic functions, like internet browsing, word processing, email, and the occasional spreadsheet.  These users could function well with an eight year old computer, if necessary, so this is more than adequate for the,.  Also, the chassis is accessible enough to be able to easily change out RAM and hard drives, when needed, and is Very configurable.  For example, my company deals with personal health information which is protected by law under HIPPA laws, so we have been concerned about the possibility of someone taking info out using a USb flash drive, for example.  The BIOS config allows the admin to disable all USB ports and to limit access to other ports in other ways in order to lock down these vulnerabilities.  Although this is certainly not a new feature, it is not one that I have seen integrated in such an easy-to-manage way.

Used with: Nexus 10
Main use: writing/notes, quick sketches for diagrams (all work related)

Programs:
Navigation on Android KitKat, Papyrus, 'Notes Mobile' aka MyScript

Pros:
-Very fine and accurate
-The weight feels great to use
-Screw on cap to protect the head
-Easy to see what your 'tapping'/drawing
-Feels very natural and comfortable to use.

Cons:
-No clip or anything, so is kinda loose and rolls around everywhere (thankfully my case is magnetic and it sticks to it)
-Though extremely accurate, it feels as though a quick 'tap' or swipe will not register and you had to press firmly

Notes/Comments:
Some programs work better than others with different styli but on the average, what can be a little annoying is that sometimes when quick writing down notes, you have to redo a part because it didn't catch the whole bit. This can be a little infuriating as it breaks concentration. I have found that some programs, like papyrus, are less prone to this but still happens from time to time there and in navigation. I have another stylus (cheap rubber head one), though it is not as accurate by a long shot, it does not do this.
Purchased as requested for a gift for someone.  They love it and it works great to protect, have a stand, and gives the iPad mini a great look.  Great price for what you get.

I like it, it defiantly is a great 'in-between' for my lap top and phone.
I love how easy it is to get books! One of the only downfalls I have to say about it is that Instagram isn't able to be downloaded.

Bought the mouse last X'mas (Yes, I'm one of those sad people who get their own presents); it is definitely a step up from the generic Logitech mouse that I had been using (around 1000 DPI).

The mouse is cool looking, with nice flexible cord, and an awesome fit for my large palm. I try to use it with Claw grip (not my natural grip, but they say its better for accuracy) - and got a real bad wrist pain very soon, so I switched back to palm grip, which is extremely comfortable using this mouse. Every shape and bump is designed to fit my palm perfectly when I use palm grip - which is weird because Razer website recommend claw grip on this mouse.... Perhaps for someone with giant hand?

Clicking speed is lower than generic mouse. Definitely not for spammer. It is also dependent on Razer's software - Synapse 2.0 - to function on windows. When the Synapse is down or failed to detect the mouse, it stopped working at all. The plus side is that my mouse is working without acceleration even on Windows 7 because the software override windows' mouse acceleration setting.

It is definitely a solid, basic gaming mouse. Large but light, stable and glide smoothly on the mousepad; and quite precise (I wish I have the muscle control to take advantage of the higher DPI) - but it hasn't help my gaming more than my old $10 Logitech mouse. Which I suppose is expected - I won't be a pro gamer by buying a mouse, no matter how much it costs. Blame the user, not the tool.

After about a month the web admin interface stopped working. If you are kind of person who just configure it once and leave it, this may a product for you. But people like me who do networking for living, this is useless. The error message I am getting is:
Settings have been updated. Web page will now refresh.
Changes have been made to the IP address or port number. You will now be disconnected from RT-AC68R.
To access the settings of RT-AC68R, reconnect to the wireless network and use the updated IP address and port number.

I bought the Securifi Almond to act as a wireless access point.  It replaces another unit which frequently cut out and needed rebooting.  I've had the Securifi Almond for just over two weeks and it has not needed rebooting.  The unit is located in the living room on the first floor and the signal is still strong on the second floor and in the basement.  Set up was straight forward via the LCD panel--I did not need to access the setup menu through another computer. On paper, it seemed like Microsoft nailed the all-in-one keyboard concept. But then, when it arrived and I opened the box, I discovered one blatant flaw: the color. This keyboard is not black, it's matte grey.

Yes, it's nice enough looking on its own, but if you like your components to match, this is not the keyboard for you. It doesn't match any piece of black electronics in my entire home. In fact, it doesn't match anything. It's like Microsoft decided to do their own thing, just because. It makes no sense.

If you don't care about color, this keyboard seems well-designed and is probably very nice. For me, I didn't even get that far. The color mismatch was too annoying. I returned it.

The Arc keyboard is a solid little unit. It works well for an auxiliary keyboard for my laptop. My only complaint is that it doesn't have any protection for when I might want to put it in my backpack to use on the go--and the curved shape means that the middle of the keyboard is vulnerable. Not a big vomplaint, but given the ultra-portability of the Arc mouse, it would have been nice.

I bought this drive about five moths ago, and it did not work out of the box.  I determined that the wall adapter/power supply was bad, so I emailed Seagate to get an RMA number for just the power supply.  They responded quickly, and I shipped it off.  It has been about four and a half months now, and they STILL have not sent the replacement part.  I have called and emailed several times.  Sometimes they say they are about to ship it, but a few weeks later I call back and they say it is out of stock.  I tried telling them to open the box of a new drive, but they told me that they could not do that.  I am very unhappy with Seagate's support, especially since one of the main selling points (for me at least) is the five year warranty.

SKIP THIS PRODUCT UNLESS YOU ARE A NETWORK INFRASTRUCTURE TECHNICIAN!     I love SONY. I am a longtime SONY buyer and I was biased to buy a Sony blueray even though it doesn't offer a WIFI capability. I sprang for this WIFI bridge offered by CISCO/LINKSYS that Sony recommends - because it is \\"optimized for video streaming\\". I am also a netflix subscriber so I thought -perfect. Long story short is that the CISCO bridge is a pain to set-up. I returned it. It isn't even compatible with a MAC unless you manually set it up with the help of someone over the phone in India. WHich I tried to do but as soon as they heard I didn't have a Linksys router/DSL modem they didn't really know how to help me. It was comical.   They said \\"Don't you have a PC you can use to set this up?\\"  And then \\" You mean your DSL modem/router is not a CISCO/LINKSYS?\\"  No and No.  Sorry!  Their help was very limited and this was a function of the bad design of this bridge.  Annoying that the bridge isn't plug and play in 2010! AND WHY WOULD SONY NOT BUILD IN WIFI? Apple TV does it! Wii does it! Xbox does it! AND YOU KNOW WHAT? They are all plug and play!!!! Can you imagine inserting a disc in your computer to configure a wireless device like the CISCO bridge? Apparently CISCO can!!!!! Crazy!! I guess we are all so spoiled by technology that when something bone headed like this comes along there is no mercy.    I ended up moving my DSL modem/router to behind my TV and plugged it into my Blue-ray directly. Probably a better configuration anyway with no real downside to my home network needs.  And I saved my $80 for new bluray discs!

After using this product heavily over the last week or two, I'm fairly pleased with the Kindle. The reading experience is generally quite good with the exception of pictures/diagrams (which often tend to be unreadable). Usability on the device is also good and battery life is satisfactory at 1-2 days depending on wireless usage.     Some of the additional positives include decent prices on both books and newspapers. Plus, the newspapers at present are advertising free.     Regarding areas of concern, I am fairly certain I don't like the idea of having my content locked-in to Amazon/Kindle due to their DRM. How will I feel after purchasing tens or hundreds of books that can't be moved to some other eReader? Not too good. This is a question all potential buyers need to ask themselves.    I also find the charges for blogs to be a bit silly since most haven't even been reformatted for easy reading on the Kindle (they contain numerous links and such that are generally useless given the poor browsing experience of the Kindle).    Overall, I rate the Kindle pretty highly and look forward to seeing future evolutions of the product line that will solve some of the current concerns.

My primary components on this board:
AMD FX™ 8350 8-core 4.0 GHz
60GB Corsair Force Series 3 SSD
16GB G.SKILL Sniper Series DDR3 1866 (4x 2GB)

Pros:
-After flashing the BIOS to the latest release (F9 at the time, F10a is still a beta), I was able to get my 1866 memory to run at 1600. (The BIOS it came with clocked it at 1333). Flashing the BIOS with the downloadable @BIOS utility was a breeze.
-All the ports that I've used work.
-I like the look of it. Gunmetal blacks and grays really do make it seem like an "Ultra Durable" motherboard.
-It's stable, and has all the options you'd want to to overclock (which I don't.)

Cons:
-The BIOS is less intuitive than my old ASUS motherboard.
-USB support during POST is touchy (making entering the BIOS set up frustrating). I have an older keyboard with a split end so it can be either USB or PS/2, but that means I have to drag out another device while trouble shooting.
-There's a completely unexplained lag between the POST screen and the Windows 8 loading screen. It shows a blank screen with a blinking cursor, then a screen that says "Loading operating system" both for about 5 seconds each. I'm running a SSD build, and I'm this annoying sequence is slowing down my reboots. I've tried IDE and AHCI modes, and disabled and removed everything but the SSD, and still those 2 screens plague me. I've upgraded the firmware for my drives, all the drivers, and have the latest chipset. There's no "Quick Boot" option for this motherboard, and I doubt that would fix it anyway, since nothing else I attempted made 1 second of difference to those screens.

My wife inherited my old ASUS M4A785-M Motherboard running a Phenom II X2 555 Black Edition Callisto 3.2 GHz, unlocked to 4 cores. (Both purchased from Amazon.) I also upgraded her to a SSD drive and Windows 8. Now, that 2+ year old rig boots in about half the time my current one does,and the sole culprit is THIS motherboard. (Hers barely shows the POST screen, and you see the Window's loading for half a second before it's up and running.)
After doing some research online, I've found out that this is a big issue with various Gigabyte motherboards, and the fix that works for most people (setting the SSD/HDD as the 1st boot device) does nothing for me.

I've had this board for over 4 months now, and I wish I would have stuck with ASUS (the maker of my previous two MOBOs which had lightning quick boots.) I would send it back, at this point, if I could. What's the point of having AMD's best processor and a SSD drive if I can't even have boot-time bragging rights? Also, I'd prefer something that's a full UEFI rather than BIOS, anyway.

The other reviews have highlighted other aspects, so here I'm extolling the virtue of the power supply for this puppy. Not that wall warts aren't satisfactory from a quality perspective (I learned this lesson from makers of pro audio gear), but an external PSU that uses a standard cable is just so much easier to manage. For example, it doesn't cover two outlets, or require a Ziotech dongle or some other cost-adding solution.

A side benefit: when I installed this, my cheap bar code scanner started working, whereas it didn't with the SiiG unit I had before (a probable old age failure, since SiiG is usually an OK brand).

Having the jacks all on one side also helps the flow of cables; seven cables into a single place is an unavoidable congestion point.

Now to see whether this unit holds up over time.
