The Toshiba Encore 2 WT8 is a basic/value personal travel PC that hits the target. This full Windows 8.1 tablet provides a responsive experience in the user interface, but isn't speedy by any measure.

The entry nature of the Encore 2 is apparent by the very low price ($144 best price on Amazon as of this review), only wireless N (no AC), just one USB 2 (not USB 3!), no HDMI or other video out. Bright spots are 64GB storage, and 2 GB of RAM as opposed to the more common 32GB storage and 1GB RAM. The extra RAM helps make this a bit faster than 1GB Win 8.1 tablets.

This is a home/personal oriented tablet. This is apparent by the selection of preloaded apps/adware/and trial-ware. For business I'll be removing a bunch of this annoying stuff.

The Encore 2 includes Office 365 personal for 1 year. I don't like the Office 365 subscription model and would rather have had the perpetually licensed office 2013. I don't consider this a big plus or minus with how I plan to use this tablet.

A 30 day trial of Norton Internet Security included. I would suggest dumping this older version of Norton and installing the newer [[ASIN:B00MHZ6Z64 Norton Security]] or [[ASIN:B00MHZ71G2 Norton Security with Backup]]. Those will cover 5 or 10 devices respectively. Useful if you have several Windows, Android, Mac devices. Norton has an IOS app but with very limited function.

UPDATE Jan 5, 2015:
There is an adapter to use the more common USB A ended cables with the Encore WT8 micro USB connector: [[ASIN:B00KSTFNBO IVSO Micro USB 2.0 Host OTG Cable for Toshiba Encore 7 ,Toshiba Encore 2 8-inch,Toshiba Encore 2 10-inch,Toshiba Encore WT8 Tablet]]. While would not help in charging it may help in hooking existing USB devices to the Encore.

The Encore 2's 8 inch is large enough to be usable. In general the touch screen has been responsive. With some closely spaced buttons on the screen I have hit the wrong one. This might be my fingers or the smallish screen or both. The screen is bright and pretty sharp. There is no external monitor connection on this tablet. No mini-hdmi like the 10 inch version of the encore 2 adds.

The on-screen keyboard is surprisingly good and easy to type on. I got a [[ASIN:B00KMQ5LLU Bluetooth Keyboard Portfolio Case]] since I didn't expect the on-screen typing to be so good. The case is nice and the keyboard works fine. If I had it to do over I might choose a non-keyboard case to be lighter and more compact. To be clear: this is a nice case.

The 64GB of flash storage seems about right to me for this level of tablet. A micro SD card can expand storage by up to 128GB (192GB total with internal). I have not used a microSD so far in my testing and use.

Battery life has been fine. I have used it all day without getting below 25%. This is intermittent use traveling from client to client. It charges in a few hours via the supplied charger and USB cable through the micro USB port.

I have used the Encore mainly for web surfing and managing email while away from the house/office but within range of a WiFi signal (including my phone's mobile hotspot). For these purposes the 8 inch screen is large enough to be useful but not so big I am likely to leave it behind.

To summarize: the Toshiba Encore 2 WT8 is targeted to the personal/home market with a bargain price. Getting that low price is a tradeoff in features/performance. This is an entry level tablet and with that expectation you get what you pay for.

For those who like details here is a list of the Specs for the Encore 2 WT8-B264 Tablet:

Software
- Windows 8.1 (Bing preinstalled)
- Office 365 Personal* 1-year. Activation required within limited time.

- Norton(tm) Internet Security (30-day trial)

Hardware

- Atom Z3735F 1.33 GHz Processor (2MB Cache, 1.83GHz burst)

Power

I think the Encore 2 is good value. It's a little low end to be my primary travel device. For those where the price point may be the difference between having a PC internet platform or not, this could be a game changer. In other words: I think the Encore 2 hits its intended market target very well.

Because it set out to hit a low price point with good function and did it I'll give the Toshiba Encore 2 WT8 5 stars. Well, there I was playing World of Warcraft and getting my butt kicked by another player, when I wished I had some faster way to get to my abilities on the keyboard. I did some looking around online and discovered this beautiful piece of technology.

What this does for you is it places most of the important hotkeys you need for first person shooters and pvp-heavy games like World of Warcraft right within your left-hand's reach so you can switch weapons, abilities spells almost instantaneously, and will improve your performance a LOT. Ever since I got this, my reaction time has improved dramatically. When you fight another player in WoW, use of skills to counter-attack other players is CRITICAL. Once you get used to playing with it, I bet you can't play without it.

That being said, there is a transitional period for this thing. I used to play games using the W,S,A,D keys to move around and the mouse button to look. What the speedpad does, is force you to learn a new method of controlling your character, which takes a bit of time to get used to, but after about a week, it becomes second-nature. I personally wanted to throw this thing through the window after configuring the WSAD keys to the thumbpad on the Nostromo, since using the WSAD keys on the Speedpad takes up valuable hotkey spaces unless you bind them to the thumbpad. After dying over and over and over and over, you'll get so frustrated, but give it a week, and you'll notice your gameplay getting better and better and better...to the point where you can't play without it. It took me about 3 days to start to notice some improvements, and about 7 days before I got used to it.

The customization program along with it is amazing too. You can customize your own macros to use in games to get off some nice combos. Or single-bind any one key to any button the speedpad. Its totally up to you, you have total control. What I will suggest though is that you bind the WSAD keys to the thumbpad and take the time to get used to it.

Now for the downsides. Well I only found two. The orange/red trigger above the d-pad and the mouse wheel. Both are VERY VERY hard to press. The mouse wheel turns just fine, but pushing it in requires a little bit of effort, and requires a little more force to push in than to push a key on the keyboard. This is a small problem though, nothing to worry too much about. I bound my jump key to the red button or pushing in on the mouse wheel so jumping isn't really THAT essential. If there was a way to make it easier to push in, it would help a little :).

Overall, this is a great buy. Even if you don't like it, you can send it back to the company for a full refund. Just give it one week, and even though you might get killed a lot, don't give up on it. I kept wanting to go back to the keyboard every time I would get killed, but I kept at it, and I'm glad I did. If you set this up right, you'll notice some signifigant improvements in your gameplay - just keep at it!

Does it improve my gaming? Not really, It "feels" better but I'm I don't think it has improved my game play at all.

Does it improve my typing? Yes, but only by a few WPM, nothing extraordinary.

Overall it's really well made, and it feels like it will last forever as long as you don't spill anything on it, and It really does feel better than those membrane keyboards everyone else uses... But I don't think it offers as much as an advantage over membrane keyboards as some people claim...

I was recently asked how the Tab 2 compares to a higher priced iPad 2. I own a couple of Apple products, including their ultimate PC, the multi-quad core Apple Pro. I teach computer science part-time at the university level.

The short of it is that the Samsung is more tablet for less money. I bought mine for under $300. Both have a 1Ghz dual core processor. The Samsung has double the RAM (1GB vs. 512MB), microSD storage expansion capability, and significantly higher resolution (1280x800 vs. 1024x768). The Samsung display is also larger (10.1\\" vs. 9.7\\"). Both have Bluetooth, but the Samsung runs a newer version (3 vs. 2.1).

Unlike the iPad, the Samsung is Flash friendly. Installing Flash from Google Play is easiest on all but the most recently produced Tab 2s. If you have the most recent one, like I do, installing Flash for Android 4.0 from the Adobe Flash archive site was just a little bit more work.

Battery life is another advantage of the Tab 2 over the iPad 2. The Tab 2 has a 7000 mAh battery rated at 14 hours. The iPad 2 is rated at 10 hours (Apple tends not to share detailed specifications).

The iPad 2 and Tab 2 have comparable forward and back facing cameras. At a little over 3mp on the rear camera, neither is particularly special. The iPad 3 and Galaxy Note include a 5mp rear camera that does a better job. Still, neither the 3mp nor the 5mp camera is going to give you results comparable to even a sub $50 digial camera with a much higher resolution chip and larger optics.

When you compare the Tab 2 with the comparably priced iPad Mini, the iPad does even more poorly. For a tablet that gives the Tab 2 a run for its money, you might want to take a look at the new $400 Nexus 10. The Samsung produced Nexus 10 display is the highest resolution on the market at a fraction of the price of iPad 3s and 4s.

This is nice product, but I purposefully rated it lowest rate, so people will read my review and not loose money like I did.

The trouble is the configuration tool. When you configure any accessory for your existing device, what you do is: choose your device (in my case it was Kindle Fire HD 7inch), then choose other properties of the accessory. In this case it was: color. And I really went through a few colors, from my original choice of color: blue to white, red, (...), and back to my original blue.

When this is done, you just place the order. WRONG! You really have to double check what you are ordering! Because... Guess what: some color (while) was not available for my device. So, when I chose white instead of stopping right there and telling me that white is not available for _MY_ device, the configuration tool just showed me this body case for incompatible device (Kindle fire tablet), and from this point on it stays with this incompatible device when you further change color.

So: I consider this a major fault of the configuration tool. Hence the [very bad] rating. None of accessory configuration tools I used during past 10 years ever did something like that.

I did return my case and got refunded for that (Thanks, the seller!) - minus shipping both ways. As being honest person, I couldn't say wrong item was sent to me - I received what my order reads. And I did order the compatible one - from the same seller!

I hope, this helps others, as the configuration tool is a crap and is pushing to sell you what you don't need (it does this under some circumstances I mean ;-)

I have confirmed that the 12V and 5V pins coming out of mini DIN 4 pin connector on the FP35 are reversed from the leads going into my external HD enclosure (I used a digital multimeter to confirm this).  There should be some sort of warning on the manual that clearly states that the 4 pin connector could lead to HD failure if the voltage pins are reversed.  After doing some research I have yet to find a power supply on the internet that has the 12V and 5V pin layout that the FP35 uses.  I can also confirm that the FP35 would damage some Seagate external hard drives with this pin layout.  Seems odd that SilverStone would manufacture the mini DIN 4pin power connector in this manner.

[[VIDEOID:moLTL4E9YZKZ38]]I don't know how many people have a need to recharge 6 mobile devices simultaneously, but the iXCC charging station should handle that many if needed. I tested the charging station with four devices - two 7\\" tablets and two Android smartphones, and it was easily up to the task.

I connected one tablet and one phone to the two ports marked with double lightning bolts. Those are the \\"smart charging\\" ports (maximum 2.4A output). The other tablet and other phone were connected to regular charging ports (maximum 1.0A output). All devices had less than a 60% charge at the start of the test. The two tablets and the two phones recharged at speeds comparable to what I've noted with the single port chargers I've been using. I put a USB power meter on the Kindle Fire HDX 7\\" tablet, and I showed the results in the accompanying video. I had the charging station connected and powered up for about four hours, and the charging station and AC power supply never got more than slightly warm to the touch.

The 6-port charger makes a lot more sense than the shelf full of single port chargers that my wife and I use.

A product sample was provided for review purposes.

Before you buy this product and you live in the UK, make sure you signin on your account from amazon.co.uk and then check the books that are available. ALL of these books are available in the UK for the Sony Ereader, which does not have the number of books that the Kindle has, but at least in the UK they are more up to date and books you might actually want to read.    The device itself has a sold feel and the 3G access is average but works reasonably quickly. For some reason the last 25% was a little weird otherwise it would have had a longer life than the OEM had new.  I got notified it dropped below 30% remaining and it sort of jumped right to 25%.  It stayed at 25% for less than a minute then I get a critical battery warning and I look and it is reporting 3% and the light is blinking like it does when under 10%.  The old battery even with 46% of the cell capacity working at least went through the cycles down to 12% then 10% then 5% then 3% (Usually each percent was about a minute with the old one).  I'll let it go through a couple more cycles to see, but I may need to exchange it unless this is normal for these?  Not much warning if that is the case.

The Efergy E2 Wireless Electricity Monitor is a tremendously useful device, easy to install. Clip the two sensors over the two incoming 240-volt lines feeding your breaker panel, plug the sensors' output lines into the provided transmitter, push the LINK buttons, and the transmitter is wirelessly connected to the portable display unit. The robust wireless link operates at 433.5 MHz and will not suffer interference from cordless phones or WiFi networks.

The display unit is updated every 10 seconds. It shows the instantaneous power in kW, and the average daily energy consumption in kWh for the current, and each of the previous seven days. Other informative historical data are also stored in the device and can be displayed readily. When set to display the instantaneous power, it is useful to walk through the house, display unit in hand, as you turn lights and appliances on and off. It's quite an eye opener. (Five stars so far.)

The company also provides software for Macs and PCs. After reading the literature, and after contacting the vendor, it wasn't at all clear to me how the data get to the computer, but it became obvious once the equipment arrived: there was a USB cable included that plugs into the back of the display unit and into one of the computer's USB ports.

There was no software disc included, instead a link to the company's website was provided. Things now became confusing with the software links buried in advertising. To make a long story short, one claimed Mac link downloaded the PC version, but ultimately, after major fiddling, the proper software was installed successfully. I would recommend that the company appoint an individual to sit beside a newbie as he attempts to follow the installation instructions. This way the major potholes (sink holes) in the instruction manual would become obvious and could be paved over.

The Mac software v2.2 (I can't comment on the PC version) appears to be quite solid andinformative and provides a valuable adjunct to the handheld display. It is NOT required if you are happy with the information provided by the display unit.

All in all, I'm very happy with the purchase. The unnecessarily-frustrating software fiddling cost the company one star in my evaluation.

I purchased this adapter through Geeks and checked out through Amazon.  I checked out many of these products on-line with their reviews. There are many cheap ones with bad reviews. For $22.99 I thought this would be a better one. However it burned out on my first charge with it. The metal housing was too hot to touch and I could smell it burning. I unplugged it and let it cool. I plugged it back in after an hour and it would not light up any lights.  My laptop would not boot back up. Hopefully, even though I set it to the proper voltage for my HP notebook, I did not ruin my notebook. Luckily, I was home as this defective piece of .... may have burned down my house. As many of other reviewers have complained about these Chinese AC/DC adapters I have had the same problem now. Unfortunately, these components obviously do not have to meet safety requirements in China as our products do. I am going to call Geeks after I submit this review. If I get stiffed for returned shipping I will let everyone know. Save your computer and house and DO NOT buy this product.   Long time customer with Geeks and Amazon.   Michigan.

I kept the shipping material for three days until it looked like everything worked fine, then threw out all the boxes.

Two weeks later I notice some issues.

- Lots of Radio noise or radiation -

The display feels like it emits a lot of heat, and it does get warm to the touch. After an hour I feel like I've been sitting in the sun.

It also knocks out Wi-Fi. I spent hours debugging Wi-Fi printer problems. Away from my desk (no monitors connected), everything works fine. Finally started a ping of my printer which is normally 1-5ms when away from my desk, but 15000ms or timeouts at the desk. Network health goes normal when I turn off the monitor. Eliminated cables as a interference source by wrapping them in foil, even then wifi is knocked out only when the monitor is powered on.

Great monitor which deserves five stars. Gave two stars due to possible long term health risk. Still using it because I don't want to live forever.

EDIT: Great customer service, replacement monitor is fine. Bumped from 2 stars due to fear of radiated energy up to 4 stars due to great customer service. Not a 5 because their QA could've been better.

I wrote this glowing review below and only hours later I went to do an update of an existing backup and it is not working (or if it is, it's going so slowly that it will take days to backup * FIVE GB * - which is ridiculous.  It took less than 5 minutes to do the initial backup, and now that I've connected the passport to my PC to update the files already backed up, it's been going for over an hour.  Same data (just a couple of edits on some excel files), same USB port, etc.  For 5GB of data.  You can copy / paste to the drive, but the whole reason I liked it is because I thought it would backup changes for me.  Sigh.    ********************************************************************  So easy to use!  I was dreading picking out a new external hard because I was sure I would experience some awful technical issue and end up buying my brother a plane ticket to Atlanta just to help me backup some music and photos of my kids.  But the WD Passort Ultra is really fast and easy to figure out.  You plug it into the USB 3.0 port if you have one (it will say "SS" = Super Speed) or any other USB port if you don't.  It does it's "installing new hardware" thing and then the notification pops up that the device is ready to use (I use my Passport using Windows 7 and Windows 8).  You go to My Computer, double click on "WD Apps Setup", follow the prompts and after a minute the WD Smartware is installed on your PC.  You then double click the WD Smartware icon and you can set your preferences.  I chose continuous backup, but you can also set a certain day of the week and time to have your files backed up. I don't intend to keep the drive plugged into my PC while I work, this way it updates right away when I plug it in.  For the backup scope, I chose the advanced setting.  It says this is for experienced users, but all it asks you to do is select the folders you want to back up.  I selected my Document, Pictures, Videos & Music folders.  If you need your email backed up or anything that is not in a central location, you might want to use the default setting.  You click "enable backup" and it begins backing up the folders you've specified onto the Passport.  I use this drive to backup personal documents on my work PC and all doc/photos/videos/music from my personal PC.  I can view them by viewing the folders on the drive and opening the "WD SmartWare.swstor" folder.  There I see a folder for each of my PC's and if you drill through into those folders you will see your backed up data.  You can do all kinds of other fancy things (versioning, etc.) but I'm just trying to keep it simple.  I bought the Amazon basics case for it, and it's perfect, holds the device and the cords.
Exactly as described; works perfectly. Great purchase!

I am very picky when it comes to my computer parts. I built my computer less that a year ago and have been tinkering with it ever since. I have a somewhat small case in terms of a mid tower, (Corsair 200R), so I need to be creative with my cooling options. Sure, you can fill your case with fans but I want to keep my noise at a bearable level. This is by far my most silent component now. I mean it can be almost inaudible up close when you play with your speed setting. Heck, my SSD is louder when the fans are @ 50%. I am very happy with its quality build. When I took it out of the box it just felt sturdy and worth the money. The heat pipes felt solid, there are tons of cooling fins, oh and by the way, just assume they are sharp when handling this one. Installation instructions were very clear and on quality paper. Overall a pretty simple installation, just make sure you plan out how your cables will run. I had a lot of difficulty plugging my CPU power back in with this thing in the way. I installed one time to check the viscosity of the included thermal compound. A grain of rice I found to be perfect. Check ALL screws for tightness before you lock it down. Luckily I noticed some loose ones and tightened them before the final seating. Below are the results of some basic tests I ran for this cooler vs my previous.
Previous cooler: Corsair H50(Fan @ 100%)
Idle: 38-42C
Prime95 torture test: 68-79C

Noctua(Fans @ 50%)
Idle: 32-35C
Prime95 torture test: 56-60C

I consider this is a good product for the non-techie type users who do not have time to perform regular maintenance on their computers.

First of all, the services provided by the Clean Machine was very prompt and professional. I was contacted by the support team within 3 hours after I installed the program and my first scheduled maintenance started on the next day. You also have the flexibility to tell them what time of the day you want the maintenance to be performed. I would recommend to pick a slot when you do not need to use your PC for hours as they spent more than 4 hours for my first scheduled maintenance. Besides, you would not be able to tell easily while they are performing the maintenance and you might be colliding with what they do by getting on the PC. They performed 17 essential maintenance tasks on my PC including upgrading the XP service pack to SP3. They also offered to install one of the top free spyware removal programs for me after the maintenance was completed. I also received a comprehensive report through email which describes all the tasks that were performed.

I do share some of the concerns by other reviewers. In order for Clean machine to perform remote maintenance, they installed a program called RADAR on your computer which basically gives them full control of your PC remotely. This also means that your sensitive data could be exposed to someone you personally do not know. It also installs another program called the Bomgar jump client which I believe is for remote access and communication with the user. This program is left running continuously every time you boot up your computer. But to be fair, the exposure to your personal data would be the same whenever you send your PC to a computer shop for maintenance. If you have complicated applications which require certain windows settings untouched, I would highly recommend that you inform the support team upfront so they do not perform upgrades/changes in those areas.

All in all, this is a nice service for those who are willing to shelve out $120 yearly for someone to maintain their PC. The type of maintenance they do could easily take 1-2 hours on the average. If you decided to terminate their service, make sure you request them to help you remove their windows user logon and all the remote access clients they installed on your PC.

3/21/09 (update)

My PC was infected with some real nasty malwares last month. The support staff from PC Clean was very proactive in helping me to diagnose and fix the problems. Kudos to the PC Clean Machine team.br />
All in all, this is a nice service for those who are willing to shelve out $120 yearly for someone to maintain their PC. The type of maintenance they do could easily take 1-2 hours on the average. If you decided to terminate their service, make sure you request them to help you remove their windows user logon and all the remote access clients they installed on your PC.

I had to return mine.  This card gave good speeds and outstanding graphics.  I built and all new computer and everything was working great for a few days it was the first time I've ever been able to play a game on Ultra settings... then poof. this thing decides it wants to update its Vbios (is part of the software) and normally I don't like updating bios for motherboards or graphics cards but I paid so much for this I figured It'd be able to handle it... NOPE!  The program crashed in the middle of the update and when I restarted it it said the most current version of the VBIOS was installed and wouldn't let me try to reinstall it through the program... so I though nothing was wrong and went about my business.  Needless to say, when I restarted my computer the motherboard kept giving me code 62 which meant something was wrong with my graphics card.  I put in and old graphics card in addition to this (my Motherboard didn't have built-in graphics) and tried to flash a new BIOS onto this card but it wouldn't work.  The computer recognized the card was in, but everything I tried to get the VBIOS corrected did not work.  After 12 HOURS of agonizingly trying to fix this card I gave up and returned it.  Thank the Maker (Dragon Age reference) for Amazon's return policy because this was my first time using an AMD/ATI graphics card and I switched back to NVIDIA.  Another beef I had when running this card was the Temperatures it ran at (normal operation) were just WAY too high... (it got to 80 Celsius before even half-way through a benchmark test) and I have 3-200mm fans (2 in 1 out) and 3-120mm (2 in 1 out) fans plus a Cooler Master case (tons of airholes) so it wasn't by any fault of my computer build that this thing ran hot.  I had to manually adjust the fan profiles to make the fans actually do their job because they were set to only kick in at 40% speed for unsafe temperatures (anything above 80 Celsius is unsafe for long-term operation I don't care what the manufacturer claims).  I was able to get the cooling under control and never saw above 87 Celsius even though it supposedly can withstand temps above 95 Celsius.  Now that I have NVIDIA back in my computer the Nvidia card runs cool(ish) not going above 70 Celsius and is idling at 27 Celsius right now (The R9 290 seemed to idle [if I remember correctly] near 40-50 Celsius).  Overall this is a good card for the buck... but if you buy it don't let it update its VBIOS (it should give a self-destruct warning since essentially the update bricked the card)... have a case with good circulation... and have it in a room with an Air Conditioner because in the middle of Northeast Ohio winter my room got HOT when running this thing.

Bought this for the price. I must've gotten a lemon--all my other previos WD external drives (Passport) have thus far worked without a hitch for a couple of years now.

I first connected this to my Macbook Pro running Lion and I noticed the drive would regularly (esp. if you have it mounted long enough) 'hang' and become unresponsive. That is, the drive light would keep blinking and the drive would make continuous seeking noises, and if it was already mounted you might be able to open it and see the top-level folders but if you try to open anything nothing would happen (any folders will appear empty).

If you then disconnect the drive and try to plug it back in, it'd just keep seeking and making noises. Eventually, though, after not using it or unplugging it then plugging it back on enough times the drive would be mounted successfully again and work like normal.

At first I thought it was just because I was using it on a USB 2.0 port and gave it the benefit of the doubt. Just recently I upgraded to the retina Macbook Pro with USB 3.0 ports and you guessed it--the problem is still there.

Since I live in a country where warranties aren't warranted, I'm stuck with this drive. It will probably be relegated to an 'archive' drive. Next time I get an external I'll make sure to test it like hell within 1-2 days (so I can have it replaced it as soon as I find any problems) before committing it to regular use.

I can't tell you how much I love this e-reader!  The pages look like actual paper under a protective coating.  It is very easy to read, even in lower light.  The screen is non-reflective, which means you hardly know it's there because you don't see a reflection.  It is very easy to increase the font size or look up words.  It clicks virtually silently when you turn a page.  For something so thin and light, it is quite sturdy.  I carry it around in my handbag and it does fine.  I haven't bought a protective case yet (after a month) but there are no scratches to either the body or screen even though my kids use it too and I bring it everywhere.  It has a very long battery life and charges quickly.    If my kids forget the books they are using for a book report at school, I can just click on the Kindle store and if there's a Kindle version it is there in seconds. No more schlepping to bookstores!     We have tried the experimental text-to-voice and the web browser.  These are both pretty much useless.  The text to voice is flat and doesn't pronounce many words correctly.  It cannot take the place of a true audiobook.  The web browser is slow and very basic.  So these features are not very useful.  The Kindle is purely an e-reader.    This has been the best $139 I have ever spent!  If you love to read, like I do, it is gold.  No more carrying bulky books around.  You can also read your books on your PC for free while someone else reads another book on the Kindle at the same time.

Sky WiFi Smartpen (2GB) - 5 Stars

Overall an invaluable tool and tablet companion that I would recommend to friends and family who prefer to take handwritten notes.

Pros
====
* The Sky wifi smartpen is a fast and easy way to save my handwritten notes and get them where I want them - on my iPad, Samsung Galaxy phone, and my laptop.
* This is so much better than trying to write on my iPad with a stylus! The Sky smartpen gives me all the advantages of writing on paper (i.e., natural feel, precision, etc.) with all the benefits of my tablet (i.e., viewing, listening, and sharing with others, etc.).
* It was simple to connect to WiFi in my home and office using the wifi controls on the inside cover of my notebook.
* Having the option to directly link audio to my notes is ideal for my key company and client meetings. It really helps me recall the important details and I don't miss anything.
* Evernote is a great fit with Livescribe's smartpen. It does everything that the Livescribe Desktop did for my Echo smartpen, but much more.
o Wireless Transfer: Sends my notes wirelessly to my Evernote account --- this is much better than having to use a USB cable to transfer my notes to my laptop.
o Sync: I can now sync and access my notes (and audio) on my iPad, my laptop, and my Samsung phone. This is really convenient.
o Search: I can still search my handwritten notes like before with the Livescribe Desktop, but now I can also add tags and search on them as well.
o Organization: I have more flexibility to organize and group info in the way that I want. Since Evernote supports almost every file type, I can put my handwritten notes, project spreadsheets, and presentations into the same notebook.
o Sharing: Sharing my project meeting notes is now much faster and easier. From Evernote, I can easily share pages of notes or an entire project notebook with my team.
o Storage: the Livescribe package included an extra 500MB of free upload capacity to Evernote every month - plenty of room for my notes and recordings.
* The online product videos were pretty helpful in learning how to use Sky and learning more about how it works with Evernote.

Cons
====
* Initial out-of-box experience was a little clunky and took longer than I expected to update the software on the smartpen.
* I had some initial problems in syncing my handwritten notes with my Evernote account, but recent upgrades from Livescribe solved the problem.
* The experience using Livescribe's Player which uses your default web browser for replaying pencasts (your handwritten notes and audio that's plays back like an interactive movie) seems to vary quite a bit by the type of browser you use. For the best experience, I highly recommend using Chrome or Safari which seems to be quick and responsive with the Livescribe player. I would definitely avoid using IE9 (which pretty much sucks with the Livescribe player) and Firefox (which seems slow and often struggles with audio playback). It might be worth trying IE10 as well.

In researching \\"rugged\\" iPad cases for my New iPad, I came to the conclusion that most of them were flawed in one way or another. I really wanted to get the Griffin Survivor, but Amazon is backordered and they have the best price on that one. In some ways I bought the Belkin as a \\"worth a try,\\" but kind of figuring that it would be an interim choice until I can get a Griffin. I am on my second New iPad -- I dropped my first one having it less than a month! That iPad was in an InCase folio-style case. Now I'm pretty serious about protection.

This case is really just OK. It's definitely not awesome.

Pros:
Color is nice - I can see it anywhere
The padding feels reasonably dependable, especially at the corners where your iPad is most likely to land
Easy to install
Has a good tactile feel. The way the sides and back are molded, you get a nice kind of \\"handle\\" to hold onto.
All the ports and holes line up well.

Cons:
It's very easy to pull off at the sides without intending to. The edges that wrap across the front of the iPad only cover about half of the unused portion of the screen. If they had just made the edge just a little wider, it would be 1000x better. This makes it feel kinda flimsy and loose, like the iPad is moving around in the case.

The openings for all the ports and buttons really degrade the structure of the case, especially around the area that has the volume controls, on-off switch, and rear camera. That one corner feels much smooshier and more vulnerable than the other corneres.

The area around the charger port is really weak. Doesn't feel strong there at all.

The silicone attracts lint and dog hair. This is probably just what silicone does, but if this would bug you you might look for some other material.

The New iPad supposedly runs hot, but I never experienced that using the InCase folio. I noticed the heat when I started using theBelkin.

This product was an unpleasant ordeal from the beginning. The installation program crashed the first 3 or 4 times I tried to install it. Finally I got it installed by deselecting the options in the Media Source portion of the install.

At this point things seemed to be going well. The device connected and the remote worked and life was good. Until I noticed that both of my cd/dvd drives had stopped working. Somehow the installation had corrupted the cdrom drivers. After uninstalling the SB Wireless software and fixing the cd drivers I decided to risk trying it one more time. After reinstalling I could not make the device link up again. Also, the Media Source(the music management system from Creative) application had a corrupted library and removing the entire Creative directory and reinstalling did not help it.

Since it was Saturday and Creative Labs only offers support on Mon-Fri 9am to 6pm using a long distance number (This is a terrible support policy) there was no support available. I sent an email and got a reply 4 days later after I had already returned the product. I have owned MANY Creative Labs products over the years but this really soured me on them. It is unfortunate that the product was so error prone because for the few hours it worked it did exactly what I wanted.

I returned it and bought the Linksys Media Link which setup easily with only one minor problem (which turned out to be some corrupted mp3s on my system) and I was able to talk to tech support at 1:00 am on a toll free line. Much better policy than Creative Labs.

Final Word: BEWARE!

My very old 3 year old HP tablet dual-core 1.2 GHz with Cyanogen android blows this thing away in responsiveness. I have a minimally loaded system. I killed off everything that tried to auto-start excepting essential and un-killable Samsung services. All my email and other accounts are set to manual sync only. Even the WiFi was set to turn off in sleep mode. For comparison, I tried the same on my  Xiaomi Note LTE phone (quad core 1.6Ghz), which I set in airplane mode to turn off the 4G radio (the Samsung tablet doesn't have phone capabilities). The battery draw in sleep mode was 5% in 24 hours, and the Xiaomi has a much smaller battery.  The high resolution screen is nice for looking at photos but bad for many other aspects of the UI. Avoid buying this video card. This has nothing to do with Amazon service. I kept receiving numerous errors which took many hours to fix and in addition I had many lock ups. I monitored the temperature and it was not the cause (though it does overheat fairly often). I'm not a flight sim addict. Rather, I purchased X-Plane and the Saitek Pro Flight Cessna package (consisting of the yoke, throttle, pedals, and trim wheel) in order to practice flight procedures so that my instructor would not have to keep telling me the same things over and over. For example, knowing how to set the flight controls for wind direction during taxiing should not require any thought, and neither should the various procedures and speeds in the pattern (carb heat when throttle is below green, flaps only below 110, trim for 60 kias for touchdown, etc.). One should also be able to make radio calls while doing everything else.

Having started with a real plane first (172), I wasn't expecting a feeling of realistic flight, and have others have noted, the Saitek yoke is just an approximation. It is indeed notchy, and somewhat sticky-feeling.

However, my real complaint about what has been marketed as a Cessna-approved product is that Saitek sells the package with a throttle system which is nothing like a Cessna. And after all, just about everyone learns to fly in a 150 or 172. Instead, you have to buy the Cessna-type throttle for an extra $150! And even if you do spend the extra money, Saitek's "Cessna" push-pull throttle omits what should be right next to the throttle: carb heat. After all, if you do intend to practice for a Cessna, knowing when to use carb heat should be second-nature. I've been taught to land with right hand on both throttle and carb heat in the event I have to abort a landing. Is carb heat important? Well, if you're turning base and you forgot to put your carb heat on and your engine ices over and quits at 500 ft, you may well die. You will not have enough speed or altitude at that point to make the runway.

Saitek should have included the (correctly-designed) Cessna throttle, or designed it into the Cessna Yoke housing, which would save on desk space and the need for wires going everywhere. Otherwise, what's the point?

However, one can make a guess as to why Saitek continues to sell the incorrect throttle quadrant with the Cessna package:
The decades-old serial connection to the yoke suggests that they made a bazillion of them long ago, and are still stuck with stock.
These things should have been switched to USB.

All in all, I suppose Saitek's gear is better than nothing. But as far as accuracy concerning the most basic controls in a real Cessna, especially for what is a premium price for the "Cessna" sticker, Saitek has done a half-assed job. This thing should cost a fraction of what they get for it. They say that general aviation is suffering due to the cost of flying. Well, guess what: even fake flying is overpriced...

I received the enclosure and mounted the drive as per the instructions. When I tried to plug it into the computer - nothing happened. I thought it may be the computer, so I tried another one - still nothing. I then decided to try a mac and see if it was software related - still nothing. I thought it might be the hard drive, so I put in a different one - still nothing. And finally I tried that hard drive on my mac and, you guessed it, nothing. I'm not sure if I received a faulty drive but either way, that thing was going back.

The aluminum is nice but the way the drive mounts is horrendous. basically, you plug the drive into the SATA connector and shove it into the enclosure. But, if your hard drive is of normal laptop drive thickness, it just floats there. There is no support on the other side which means once you put it in the enclosure, it's susceptible to being knocked around by the slightest movement. The entire drive is supported by the protruding SATA connection which is not designed to support it. I have no doubt that if it had work and I had kept it, it would have damaged my hard drive connection.

After I returned it I bought this enclosure from Acomdata. A little more expensive, but a ton less than having to replace a broken hard drive and trying to recover data. The Acomdata drive is ten times better. [[ASIN:B00292BSFI Acomdata USB 2.0 2.5-Inch SATA Hard Disk Enclosure HDEXXUP-240-BLK (Black)]]

Be wary of this router when looking for a DD-WRT VPN ready router. Returning this router was dreadful!

The firmware that comes with this router cannot process OpenVPN like it claims in the description. The data speeds are basically nonexistent when using OpenVPN. You are better off buying a regular router and running OpenVPN through a client application on your device. If I had known the router's firmware couldn't handle OpenVPN I never would have purchased this in the first place.

When I went to return this item the seller told me that I should not compare OpenVPN processing on a router versus on a computer using a client application. I told him you shouldn't claim a device can run something that it cannot run. I was charged $15 restocking fee and I had to pay $15.50 to return shipping. I do not advise purchasing this router! If you want to run OpenVPN on a router look up DD-WRT routers with Sabai firmware.

I'd like to have titled this review \\"Nice idea, but CHEAP execution. However this product is not cheap. It costs a lot as mice go, and one should be able to expect a top-notch product. However, this touchpad is done at cheap cost, sloppily and sold for a relatively high price.  What is right with it? The concept  of an external touchpad is great. The size and weight of the product are good. That's about it.  What is wrong with it? The design and finish are just plain poor and poorly thought out - or maybe just NOT though-out. The surface of the trackpad has a really bad feel. One would expect far better from a standalone touchpad - I have seen far better surfaces on integrated touchpads in laptops.  Furthermore the buttons are stiff and the are positioned wrongly. They should be flush with the surface of the touchpad, not higher than it as they are.  This product is just sloppy in everything but the pricing. Dont be fooled into thinking it is a high-quality product - it isnt.

The Belkin F2E9142  will not adapt the apple studio panel sceen that I own.  My screen is terminated in a flying lead with a male ADC connector.  This connector plugs into my Apple G4 Cube processor.  The Belkin product will not mate with my screen because both components terminate in male connectors.The Belkin product is incorrectly described because it doesn't allow connection of an ADC screen to a DVI based processor.  What it will do is allow an Apple cube to be connected with an up-to date DVI screen.  To use an Apple Studio ADC terminated screen one needs an apple adaptor costing $350.  The item is costly because the studio screen does not contain a power supply and draws its power from the Cube to operate the screen itself and to power the 2x USB sockets at the rear of the screen. Any one wishing to update the Cube for an Apple Mini would do better to buy an iMac which comes complete with the latest screen technology and the Duo intel core processors with Snow leopard SW

My Primary Use: AUTOCAD

After years of use my trusty Microsoft brand infrared mouse started going out. I immediately went down to the local big box store looking for a basic mouse. Can you believe they didn't have one? So I picked up the next step up, a Microsoft \\"comfort\\" mouse. Okay, felt nice but didn't work with Autocad - the middle mouse button was delayed and after looking online this seems to be a common problem. So back it went. Went to a different box store and picked up a different brand - piece of junk.

Frustrated I went to the local K-Mart which I try to avoid and saw this mouse and was leary of it's flashy appearance. I thought I might as well try it out as a last resort and when I got it home and plugged it in and saw that the middle mouse roller button glows red (thanks to a red LED) I rolled my eyes and thought - give me a break! I don't need flash - I need functionality. Well, I must say this little mouse delivers in both areas and is fully functional with Autocad although the roller button sits a little lower than the old trusty Microsoft I had. After a little getting used to it - it works great, feels great, and looks great!

The Good:
--------------------
This is my first 'laser' mouse - I didn't know there was such a thing and it seems to function real good. So good, in fact, that I can now stash my mouse pad away which I was previously using because my IR mouse couldn't pick up the wood grain on the desk effectively. This laser mouse works great in that regard.

The contour of this mouse is nice and fits my hand well. The buttons have a nice feel. It's not a sharp click but more like a comfortable sine-wave style click... smooth! The mouse wheel and button are smooth as butter as well. Everything is also nice and soft thanks to a contoured rubber moulding everywhere your fingers and hand rests.

I would highly recommend this mouse if you're in the market for a basic replacement. Sorry Amazon but I got this for $14 and change at the local K-mart. Might check your local stores before buying online on this one.

The Bad:
----------------------
That LED in the mouse wheel may look good but as I said - I'm not looking for flash but functionality. It's annoying that it doesn't ever 'sleep' - it stays on all the time your computer is on.

*****************************
UPDATE::::: REDUCED FROM FIVE STARS TO ONE!!!
After 6 months or so of usage the wheel intermittently doesn't engage and just spins without activating the scroll function. Additionally, the little plastic feet came off over a month ago and I've had to resort to putting tape on the bottom in order to get it to move smoothly along my desk.

BOTTOM LINE: I would not recommend this mouse as it hasn't even lasted a year without some serious issues. I'll be buying something else soon.

No matter how sweet this thing looks, maybe in a perfect world, it is great. I have been fighting this thing for about a month, and I'm telling you that if you ever let \\"Network Magic\\" into your computer, nothing will ever work right again. I can't even burn a music cd anymore with Power2Go. I have to restart my computer every 5 to 10 minutes just to cruise around. I've tried every setting on it that there is....You would do better buying a 10 year old G router off Ebay. I'm no Geek, but I know my way around a computer....and this thing makes me want to smash both my computers. I'm eating my money and plugging back into my half-broken Belkin pre-N. So what I'm sayin' is....\\"Don't do it\\"! This is nothing against Amazon, I didn't buy it here, it's not against where I did buy it, this is against the product...\\"Don't do it\\"!  As soon after I wrote this review, I went to uninstall \\"Network Magic\\". I was shocked, it was taking up 32.6 GB, I didn't type that wrong 32.6 Gigabytes. I took it out and the router still works the same...hardly at all, just like before...No wonder they're making comps with so much space now...a few programs like this will be all it takes to fill it up.  OK, it's been another week, probably 12 hours of messing with this thing, thought I had it going, and then back to the same. I called support, and after about 1/2 hour, they told me router is great, it should be working fine, and I should add...they can kiss my ass all the way....\\"Have you tried unplugging, resetting....\\". I've been trying for 5 weeks. Well, sir, have you tried resetting your router?\\"... Well sir, I can tell you, this router is a legacy model, and it works. Support nonexistent...there were moments that I thought I was talking to a computer voice, because they didn't seem to listen to anything I said. DON'T DO IT!!!

I purchased an ASUS 900HD nine months ago and it has seen very light use. The power supply quit working about three weeks ago. I submitted a help request on their Web site and after waiting for three weeks with no reply, called them. The woman I spoke with tried to trouble shoot the problem (try a different electrical outlet - duh) all of which I had already tried. Then she told me since it was nine months old, the battery (understandable) and power adaptor (not understandable) was out of warranty (six months for 'accessories'). I told her I was extremely unhappy and asked if she would like to make an unhappy customer happy for the relatively low price of a power adaptor (retail $49.99, their cost = much less). Nope. So I went online to the Web site she provided - and they are out of stock. So now I have a paperweight until ASUS can restock power supplies. My question, which I will never know the true answer is: Why are they out of power adaptors? Is this a systemic problem? For the light use this adaptor has seen in nine months (actually it started giving me intermittent problems in eight months)this is a very poor product.

After reading reviews on this product, I was really looking forward to getting it to boost the signal on my Fios Actiontec m1424-wr router. I have it on the 1st floor of a house on one end. I immediately saw the signal strength on the 2nd floor on the other side of the house increase from poor to very good. But then as I tried using the browser, it took about 2 minutes to load a page as opposed to about 5 secs. I tested this a few times unplugging and disconnecting the device, but it was definitely the booster that was causing the delay. In addition, the switch for the boost strength was recessed or fell in, so that I had a hard time moving the switch. I got it exchanged from Amazon for a new one. Again, the switch was recessed and hard to manipulate. I was hoping the booster for the signal strength would at least work right, but it was almost as bad loading pages. To clarify, I connected this directly to the router by replacing the router's antenna with this using the supplied cord. From what I've read, this is the frequent method of using this device, not as a wireless adapter booster as per the instructions.  In summary, this device actually slowed down web page loading considerably. I also think it was poor quality that the switch was recessed and hard to access. Going through two of them was enough.

I have had this product for just over a year and have used it almost daily for little on the go jobs, like checking odd emails, recipes, weather etc. Little bit of games like angry birds, fashion story etc. I had bought it as an alternative internet enabled device for my toddler daughter. Instead of a $99 leap pad, I got a $169 Acer Iconia. Seemed to work initially, but she soon lost interest in it, and took over my laptop. Then, by default, this became my go-to. Worked great for about 2-3 months, then the charger burned out. It was still under warranty, so Acer reluctantly sent me a replacement for the charger plug that goes into the wall. Then, slowly, the whole system turned frustratingly slow, going on to becoming slower and slower and slower. By the time the browser loaded the page, the Iconia would turn off the screen.

8GB is woefully tiny, and the SD mount is simply for storing files and pictures, and after about 15-20 additional apps, the tablet would refuse to install more. It might not appear so much of a big deal if you are reading this before you have purchased the product, but trust me, eventually, you will hate it!

I still stuck with the tablet loyally, as I was a handy alternative. The deal breaker happened last week, when the devise slowly totally died out. Now, the power button turns on, but nothing happens after that. The screen is blank. I checked online on other android forum. Turns out, it is pretty common. Hundreds of issues reported, where the mother board fries itself, after about a year of use. I checked with Best Buy Geeksqaud and they say, they have seen this many times. Their suggestion was to just buy a new one (this time, get an established brand, like Apple or Samsung, as the rest are still figuring it out, it seems) as the cost of repairing this one would run into at least $100 to $150!

Acer customer service is the most painful part of this whole experience. They wont even talk! They are not willing to stand behind their product, and look for excuses to get you off their phone/chat, whereever you manage to catch them. I guess, its an outsourced function for Acer, where some overseas cheap company handles the customer care (pain) function and they couldn't care less!

I bought this tablet (and wanted to keep) but became concerned about some performance issues. I purchased via the Microsoft online store. Return within 30day return period was relatively pain free

Pros

At $149 ($30 cheaper than HP) for a real computer a decent buy.

1. Much smaller and lighter than a laptop for travelling.
2. Leverage the T-Mobile capability when Wifi was unavailable.
3. Load a few apps and games.
4. A real computer with a file manager, micro USB for file transfer.
5. A cheap guinea pig device to upgrade to free Win 10 and try it out to reduce aggravation before I jump in with both feet to upgrade my laptop.
6. Maybe stream shows or display tablet screen to my TV.
7. 32GB storage expandable to 64GB via micro SD.

Cons

1. Weak Wi-Fi reception which was an annoyance. I would have had to buy a Wi-Fi range extender whereas no other devices I own have any problem with Wi-Fi reception in same location.

2. Tablet sometimes froze while trying to stream video wirelessly to TV using Microsoft Wireless display adapter.

3. Not sure why but if I was logged on as one standard user, turned off all radios (Wi-Fi, Cellular), shut down, rebooted and tried to logon as a different standard user the Stream would return a message “Device is offline, logon as prior user” message.

4. Tablet is not MHL capable (MHL micro usb/HDMI cable to TV would not work). I contacted HP before purchase. First HP support rep said it was MHL capable. I ordered MHL cable after placing tablet order. Found out from second HP support rep Stream 8 is Not MHL capable.

5. MS App Store Implementation - Microsoft’s app store implementation is dumb (I am not talking about number of apps available). In order to download apps you must have a Microsoft account locally installed on the Stream 8. So when you are using apps you are logged on to app store (unlessapp can be used with Wi-Fi and Cellular turned off). This is idiotic. If you want to install an app you should merely be able to login to app store, download app, and log out. Also – app is available for only the MS account on Stream 8 it was downloaded to and cannot be shared with any other user accounts on device. I found out after the fact customers have complained about this MS app store implementation in forums for several years.

6. Can’t use 32GB Micro SD storage to store apps or store downloaded maps for a map app such as HERE maps.

7. OS Microsoft Answer Desk - I was somewhat disappointed in Microsoft Answer Desk (they were ok if Windows 8.1 questions did not go beyond their script) but get beyond their scope and it was “We’ll have to get you to paid support”. It was interesting when they sent follow up emails regarding a question discussed in a chat with a link to the answer desk indicating if I wanted to discuss the issue again with the same support rep just click on the link, but in reality it was impossible to reach the same support rep to discuss instructions the rep had previously provided.
I've had the device for two years. The last firmware upgrade does not and will not support Windows XP...
The description wasn't clear enough, I figured I'd be able to plug this into a port and see if there where any problems with it getting signal, didn't work.

Wow, what a disappointment. Don't bother with this laptop the design flaws are bad enough without having to deal with the really slow AMD processor.    Honestly, I don't know who was responsible to designing this laptop but it's just awful.    Cons:  1. AMD processor is really slow.  Do a SuperPI calc to 2m and you'll find it at least TWICE as slow as a comparable Intel processor.  Not only that, Windows 7 is just sluggish.  Opening photos should not take several seconds, please, it's ok for my Atom based netbook for not for this notebook.  Try running anything above 360p on Youtube and you'll see how bad this laptop is.    2. Battery life.  What battery life? You'll be lucky to get over 2hrs in real life usage with wifi. My battery after two months of usage went bad and now only gives me 30mins.    3. Problems with going in and out of sleep mode, it takes forever and if you accidently shut the lid while it's going into sleep mode it just hangs and dosen't go into sleep mode and stays on in a strange state, wasting your battery life.    4. It gets hot. After about 15mins on your lap you'll want to place a book as a shield due to the heat. I've had about 16 laptops and this is definitely on the hotter side. The hottest laptop I've had was the ultra light Dell X1, but that was ok since that was a fanless design, unlike this Thinkpad Edge.    Less serious design problems:     5. Power cord is on the right side. With most users being right handed why would you want a cord hanging out on the same side as where you use a mouse?  Also the headphone jack is on the right side too, so they want you to stick a bunch of cords on the right side of the laptop?????  Painful.    6. Delete button not in an easily accessible position. It's on the top right embedded THIRD from the right. Why not make it the 1st button from the right?    7. Putting the Fn button where the Ctrl button should be, in the left most bottom corner of the keyboard. Come on, this is an EASY one, sheesh.    8.Microphone is placed under the Fn button.. umm shouldn't it but next to the camera on the lid? Large hands will actually cover that tiny hole while typing.  A terrible place for a mic.    PROs:    1. Keyboard feel is good.    2. Dual trackpad and pointer    3. Has both HDMI and VGA output.    Conclusion  I would not buy this laptop or recommend it to anyone.  As an alternative Get the ASUS UL20A-A1, yes it's a 12\\" laptop but FAR superior in every way.  If you really need a 13\\" laptop then the Dell V13 is also good but the battery life is weak and is a bit more expensive.

I purchased this drive to have a shared storage device for our computers, and to share media (music and movies) within our house.     It does what it's supposed to do to a point. If you are running windows, and have their software installed, it seems to be easy enough to use. If you have a Mac, the interface seems to struggle. I have a Linux machine, and the web interface doesn't really work so good, even though it runs on a Linux platform itself. The web interface is basically annoying and somewhat sluggish, walking you through folders and files. What makes me dislike it, is that to get files on to the drive, you have to use a Java applet, which failed under Linux and didn't work right under Mac either. So at that point, you had to drop in files one at a time, which is unnacceptable considering I had some 10,000 music files to load in. Gaining access through a network connection, and using a 'backdoor' approach, you can easily drag in piles of folders and files - but this would be confusing to novice users. I was able to get my files in there no problem that way through both computers, but again, this would not be easy for someone who did not know how to do it. Once files are stored in the drive, the interface again only allows you to 'download' files back out one at a time, unless you use the same approach. So sharing is greatly hindered through the web interface that they expect you to use.    The other part thing that I find confusing, is that in order to log in through the web page, you have to go to Lacie's website, then log in which portals you back to the drive that is sitting under you desk. This would be fine for logging in from the office, etc..., but it's kind of dumb if you're at home and the drive is a few feet away. Ultimately what bugged me the most was how much it was doing on it's own. I watched it when no one was logged in, and none of our home computers were on. It was constantly sending/receiving info on the internet, and writing some kind of info to the drive - not sure if it was logging info or time or what, it does not automatically update or anything like that. If I have a locally shared drive on my home network and I'm not using it, I would expect it to be idle. Last night it was frequently using the internet connection, and you could hear the drive writing, which to me doesn't make any sense.    Overall, it's a nice compact drive, great price, large storage capacity, and really seems to be simple enough to operate from a Windows platform. If you're on Mac or Linux, and know how to connect to 'remote' servers on your network, you can add/remove files easily. Otherwise, the web logging (or whatever it was doing), the flashy user interface, and the random login through [...] made this drive kind of sloppy and slow. I'm not overall against it as a storage device, I would just like something a lot simpler from a technical standpoint.

It's now November, and the repaired mouse has died yet again. I'm considering tossing it in the trash at this point.

Sadly, the mouse isn't the only problem. While replacing the latest set of batteries in the keyboard, I noticed that the metal contacts are seriously corroded. There is no problem with the batteries, or previous ones I have used. I live in a dry climate, and don't normally travel to high-humidity environments (or sea air), so it's beyond me how corrosion can be an issue on a six-month new keyboard.

I own a much older previous version of Gyration's wireless keyboard and mouse combo. They still work flawlessly today (connected to my Home Theater PC). As for the new stuff, it's junk. I would NOT buy this again, and don't recommend anyone to do so.

I have good luck with the Vantec version (hard to tell who makes what from whom these days) and Vantec's customer service is outstanding.

I can confirm that the Vantec's will support 4TB drives (GPT formatting mandatory) and I have run up to 3 of them successfully in this enclosure on a 2011 HP dv7 Pavilion laptop (even through a Trendnet TU3-H4 4 port multiplier). My 4TB drives were from HGST -- I would stick to the 5900 rpm models when running multiple 4TB in any kind of enclosure like this - 7200 rpm drives run 20-30 degrees hotter (141 F vs 114 F). For multiple TB apps like backups you won't notice the performance difference.

The single drive enclosures from HornetTek (e.g. JAWS) I consider to be excellent but they do not support 4TB drives and getting any kind of answer out of Hornettek about a firmware upgrade is next to impossible. So I think this whole area (aka "Vintage" on their website) is a dead-end product line for them. More money to made by re-reselling others' enclosures and making iPhone cases!

Two stars to Hornettek for quasi-truth stretching. Five stars on the NexStar version!

BAD:

2) the drivers included crashed (bluescreened) on one of the machines I was working on. But it worked fine on the other one. If you look on their website for drivers you will find... NOTHING. Not even a link to their product. Not even a link to their current drivers.. forget about updated drivers.

So day one of having this capture card and I have to say it is an absolute nightmare and a flop. The card lacks in both software and compatibility. Let me start off by saying that I DO HAVE a computer compatible with this card. Well, what exactly do you need to have in order to ensure compatibility some may ask? Well, I honestly wish I could answer that but the fact of the matter is I can't, and neither can Avermedia as they seemingly made a product that they have zero knowledge about. I do not even think the company knows how this card works to its entirety. Avermedia fails to put an emphasis on the REQUIREMENT of native USB 3.0 ports, and this ultimately screws over potential consumers that thought they could get away with an adapter or some expansion slot of some sort. Basically, if your computers lacks native USB 3.0 ports or a compatible motherboard, you're never going to be able to achieve 1080p at 60 frames per second with this card and you most likely won't even get it to reliably work for you. Now, what if your computer does have native USB 3.0 ports, and what if you do have a compatible motherboard and all the other 100 intricacies you seemingly need to have to make this card \\"work\\"? Well....Good luck. The card is a flat out nightmare to handle if you haven't understood where I am getting at. I fail to understand how this card has a single decent review on Amazon, but I'd have to imagine it's people who don't have/know of any reasons to utilize 60 frames per second at 1080p(basically people throwing away money at a high-end card while a card that is 70$ cheaper can do they job they are seeking). Do yourself a favor, look at any reviews on forums or Youtube and you will get the same idea that compatibility and USB 3.0 drivers will be the bane of your existence with this card. How about once you do get the card setup and somewhat \\"working\\"? Once again, good luck! At this point, it is probably the most luck you'll need(as if you didn't need enough luck up until this point).Why? Well, to put it as kindly as I know how; THE SOFTWARE FOR THIS CARD IS ABSOLUTELY THE WORST CAPTURE CARD SOFTWARE I HAVE EVER USED AND THE FACT THAT AVERMEDIA ACTUALLY RELEASED THIS GOD AWFUL SOFTWARE IS A TESTAMENT TO THEIR LACK OF RESPECT FOR THEIR CONSUMERS. Now in case that statement in all capitals didn't emphasis it enough, the software is just pure s***(no nice way to put it). Despite their update for the software back in early July, the software is still awful. The presets at higher recording settings are a joke and clearly demonstrate Avermedia's lack of knowledge in the subject, and when you try and run 1080p at 60fps recording, the software will crash, your recording will freeze, and the recording will stutter and just stop working MOST the time. It honestly boggles my mind how such awful software could have been released with a \\"higher end\\" card and it is truly a shame that such awful software comes along with a device that has so much potential in terms of hardware, the only problem is that Avermedia is clueless about the card they developed and it is demonstrated by the amount of time it has taken to come out with more updates to actually make this card usable. If you purchase this card and hope to get high quality streams/recordings...GOOD LUCK.    Oh, and yes, I did contact Avermedia's customer support and I have never heard more confused employees in my life. The customer support clearly has had no training of any sorts in Avermedia's NEW card. It is truly a shame that what could be a great card is plagued by all the issues it has.  Good job Avermedia. If you wanted a flop, you got it.

This thing fits and functions well. And the K2 in it looks neat and seems well-protected. I liked it a lot for that.  But initially, it had a fatal flaw.  As I said in the intitial version of this review,     \\"...the thing is made to be folded over for one-hand use.  When I do that, my hand absorbs a nightmarish chemical reek from the mock-felt interior.  It is actually hard to wash off; as I write this I have scrubbed my hands 3 times in hot water and soap and they still faintly reek of it....\\"    Based on comments and various other reviews, I think there must be considerable variability in how much smell these covers have and in how sensitive people are to the smell.    I was going to return it, but I thought that was a shame, because of its good fit and good look, and the other options out there didn't look very good to me, or readily available. So first, I tried to get rid of the smell.  I put the cover, folded open with the Kinlde2 removed and with the interior up, outside in direct sunlight for an entire day, 8AM to 4PM.  And that worked!  That was enough to evaporate and drive off essentially all of the residual glue, or solvent, or whatever.  Now I can stick my nose right up against it and sniff - it smells pretty much like a new glove, with the faintest of chemical undertones; and the smell doesn't transfer to my hand anymore.    I would now rate this as 4-star, but Amzn does not allow rating changes.

I like the looks of this mouse, but am actually finding the fact that it's so flat very uncomfortable. My hand is used to resting on a mouse, and my fingers work better with that support, so this mouse causes me a lot of hand strain.     It's also somewhat jittery, even on a flat surface. Even if I change the drag speed, this mouse doesn't track smoothly. Don't even try to use it on a bedsheet (which I do often).     Haven't needed to use it as a presenting tool so I don't have experience to report there.    Just not the mouse for me -- I'm buying a more traditional style.

I originally bought this mouse to play WoW with, but many MMOs saw me using this as well.
I used to use, and now use again, a Logictech G5.
The Naga was great for MMOs, as well as swapping weapons quickly in BF, TF2, and most FPS games.

That said, I play alot of games in my spare time.

But basically, the small tendon that attaches my thumb to my wrist has been strained, I originally thought that it was due to pouring massive amounts of drinks at work, but then discovered after some trial an error, that it was actually the pressing the numpad on the Naga.

My hands are about average size, Men's Large gloves, and I find it saddening that such a pretty and functional mouse ends up causing muscle strain after repeated use.

Since swapping back to the Logitech G5, as well as a fun steroid shot from my doctor, my hand is recovering.

Should I spend less time gaming? Probably.

Should the mouse I use cause this kind of physical damage? Never...

I've owned a Kindle keyboard with the lighted leather case for about a year now and I love it. It feels solidly built, it protects my kindle, and the light has worked well for me. When I purchased the same case for the new Kindle, I was a little turned off by the fact that it was still at the same price point (still $60 when the Kindle itself was only $79); however, I decided that because the first case was of such high quality that perhaps the price point was still valid. I judged incorrectly. This case feels like a huge step down in quality.  Pros  - Lightweight  - Fits kindle snugly (Perhaps too snugly if you want to remove it on a regular basis.  If you just want to put the kindle in and leave it, the fit is a good thing)  - Centered light provides more even coverage (I've never had a problem with the side light, but I know that it has been an issue for some people  Cons  - Flimsy (The case hardly feels like it is made of leather. It feels almost like cardboard with leather-looking paint sprayed over it. I understand that this contributes to the lightweight quality, but I would have preferred a little more substance for the price. Also, the light mechanism seems as though it could break fairly easily)  - Scratches easily (I've had this case for less than a month and it is already covered in scratches. The Kindle keyboard case looks barely worn after a year of constant use.)  - No closure (This case should have provided some possibility for closing it and keeping it shut. I realize some people may not have liked the elastic, but what about a magnet? The lack of a real closure significantly reduces the ability of this case to keep the kindle protected when not in use)  Overall, this is probably the best case available; this is not saying much and comes from the fact that is the only combined case/reading light I've seen thus far. It might even be better to try to find a sturdier case and buy the light separately, though this seems very inconvenient. If you purchase this product, just know that you are paying a high price and receiving very little in terms of quality.

At first, I was pleased to have avoided paying Apple's seemingly overpriced cost for a stock power supply. The cord was longer, too. However after four months of use, the LED on the magnetic computer-end attachment began to flicker occasionally, and I had to fidget with the cord to make it stay lit. This problem became more frequent until it stopped working entirely at month #5.

I wrote the company to request a replacement, and the response was that the window for returns had closed one month after my purchase.

I gambled that I might get more than I paid for--and hopefully others have fared better--but this item clearly is designed cheaply. My original Apple cord lasted almost two years before crapping out, therefore I suggest buyers to consider whether they will really be saving money with this purchase.

This machine is a shame because before this I really liked ASUS.  I run 2 servers at work with ASUS boards, my laptop is an ASUS, but I'm appalled at how I was treated when this cheap computer broke.  The case is completely stupid.  They tried to hide the on/off button and the 'open' button for the DVD drive, and it does makes them hard to find, but it also sucks because the on/off button is on the top corner and every time you need to move the computer a few inches you accidentally turn it off (unless it's off, then you accidentally turn in on) I don't know which is more annoying. Everytime I want to turn it on I need to search for the button because they hid it!  I still don't know where the button for the DVD Rom is? If I touch the cover plate long enough I apparently find it because it does open.  An extraordinarily foolish design for a case.  I hate it.  It also comes with some space-age BIOS that looks more like a pinball machine!  They gave the BIOS page a new macho look, but it doesn't do the simple things that BIOS's have been doing for years, like allow it to boot to USB devices.  Because it doesn't boot to USB devices, I couldn't copy the drive onto a Solid State Drive, as I do for all my other computers, and then the 3-terabyte hard disk drive suddenly crashed the other day.  This computer never shipped with a recovery disk, and it didn't come with a Windows sticker that has a product ID either.  So what does ASUS support recommend?  They're sorry that they don't supply recovery disks, and they don't give out Windows product IDs, but get this--they told me I can BUY another Windows 8! Gee whiz, that helps a lot!

This looks like a solid stand, seems well manufactured, all the pieces fit together well and it looks nice when assembled. However, due to poor engineering, it is a completely worthless product. The wheels are attached on a thin plastic edge under the stand that is only supported by a small layer of plastic. The result of this is that if you (accidentally or intentionally) turn one of the wheel locks on, and if you try to move the unit, the locked wheel simply BREAKS OFF. This means it requires only a small amount of pressure when the stand is sitting on low-pile carpet in order to break. This is just plain bad engineering / product design. Probably if you had the stand resting on a hard, flat floor, it wouldn't be an issue but I wouldn't trust this on any type of carpet.

I bought this simultaneous with a budget Econo Mobile stand to see which I would prefer. The Econo Mobile stand has no problems at all. You can lock one or both wheels and move it around all day and the wheels are perfectly sturdy thanks to being encased in plastic all the way around. I highly recommend that stand over this one. This stand, although well manufactured, is functionally worthless.

Originally, Barracuda was what you used for decent performance work arrays.
Now, they are cut-rate desktop drives with high failure rates.

My original purchase of the 2TB drives was Nov, 2010. They started failing at 1 year.
The warranty replacements for these started out as the same drive, ST32000542AS.
In 2013, a replacement was a ST2000DL003-9VT166 which failed within 1 year.
In an array of 5 of these drives, I've replaced them 13 times (2015-03-20)

I also had work arrays with Barracuda 500GB from 2008 that failed, one drive every few months.
As they failed, they were swapped with 1TB drives.
In 2012, we lost three drives in rapid succession, and lost the entire 4+4 RAID10.

That's when we put in a 4+2 RAID6 of WD-RED drives (still happy).
Since then, I've also swapped in WD-RED drives for a 1+1 and a 3+2.
Out of 10x WD Red drives I've installed over the last 3 years, none have failed.

The failures seem to be media flakes.
When it happens out in the middle, there are scratches, and high reallocation rates all at once.
When it happens in the reserved area, the drive reports as 0 bytes and won't come online.
