With dual band and mimo, my Nexus 10 should have showed the fastest speed tests in my house. Unfortunately, not only did this not happen, but I noticed right away my speeds were slower than my older 2.4GHz wifi router by Rosewill! So I decided to perform several speed tests with different devices and connections on both this and my older router. My results were as follows:

- My old 2.4GHz router, on all devices tested, showed the same internet speeds as being directly connected to my modem via ethernet. So pretty much no loss from modem through wifi. Considering my internet runs at about 2.5 MB/s downloads, this makes sense because even the shittiest 2.4GHz wifi should have 6.75 MB/s bandwidth.

- The Anker N600 should have 37.5 MB/s bandwidth on each frequency band. So obviously my internet is the limiting factor and both routers should show same internet speeds. However, the N600 showed poor performance on both 2.4 and 5 GHz bands. 2.4 runs at 1/10 the speed of my old router! 5Ghz showed about 3/4 the speed of old router. The only way to get the same speed was to directly connect my computer to the router via ethernet, but that's not exactly what I bought this thing for. All configurations and positions of devices were replicated in each test.

So, yeah, this thing isn't great and all the other reviewers obviously don't know what they are talking about. Actually there is something very suspicious about the 5-star reviews here. They seem to be from the people selling this device because their reviews simply consist of a list of specifications and instructions for setup. Wtf kind of review is that?! I think this is unethical and Amazon should consider investigation. However, it seems Amazon is BEHIND the production and selling of these router so I doubt that will happen.

Anyway, spend the extra money and buy a name brand or speed-tested device. I recommend the Asus Gigabit dual band RT-56U. My office has one and the recent firmware added VPN server support which is AWESOME. You can virtually join your network from anywhere and share files. Also it is a very fast router.

Making fast network devices isn't easy and Anker is obviously behind on their tech. Maybe in the future they will improve but I don't think I will give them a try again.

FOOL'S GOLD is the best description of this offering. For about $35 and up you can get 128GB of real memory. At less than half that price you get a hacked drive that reports 128GB available, but will not store more than a few GB. YOUR DATA IS AT RISK.

Beware of fake capacity flash drives. This and many other cheap apparently high capacity flash drives are often low capacity 8GB or 16GB drives that have been hacked (controller chip settings altered) by dishonest Chinese suppliers so that they show a false inflated capacity. That is why their price is so low. Such drives are then redistributed by many clueless resellers and by many other fully-aware resellers who are out to make a quick profit.

Such drives will show their false capacity in Windows properties will work normally under low usage. However, once their true capacity is exceeded, they will quietly lose or corrupt your valuable data. Files will look okay in their folders, but will be corrupt when viewed, played, or otherwise read back. Your documents, photos, videos and music will be irretrievably lost.

Good 128GB drives are out there, mostly brand name drives plus a few generics, but their cost is about $35 and up (as of Q3 2015). The lion's share of this cost is the memory chips themselves. The circuit card, case, assembly costs, packaging, and distribution only add a few dollars. The Chinese are great at producing a wide range of interesting novelty designs, but they don't have a magic supply of cheap memory chips.

Be especially cautious of sellers that offer the same style in multiple sizes, but where each doubling in size is only 25% to 50% more than the size below. For example, if the 64GB drive is less than $5 more than the 32GB drive, or where the 128GB drive is less than $10 more than the 64GB. Real memory is not that cheap.

If you do buy a low-priced drive, the first thing you should do is test the capacity using a utility called h2testw. This will fill the drive with data and then verify that it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. It is the verify phase that exposes the fake capacity. Testing the first 32GB is usually sufficient. For reasons stated above, you cannot trust the capacity displayed in Windows properties.

You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt.

Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.hat it can be read back intact. The write phase usually completes without error. You can also test by filling the drive up to at least 30% with videos or other large media files and then *most importantly* check to see if they can be played back. If the capacity is faked, the first few will play, but past some point, the rest will be corrupt. Search for "fake capacity flash" using your favorite search engine for more information.

From the very first moment I powered it up, the Seagate Central has been absolutely terrible. Without a doubt, it is the worst piece of electronics that I've ever purchased. I can't remember regretting a purchase as much as I've regretted buying my Seagate Central, never more so than right now.

About an hour ago, I power cycled my Seagate Central (I'll get into why in a minute). I'd only done this once before, and like last time, I followed all of the manufacturer's instructions. I went on the web interface and stopped all ongoing activities, then unplugged the unit after the shutdown had completed. Again, I was following Seagate's instructions word-for-word.

After waiting about 10 or so minutes, I plugged my Seagate Central back in. I assumed that it would go through it's usual start up procedure, just like when I first plugged it in, and just like when I power cycled it before. Except, no. All I got was a solid yellow light on the top of the unit, and a steady beeping sound coming from somewhere inside the case. The disk isn't spinning, the drive isn't working. I want to emphasize that I have never physically moved the unit from the tabletop I set it on when I first plugged it in. It has never been bumped, dropped, or damaged in any way. It has never been subjected to extreme temperatures, just a 70 degree apartment.

After searching around the web for a while, I learned that this beeping sound was common among Seagate HDDs. In USB drives, it usually means that the drive isn't getting enough power. This, of course, couldn't be the case for my Central, seeing as it's plugged directly into a wall socket with it's own power adapter. Apart from that, so far as I can tell, I'm essentially screwed. The drive is simply broken and cannot be repaired (at least not by me).

This experience was merely the straw that broke the camel's back. My Seagate Central has never, EVER worked as advertised. It took me several days to back up mylaptop (about 260GB of data). It took almost a week to move that backup from my public share folder to my private folder (TWO FOLDERS ON THE SAME DRIVE!!!), which had to be done once I realized that Seagate puts your backup file in your public share folder by default, completely obliterating it's ability to index and share other files in the public folder. Even after I cleared out the public folder, it still takes work to get it to recognize files I've recently added. Usually, I have to stop, then restart UPNP a few times to get it to actually rescan (on two occasions, when that hasn't worked, I've had to resort to power cycling the Central, which apparently can destroy it). Then, there's the Seagate Media App, which is supposed to allow you to access media files in your public share folder from any Android or iOS device with the app. It's a complete JOKE. Even when my phone and my Central are on the same local network, the chances of the Media App working are probably 25%. If you're outside of your home network, forget about it. I've gotten it to work maybe three times, and only for about 5 minutes, after which the app suddenly disconnects from the Central and can never find it again.

I consider myself a very, very careful shopper, especially when it comes to electronics. I researched all the different home media NAS units relentlessly, meticulously. The Seagate Central seemed pretty legit. The videos of Seagate employees demoing it at CES and other consumer electronic shows made it seem like a next-gen type of device. I think that's why I'm so upset with my Seagate Central. There's absolutely no reason for a company like Seagate to make a product this bad, and to totally neglect any and all complaints from users. There's absolutely no reason for any consumer electronics product, in this day and age, to be so faulty and unreliable.

If you're thinking of buying a Seagate Central, do yourself a favor. Go to an ATM, withdraw the money you were going to spend on a Central, then go light it on fire. You'd be getting just as much out of your money doing that as you would buying this NAS, plus you'd be avoiding all the endless frustration and the sinking feeling that you've been totally screwed. I can say with confidence that the Seagate Central is the worst piece of electronics I've ever purchased, maybe even the worst thing I've ever purchased. It was so bad, that even writing this long, angry Amazon review rant hasn't quelled my rage. To do that, I'm going to stop writing this review, get up off my couch, grab my Central, head outside, and then I'm gonna frisbee that sucker as far down my street as I can fling it. I guarantee it'll be the most fun I've had with it ever.

The color purple is not a hue I expected. It's hard to describe and I can upload a photo if desired. On the functional side, I discovered quickly that I can't utilize the case fully without compromising it.  Namely, the crease became easily worn out. I'd used the case flatly, just a few times, so that I could handhold the iPad, and by the time I switched it back to the stand mode, the stand wouldn't function properly and my iPad would easily slip from its position (the bump closest to the edge of the case that would provide the lowest viewing angle).  Essentially, the case is not so versatile that it can handle going from a stand to a handheld flat case and back.  Perhaps the nature of the material inhibits it from being so versatile, as it is a pretty stiff leather-like book after all, and like a book, once you fold the cover back from the spine, a crease forms, and that crease can never be undone.  While its design makes it look wonderfully sophisticated, it falls short in functional versatility.  Also, the package comes with a nice pen but there is no holder in the case to hold it.  The plus side is that this is a business that cares about value and provided a good bargain despite this flaws.  I hope the business continues to listen to its customers.  Thank you.

Firstly, I'd like to make it known that I have given this product serious consideration before giving it only 1 star.

I am an avid gamer and I've always dreamed of using my mouse with no cable friction, within the first 15 seconds of using the Skorpion I knew this product was not for me. This product actually gave me a lot more resistance as my mouse tracks closer to the corners of the pad than the usual -- a cable rubbing on my table as my mouse moves closer to the corners of the mouse pad. This product does NOT even come close to giving a cordless experience.

I decided to just tape my mouse cord to my wall (40cm behind and below my table -- my table rests against the wall) and it worked great! Not perfect, but I'd give this method a 8.5/10 and the Skorpion a 2/10 -- just because it does nothing to improve the experience with my mouse. If not for it's sturdy build of well-constructed plastic, I'd give it a 1/10.

In closing, I feel that these \\"mouse bungee\\" products hold great promise if they can be perfected to provide a cordless experience but when it comes to the Skorpion, it doesn't come even come close to it, you're better off with simple tape.

I bought a brand new HP Pavillion laptop about a month ago. I haven't used it very much at all for fear of scratching it up or putting an ugly scuff mark on it. I like to take very good care of my electronics and I believe in investing in products to protect them. Unfortunately I have had a hard time finding any type of hard shell case for my laptop. I couldn't find any made by Speck, Otterbox, or any other well known and respectable brand. After reading a lot of great reviews on this product I thought it might be just the thing to keep my laptop from getting all marked up while in use and then I could place the laptop inside a reinforced carrying case or bag when not in use or in transit for protection. It wasn't really what I was looking for but I thought that even if it didn't look really good then maybe at least it would provide some protection while I looked for something a little better. So, I was happy to receive the case today (well before schedule) and now after opening it up I am seething. The packaging the case was shipped in arrived at the office just fine. On the mailing packaging there was no damage, no tears, and no wear so I didn't even open it up to check out the case until I got home from work. The case inside came with each part packaged in a clear bag. Each bag was open at one end. First I pulled out the bottom section of the case. It appeared exactly as described by other reviewers, i.e. vents on the bottom, legs intact. It appeared the correct size but when I tried to fit it onto the bottom section of my laptop it would not line up and fit in place. I had TRIPLE CHECKED that I was purchasing the correct case BEFORE I placed my order. I thought that maybe with the top part in place the bottom might pop in better or at least fit onto the laptop. When I slid the top section of the case out of the bag I noticed that it looked like a line or a crease running across the top section of the case. I just had the lamp on in the room so I thought my eyeswere playing tricks on me. Upon closer inspection the entire top section of the case is warped. I was wondering if maybe this is something that happened in transit when I noticed that on one of the corners the paint was all scratched off and scuffed. It looks like somebody dropped it on a concrete floor and then stuffed it inside the unsealed plastic bag. Besides the damage the item itself looks cheap, cheap, cheap and very tacky. For the price I wasn't expecting anything super high quality but I also wasn't expecting such a rip-off. I just paid $20 for two thin, flimsy, and flexible pieces of plastic - one which is damaged and the other which doesn't fit correctly. I am definitely disappointed and really ticked off about this. The pictures shown here on the Amazon website by this seller do not look like the item that I recieved. I have already sent an e-mail to the seller about returning it for a refund. The lowest rating that I have every given to a purchased item before this was something like 3 or 4 stars out of 5. If I could give this item a -5 star rating then I would do it without batting an eyelash. Sorry for the repetitiveness in this review I am ticked.

I bought this 5 months ago, was very happy until about a month ago and now my wireless mouse keeps connecting and disconnecting as does an external drive on which I keep my photos.  I have 4 items plugged into the hub which is fastened to the wall - printer, mouse, headphones, and external drive.  I'm using a MacBook with Leopard OS, and have my backup drive on the firewire connection.  I'm guessing I got a bad bit of hardware.    Updated 7/09.  I have discovered that the problem was actually the wireless mouse I was using (a LogiTech V450) and not the USB hub. I found that beside the mouse erratically losing it's connection, the external drive was also intermitently disconnecting to my computer (a MacBook.) This caused havoc with Time Machine, OS X's automatic backup.  In researching that problem I learned that sometimes Airport, the Mac's WiFi utility, can interfere with USB connections. That I started me thinking about the wireless mouse. I have now switched to a Belkin mini-mouse plugged into the USB hub, and all the USB issues have disappeared.

This product is the same as paint protection film which I have installed on a number of cars and motorcycles.  I have put (stiffer) protection film on all of my iphones. This is the first time I have thrown away a product like this in disgust. The fluid provided makes positioning of the film nearly impossible as it does nothing to diminish the tackyness of the adhesive. Once I got the film positioned, there was a fine distribution of bubbles that no amount of rubbing with the squeegy would remove. While some would go away over time, that is a silly requirement for a film that you have to look through in the meantime, and for which there will invariably be permanent spots. Finally the fact that others have seen fit to post very detailed instructions for applying this film means it is at best a marginal solution and at worst a waste of money. The Power Support product, which is thicker and less like paint protection film may be a better product to wait for.

Bought this tiem to replace a Thompson V7.  Set up was firly straight forward, however the unit would disconnect after about an hour.  I then got on the various boards and realized that this unti was having problems all over the world.  Upon on closer inspection it was all pointing to firmware problems.  I tried several different firmwares before finally getting ahold of the latest one (1.028).    This firmware is alittle more stable than any of the others.  It still causes the unit to drop connections about 1 every 3-4 hours.  Wireless signal is strong but also degrades over time.  The gigabit ports work s advertised and I have used them to test data thorughput from a NAS server to another Server.  It plugs away with no problem until about the 3-4 hour mark when the unit itself disconnects and goes through a reset process.    I was surprised that the firmware itself is very basic and does not include any capability to see devices connected to it via another gigabit switch.  My DLink 655 has no problem seeing the MAC and allows me to to assign a static DHCP address by selecting the MAC/Computername.  NOT so with the Netgear.  You have to manually add this thrugh a sub menu choice.  Apparently there is a beta firmware out that UK residents are using that works, I haven't seen it yet so can't comment on it.  Unfortunately this device, while having some good processors and speed is a pile of junk thanks to its poorly written firmware....I will be adding more to this if and when Netgear gets a better firmware out to us.  In the interim I would NOT reccommend this item.

The short review is more of a warning:

The heating plate is about 3.5\\" wide, while your standard US coffee mug is about 3.75\\" wide and therefore will NOT fit.
This is classic Chinese engineering - be inspired by a photo of someone else's product, manufacture it cheaply, but skip the prototype phase where you would normally have TESTED it (before starting manufacture). You have to wonder if this is a plot to get Americans to overfill their landfills.

Here's what WILL work:
a) a flat-bottomed, small diameter metal mug. Try a camping store and you are all set.

b) If you know someone with metal machining tools, you could drop in a 4 inch metal disk (tapered to fit the 3.5\\" hole). Unlikely for most people but someone promised they'd make a disc for me.

Teacups have narrow bases and might work, but I do not own any. I tried a metal travel mug, but because it is insulated all it does is heat the metal exterior.

The device came with a defective battery (windows couldn't recognize it, it did not charge). The keyboard didn't recognize all my input and the touch pad wouldn't recognize the multitouch gestures and scrolling.

The screen is good for a notebook this price and being a touch screen it's even better.

I would have been really satisfied with a working battery, but that and the other issues made it unusable, even more from a mobility point of view.

I requested a replacement and amazon didn't have one in stock, so I had to accept a full refund. I was unlucky, I won't be able to get a laptop this black friday season because of this.

You get what you pay for. These connectors are junk. Using two different crimping tools, which crimped other brand connectors with no issues, gave varying results. Around half the time, not all pins were completely depressed, or went crooked, making an unreliable/unusable connection.

I'll be sticking with my ideal brand connectors or the Platinum Tools EZ-RJ45 connectors.

Also, the wire channel is much shorter on these connectors making getting the wires in the connector to stay in the proper order more of a pain. In my picture, an ideal brand connector on the left and the connector in this review on the right.

The left and right mouse buttons are actually a part of the touchpad and not seperate. So, when you lift your finger up and go to press the left button to click on something... BOOM, you just clicked on an ad or some other random place. If I'm not explaining it well, here: The touchpad is layered over the buttons. Every time you go to click on something the mouse shoots off into a random area and click in that location on your screen. Total waste of money.

Sure, this is a great modem, perhaps the best, BUT DON'T BUY IT!
Spend the extra $10 for the white one, which is the retail version.

The problem is that this company, Zumbee Inc., is selling USED modems, modems which were originally distributed to customers of ISPs such as TWC.

After installing mine yesterday, it got \\"kicked out\\" of service today because it came up in Time Warner's data as belonging to another customer (based on the MAC ID, which is like a fingerprint for modems).
Time Warner straightened it out for me no problem, but I think it's sick that I'm buying something, believing that it's new, and it turns out to be used.

Hoping Amazon will help me resolve this issue.

Since this keyboard has lasted more than a year under many hours of typing every day, I'm giving it one star. Otherwise, it is somewhat problematic and I think it should not be your first choice for a keyboard. First and foremost, the wire is unusually short. I have a desk with a pull-out keyboard ledge. The cable is so short that I couldn't plug it in normally (through the ledge, under the desk, and plug in from the rear) but had to attach it over the top from the front. I sometimes move keyboards to the desk extension (the short leg of an L-shaped desk) if I need to work on paper at the same time, and the wire doesn't stretch that far so I can't use the extension. It's difficult to work on papers because that over-the-desk cable gets in the way, and if I'm not even using the computer and just need to do other work on my desk, the cable is still in the way. It's a big annoyance.

Even more of an annoyance is that the labels on the keys began wearing off after just a few months. I type a lot, but this is the first time I've ever experienced such a thing in all my years using a keyboard, even back to the days of typewriters! Since I am a touch typist (90 wpm), I rarely look at the keys and have managed for the most part without any labeling, but it's just plain weird. As other reviewers stated, the keyboard is unusually cramped and gets uncomfortable after a while. I do not recommend this keyboard unless you have no other options.

SUMMARY:  Not good for the Kindle Touch (2011) because of the adapter. The lamp is great. However the adapter for attaching this lamp onto the Kindle Touch (2011) is absolutely inferior, insufficient, falls off, and scratches the back of the Kindle. Not good at all.   The adapter ruins this product's usage, for this model of Kindle. The product page advertises compatibility, so this was a very misleading experience.  The adapter, however, is not needed for all other Kindle models.   You should find out if your model fits the lamp's main clip natively or not, before you think of buying this lamp. We cannot be sure which models fit natively, that info is not on the product page, at the time of this writing.  The actual lamp is well-designed, and the main clip might serve many readers very well.   DETAILS:  This is a great lamp, well-designed, well-packaged, great illumination (low and high setting), and looks and feels very solid. It attaches using an adjustable clip. ...Think of a gentle vice grip, with an internal spring which lets you widen the \\"clamp\\" as needed.   For a thicker Kindle or e-reader, this lamp's main clip design looks like it would be great... if your Kindle model fit natively.  Unfortunately, none of that holds true for the Kindle Touch (2011 model). This lamp comes with only a plastic, U-shaped adapter, to attach to that model.   CONCLUSION:  This adapter defeats everything good about the lamp, and makes this an unstable and cheap afterthought, by contrast to the original lamp design. The adapter does not fit the top of the Kindle well. It does not even attempt to \\"click\\" in. Was not designed to stay on.  Looks like a great design for thicker Kindles or readers, maybe five stars for them.   However I can hardly give even two stars for this lamp -- and I wish the U-shaped adapter was clearly explained on the product listing -- or better yet, re-designed and proven to work to an acceptable level.   In fact, if they re-manufactured this lamp to reallyfit the Kindle Touch (2011), I would absolutely give it a try, because the lamp seems great, it just cannot properly attach to this model.   Next time I buy a Kindle lamp accessory, I will have to wear my Three-Wolf Moon T-shirt, to ensure supreme excellence on every level.  NOTE:   This adapter is supplied in the package, just in case the purchaser has a Kindle Touch (2011) model, even though it does not attach well at all.

A little while ago my laptop stopped charging. Rather than immediately taking it into the repair place to get it looked at, I decided to take a punt on ordering a new charger (my old charger was pretty old, and had been kicked around a bit). This one was cheap so I got it with one-day shipping (Had no problems whatsoever with the shipping part, it arrived on time and packaged fine).

So I tried plugging it into my computer, I found that if I held the cord in just the right position it would charge, which obviously wasn't a complete solution (though it was admittedly helpful to get a little extra time), so I took it to the repair shop. Fair enough, if the problem actually was with the computer, changing the power cable wouldn't be expected to do anything.

However when the repair shop did get back to me they said they had tested it and the fault was with the charger, not with the computer. I went back on Amazon, bought a new cord for about twice the price (around $16) that was certified by ASUS, and have had no problems since, and am using it now.

TL;DR This cable didn't work for me; get a slightly more expensive one that will.

I will never buy a Lenovo product again. I received my tablet and upon about a month of having it, the Internet connection stopped working. I tried on several different networks, and the connection was either absent or only one bar, even when standing right next to the router with another device that was clocking in normal download and upload speeds. I called Lenovo customer support for a repair, and they immediately shipped me a box to send off the device. I was a bit pleased with their promptness. However, upon receiving the device, I could tell that they had done nothing to take care of the device's environment, as my Thinkpad was so cold that I could barely touch it and had to wrap it in a blanket to warm it up. I have had a computer and TV delivered in the middle of January and neither had a problem with being cold like that. And this was late October/early November that I had sent off my device for repair.
Once it warmed up, I charged it and turned it on. The internet was working, apparently network card issues are common with this device. After I reached the desktop, the screen went black and flashed to the login screen. I thought that was weird, but kept going without any interference for about an hour. Then, the tablet did this screen thing again and again until its screen was constantly flashing on and off. This caused the tablet to crash at least five times that night, the night I FIRST had the tablet back from repair. Needless to say, I was frustrated and decided to let it rest overnight.
The next day, the tablet started working fine before repeating the problem. I refreshed the computer and reinstalled Windows, and still the problem persisted. For some reason, I kept thinking the problem would go away, so I kept holding on to the device in hopes that time would heal my Thinkpad. After a week of this frustrating problem, it stopped. For a week, I never experienced the screen black out and turn to the login screen like I had previously. I thought I was right and the problem went away. However, after snapping a couple pictures one day, the problem came back. At first, the screen time out was once maybe every 10 minutes or so, before it progressed to a constant flash by the end of the day. Again, I tried refreshing the PC, reinstalling Windows, and everything else I could think of to solve the problem, to no avail. The computer crashed several times, so much so that it drained the battery life.
With finals coming up, I really needed this tablet to perform at optimum level. I should not have so many problems within only two months of having the device. I called Lenovo to ask for another repair. They sent me a box, however you do not get any sort of confirmation via email, text, or anything with the information regarding your repair with them until they are ready to ship it back to you. Thus, I had to call back to get the case number, since I didn't think to write it down when the guy quickly read it off to me. The servers of course happened to be down that day, so they could not tell me. When I called back the following business day (because that is when I was told the refund staff would be available), I was told that a representative from this department would call me back within 24-72 hours. Since the 72 hours fell on this past Thanksgiving day, I gave them until Friday to reach me. No one has called and it is now Sunday. I am calling tomorrow to demand a full refund, and again will never buy another Lenovo product. This device is absolutely terrible and gimmicky, which is sad, because it is so amazing in concept. I was really looking forward to a Windows 8 tablet with a stylus, and now struggle to find something comparable without emptying out the bank account (this is already a high-price tablet to begin with).

On the note of the stylus, it wasn't that great anyway. It has no eraser (which makes writing on pdf's annoying if you make mistakes), and can get horribly off sometimes (by an inchor so) if you either move your finger to the screen while using the pen or hold it at an angle. At the edges of the screen, the pen detection is typically quite off. Maybe it's too soon for the technology of a stylus with Windows, but I did really enjoy being able to both highlight and annotate my research papers, as well as draw diagrams, etc. on them.

Okay I'm writing this review a little early, I've been using it for 4 days now and the feel of the case is just amazing, the polish and design gives you a really good first impression. I had a concern about the case not having a built-in screen protector but you really cant wish for everything. The exposed screen makes me slightly uneasy but you can easily remedy that with a screen protector.
The typing positions are VERY stable, even though it doesnt seem so! Theres no clicking mechanism, the two positions just utilize the friction between the rubber of the case and the inside fabric of the cover, it is more stable than you'd think, I was very pleased when typing away on the iPad's screen.
Something that is usually underrated, there is a tiny groove on the right side for you to put your finger through when you want to open the case, the designers did put an effort into making this a good experience for the user. There were even markings on the inside of the cover to point out where you should position your iPad. Little details matter.
The 'grippy' case makes it suitable for any surface, and even carrying it feels great. The only problem is that it will make it quite irritating to shove in your backpack with your books, the rubber makes it difficult to slide between books, so I wouldnt recommend this to students who usually take their ipads to university.

EDIT: I reduced the rating to ONE star due to the extreme difficulty I had just to REMOVE the case. I wanted to take it out of the case and what a pain that was, I hurt my hands just trying to get it out! Also, the wobbly stand ALWAYS falls off whenever you pick up the ipad, making it incredibly awkward and it doesnt look good when you are out in a coffee place or class. The fact that there is no built-in screen protector let it collect a LOT of dust and smudges. For this price you can get a case with a built-in screen protector.
Bottom line: good first impression, bad on the long run. Not recommending this to anyone.. Not recommending this to anyone.

Great style, look and feel. Great fit for the SP3 (with exceptions), and by most respects, I am happy with it. HOWEVER, take note of the following regarding use with the SP3 (i7): There are no openings for the speakers at all - the leather completely covers the speakers! The top of the case does have holes intended for venting, but they are not positioned correctly: They sit flush against the side of the SP and do not touch the SP vents. With the i7 version and doing CPU intensive tasks, this causes problems considering the rest of the SP is also snuggled in leather. As a smaller downside, the keyboard cannot be folded underneath the SP3 along with the case front - ergo, you must remove the keyboard if you want to use in "tablet" mode. Last but not least, the keyboard cannot be locked into the propped up elevated position (as shown in the picture). The leather lips used to secure the SP block the magnetic anchor points needed to lock the keyboard up. They could of solved this by putting an additional set of magnets on the leather lips, but they didn't. These are the only downsides I observed with what "could" be an awesome product!

This is the first time I have felt compelled to write a review, because my purchase was such a negative experience.

I received the laptop last Wednesday. I performed all Windows updates, customized settings to my taste, and installed a lot of standard software on the first night. Standard software like Microsoft Office, Google Chrome, Google Earth, Mozilla Firefox, iTunes, etc. I pretty much spent all night doing this.

I didn't touch the laptop at all on Thursday, because I was busy with other things. Friday night, it began experiencing repeated crashes (blue screen of death). I performed suggested diagnostics to no avail. After a series of crashes and restarts, it was crashing nearly immediately after login. So I reset it to factory settings.

Saturday, I went through the same process of customizing settings and installing software. Today (Sunday), it crashed again, and now it will not boot at all. It goes through a startup repair sequence on every boot, but cannot make a successful repair. It then takes me to a HP recovery screen that offers several options, none of which are selectable (clicking on the options results in no action). I am left with the only option to reboot (and repeat the sequence) or shutdown.

So I initiated a return this morning.

On my work laptop, I run Windows 7 with all the same applications and have never had a single crash, in 2+ years. So it should not be the software I installed. I can only assume it is the HP laptop.

I used a leased Centurylink c1000a for about a year, and a week ago I decided to buy a used one and return the leased one.
Setting up the "new" used one was a real problem. I knew the correct procedure to get into Quick setup, but the modem/setup webpage would not allow me to enter my ppp username and password. I did searchs, did resets and reboots, talked to Centurylink tech "help" 3 times, and got nowhere. During the last Centurylink tech "help" session, they tried to access the modem from their end, failed, and told me the modem was defective and should be returned. I was ready to accept that, but decided to see if using a different browser could possibly make any difference. This was my own idea and I hadn't come across the suggestion to do so either on the web or from Centurylink tech "help".
I had been using Chrome. I tried Firefox and unlike Chrome, it allowed me to a alter the ppp un and pw, but it wouldn't stay altered. That seemed to indicate the browser did influence the process, so I re-activated MS IE. Literally, in a few minutes the modem was setup and has been working perfectly for a day now.
I'm using Win 8.1 64bit and it's just possible that that might make a difference, Microsoft products being what they are....
In any case, I give this modem failing marks on 2 counts: 1) that this kind of problem exists in the first place; 2) that nowhere in the Centurylink or Actiontec webpages or tech "help" assistance is there any mention of the browser influencing things. This modem has been out for over a year and from my experience, this poor tech work.
If you're having setup problems, try switching browsers and see if that helps. Good luck.

I have never been so angry that I have felt a need to post a review on Amazon, but for this hard drive I make exception.    Lets start with the pros - It is pretty fast when it works.    DONE    Now for the cons - Constant BSOD's (blue screen of death.) I did everything I could to remedy the situation. I updated the firmware, I secure erased it, nothing worked. Many people are having this problem, and all the company can say is the upgrade the firmware. It does not help that OCZ is a shell company. I couldn't get a hold of one person in their office. Seriously, either nobody works there or nobody answers their phone.    The problem seems to lye in the sanforce chipset, so don't you go thinking that you will just buy a Corsair/Crucial hard drive because they are having the same issues. If you need an SSD then I strongly recommend shelling out the extra money for a Intel 510. They are supposed to not be as fast but I cannot tell a difference. Intel is STABLE, that is more than I can say for most everyone else. Check out these fail rates if you don't believe me.    - Intel 0.59%  - Corsair 2.17%  - Crucial 2.25%  - Kingston 2.39%  - OCZ 2.93%    So please... do not buy this company's garbage. Let the guiding hand of capitalism bring them to financial ruin.

While I had misgivings about buying an off-brand laptop charger, I couldn't pass up the price. The item arrived quickly, and seemed to work fine at first. Within 3 months, I started having problems:    1)It started running hot, which I noticed first because the label on the brick came off because the heat melted the adhesive. I just thought it was cheap adhesive and didn't think much of it.    2)The part of the cord that covers the wires inside it separated in 2 places (on either side of the power brick), leaving the wires inside exposed. Because I use this at home, not traveling, and don't move it around much, I thought I could just be careful, and it wouldn't matter.    3)As of today, the power is now cutting out intermittently, and I'm worried it will do damage to my laptop. I have it plugged into a surge-protected power supply, and like I said, I'm not moving this around, so I don't know why this is happening.    I sent an email message to the seller today, describing these problems, and hopefully they will offer and exchange/refund. But next time I'll go with the Toshiba charger and pay the extra money.

These screen protectors are of good quality!!! However when I ordered them I expected them to actually be CLEAR, since that is what the description said. When I got them in the mail I opened them up and they turned out to be ANTI-GLARE, and NOT clear.

Since one of the things that attracted me to the Nexus 7 is the awesome screen quality, I did not want to "distort the screen" with an anti-glare screen protector. (Which if you have compared an anti-glare, meaning the protector is kind of pixelated to help deflect sunlight, with a clear screen protector, meaning...you guessed it CLEAR) you know what I mean about distorted.

I have an anti-glare protector on my iphone and there is definitely a loss of quality, which I am ok with because I use my phone outside way more often then I do my tablet.

So if you are looking for a CLEAR screen protector do not buy these. They are in fact ANTI-GLARE.

Also the customer service is not very good. I tried to email them and explain what I have put in this review, and did not get a response for a few weeks. Finally when I got a response...it did not address anything I had written them about.

I searched for a replacement for my power supply for my laptop and I thought \\"WOW\\" I can't believe that I found one this low in price. It was to good to be true. Please go directly to Sony for a replacement. Mine didn't even last two weeks. I found out that the number after the voltage is what matters. The replacement purchased here only had a 1 after the V which means only one volt. That's why it did not last. Be careful not to go over the voltage required for your laptop or you could blow your hard drive.

One of the attributes of the Ipad 2, is how thin it is.  Use this Belkin case, and you completely take away this attribute.  The Ipad 2 fits into this case very snuggly...too snuggly.  Once you have it in, you have a VERY hard time taking it out.  Who needs that?  Compare this to a Leather Yoobao case.  The Yoobao fits snuggly, yet maintains the ability to insert and remove the Ipad from the case easily.  The Belkin's material makes it difficult to remove the Ipad from the case. Once you do have the Ipad inserted, their are holes in the proper places to access the buttons, port and headphone.  But here again, the access with the Yoobao style case is much better.      The Belkin keyboard paired and worked well.  You could cut and paste with dedicated keys.  You can also turn the music on and off, turn the volume up and down with dedicated keyboard keys  (much like the Apple Wireless Keyboard.  The Apple Wireless Keyboard is compact, yet is more spacious than the Belkin.  The space of the keys on the Apple Wireless Keyboard are layed out about one inch wider and 3/8 inch taller.        You have to wonder, why it isn't better to use a Yoobao leather case which maintains the thinness and lightness of the Ipad 2, and just buy an Apple Wireless Keyboard.  It is true that this would leave you with 2 items to carry...but it allows you to take advantage of the light thin attribute of the Ipad 2, and have a better keyboard when you need it.  With the Belkin, you may have the keyboard attached at all times, but the Ipad is heavier, about 2 1/2 times thicker than with another case (like Yoobao)and rather awkward to unfold.      While this is a nice beta try by Belkin, I would pass.

After only 6 weeks of use and no noteworthy physical trauma, this drive failed catastrophically, corrupting most of the data on it in the process. I wish I listened to the voice in my head saying, \\"Hmm, this doesn't seem very sturdy,\\" when I took it out of the box, but I instead used it as planned for housing files I need at home and at the digital lab that I use for work. As another reviewer observed, this hard drive had an annoying spontaneous ejecting habit. My real problem was when it imploded - with a backup in progress - after less than 2 months of use. It was functioning normally one minute and then the drive's light started blinking and my computer was unable to recognize it. We tried the drive in another enclosure and hooked to a linux computer that usually will recognize even corrupted drives. Nothing.  The data recovery lab I ultimately sent it to had to replace multiple \\"physically damaged\\" components to restore functionality and found more than half of the data was in fact corrupted. Mind you, this drive had never been dropped and travelled primarily in a protective camera bag.  Call me crazy, but I think that a drive billed as \\"ultra-portable\\" should be able to withstand a few weeks of regular desktop use and the occasional commute.  Do not recommend.      Note:  I have a few older Seagate external hard drives (different models) that I've used for 1-2 years without incident. I've travelled extensively with them and had nothing but good things to say. That's why I went with Seagate on this one. I might even have been able to forgive the company its obvious construction and quality departure on this line but for the nightmarish customer service experience I had with Seagate after the drive crashed. Suffice it to say, I've sworn off Seagate products indefinitely.

I needed assistance with my computers color profile and how it renders differently on the Dell than it does on another monitor. I did everything I could to troubleshoot the issue myself. As a last resort, I contacted Technical Support. I'm not a big phone talker, so I decided to use Dell's chat option online. However, I wasn't able to make it very far since most Dell monitors do not have a service tag on them. It's even started directly on Dell's site, most monitors don't have service tags. If that's the case, why is a service tag required in order to start a chat session? So, I decided to pick up the phone and contact their support, figuring a human can get around this nonsense. I called and had to sit on hold for about 45 minutes. I started to get a bit frustrated since the whole time sitting on hold I kept trying to troubleshoot the issue myself without success. Finally, a soft spoken female answers the phone and asks me for my service tag. I let her know that it's a monitor I'm calling about and they do not have service tags. I proceeded to tell her about the issue I'm having and the phone started to make sounds and eventually disconnected me. I was not going through another 45 mins hold session with this crappy tech support. Dell is way too big of a company to have technical support that is this bad. They have plenty of links to contact a sales rep all over their site, but you have to dig and dig and dig to locate tech support, wait on hold for close to an hour, to only be disconnected. Please note that this review is mainly for the service that I received, which is the package deal when purchasing this semi-expensive monitor. I could possibly have figured out the issue with the monitor if I persisted, but do not feel like I should have to.
My repair tech said that it was the wrong fit for my Chromebook which I don't believe, but who am I to argue?  Now, I'll have the hassle of returning it or forgetting about it.

But in the end it always goes the same way; no reliable connection, constant rebooting, calls to tech support, with the hope that a firmware beta has been released that will prolong the death of this worthless and apparently completely faulty piece of hardware that will most assuredly end up being sent back to it's home for a quick resuscitation just to be sent right back out to some other owner; where the cycle will repeat itself, over and over again. And the only real pain on your end is paying for shipping approx. $12-15 every time you RMA--so my grand total for this here router is now at $131 when I add extra shipping costs, thanks ASUS, you're the best! So if you love wasting money and time and getting very little in return, then this is your router.   PS Anyone wanna buy a \\"new\\" ASUS RT-N16? I'm looking to upgrade to something that works.

I received my ativ 700t yesterday that was on my wish list since several months because of its versatility. I solely bought it to use it as a home/office machine thinking i would use it with a docking station on external monitors in office and as a laptop at home. While i have not yet tried it on external monitor yet, just using it as a laptop was a terrible experience. Keyboard is made of solid metal making it really heavy. I also have a 12\\" fujitsu Core I7 laptop at home all possible ports integrated and much thicker than ativ but its much lighter.

As i mentioned, everything looks too small on ativ and changing the resolution made characters blurry. Touch responsiveness is good and so is the pen. I bought it to do a lot of pdf reading and possible annotations where necessary using the pen, taking notes in meetings and have all my work related stuff at one place whether at home, office or a conference. Holding the tablet alone in portrait is awkward. Just too long. Width fit pdf's were too small to read. In landscape mode, character size was great but since height is not much, only a small part of the page was displayed. I am also test driving the galaxy note 10.1 and while it is also kind of too wide, its less wide and lighter than ativ. I have despised windows 8 so far. May be i will like it if i learn it more but i find windows 7 more user friendly. In desktop mode, when you touch on a field where you want to type, the keyboard does not automatically appears. I have to manually enable/disable the screen keyboard through the keyboard icon at the bottom. This may have to do with some setting but this is the default setting i am talking about. I tested the WIDI on ativ 700t and it worked great while playing a youtube video. There was probably a lag of less than one second but connection was clear and stable.

I like windows and android tablets more and hate ipads especially due to lack of memory card and other slots, just okay camera, no widi etc. However, i must admit that as a tablet, the aspect ratio and size of Ipads are the best. I dont know why samsung and other companies are making these things wider and wider. I just saw some new tablet with an aspect ratio of 21:9 which is ridiculous.

My ativ is going back. I will wait for a better sized hybrid tablet/computer with digital pen before buying again. Or may be soon enough ipad will come with a digitizer pen and despite being an android/windows fan, i would go for the ipad with pen just for its aspect ratio.

Chances are, if you're looking at a fanless Radeon card, you're probably looking into video acceleration of some sort. You need advanced warning that this feature has been broken for over a year on this hardware.

Catalyst 11.7, which came out July of 2011, is the last driver that has supported accelerated 3D Blu-Ray playback, which requires nearly twice the CPU resources of regular Blu-Ray playback. Even if you're fine with going back to the old driver, VC-1 acceleration is broken in this driver. Pretty much every Blu-Ray movie that ISN'T in 3D will play so slowly that you're better off DISABLING video acceleration for it.

No driver before 11.7 supported acceleration for 3D Blu-Ray movies, and no driver SINCE 11.7 supports the feature. Basically, if you're planning on using this for that feature, as the card was listed on AMD's HD3D page, STEER CLEAR. Go Nvidia, buy an Intel Sandy/Ivy bridge processor, do ANYTHING BUT buy this card.

I presented this issue to AMD's technical support in MAY, and August is nearly over. They've repeatedly closed my support requests without fixing the issue or even MENTIONING it in any of the driver releases that have come out in that time span.

The only star here is for HIS, which has nice packaging.

The drive worked for about a week under light load. When loaded heavily, the design of the chassis is not made to adequately dissipate heat, so the drive quickly reaches 65 deg C and above (the max rated temperatue for many of the ICs they use, including the thunderbolt controller). After using this drive as the source drive for some video editing work, the drive shut down by itself, and is now making a clicking sound and will not turn on. The clicking sound is likely due to a sparkgap (but I can't find one on the board) or failed inductor (most likely) and is not the fault of the disk drive.

I opened the device to determine why it failed so fast, and found very poor thermal design. The disk has an airgap between the bottom classes and is isolated using 3 support pads with poor thermal contact. Rather than using some thermally conductive sil padding, to improve thermal performance, they just used these 3 poorly placed pads .

I am sure I violated the warranty and cannot get an RMA now since I opened it, but given the poor design quality I would not trust their products with my data anyways. Very dissapointed in the design of this drive. If they increased the thermal conductivity and added some more passive cooling features (maybe some side air vents to allow minor air exchange / sil padding to increase thermal conductivity) it would be a much better product.

I got my first tablet years ago when I was still in grade school, it was this tiny little Graphire thing that you could hardly use. It was all plastic and clear, nothing like the sleek design of the Intuos or Bamboo tablets. I don't use it anymore, but you know what? I could if I wanted to. I could use that tiny Graphire because it still works. Unlike the Intuos 4 and Intuos 5s I have bought within the last year and a half. As an animation student, having a tablet is absolutely essential. I can't do any work what-so-ever without one and Wacom is supposed to be the top of the line in this area. However both products I have bought, most recently the Intuos 5, have struggled with USB port issues.

I bought my Intuos 5 back in April of THIS YEAR. The USB port stopped working in MAY. That is absolutely ridiculous! I was only lucky that I had already finished all of my school work! I sent it off to be fixed, and it was. I couldn't use it for two months though because I had work where i couldn't use my tablet. So I have been using my Intuos 5 for approximately a month and now its broken AGAIN. Its on September! How is that even possible?? Does anyone at this company even know what they are doing?

My answer is yes. The people at customer service are kind, and make sure you have everything you need to get it sent in and fixed. But after that? Down the line? Obviously something is out of whack. I just called customer service again to get help and it turns out the serial number for this one is different than my old Intuos 5. Which means that Wacom didn't even send MY tablet back. They sent me some other poor schmuck's tablet that doesn't work either.

I don't even know what to say about this product. It works really, really well. WHEN IT WORKS. However that won't be very often, now will it?

So lets see. If you don't mind having to take 2 week breaks every few months to send this thing out for repairs, then I say go ahead. I completelyrecommend this tablet. But if you need consistancy and your lively hood depends on the Intuos actually performing well for a long time? I say search elsewhere or buy used. DO NOT waste your money to buy this new and have it crap out on you every few months. You deserve more than that.

The mouse isn't particularly nice either--it is imprecise and the sensor is not under the center of mass so it only works well on flat surfaces, not the arm of my couch on which the cheap wired mouse that came with my machine works fine.    This would be a lousy piece of hardware for 20 bucks, for the price that is charged it is absolute junk.    Given Microsoft's resources I would expect them to have done a more thorough job of testing.    Edit:  28 APR 2011:  Putting the receiever on a long USB cable and hanging it over the top of the monitor seems to solve the problems I've had.  Apparently the signal isn't strong enough to penetrate common furniture materials.    I'd revise my review to 3 stars if the Amazon system allowed it.

Apparently my MSI GT70 0NC-494US won't boot up because my hard disk is broken. Brought it in our local service center, they said they don't accept international warranty here in the Philippines. Now, after 4 months my laptop screen is falling, almost every week the horizontal lines get bigger. Really for this kind of laptop? so much hassle! I bought this because of global warranty only to realize that Msi Philippines doesn't accept global warranty. What is the point of this global warranty if they grant it?

For an high end laptop, hard disk should last atleast 2 yrs and now i think my laptop is falling apart! I barely even use the laptop. Poor MSI SERVICE CENTER.
It was the wrong size. I sent it back

Got this a week ago, I had A-Power's 900w and killed it when i tried swapping out the stock noisy fan, set back of $70, my fault. Bought this 1100w to give the brand another try, died in less than a week. For the money, around $100, it's most likely cheaply made when one considers other name brands are more expensive and probably more reliable. molex and sata connectors are on other side of psu, unusual and very hard for wire management. My system has two ati cards in crossfire, even though this has the required connectors, it could not handle 1-2 hours of gaming, it sparked and popped, disco all wires and checked my components. did not power on again. out another $100. Total: $170, could have bought a name brand psu and better performance. Dont want to go thru the hassel of rma w/ mnftr as geeks.com will not touch it (geeks says sales are final and warranty goes through manufacturer) If you have a single gpu, buy it at your own risk, if you have expensive components invest in something name brand and more money, it will be worth it, Im going with either Antec, Corsair (very popular), Cooler Master, or another major brand player. Stay away unless if you want bragging rights of 1100w system, not worth the money and potential to harm you components.     Pros:  -inexpensive  -case looks great and red fan    Cons:  -Cheap  -Cheap  -Cheap  -Died in less than a week  -built in harness is split on both sides (wth ???)
Got it the middle of December, 2014 and it worked great until 04/18/15, when it stopped working.

This charger sucks!  It keeps coming away from the laptop.  The biggest thing I don't like about it is that it gets VERY, VERY hot!  So hot that I have to unplug it from the computer in a short amount of time.  Don't waste your money!
The anti virus is not effective at all

Description says it has the Ralink RT5370 chipset, but the first one I tested out of the three I ordered had a Realtek 8188CUS chipset. No big deal, it still works with the Raspberry Pi, but it wasn't what was advertised.

Update 1/5/14:

This chipset does not seem to work well with the HSMM-Pi setup as far as compatibility with the Broadband Hamnet v1 router firmware. Others who got the same dongle with the Ralink chipset don't have the same issues.

I had a Wireless IntelliMouse Explorer that works great except for the batteries having to be replaced too frequently. I wanted to replace it with a \\"better\\" product so I got the Microsoft Wireless Laser Mouse 6000. I found a couple things with it that I am not satisfied with.

1. It has erratic movement of the pointer when used on my desk surface. Microsoft support tells me that will happen on a reddish brown colored surface. So now I have to use a mouse pad which defeats the purpose of using a wireless mouse.

2. I like to keep a PS/2 mouse connected also. Having the PS/2 connected with my older wireless caused no problem. Now with the Microsoft Wireless Laser Mouse 6000 connected, I have different tracking speeds between the two. When I adjust the Wireless 6000 to the pointer speed I want, the PS/2's speed is very slow, about half the speed. In other words, the PS/2 has to travel twice the distance as the Wireless 6000 to move the pointer the same distance.

Sooo, I'm back to the battery eating mouse.

Very disappointed. Window software does not work with Windows 8. Device keeps saying a software update is available and even gives a new version number. No link is provided in the Seagate program that tells you this. No update seems to exist. Their web site only offers the shipping version. A call to support said they had other calls about same problem. Tech sent me \\"updated\\" software but after install discovered it was same version that shipped and would not work. Also, network device seems to show and then not show in explorer.

Tried it on my Mac. Time Machine would never recognize it. I wish companies would stop rushing half-baked products to market and qui making compatibility claims that are not true. This device is not ready for primetime NOR is it Windows 8 compatible. Answer to your customers first, and then your CFO.

Really wanted to love this power supply as the packaging was pretty amazing for what this is.  They definitely hired some professional packaging people to work on this and you get an overwhelming confidence in the quality of the product you just purchased.  The modular cables come in their own little bag which was also a nice touch.  Also through in a rubber sound dampener also a nice bonus.  The thing is I know one can be duped by nice packaging but I really did feel on first glance that thermaltake takes pride in their products.    After hooking this all up with my new build I immediately heard an annoying capacitative sound coming from the power supply as soon as there was a load on the 12V rails from the first boot up.    I'll update once I receive the new one.  It doesn't bum me out as it would others because things like this happen with diy builds.  On the other hand, the quality control just isn't there.
This did not work as well as a Netgear in my network. I ended up returning this and picking up another Netgear GS116. I wanted to like it for the price but it was noticeably slow on my network.

No markings on the Antenna's at all,  so not sure if they are actually made by Asus.  The 3 antenna's came in a envelope with no box at all.  The antennas were not good quality,  so loose at the base that they would not stand up or stay in position.  I sent them back.

Does NOT fit in gt-n8013 samsung galaxy 10.1 note 2.
It might work great for some other samsung note product. Doesnt fit in mine.

Bought this 5 1/2 months ago. The first 3-4 months were perfect, one of the best headsets you could get for your money. Around December is when I started to have problems with it. It would disconnect at random times even if it was plugged in during charging and the charges didn't last as long as it did the first few months. Then a few weeks ago the left part of the headset broke off so now its just dangling around by a wire. Really not worth the money.

I just bought this item here on amazon 7 days ago and I'm having a  problem with my Canon T2i. Video recording stops after 4 seconds, which further research reveals is the fault of a counterfeit memory card. As soon as I read many similar stories on the net, I checked back here on Amazon to find the product page for this memory card indicate \\"This item is currently unavailable because customers have told us there may be something wrong with our inventory of the item, the way we are shipping it, or the way it's described here.\\" I sincerely hope Amazon supplies me with a new, non-counterfeit, fully functional memory card or refunds my money in full.

The boss found these on special and got 3 for the office, and I got one.  I hate it SO MUCH! The trackpad is absolutely awful - extremely temperamental, fails to register clicks very frequently.  Additionally, the keyboard has these extra keys along the left side.  They open your email, web browser, the \\"hp media center\\", the calculator, or the print dialog.  They are pointless and extremely easy to accidentally hit, so you bring up the calculator in the middle of typing an email, for example.  Additionally, while you can remap most of the keys using hacks, you can't remap the print key without remapping the \\"P\\" key also.  Idiotic design.  Did HP's engineers ever use this?  They should be sentenced to using nothing but this machine for the next year.    It's fine when using an external mouse & keyboard.  But IT'S A FRIGGIN' LAPTOP IT SHOULD BE USABLE ON MY DAMN LAP!!!

I received my Kindle 2 as a present. I had not heard anything about this product before I received it. After it was explained to me what it was, I thought \\"Great\\"! I am an avid reader, but after having my Kindle for two month's I am disappointed. I thought when I first got it that I could now read in bed without turning on a light, but it is not back-lit as I would have thought it would be. Also, even though I can adjust the font size, I find it is very hard on my eyes. I am always blinking alot and just straining my eyes to see  better. Another annoyance is the battery icon. It is a very light grey color and hard to see how close it is to needing recharged. For the price, I think you could do better.

They advertise this mouse to have a range of 10 meters.  Not even close.  I bought it to use with a bluetooth keyboard using my TV as a monitor.  This setup is at most 15 feet from the computer, directly across the room.  The mouse does make contact with the computer but the pointer jumps all over the screen.  The keyboard functions perfectly from the same place. I tried contacting tech support and eventually I got a generic e-mail with a list of things to try.  All of which I had already done.  When I informed them that it still didn't live up to their advertising they sent me another one that worked the same and then they closed the support claim.  If you are looking for a wireless mouse to use more than a couple of feet from your computer look somewhere else.

Bought this SSD last year to install in place of my ever so slowly dying hard drive. Just installed it around 9-days ago and got the blue screen of death this morning when turning the system on. Had to use my cell phone just to get the return information. Couldn't run any diagnostics since, hello, the disk is completely dead.

I only wish that I had known about this LEMON before making my purchase. Off it went to Seagate via USPS Priority Mail, of course, at my expense. I am just glad that I saved the dying drive, which go my back up and running for now.

Unfortunately the product i bought came defective, Avermedia did not help me at all. I am hoping that the store replace the defective product bought for one that works. If you are looking for a capture card that is not a good option, all I gained from it was a headache and lose money.

I recently Bought a Samsung Ultra it didn't work right out of the box. I bought it the night before a trip to Asia. While in Asia I bought and Intel SSD had it installed hoping this would fix one of the problems. It didn't I have Solid States drives in all my computers I added it to each one. I have another Samsung i7 laptop that's been great the Ultra has been nothing short of a nightmare that keeps getting worse. I Talked with best buy who sold it to me they gave me full trade in credit after almost 2months. I bought a dell xps12. it is the best Ultra book in my opinion. It will be a very long time before I ever buy another Samsung ANYTHING. There customer support is horrible their quality and execution is poor at best. Samsung has problems with ultras returning from sleep also they lock the bios down and installed windows key making upgrading nearly impossible with a disk if you can believe that. Also their tech support tells people that you void your warranty when adding a SSD oh by the way you have to replace the motherboard and keyboard to fix both problems the bios lock down and software non compatibility and the sleep problem. the ultra is not compatible with Intel 520series SSD.I can only tell you how difficult this has been. Samsung's website states you don't void your warranty when you change the hard drive. Maybe Samsung can learn to teach their employees how to properly handle service calls. Maybe Samsung can even decide next time to not try to market anything that has this many problems until they can make it right. The best advise I can give is return them while you still can and get a Dell xps12, Acer, asus, lenova one of PC magazines top ten ultra list that Samsung doesn't make it on. I was very surprised how many samsung's are broken right out of the box this reminds me of GE televisions in the 80's 70 percent failure rate out of the box. Samsung must be Looking to make all the money all the time putting quality and customer satisfaction below profitability.

Purchased this drive 6 months ago.  Several weeks ago the drive made a horrific noise and then stopped working.  Contacted the company and they told me to send the drive back.  After receiving the drive I was informed that their diagnostics showed the hard disk inside the drive had failed and they would be unable to repair.  All data gone.  They would replace the hard disk and return it to me as it was still under warranty.  That's great.  Now I will have a new hard disk for a drive I clearly cannot trust.  External drives fail.  I get that.  But if you can't trust a drive to make it 6 months, what is the point.  I will not be purchasing another Fantom drive in the future.  Purchase at your own risk....and if you do purchase, I would suggest investing in an online back up to protect you for when it fails.
It didn't have the correct connector holes.  Had to return it. Quality seemed fine, it just didn't fit properly.. Dissatisfied.

After a long long time, I received it and I cast it away at once. I don't want to wast my time to ask to refund, because of the little money. I suggest that you should buy a little higher price mouse shipping in USA other than China Shenzhen.

I recieved my Viking C01064 256MB PC100 ram for my Compaq 18XL280 Laptop with anticipation of extra speed and performance. What a disappointment! After installing the ram, I found that the computer sat on the initial "Compaq" screen and wouldn't proceed any farther into the boot up process. Apparently the computer won't recognize the new ram. Switching back to my old 128MB ram worked so it appears the problem is with the new ram. This particular 256MB ram was the one that the "Memory Finder" said was compatible with my computer so I'm assuming it is correct. At this point, I'm going to get busy contacting Viking's 24/7 Technical Support line and see what happens but I'm not real happy about it...we'll see!

Nice device if you are no more than a few feet away only, wireless has hiccups, send it back.  but for volume ..forget about it, better sound and volume with brookstone's Outdoor Wireless Speaker, worth the extra $$  [[ASIN:B003E6NP3G Weather-Resistant Indoor/Outdoor Wireless Speaker]]

Well this almost worked. My wired devices connected just fine and connected through to the Internet and they all worked great. But my wireless devices had real problems. They would connect to the router but could not see any network shares and the could not see local servers, like Plex or Apache, and they could not connect to anything on the Internet. It was like the wireless part of this router was just not able to see anything except the wireless. The rest of the world seemed not to exist at all.

After fiddling with it for must of an afternoon and evening and part of the next morning I finally gave up and put my old modem back in place so I would have service both wired and wireless.

I may try a different more modern router soon as this router, the wired side, apparently handles the shared Internet connection better as with this router Speedtest.net reports 55+ mbs while with the old router I only get 45-50. Yes, I did test multiple times to be sure. I would think this is not really the Internet connection that is the difference but better performance in the router.

At least the return through Amazon is easy so I am really out nothing but a little time.

From this experience the next router I get will probably not be Netgear as there are a lot of routers out their and I don't want to repeat this fiasco.

While this is a SATA 3, PCIe-3 motherboard, be aware that it only has one SATA 3 plug inside of it. So if you run two hard drives, only one can run at SATA 3 speeds, and the second hard drive can only run at SATA 2 speeds.  A very bad road block.
I wish it is either thicker/substantial, or cheaper. Buyers could get a better product somewhere else. The picture is deceiving.

the screen is cut so poorly, that it doesn't fit correctly. The quality of the material is very cheap, and does not provide adequate
