Connected this hardware, following the instructions TO THE LETTER... they took nearly 20 minutes to find each other and link up, and then the best speed I could get was a shameful 0.03 MBps. (Took an hour and a half to load the speed-test website). I could do better on DIAL-UP.  Needless to say, I switched back to the wireless bridge, and initiated the process for a return.  Anyone who gets the full rated speed for this (or even half way there), has experienced a genuine miracle.

Why did I get it?  1. To have the internet on the go, wherever Wi-fi is around.  2. Mobile Skype, wherever Wi-fi is around.  3. Read e-books and text files.    So how does it work? This thing is geeky. Pretty much a half-baked product. However, after owning it for 2 months and going through two OS versions and 2 firmware updates (now it on OS2008, second firmware), it is finally coming close to being a somewhat user-friendly device. Before that, there were regular hang-ups and other kinds of problems.   1. Internet works fine, rather fast. Supports all kinds of sites - Flash, Ajax included  2. Skype works well. However, the audio quality can have less hiss  3. Still only one e-book reader soft - fbreader. Pretty cumbersome to make it usable, but now after hours of tinkering this one works OK too with tap scrolling, capability to use landscape and portrait modes, etc.    However, there's one thing that's not going to make this thing a keeper for me. Display quality! All the geeks on the net were drooling about the resolution on this thing, being higher than iPhone, iPod Touch etc. But the resolution is not all! I think, the problem with N800 display is back-light. It's not spread out evenly. Some portions of the screen is lighter than others. That's why it's hard on your eyes. Anyhow, a text looks a bit blurry. That's a killer for me. I think it's actually a systemic problem for Nokia. I saw n95 phone, which had the same problem. I can make comparison with the displays on iPod Touch and Palm TX. Ipod Touch may have a lower resolution, but, boy, how nice it is to read internet pages on that one. I can't wait till Apple loosens its tight grip on the software and people can create e-book readers for this thing. Palm TX has actually a pretty good display - not that bright as N800, or iPod Touch, however I read some 100 books on it and had no problem at all. And both iPod Touch and Palm TX have smaller screens than N800. Today, when you can see gorgeous Samsung screens oncheap $100 phones, it's not acceptable for Nokia to save money on their displays. For $200 I paid for it, I still keep it till a something better comes around, then this brother goes straight to eBay.

I purchased this Pandigital Star not expecting too much as a low-cost device. I was not disappointed [sarcastic]. This is not my first tablet, I have both a Samsung Galaxy Player 5.0 and a Le Pan TC 970. After delivery I charged it overnight and added an 8gb SD card. I was pleasantly surprised after boot-up that the tablet had so few already-installed apps - I like to add my own to purpose it for my needs. It also felt great in my hands - substantial and just the right size between my other two tablets. It was nice to have the HDMI port and I hooked it up and it looked great on my HDTV (using pre-loaded HDMI switch app). Pretty good so far.

I checked out the Pandigital-branded GetJar Store (it's just a loader for the mobile website) and was unimpressed with the selection though I did install a few apps to see how it worked (Dolphin Browser HD, Skype, GO Launcher EX, Shazam, Maps by Google, Gmail by Google, Solitaire Free, VLC Direct, Mini Piano Lite, Google+, Google Voice, etc. - mostly older versions). I also added Amazon Appstore, SlideME Market and 1 Mobile Market and apps from all of them along with side-loading my core apps (AVG, Keepass, Dropbox, Pandora, Last FM, Jamendo, Google Talk, etc). I also side-loaded an older Android Market from Google (no rooting required) but it didn't show very many compatible apps for me.

Things started slowing down at this point and running apps in the background kept getting me the low-memory and low on space notifications. I started moving apps to the SD but all of a sudden it wouldn't recognize the SD card. I checked the Settings-SD and it was still there so I unmounted it and re-mounted it - same problem. I then tried unmounting, removing, reinserting, mounting and it was back. (by the way it was a b?#@h to mount and unmount with my fat fingers) This continued to happen, generally after the tablet went to sleep and I unlocked it but could happen in any long session accessing the SD card.

Eventually, it would not recognize the SD card at all. I conclude there is a problem with the SD socket on this device. The other problem (low memory/out of space) tells me that 256MB ram and 2GB flash memory is much to restrictive for use as a general tablet, even with an external SD card. I consistently had under 40MB ram available and no space left on the internal flash.

My conclusion is that it does not qualify as a general-use tablet (for me at least) but might work as a dedicated e-reader (if you don't carry too many books on it) with occasional internet forays or occasional game/multimedia use (if you don't use memory-intensive apps).

We'll see what the warranty service is like and I'll update at a later date if warranted.entually, it would not recognize the SD card at all. I conclude there is a problem with the SD socket on this device. The other problem (low memory/out of space) tells me that 256MB ram and 2GB flash memory is much to restrictive for use as a general tablet, even with an external SD card. I consistently had under 40MB ram available and no space left on the internal flash.

My conclusion is that it does not qualify as a general-use tablet (for me at least) but might work as a dedicated e-reader (if you don't carry too many books on it) with occasional internet forays or occasional game/multimedia use (if you don't use memory-intensive apps).

We'll see what the warranty service is like and I'll update at a later date if warranted.
Merchandise stopped working shortly after using. Company was very prompt in giving me a refund.

any audio that you hear through the headset (i.e. game audio, music)  somehow ends up being transmitted through the mike which annoys other people and could make private things unintentionally public)  also very uncomfortable.  you almost get what you pay for.  definitely not worth cheaping out on this item.

For the sake of your sanity and the peacefulness of you neighborhood, please don't bother buying this adapter. It may lead to uncontrollable bouts of screaming. I have another computer which picks up our wireless signal fine, but with this adapter the signal is frequently dropped. Unplugging and plugging it back in usually gets it online again for at least a few minutes, but it's a big pain in the neck. Having to do this repeatedly meant keeping it plugged into the front of the computer within reach, which meant that it got knocked into frequently because it sticks out a good 3\\" from the computer. Now it has come apart and has to be replaced. Piece of cr@p.
Tip too rigid. It does not work well.

I purchased a 64gb cruzer blade.  Packaging and label both confirm 64gb, even on the drive itself.  However, it came out as 31.9GB only.  Seems like a completely unacceptable manufacturing/labeling error!  Not even worth the effort to make a return or call warranty for this type of small purchase--just sorely disappointed.
Look at the dates of the reviews and you will see why this card STILL has such a high rating.  Thank you and goodnight.
Huge amount of data lost suddenly with no reason.  I have been using it for more than a year and half of my data were lost suddenly. sigh!

PIECE OF CRAP. Bought it for my grandson. They told him his computer was too far away from the modem for it to work. His bedroom is Right next to the room with the modem (maybe 20 feet away) and his ENTIRE house is less than 900 square feet!!!

This battery is cheap and functional. It seems to hold a charge well and I'm getting about 3 hours of life out of it which is as good as expected.   However, it doesn't fit flush to the bottom of the laptop, one corner sticks down about 2mm. It makes me nervous the battery is going to fall out and has a cheaper look than an OEM battery. It's a good deal compared to a $130 Lenovo battery, but the next time I need a battery I will probably shop around for another third party manufacturer with tighter tolerances.  EDIT: Lowered my rating to two stars. After some testing, I'm getting 2/3rd the battery life out of this almost new battery as with my 1 1/2 year old OEM Lenovo battery. I'd recomend buying an OEM battery. It costs twice as much, but you'll get twice the battery life.

I figured there wouldn't be much of a difference between micro USB cables, so I went with a long one that was cheap.  I wanted something so I could use my devices on the couch and charge them at the same time.  Short story, it sucks and doesn't do the job.  The small end doesn't fit very well with ANY of my devices and RARELY WORKS.  The contact is so bad that it will wiggle with ANY device I plug it into, and that causes it to constantly lose contact.  I have other chargers and cables that fit these devices fine, so it definitely is this cable that is the problem.  I have bought dirt cheap cables in the past that functioned just fine.  I never thought I would be writing a negative review on a simple USB cable, but I want to warn others.  STAY AWAY FROM THIS CABLE!  DO NOT BUY!

I ordered this sticker before for my Macbook 13" and it was exactly as pictured, but for some reason the one I received was oversized. There was no way to angle it so it both fit the screen and lined up with the apple. I'm very disappointed and hesitant to reorder.

Was unaware the refurbished product carried no manufacturers warrenty or support, It came with no instructions or setup software. Fortunately I was able to get help from my Internet provider in setting it up. Works fine now but would not recommend anyone buying a refurbished unit unless they were familiar with configuring a router.
I was searching for a memory stick pro duo that my camera used. Instead, I got this product. Beware, this is the size that works with phone memory cards and not regular cameras.

HP products have left a bad taste in my mouth many times before. This time I let the specs and price overcome my good sense. I was looking for a netbook replacement, wanted a little bigger screen and more resolution without losing portability (size and weight) advantages of the netbook.

I really wanted to like this unit. The ability to turn off the touchpad without two hands on the keyboard, 4G memory, big hard drive (though I planned to replace it with a 7200 I have in hand), adding Bluetooth (though I really have no need), VGA and HDMI out. Home Premium 64 (that is to say, anything but Starter is a plus).

Sadly, she's going back.

1) Upper left corner of the bezel is warped out. Just enough to get a business card in, but darn it, it should be perfect out of the box.

2) It would never connect to my N router at higher than 65mbps. Finally got around to searching on the card, to check if I had the latest drivers. Well folks, this is a single-band card, so that's all you get. 2.4 only. So really, G wifi plus a little. Welcome to 2002. Not acceptable when my other laptops all connect at 150 or 300. OK, it doesn't affect the internet connection, but doing backups or working with files on my NAS is at half-speed or worse compared to everything else.

Shame on HP for using those cards. Lame.

So Linksys claims this product works without drivers on Macintosh systems (\\"anything with an Ethernet port\\"). However, it does *not* handle AFP (Apple's file-sharing protocol) at all. If you are attempting to connect a Mac to a network file-share using AFP (common to versions of MacOS earlier than X), you will fail. This includes other pre-OSX Macs, as well as Microsoft UAM volumes.
Otherwise this product works as advertised. The Mac could indeed surf the Internet and use network services utilizing standard TCP/IP protocol. However, I feel it is highly irresponsible for Linksys to claim that their product works on Macintosh PCs when 100% compatibility does not exist.

First of all, the provided instruction as well as the video is very clear. With patience, I was able to clear the dusts as I was working on it in a pretty dusty room. I'd say it's very helpful.

However, I'm disappointed with the fact that it does not perfectly fit on my iPad 4th. Trying to match the home button hole while centering it is extremely difficult if not impossible. Mine ends up shifted a little (about half a milli on the side, and almost a milli at the top); noticeable but otherwise not bothersome.
My previous iPad 4th used a cheap one ($2 for 3 sheets) that I got for free from my brother. It fit perfectly even the Apple rep could not see it when I returned the iPad for upgrade to the 4G version.

My greatest disappointment is because I bought the more expensive sheet with the intention to avoid finger prints while retaining the vibrant retina display. Much to my dismay, this one still leaves fingerprint marks. After a day of use, smudges are noticeable all over; much like the cheap one on the other iPad.

The oleophobicity seems to work just like shown in the video. But cleaning the smudges with water (or simply dry wipe) would leave wipe marks. The cheap one would clean much like a normal cleaned glass. In that sense, I have no use of the oleophobic characteristics.

For 25 times the price (per sheet) over the cheap one, I expect a significant benefit. If return shipping is free (since obviously, this is opened and used), it would have been out the door already.

I just returned mine after 3 frustrating days. Where to start....
1. The drive does NOT work well with USB 2.0 connections, and not at all with a USB extension cord (so the max distance from drive to computer is about 6\\". And, as someone else has pointed out in a review of some USB3.0 drive, you CANNOT connect it through a USB hub -- must be direct to computer.

2. Software did install OK.
3. BUT software is not intuitive on how to use the backup function (requires much more clicking and selecting than either my Iomega or HP Simple Save)
4. Only once (after I had to figure out how to use the software because of lousy customer service [see below] did the software recognize the drive, and allow me to click on \\"Start BackUP\\" -- BUT it NEVER started, just hung up -- and I gave it 12 hours
5. After that, software never allowed me to click on the drive and get to start backup.
6. I wrote to customer service through the website form the first time with 4 simple questions. 50 hours later (not the promised 24) I had received NOTHING BACK. So I wrote again with 2 more questions. 24 hours later, still no answer.
7. So I called. They did actually answer. He first blamed my computer. Then the fact that it was USB 3.0 to 2.0. Then he said he had no idea and it was probably defective.
That is way too much drama.
So buy at your own risk, with this info in mind

But since the upgrade, every app that is run anywhere always shows up in the carousel. I can live with that, by ignoring the carousel, and using the app and book entries on the top bar. But not all the apps show up in the app list. And the new Kindle system software takes up more storage space, so I had to remove half my books, or I could not update any of the applications. If I knew this would happen, I would have spent the extra money for a real tablet.

I own 3 Macbook Pro's and a Macbook 13 inch (white). All bought 1.5 to 2.5 years ago except the Macbook 13 inch which I got a year ago for my youngest daughter and has a battery I wish my pro had in a computer that is half the price! That little battery lasts 8 hours and came out about a month after I picked up the 3 pros with total clunker batteries that last 3 (supposedly 4) hours--Apple always does this to me- got me this time with an iPod Touch giveaway with purchase of the Macbook Pro-that is the giveaway a new model is soon to follow so WAIT DON\\"T BITE on the deal. So all the pro batteries for the larger- 15 and 17 inch lines should be recalled and its a disgrace IMHO that this is actually being resold with many people having to buy one every year-check out Apple's own reviews for those who doubt this on the Apple site under the same battery model number.    My daughter's similar 15 inch battery failed within 2 months and cycle count was below what is minimum to be declared functional (according to the tech at APLCARE who replaced it and sent it without asking for old one back first--what you expect when you buy a top of line laptop that cost more than double its winblows competitor -fortunately when you are within warranty Apple treats you respectfully.   However, I felt like Rodney Dangerfield 2 days ago after 2 hours of futile gripes and pleas of outrage (I have worked designing embedded systems for 25 years and so I know when an item is a failure vs. a wear and tear issue)!  My 17 inch macbook pro and my wife's BOTH failed within the same week! Precisely when the option to pick up APLCARE for my Macbook expired a month or so earlier and I checked on the prices of replacing the whole shebang and at 1199 it seemed with 3 what -maybe ONE would fail--I could buy a whole other Macbook for price of 3 Aplcare contracts! This seems to be reason customer service really decided they hated me-I made the comment-a sin-but with 3 of them its hard to not think its cheaper to pool the 3 times 300 bucks in self insurance and have enough to almost buy a new Macbook if not a Pro at current prices.     My battery, this same one you will be buying to replace your old one is the same defective dangerous jiffy pop battery that failed you before and will fail you again in a year or so.... not only puffed open to a whopping 4 inch thick flat out pried open looking battery -it leaked brown battery acid into the housing of the battery case, which sits adjacent to your RAM interface (slot where you can add more memory) and it almost destroyed the entire computer power system in addition to potentially causing a fire. I can not for the life of me understand with the Apple site rife with 100s of similar gripes (and this is what gets screened by apple) on their review of same battery how Apples' VP of customer support can show his face in public.    I wrote a review after becoming so infuriated that customer care was initially going to replace at least my insanely mutant battery and then abruptl stated NOPE WE WONT-sorry never said we would! Oh and this is recorded so don't say we did say we were going to replace it and they are not defective-this is normal for a failing battery to expand and pop out of your laptop 3 times its size like the incredible hulk.  My review on APPLE site, Indicating that I was ready to try and band together people interested in filing a class action law suit against Apple for this insanely stupid customer service cheap out no doubt never made it to their site so I figured maybe it would be therapeutic to vent to other poor souls who are paying to replace this-some blessed few are getting free ones but its a crap shoot apparently.   I was so angered by the vitriolic customer support rep. and his totally condescending attitude-he basically asked me if I HAD PICTURES OF THE ACID I CLAIMED LEAKED As if I was making it up- I said I have two bulging batteries like this and I say this is clearly a defect not wear and tear--Isay what are odds 3 Macbook Pros all have battery fails--apparently the \\"gentleman\\" Never took probability and statistics as for 3 batteries bought randomly by the same household to fail on each battery and their not be a defect places odds of about \\"NO WAY\\" that one person winds up with 3 failing batteries. He said, I probably was just unlucky and claimed to not have heard of many bulging battery issues (this with the Apple site full of reams of customers all citing the bulge battery issue--it literally grows and pops out of the frame and will not fit back in. THey seem to expect Apple users to  be monitoring battery issues via diagnostics like checking one's oil or tire pressure--get real apple these are consumer laptops not Crays. I offered to mail them the battery and accept a replacement after they verified the truth of my statements but they just found a way to deny me by acting like I was uncooperative in not letting someone \\"Take a look\\" at my Mac-which could of course wind up costing me installation fees as well as repair fees-been there and done this with 2 hard drives on a Powerbook.  Not only is this battery functionally non-functional, its potentially dangerous and likely to break your computer as it also starts power cycling down your notebook over and over when the failure begins to manifest....an audible pop finally was noticed and that is when I realized this thing was dangerous and as I felt the battery and noticed why my laptop was propped up as if floating above the table, the heat was close enough to recall the earlier MAC power brickes that literally lit ablaze-why is it Apple muffs its batteries all the time then will not recall them--just like the iPhone Consumer Reports issue on call drops--it shows a total arrogance developing at a once earnest and hard working little company that came back from dead with a visionary leader who seems to have gotten lost in his own success,  So, I could not even power cycle mine on with the battery pulled out--maybe the acid that was leaked into the casing that i had to wipe out was glitching something--I could not boot to the hard drive and fortunately was able to firewire in to the laptop as a remote hard drive and salvage my iTunes and photos which I stupidly had not checked in time machine to back up. Fortunately i remembered I had bought a terabyte backup drive and run Time Machine backup just about a week before this failure and once I bought a new battery I was able to restore the Macbook pro by wiping my hard drive (which nodes had somehow become fubar) and recopying the music back from an old iMac that I use basically also as a redundant memory store.    On my wife's, battery failure--I was already checking on it and she (who had made fun of me claiming mine failed as I do not care well for my items) as hers too became a jiffy pop battery that bulged out of its frame....but we yanked it right away and she could run with power cord alone til new crappo 2006 made battery came in mail--another 270 bucks to Apple for their defective batteries-agida. Let me preface this by saying that Anker was kind enough to send me one of these to review. This did not effect my view of the keyboard at all as you'll see below.

Ok, so let me start off with what this keyboard has running for it.

-The backlighting is good and i live the scroll wheel concept, its awesome to be able to control the backlight more than on/off
-The macro keys are well placed and they are very functional, i am happy with what they do
-Letters are clear and they are visible
-Placement of the keys are good. I can't stand the british layout but they clearly had good intentions
-This keyboard looks GOOD. Let me rephrase that, this keyboard looks good when you only see the bottom of it, the brushed aluminum on the bottom is awesome and i really wish they followed that design throughout the keyboard.

The Bad
-Macro Keys: There are way too many of them, Its almost like they are there just for Anker to say that we have 20 million macro keys
-Design: Other than the metal bottom, aesthetics aren't particularly good, the macro keys look kind of odd, they are unsymmetrical and frankly, the scroll wheel just looks out of place
-Feel: Spacebar feels like crap, the keys don't feel much better. When you use the keys, it feels like they are going to get stuck at the bottom. I would say that the keyboard on my dell laptop is much better to type on than this. Furthermore, they keys rattle like no tomorrow and the membrane that Anker used to detect keystrokes isn't particularly accurate.
-Quality: Meh, the keys feel really cheap as i said before but the entire thing itself isn't that bad. I would have preffered better build quality on the whole though

Final words.
Would i recommend this keyboard to a friend? No. I really don't understand what Anker did here. It doesn't make sense that they would put out a keyboard with a British layout in the United States and the quality of the materials they used strikes me as just plain stupid. Sorry Anker, but you messed up.

Sorry to post this, as I know Amazon says \\"Don't describe your seller or shipping experience (you can do that at amazon.com/feedback)\\". BUT MY CUSTOMER FEEDBACK WAS DELETED.

I ordered this laptop as it is advertised above: Panasonic Toughbook CF-74, 2GB, running Windows 7
That's what it says on this page, that's what it said in the e-mail order confirmation, that's what it said in the \\"pending Orders\\" page here at Amazon.
But what Rugged Notebooks sent was: Panasonic Toughbook CF-74, ~ONE~ GB, running Windows ~XP~!

Note the difference? Funny thing, when I sent a \\"contact the seller\\" message, they CALLED me. (how the heck did they get my phone number?!?!) Of course, by doing this there would be no \\"paper trail\\" of messages that Amazon representatives could look at later.

Rugged Notebooks initially admitted they had screwed up, and were going to e-mail me a return label. THEN a senior representative called back and said they had NOT screwed up, and that I should have looked at the \\"fine print\\" on the second page. They still were willing to have me send it back for a refund, so that's what I did.

4 days AFTER UPS reports Rugged Notebooks received my return, I still had no refund, so I opened a dispute with Amazon A-to-Z. A day later I got my money back (which is one reason why I use Amazon).

I posted a shortened version of this in the \\"Customer Feedback\\" for Rugged Notebooks, and lo & behold, it has been removed, along with my 1-star. I have requested an explanation from Amazon as to why they removed it, but in the mean-time I am posting this here.

In My Opinion, you should NEVER buy anything from Rugged Notebooks.

I bought two of these tablets for my boys' birthdays. There were no customer reviews of the product when I bought them in June so I decided (based on some legit techy reviews) to be one of the first to try the product. I wanted to give the tablets to my boys already set up with their favorite games and books. I fell in love with the tablet as I was setting up the first one - it seemed comparable to some of the higher end tablets and I thought I had a really big score in buying these. However, when I was ready to set up the second tablet (the day before we were celebrating their birthdays), I noticed that it would not turn on most of the time. I literally had to play with it for 10 minutes to get it to turn on. We exchanged that one and within a week, the new one stopped taking a charge. I didn't have the money to replace those tablets with higher quality ones so I've been exchanging them every time they just stop working. We've been through 5 so far and both are currently messed up and in need of exchange. One made it 2.5 months and all of the others died before within a few weeks. It's always one of two problems - the power button doesn't work or it just stops taking a charge. I actually thought my kids were doing something to mess them up - until the guy at Sears told me that they've had a lot of customers returning them for power issues and that he doesn't recommend them. Thankfully I purchased the 2-year warranty on them. I will be returning one Zeki tablet directly to Sears (because it hasn't been 30 days since my last exchange) and the other through the warranty claim company. I'm going to use the money to purchase a Kindle Fire for them to share until I can purchase a second one. The Fire is better suited for their needs (reading books and playing games) and I KNOW that the Fire is a solid product.

(Disclaimer: Please note that this review is for the TX-1000, but mysteriously appears under the TX-2500, which I don't own, and have no experience with. If you read the review, you'll notice that I've mentioned the TX-1000 several times. Some of the issues here might apply to the newer models as well.)    In a nutshell, this was my first ever AMD-based PC. But I can guarantee that it will be the last. It will also likely be my last HP laptop.      When I was on the lookout for a tablet PC, the HP TX-1000 stood out like a Christmas tree in terms of the price. It was less than half of any other tablet PC on the market. So even though HP has absolutely no pedigree in creating tablets (and I'll tell you why shortly) the price alone made for a compelling reason to consider it. The more I looked at it, the more attracted I got to it. Add to that situation the fact that I had very recently acquired an HP desktop, which had totally blown me away with its presentation (especially over Dell). It was so much better (in every possible way) than Dell - at a cheaper price that I started thinking that it was possible that sometimes you did get more than you paid for. I thought HP had once again finally arrived as a serious player in the PC arena.     And then came this HP laptop, very rudely yanking me into the realm of reality. Boy, was I ever mistaken about the company. Did I ever jump the gun on passing a judgment. Was I ever wrong about getting more than you pay for. At the risk of sounding repetitive, this HP laptop jolted me into an extremely rude awakening. I can't say enough about what a HUGE disappointment it was to me.     Speed. First of all, the laptop was just plain slow. It's the slowest computer I have ever used. Ever. It's relatively even slower than the iMac I had some ten years ago (back then, the iMac was - relatively speaking -- the slowest computer I had ever owned, and was annoying enough that I returned it after two weeks of slow running, crashing, and notfinding any software that ran on it). For something that claims to be a using a 64-bit processor and 2 GB of RAM, this laptop crawls slower than a sick turtle. After a few weeks of tweaking around, I found the reason for that - the AMD Turion and HP's sorry excuse of a motherboard. My venerable Dell m700 (with Celeron and 1 GB of RAM) easily outperformed this manifestation of lethargy in any number of performance tests and I/O benchmarks that I had created (from real-life scenarios in which I was using both the laptops). So then, I came to the conclusion that the only reason HP was selling AMD was so that it could sell a tablet PC for half the price of its competitors.    Wireless. The second reason for relentless vexation was the wireless card. It would just randomly stop working every now and then, and would never work again until I rebooted the laptop. I called HP and had the card replaced. That solved the problem enough so that it doesn't happen quite as often, but it still happens once in a while. However, I was to later learn (as recently as a few weeks ago) that I was one of the lucky few who actually got it working (even if it was not a complete cure) with a replacement card. The issue seems to run much deeper than the card itself. In fact, if you go to HP forums, you will hear constant noise about how the wireless problem breeds from a sinister defect in the motherboard, and how every laptop they've ever released in this series actually will eventually stop working (usually a couple of months after the warranty expires). I am now starting to see other signs that indicate that mine's only a few weeks (if not days) from that fate (see the \\"spooky turning on\\" a few paragraphs down). Another reason this laptop is so cheap - HP compromised on the motherboard, as well as the wireless card.    BIOS. I have had laptops going back to my old Quantex (dating back to 10 years ago), that used to have BIOSes smart enough to tell when the battery was about to run out of juice. They would then warn if you tried to start your laptop on low battery. On the flip side, they WOULDN'T warn if your battery was charged a 100%. This brilliant offering from HP, on the other hand, keeps warning you even if you just replaced your depleted battery with a fully charged battery. I am so used to this basic functionality in all my other laptops that when I replace my battery on the train, turn it back on and go back to my phone to check messages, I come back a minute or two later and expect that I am at the log on screen. But to my utter exasperation, I find each time that I am still stuck at the annoying BIOS message that warns me of a LOW BATTERY!!! So the laptop simply won't go ahead and boot unless I hit the Enter key. I can't imagine how much time I have wasted due to this. (Moreover, I probably lost a couple of years of my life due to the rise in blood pressure, and my already precarious spot in a good place in the afterlife due the choice curse words I have uttered each time.)    But if that's an annoyance, what it does when the battery is low is downright scary. When the battery is 25% or lower, and you start the laptop not knowing how much battery is remaining, it starts up without warning you at all. But that's not the problem - in fact, it's a good thing. The problem is, it just dies when the battery reaches critical mass, without EVER attempting to hibernate (as my laptop is configured to). It just goes poof - and SHUTS DOWN! Just like that! That means all my unsaved work up until that point is completely lost. It happened to me twice before I realized what insidious bug was causing the problem. I have now started keeping track of the battery levels when I hibernate the laptop, never turning it back on if the level was below the 25% level at the time of hibernation.    Another annoying thing about the BIOS is that over the past two weeks, it just randomly turns on! I don't recall doing anything to it. Randomly, in the middle of the night,the laptop just turns on! It could be some weird wake-on-LAN setting that got tweaked, or maybe my laptop is about to die (like the other ten thousand or so owners), or it's possessed by evil spirits. But it just turns on and wakes me up almost every night! Of course, when it happens in the middle of the night, I'm too sleepy to resolve the issue. When I'm wide awake, I forget to investigate. As a result, the problem has continued for the past two weeks.    Track Pad. The track pad in its initial setting was unusable. Even after month of tweaking, the base of my thumb would keep touching the pad and make the cursor jump to another part of the document. It was small enough a problem, but annoying enough that at one point, I wanted to return the laptop. I finally hit the sensitivity setting that resolved this issue.    Active/Passive Pen & the Display. One of the biggest disappointments was the fact that the TX-1000 does not use an active pen to do its tablet work. That was another way HP managed to cut costs and make the tablet seem like a no-brainer over the other vendors, at least in terms of the price. The fact is, the passive pen is absolutely useless, and the touch screen very insensitive. In fact, at times, I have had to press so hard that I'm almost afraid that I might end up breaking the screen! An active pen is a thing of beauty, and a joy to behold. It comes with features such as mouse moving with a hover, the ability to erase text with the opposite side of the pen (as with a regular pencil on paper), and the pleasure of writing effortlessly on the screen. You get none of that with HP's TX-1000.     In any case, the \\"passive\\" pen technology has been around for ages in all the Pocket PC's, which work impeccably with a stylus (I've owned the renowned (and my favorite HP hardware) HP Jornada 548, The Dell Axim, Samsung i730, and most recently the AT&T Tilt - which BTW also work pretty well with just your thumb). On top of that, every one of the pocket PC's have had a crisper, brighter display. And none of them ever showed the underlying touch grid on the screen. I could barely see it on the Samsung, and that too, only if I stared hard in broad daylight. But it was never a distraction. On this laptop, the display is terrible. It's faded, low contrast, and shows the underlying grid even in moderate lighting (such as on a train), which turns out to be a major distraction. In broad daylight, working with this laptop is not recommended. I have since gotten used to this and have swallowed it like a bitter pill.     So if those things aren't bad enough already, consider the regular litany of annoying HP software/crapware that arrogantly starts up with Windows (msconfig.exe has become my best friend ever since I started buying off-the-shelf PC's). HP is arguably the worst software producer of all. HP software is only mildly benign than a virus. What makes it more dangerous than all the other free garbage out there is the sanctimonious attitude with which they add it in there. \\"Oh, you probably don't know what you're doing. Therefore, here's our offering to protect you from yourself.\\" When in fact 90% of all problems are caused by the software starting up on Startup. It's ironic that when I was speaking with an HP tech for resolving my wireless issue, the first thing he made me do was turn off all the \\"crap\\" that loads up at Windows Startup. WITHOUT EXCEPTION, every one of the apps/utilities we turned off were from HP.     So why did I even bother to give it one star? Several reasons:  1. I couldn't rate it any lower ;-).  2. The full-size keyboard is decent.   3. Contrary to what I had expected, the swiveling hinge which connects the screen to the rest of the laptop is pretty solid and doesn't rattle on the train, as some of my skeptical friends had predicted.  4. I upgraded it to Vista Ultimate, and everything worked smoothly. In fact, after the upgrade (and applying SP1), the laptop has been slightly more stable.  5. I just like Vista better than XP in most respects (but that has absolutely nothing to do with the laptop).  6. Unlike the ten thousand or so poor devils out there who own the TX series, my wireless issues almost got resolved, and my laptop is still breathing.    So the one thing I did learn was, if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. Then there was this other little gem that reinforced itself - you get what you pay for.

After reading the decidedly mixed reviews, I finally ordered this docking station, thinking that since I'm fairly tech-savvy, I could overcome any challenges I might encounter.

In short...not so much. After about 45 minutes, I was finally able to get my desktop on both screens, and actually have the image fill both screens (I'm using a Samsung Series 9 laptop and a Samsung 22\\" monitor - a fairly \\"vanilla\\" application).

After three days of use, the screen on my laptop is completely filled...and the screen on my monitor has black bars on three sides (the image is all the way left on the monitor). I tried to navigate what Targus calls \\"support\\" on their website - and found absolutely nothing of any use. I downloaded a new version of the software...to no avail.

Now I have a 22\\" monitor that basically functions as a 17\\" monitor - and aside from the convenience of only having to unplug two cables (one USB and one power cord) when I want to take my laptop somewhere else, it seems that the main benefit of this costly docking station cannot be achieved.

Don't do it, folks!

Summary: Well thought out device, but this version (1000) is a little too small to be truly useful DOES NOT CHARGE TABLETS

One nice thing about most new devices these days is that they almost all charge on USB voltage (5V That means that the only thing you need is a USB outlet and you're set. The other nice thing is that most mobile phones now charge with a micro USB cord.

This device stores power and charges using a micro USB cable - the same cable that charges this pack also reverses to charge your phone.

My first impression is \\"wow, this thing is tiny\\" See picture) It's as tall as a chapstick tube and thinner. You could easily carry it in your pocket without noticing. The problem is that it only stores 1000 MAH *Milli-amp hour) which means that it has less charge than your average smart phone - for example the HTC EVO and HTC Touch Pro 2 use a 1800 MAH battery. Half a charge is better than nothing but it would be much more useful to be able to provide power while on a long flight.

There's something of a quandary here. If it's too big you won't carry it with you all the time and then you're out of luck when you need it. On the other hand, if you plan to carry it in a briefcase or purse, then it doesn't need to be that small. I'd propose that this is too large to put on a keychain and therefore it could be at least 2x as large without being inconvenient. In this case I'd propose that it would be more useful to store more power.

Although 4000 MAH is actually almost exactly 4X bigger (by volume) it's still quite small - smaller than most smart phones - consequently I'd suggest looking at [[ASIN:B005L38XLY Belkin F8M159tt Power Pack 2000]] or [[ASIN:B005LIDN50 Belkin F8M160 Power Pack 4000]] which provide 2X and 4X the power. They are quite pricey however. Although Belkin makes fantastic stuff, you may want to shop around - there are quite a few USB battery packs in the 4000-5000 MAH range from reputable manufactures for the same price as this device.

Another option would be the [[ASIN:B001F5Q3RS Energizer Energi To Go Mini & Micro USB Tips Cel2musb]] and some rechargable batteries - a pair of AA's should give you about 2000 MAH. Not as neat and easy or small but more effective. I'd also consider the 2000 and 4000 MAH versions, but they get a bit pricey.

How will I use it? My smartphone charges when docked to my computer and I also have a charger in the car for when I use it as a GPS. On the other hand I have a digital Camcorder which always seems to be at one bar of power just when I want to shoot a soccer game, etc. I plan to put it in the camera bag for use as emergency backup.

If you have any questions, comments, or if you found this review helpful, please let me know!e. On the other hand I have a digital Camcorder which always seems to be at one bar of power just when I want to shoot a soccer game, etc. I plan to put it in the camera bag for use as emergency backup. If you have any questions, comments, or if you found this review helpful, please let me know!

TL;DR: Bought 3 headsets and all of them failed.  The good:  This headset is absolutely fantastic. The sound is really rich and clear. Playing games like TF2, CS, Space Marine, etc was an absolute joy. The headset itself was really comfy over long periods of time (you know, like 4 hour raids or Saturday TF2 marathons). The mic quality was \\"decent\\" but the mic was fully adjustable and removable too, so that was cool.   The fail:  First headset: Extremely long cord led to bf tripping over it, ripping the Audio connector very cleanly off from the cable. I was able to repair this by stripping it down and re-soldering it. Unfortunately the microphone was not so forgiving, and never worked again. This happened about 1 month after buying it.   Second headset: Same issue. Had cord attached to the side of the desk, still managed to snag it. In this case I ripped the Microphone connector off at the base and was unable to repair it. Audio still worked fine, but we bought these for voice comm.   At this point we felt that the issues we had were not necessarily a failure of the headsets, though we were surprised by the poor quality. For comparison: we have a $10 plantronics headset working flawlessly some 8-odd years later. Plus, these headsets were still \\"on sale\\" at the time.   Third headset: Purchased at the end of July 2011, roughly 4 months ago. At this point I have completely babied the headset. The cord was managed well and never tripped on. I never pushed the limits on volume, etc. THE @#$%ing thing still died. Put it down after watching a youtube video, returned roughly 15 minutes later to discover that the headset is completely dead. No Audio, no Mic. Checked for possible shorts anywhere, confirmed the ports were working, etc. Nada, it's dead Jim. Going to try to RMA as I still have the original box and receipt, but really. Wtf Creative?  In conclusion, if you need a good headset for really cheap and don't plan on using it much, this is probably a great buy. Otherwise,you should suck up the extra 30 bucks or so and buy something much higher quality. Personally, I'm done dealing with Creative.

How anyone can honestly rate this screen protector at more than one star is beyond me. I've bought several different screen protectors for a 3rd gen iPod Touch and new iPad. The ArmorSuit has been the worst of any I have seen. First off, the application of the protector involves a fair amount of work compared to other types. You have to use a liquid spray on the back of the protector and on the screen itself. While the fit of the protector is fine, the final clarity leaves a lot to be desired. I noticed what looked like imperfections or slight fingerprints underneath the protector when it finally dried. About a week later, I put on a flexible case cover for the iPod Touch. Within about 5 minutes, several areas had started to buckle up. Despite trying to smooth them down and adding more liquid, and using a heat blower, this did not solve the problem.

Not only that, but the manufacturer claims that the technology is self healing. I can verify that there were indeed indentations that remained in the film surface after trying to rub and smooth the edges out. If this is the type of material that our military uses, then I really feel sorry for the quality that they are getting with this.

Since the manufacturer offers a lifetime warranty, I was initially going to get a replacement. But then found out they wanted about $3 plus tax for handling and shipping, and you first have to mail the original protector back to them. I figured the same thing would probably happen to the replacement protector and didn't want to spend another cent on this. I did some research and ordered another type of protector - Tech Armor. Received it earlier this week and installed it without needing any liquids, absolutely zero bubbles or lint, and the clarity is a lot better. Installed the case and no buckling of the protector whatsoever. Not only that, but I left the ArmorSuit home button protector on, and you could clearly see that this material had a yellowishcast to it compared to the Tech Armor. The Tech Armor protector provides a glass like finish and very happy with that. I wasted $10 on the ArmorSuit so hopefully this review will save someone else from making the same mistake.

This piece of equipment is so incredibly frustrating to use for two reasons. 1) It has potential. It could be a great way to add huge amounts of \\"cloud\\" storage to your arsenal, a way to share pictures and other documents, as the inclusion of \\"Active Copy\\" makes it a viable backup alternative. 2) It falls flat on every single one of these promises. You get gigabyes (or terabytes) of space...when it detects your drive. It has been my experience that my drives are detected about 33% of the time, and when they are detected they will randomly become de-synced from the service and require a manual restart to get them back online. This totally defeats the purpose of having a \\"cloud\\" storage option, as it requires the user to interact physically with the device (and is generally a frustrating experience overall. Active Copy is a nice feature, but I refuse to back up anything important to the device because, at a moments notice, the drive may simply stop working. Drives stop working even during the active copy process, causing the backup to stop less than halfway through. That wouldn't be TOO terrible, but the copy speeds are slow slow slow. On gigabit ethernet I get speeds of 3 mb/s, slightly more than what I get while downloading off the internet. using gigabytes of space is hard when transferring files takes hours.     Combine the slow transfer speeds and the the device's knack for going offline whenever you need it and you've got a sub-standard product. However, the product has the ability to redeem itself with what should be its crowning feature - movie storage and streaming. Unfortunately, the movie streaming and storage is just as bad as the other aspects of the product. Storage is, obviously, dependent on the other aspects of the review (such as write speed and device uptime) However, if you do manage to get a few movies on the device, feel free to stream them. Unless they're .mkv. Also, each movie has to be \\"optimized\\" for playback, a process which takes longer than downloading the movie (~2.5 hours of a 700 MB, 90 minute movie) If you do have the patience to optimize a video file, you can attempt to play it back, but you won't enjoy the experience. Subject to frequent stops and a buggy media player with few options, the experience leaves a lot to be desired.

Toshiba Satellite Radius L15W-B1310 11.6-Inch 2 in 1 Touchscreen Laptop
The Return of the Netbook

UPDATE 8/27/2016
(1) No issues at all upgrading to Windows 10 and, more recently, Windows 10 Anniversary.

(2) The Qualcomm Atheros AR956x Wireless Network Adapter had been having annoying issues connecting to WiFi when coming out of hibernation (opening the lid) for the past year or so. It would either take over 5 minutes to find and connect to my WiFi or would completely fail to find any wireless networks at all. I manually installed various versions of the driver from Toshiba but none cleared up the problem. Recently, I uninstalled ALL the network adapters listed in Device Manager, rebooted, and now it connects to my WiFi immediately after opening the lid (funny this did not work when I'd tried it in the past).
--------

Before the age of touch tablets, there were `netbooks' - extremely portable laptops that were small, light and relatively cheap (compared to full laptops) with very modest specs designed only for the most basic of chores like browsing the web and reading email. Netbooks had fallen out of favor over the years to tablets but the Toshiba Satellite Radius L15W updates the netbook with a twist by combing the netbook with a tablet in a single device.

Following the latest must-have trend, the Radius - powered by Windows 8.1 - offers a transforming rotatable touch screen that allows you to use it as a standard laptop or a tablet or both at the same time. The laptop brings some nice features to the table for an inexpensive model including built-in Bluetooth, a USB 3 port and an HDMI port as well as the good old SD card slot and headphone jack plus a physical volume control (I really miss those). As was true for netbooks of the past, the Radius' specs are fairly modest with a dual-core Celeron processor (a step up from the Atom processors found in old netbooks but still rather modest), a 500GB harddrive and a meager 2GB of memory - the absolute MINIMUM recommended by Microsoft for Windows 8.1. Memory for this model is not upgradable and is shared with the Intel graphics chipset. Interestingly, Toshiba decided on the 64 bit version of Windows 8.1. The battery is internal and not replaceable without opening the case.

The Radius is very thin and light but does not feel flimsy in any way. The hinges for the rotating screen appear to be metal hinting at a sturdy build. The chiclet keyboard is very reliable and only requires a light touch. The touchpad isn't quite as responsive as I'm used to but wasn't too difficult to adjust to and the touchscreen reacts quickly and smoothly (plus I have a wireless Bluetooth mouse). The screen is clear and bright in AC powered mode but can feel a somewhat cramped in term of real-estate when using the standard Windows interface. Radius has a built-in orientation sensor and will flip the screen accordingly in tablet mode. Unsurprisingly, the bottom firing built-in speakers are easy to block and tinny-sounding but offer better volume than some. The DTS Sound feature appears to be little more than a built-in audio processing and equalizer app but it does a pretty good job with a set of headphones plugged in though really only serves to give a (useful) volume boost when using the built-in speakers. [UPDATE] The laptop also has screen mirroring capabilities for use with smart TVs allowing you to send video and sound directly to the TV via WiFi. Connecting to my Sony smart TV generally took a few tries but once the laptop connected, it worked quite well.

The Radius comes with Windows 8.1, the goto version of Windows for tablet duties. Toshiba thoughtfully includes Pokki Start Menu to replace the Windows Start Menu missing since Windows 8. The Radius also comes with a trial subscription to McAfee anti-virus. Setup was simple enough. Once Windows had finished its setup procedure, however, it became very clear that havingonly 2GB of memory was going to be an issue - Windows and McAfee alone ate up around half of all available memory. Once I installed Outlook to access my work email, opening a half dozen web pages would easily push the Radius past 85% memory usage where it slowed to a crawl. Even without Outlook running, opening a number of web pages at the same time would cause 100% disk usage leading to temporary slow downs and long pauses. The internal disk doesn't seem particularly speedy considering it can easily hit 100% disk usage for 10 seconds after opening a single web page. (NOTE: see UPDATE below)

The Radius works quite well as a tablet, its small size and weight making it feel quite natural to use in this mode. The touch display is very responsive (if you're not doing anything very resource intensive). Once you flip the display back past a certain point, the keyboard is disabled - so you don't accidentally press keys while holding the tablet - and the orientation sensor becomes active so you can turn the Radius any way you like and the display will still appear right-side-up. The Radius is probably at its most likable in tablet mode.

I've been a longtime happy owner of various Toshiba laptops - including one netbook - but feel Toshiba made a misstep offering the Radius L15W with only 2GB of memory and believe this laptop would have been much more usable if it had only included 4GB of memory instead.

P.S. 1/29/15 - Let me add a few more comments after an additional month of daily usage:

- The laptop can get VERY frustrating unless you take great care to limit the number of apps running and constantly monitor memory usage via Task Manager. I would highly recommend removing any unnecessary startup programs such as the Adobe Reader quick start and update programs. Once you exceed 85% memory usage, the laptop will start 'paging' (using the hard disk as memory) leading to a long slowdown. I have started exiting email once I have finished reading and only open one or two web pages at a time while watching memory to avoid this. Do consider the 4GB memory version of the Radius if you can afford it, you'll be much happier.

- I have been plugging the Toshiba into my HD TV via HDMI to watch streaming SD content from Hulu. This actually works pretty well just as long as there is nothing else is running or open on the laptop.

- Windows 8 does not include Microsoft Solitaire or the other standard Windows games but it can be downloaded for free and installed although the process of doing so is actually MUCH more complicated than it should be IF you don't want to create and link your Windows account to a Microsoft account.

-------------------------------------------------
UPDATE 911/2015
Considering how much time I wasted waiting for this laptop to stop acting sluggish or frozen due to 100% disk usage, I replaced the internal HDD with a solid state drive - the $75 [[ASIN:B0106AOB7G OCZ Storage Solutions Trion 100 Series 240GB SATA III 2.5" Solid State Drive TRN100-25SAT3-240G]]. Yes, I lost half of the drive space but the difference is like night and day. The machine is now much more nimble and offers a much smoother and more enjoyable experience. With the SSD upgrade, this laptop rates rates at least 4 stars. I'd HIGHLY recommend the upgrade for anyone using this laptop. You'll be glad you did!up around half of all available memory. As others have mentioned, this battery is not a perfect fit in the MacBook Pro. For the first six months of use, this didn't cause many issues for me. However, over time the fit became looser and the electrical connection between the battery and the notebook became worse. It got to the point where my computer was shutting down due to lack of power whenever I would move it. This basically made the battery useless. I recently bought the more expensive replacement from Apple, which immediately fixed the power off problems. I wish I had just bought the Apple battery to begin with.

Two stars rather than just one because I did get some use out of the battery for the first few months.

Overall solid construction, sort of a soft-touch play on the Macbook Pro.

Dell dropped the ball on the screen, however. The quality of the display is very bad because of poor contrast, poor color rendition and grainy appearance. The space between pixels is large enough to be seen, and the overall effect is a white halo around black text on light backgrounds. This specific issue with text makes this unusable for me without an external monitor. Excel also looks funny because each box has a white inner and outer border as a result of the screen. Smaller icons look poor as the pixel dot pitch obscures their detail, and oranges and greens look unnatural due to the poor gamut.

It is the worst monitor I have seen on a laptop since 2002, and I have used many, many laptops.

Bottom line, if you can tell the difference between DVD and VHS (and some people say they can't), this display will drive you absolutely bonkers.

It is simple to use and the fully functional keyboard. Of course, one can only become so accustomed to the tiny keys, but it gets things done better than pushing letters on the screen.    One thing I suppose the cover could use is an additional flap that supports the tablet should you set it up horizontal without the use of the keyboard.. In other words, if I was to fold the keyboard section over so that is behind the tablet, there should be an additional support so that it remains upright in a triangular form.    For those who use the S pen frequently (such as myself), I find that the tablet is just one or two millimeters shy of fitting snugly in the case - when I detach the S pen, it is often caught behind part of the cover until one pushes the tablet further to the right so that the S pen is not obstructed.    The tablet wiggles about and often has to be pushed further in the case to reach the lower areas of the screen that are blocked by leather.    The leather strap the closes the case broke after a few weeks of use.     The usb part of the keyboard broke after twisting the cable while it was plugged in.

Most of us using this card are probably getting it for the SATA III capabilities, which max out at what, around 600MB/s? Of course, in order to use that, you need PCI Express Gen 2, which has max throughput of 500MB/s. If you don't have that latter item, this card is rather a waste, isn't it?

This card has no configurable BIOS options (no \\"press Ctrl+F for options\\" after your system finishes posting) but on three separate systems I tried it with, it said \\"Using PCI-E Gen 1\\" on each one. I know that all the systems had PCI Express Gen 2, but yet between that warning and my benchmark speeds using a Crucial M4 128GB SSD, I had terrible results. My ASRock motherboard's built in SATA II controller was pushing 207MB/s, but with this card, I was only hitting ~170MB/s.

Syba's support wasn't helpful - they gave me one email saying \\"try it in another slot!\\" and that was about it. I guess I got what I paid for, but Syba (or ASMedia? The box and BIOS don't mention Syba whatsoever) Thanks for accepting my return so promptly, Amazon!

While this computer appears to be an excellent product, support issues kill the experience. I tried this unit, and returned it, because there was no support to resolve two issues.

First, the Social Networks key software is very outdated. I thought it would be helpful to use the key to activate a different program that is current and actually usefull, ie. YooNo or TweetDeck. When I called support to ask about a utility, or registry entry that would allow this, I was told that type of support would cost me an extra $300. I then found out that Gateway does not have a method, at any price, to re-program that key.

The second problem was far more crucial. When using Windows 7 background slide show ( provided in the default software ) instead of the fixed Gateway logo background, the touchpad would start malfunctioning when the background changed to a new slide ( all part of the default show provided by Microsoft ). It was possible to fix the problem, but it would occur again with some of the new slides. An external mouse worked fine. Gateway had absolutley no willingness, at the highest levels, to address this problem, making the computer useless for my work.

Gateway also expressed the position that adding any software to the computer essentially relieved them of any support obligations for faulty performance. Perhaps if the powersupply failed, or the monitor wouldn't turn on, they might fix it. I clarified by asking if this policy applied in only Microsoft Office 2010 were installed, and the head of customer service affirmed that position.

As a long time Gateway fan, I was disappointed to encounter these new service policies. However, I can no longer recommend any Acer/Gateway products as a result.

I've had a hard time finding a case for my ipad mini and this one is one of the worst.

That rotating thing is a real pain. If you are going to rotate it you better remember where you started from because after rotating it you can't just close it and expect the magnet close to work. The rotated iPad's magnet is now at the top or off to the side, depending, and the case's magnet is at that bottom, or top, or side, depending, but you won't realize it until you notice it's still on and there is no click when it closes. Then it's a comedy of errors trying to find the right combination of rotation and closing to get it back correctly aligned to the magnet with the close button.

The little plastic strips designed to hold the ipad upright at different angles are worthless.The iPad slides across those things as if they were skids greased for easy sliding. No amount of coaxing will change things. The iPad just flies across them to flat in a blink. I found if you stand it upright and push it hard against the back rotating thing and keep it away from the slippery plastic strips it will stand upright until someone walks by creating a slight breeze which causes the iPad to slide forward until it hits the plastic strips which then cause an increase in slide speed to the iPad until it is lying flat again in under a second.

The magnet works but it doesn't hold. When I'm carrying the case there is so much clicking going on as it connects and disconnects constantly putting the ipad to sleep then waking it up again over and over that it sounds like castanets.

The elastic band designed to hold the flap shut looks like the clasp broke and I had to make a makeshift fix, like tape on broken glasses. I looked before I ordered but didn't notice this case had one of those.

The price is such that it isn't worth returning. By the time I pay for shipping etc it'll take up almost all my refund. If I had it to do again, I wouldn't. Just sayin.
Did not work - at all.  Seemed as though it was an empty piece of plastic!  Very disappointed.
I was able to get most of the bubbles out but the screen protector was very murky, making the actual screen appear dull and fuzzy. One star for fitting the Tab 4 properly.

I bought my Kindle Fire HD in November 2012, at first I was very happy with it meaning for the first hour. After an hour it started fully shutting down without my permission to. We called in and they sent us a new one for free with in a week and I have to say their customer service is polite. It worked until April of 2013 in  which then I was having the same problem with the new Kindle I got in early December. What made this even more frustrating was that this Kindle I had for more than one week and had lots of pictures on it and it would not turn back on unless I plugged it into the computer and would still was occasionally shutting down. We called customer service and they helped get most of the pictures off. Then I was sent and new Kindle and I got most my games back on because they were stored on the cloud but I had lost all the progress on all my games which I had been playing for months which was also highly frustrating. It is now almost the end of July 2013 and my Kindle is now not fully shutting off but powering off in just two times today without my permission. The only thing I have to grant through all of this is that there customer service is friendly. If you are reading this review I warn you to save $150 more and buy and I pad mini. Though they will send you a new Kindle it is not worth the stress of loosing your pictures and progress in your games. I hope that the troubles with my  third Kindle will resolve themselves but if it gets worse and starts fully shutting down or continues Amazon will be hearing from me for the fourth time and I will hopefully receive another Kindle and I may consider buying and I pad mini. I hope you take my advise and do not invest in this piece of trouble.

A few weeks ago, I began having a boot up problem with my MintBox 2 computer which is running Linux Mint 17. It would freeze at the BIOS entrance F2 display. But if I manually powered off the computer and then powered it back up, the boot proceeded normally.
This was a major nuisance as the computer itself is in another room. I had to get up and walk into the other room every time I rebooted. I tried reinstalling the grub boot loader, updating the BIOS , changed the boot order and anything else I could think of. Nothing helped until the thought occurred to me to remove the usb devices and see what happened. I first removed the usb receiver for the Solememo TP801 and rebooted. Guess what. The computer booted up fine and is now just like it was originally.
I ordered this device on November 28, 2014 and now realize the boot problem began when I inserted its usb receiver. This device is now worthless to me.

I constantly looked at it for the first month, using a dental mirror to check for leaks in the places I couldn't see, and everything seemed fine. No this is not a tragedy, like some people have experienced with AIO closed loop water coolers, although it is annoying, and quite possibly damaging.  After 7 weeks, it starting leaking at the left hand pump fitting, where it connects to the tubing. This is a 7 week old complete build, and it dripped on my new GTX 780, leaving a greenish yellow salty residue. Thank God I have a windowed case and I noticed it right away ( I think). Very slow drip, but any drip is simply unacceptable. The GPU seems fine, but I doubt I'll risk it again with a water cooled solution. Going with an air cooler, as I modestly overclock my 4690, and a good air cooler should keep temps manageable.

The description claims "Extend the range any wireless network by up to 10,000 square feet", and that the repeater can penetrate walls with its dual 600Mw amplifiers. Ok, let me address this. I had my main wireless N Western Digital router about 50 feet from my the repeater, separated by one exterior wall. The signal was marginally boosted at best. I was getting download speeds of up to 50Mbps when I had previously been using the Western Digital wireless router, but then I moved it to another area of the house. As a result, the signal was weaker and I had to boost it.

I bought the Amped repeater after reading the reviews and description, and the best I got after repeating the signal was about 5Mbps. I realize you will get half the original signal on average when you boost a wireless signal like this, but this wasn't even functional. Then to top it off, one of the antenna broke off the base so I am stuck with one antenna. I'm no longer using it, its collecting dust in my stash of junk. I've turned to running conduit along the outside of the house with cat6 cable and connecting another wireless router running in access point mode to repeat the signal at no loss of strength. Save yourself the money and frustration, this thing isn't worth it.

I ended up buying a brand new one with a price difference of $170 (this one being $399 used on Amazon) and its a huge difference. Doesn't lag and runs smoothly. I had the card for barely a year when it died out. I heard a rattling inside my case and I thought my system fans or CPU/GPU might be acting up. Then I started getting static and buzzing feedback constantly in my headphones. I thought my headphones were broken until I switched to onboard audio and everything sounded fine. After removing the soundcard the rattling inside of my case stopped. It was easy to discover that the soundcard was faulty. After contacting Creative they refused to send me a replacement since I was a couple of months over the 1 year warranty period. The best they could do was offer me a 10% discount on their store which was a bit insulting to me.

I advise against buying this piece of hardware. If anything bad happens the manufacturer (Creative) will not help you. You're basically out of your money. And for such an expensive soundcard they should really take pride in their hardware and offer better customer service.

I'm never buying another Creative product again. There are many better sound companies out there today with DAC's.

Hello.  I generally don't leave product reviews, but these speakers were a true waste of money, so I feel compelled since times are so tight.  These speakers are cute, for sure.  But they have no quality of sound at all, and I'm not even all that picky when it comes to speakers.  But if you want to listen to music, or have louder volume for whatever you are listening to, you will not like the sound you get from these speakers.  If you try and turn them up loud (not blasting, but loud enough to hear when not right next to them) it sounds like they are going to blow, or are blown.  Very hollow sounding too.  You'd get better quality from a hand held radio than this set.  Save your money, spend it elsewhere.

Although the box was missing the install CD, it was easy to get this up and running. The picture quality for still images was very good, however when streaming video the picture quality was very poor. The unit worked for about an hour, then just stopped working.

First off, I am SERIOUSLY DISAPPOINTED, as these speakers sound VERY good considering the size and price.That's all they have going for them, however:

Unfortunately:

The raging white noise that's present when no signal is present- say for instance you get a phone call, so you mute your audio player on your computer. You would expect the speakers to be silent, right??? WRONG!!! The emission of a loud, constant white noise accompanied by a clicking and squealing noise was absolutely beyond belief. Forget using your USB mouse or keyboard, as the mouse MOVEMENT is clearly audible through the speakers, along with some key strokes, albeit to a lesser degree.This product is meant to be used in the \\"near field\\", and it has a great stereo image and acceptable frequency response given the constraints of the appx. 3\\"x3\\" cube. Where it falls short and is absolutely unacceptable is the level of noise emitted when NOTHING is playing, and you're simply trying to use your machine!

To be fair, I tried these on 4(four) different machines in my household: 2 desktops, 2 laptops. Same results. Returning immediately to Amazon. Thank God for Amazon Prime!

This is my second tablet, my first being a 4\\" eclipse.. to begin, I'm a user thats completely digital, server in the Living room, web servers, PC's in every room and even have my old m105 pda laying around somewhere, and scripting to handle it all, Somewhere along the way \\"name brands\\" and their $$ gave way to paying attention to the real hardware. the AGPtek arrived today and I have to say it is a great lil tablet, with dataviz documents to go, google play and a few other apps [I uninstalled a few games and un-needed apps]. Screen resolution is great, Netflix plays flawlessly and once i installed the media player, it played video from the AV server flawless without converting into a 'mobile' format or using transcoding from the DLNA media server.
My only concern is the skinny charging plug/jack; it Does Not charge through the mini usb port. If your giving it to children or your a lil rough on inserting power cords, it could pose a problem in the future. I like to have adapters that I can have ready to go in the car and the lack of the usb charge means another Charger.. small price to pay for a tablet that fits the budget, performs great and looks good too.

UPDATED: Unfortunately I have to revise my previous glowing review. This dock worked decently (with the occasional hiccup) until a couple of months ago when it just went mysteriously and completely dead. It would not recognize that anything at all was plugged in. Over the past couple of months I have spoken to customer service multiple times, have been issued an RMA number that that will not work with their inane online processing system that spits out errors at every turn, been apologized to more times than I can count, yet still sit here with a completely dead dock and absolutely no indication of replacement or repair in sight. Perhaps my unit and CS experience were a fluke, but I am anxious to get past Belkin and their expensive paperweight and search for a working solution... cross my fingers and hope for a Sonnet I guess.

ORIGINAL REVIEW: I use this little dock to run multiple external hard drives and a MOTU audio interface. So far, I have had no hiccups. It's handy because I mounted it backwards so all the ports are facing me. Since the stock ports are all on the rear of the iMac, now I can swap components out without doing the blind reacharound.

You've heard the pros, so no need to post any, this is a negative review.  I visualized having a central point to store and stream media, and save files other than on a local PC, thumbs or a library of disks. The descriptions of this product make it seem perfect.  I would also assume this is a common desire.  This device wasted my time for two years. The interfaces were lethargic and flaky, the performance bad, and Linksys support mustn't like this product much either. They were about as much help as a sponge in a hurricane.  After a long struggle against a molasses-slow web console, mediocre network performance and mysterious mid-stream connection drops I was finally able to update the firmware (a single upgrade made available after two years), which more than doubled the interface speed. Big issue there--how could a product with so many glaring faults get off the QA desk?  My Linux boxes hate connecting to it, my Windows 7 pukes on the uPnP and security whenever it is most inconvenient.  I'm still troubleshooting it. I won't tire you with too much tech or Linksys-bashing... considering Linksys makes many darn good products.  This is not one of those good products.  If you want to out-of-box have a streaming library and reliable network data storage, look somewhere else, such as a router with a USB slot. Perhaps other brands are better, but if Linksys blew it, I can't imagine many doing better.  I'd suspect a bad unit--overheating motherboard or such except that my issues are popping up all over the web, experienced by many. Instead I intend to disable uPnP and another feature that turns failed logins into guest access--under advisement from another troubled user.  Don't plan to make this work out of the box. perhaps don't plan it to work out at all.  For anyone interested, update the firmware, disable the guest account stuff and uPnp. Also, create a login with the same user name and password as a login to your local machine and use that to access your files or theadmin setup. Assign it a static IP and hopefully your router has a reserving engine for this. (Note, I didn't get good results using dhcp to assign an IP from the router, and make sure you set the DNS to the IP of your router (most home routers serve DNS.  Also you might try mapping a drive to the storage locations in windows. But this device costs too much, plus the hard drives... to be a backyard project. Good luck.

Not OS 10.10.3/Mac compatible - This review comes after I evaluated/tried to get two units working with my iMac (Mac OS 10.10.2/10.10.3) and two iOS devices (an iPad Air 2 and an iPhone 5s / Both running iOS 8.2/8.3. The included Tuxera NTFS drivers could not be installed on my desktop computer. Mac OS 10.10.3 cannot read/mount the included .dmg file (error message when attempting to mount the disk image: The following disk images couldn't be opened: Image - Tuxera NTFS for Mac.dmg, Reason - image not recognized). The wireless network created by the device is unstable. It constantly drops out, can't be seen during wireless scans, rejects known passwords and appears to 'turn off' when idle. This 'Mac Compatible' product is not worth the 10+ hours I've spent troubleshooting it. I've spent numerous hours trying to get it to work (two different whdd units over five days worth of troubleshooting) with my iMac, my iPad and iPhone (and an Airport Timecapsule running version 7.6.4 for internet bridging). The software for the iOS devices is difficult to use/non-intuitive and the instructions are not helpful. I couldn't figure out how to copy the photos from an SDHC card (32gb, class 10) to the wireless hard drive. They transferred to the iOS (my iPad) device, but that's not useful if you're trying to make room for numerous photos. I had to install NTFS-3G and MacFUSE in order to enable read/write (from the desktop) to the NTFS formatted whdd. All in all - This wireless portable hard-drive needs considerable work before it's 'compatible' with Mac/iOS devices. Calling Toshiba for 'technical support' resulted in numerous (three) hang-ups, a promised call back that never happened, numerous communications/language issues, a statement that technical support is not available for this product and a total lack of support. Thankfully Amazon allows me to return the device. Perhaps I can find something that is more compatible with my Mac.
