The pros: the support was great from the dealer, getting a fast refund (only for the battery - the transport to return it was not refunded). UPDATE: the seller also refunded the return of the item.

The cons: it has been a waste of several days. The netbook only started up on the first attempt after switching to the new battery. From the second restart, the process just stopped while reading the BIOS. To pass that, I had to switch back to the old battery, start-up once and then switch to the new battery.

conclusion: do not waste your time nor money, this battery is no more than a brick at least for me. Unless you have extra time for the attempts... good luck.

We bought two of these as Christmas presents last year. Last night one Kindle stopped charging because of a broken pin in the USB port, and the entire USB port is loose on the other. Basically one's dead and the other is soon to follow.

Of course they are both just barely out of warranty so we're stuck with them. Apparently this is a widespread, known issue with poor design on the USB ports that goes back several models. It reeks of "planned obsolescence" on Amazon's part. It's the Achilles heel of the Kindle. Search for this issue on the web or look for broken Kindles on Ebay, you'll find tons of them with this issue. You'll even find 3rd party services that have built up around fixing this one issue since Amazon won't fix them.

I wish I'd known, I'd have just paid the extra money to get an iPad instead, at least they last.

The Kingston DataTraveler family of drives should be a great product.  The pricing is excellent compared to the storage capacity, and they work very well in regards to compatibility with PCs and USB ports.    Where the Kingston drives fail miserably is in their user ergonomics.  First up is the cap.  The cap is on tight - real tight - and that is good, since it helps prevent it from getting lost.  However, the shape of the cap - tapering in the same direction you'll need to pull it - combined with the tightness, and therefore the effort needed to remove it, makes it very difficult to grip long enough to get it off.  Kingston could have overcome this easily by including some grooves, ribs, or some flares or depressions to enhance your grip, but inexplicably they didn't.    The fatal flaw for me is the keychain loop on the rear of the drive.  For me, the USB drive is all about mobility.  I like to be able to carry 4GB of data around with me; it's fantastically handy to port that much storage.  But, and this is a big \\"but\\", you MUST be able to make sure the data stays with you.  Who wants to lose their data? No one does that I know of.  And this is where the drive lets you down.  The loop for hanging it on a keychain is far too weak to hold up to even light duty use.  Mine broke within 6 days of use, and it was shocking how little effort it took for the loop to break. A very gentle tug of my keys from a backpack pocket, an act that my [[ASIN:B0003009E4 Lexar Media 1 GB JumpDrive Sport USB Flash ( JDSP1GB-231 ) (Retail Package)]]has endured for nearly 2 years without complaint, and yet the Kingston snapped its loop completely off.  To further add insult, it now has 2 very sharp barbs where the loops were, requiring me to perform some surgery on the drive just to make sure it doesn't pose a danger to fingers.    I'm headed back to the Lexar JumpDrive Sport family, which I appreciate even more than I did now that I've seen the failings of the competition.

I bought this router mainly because of the rave reviews about the easy installation.  If you have a few new computers and a new wireless printer, the installation may be rather painless.  But if you have computers with different OS and your printers are a few years old, watch out.  My main desktop and three laptops connected without much trouble.  The printers took more time and my laserjet is still not working.  The big problem was a much used desktop with Windows XP.  When we attempted to connect it, we got the message that we should first install Service Pack 3.  How do you do that if you no longer have internet access.  We had to retrace our steps and return to the old router.  But then the old desktop would no longer work and connect to the internet.  I expect that eventually we will get it straightened out, but it may take more than a day.  Why does Linksys not put a warning in their package that Windows XP must have Service Pack 3 installed prior to installing the Linksys E3200 router?  I have always used Linksys and this was the longest time installation!
Warranty was for 1 year. Died at the 13 month mark. Figures... Worked well while it lasted. For $22, I will probably buy again.

The case I got is counterfeit.  I was having problems with the plugs falling out and the screen scratching easily.  I contacted Griffin customer support, and they were able to confirm that that my case is not a Griffin manufactured case.  Griffin customer support is excellent about verifying their products.  If you want to check if your case is counterfeit, send pictures of the box as well as pictures of the front and back of the case to support@griffintechnology.com.  They will get back to you promptly.  If you do have a counterfeit case, they will also send you a discount coupon to buy a \\"real\\" case from them directly.

I bought the first unit from Amazon and it arrived with a broken rear SATA port. The broken piece in the bag seems like is was crystalized sugar. It feel apart when touched. I returned it to Amazon for a replacement. The replacement came in and it just didn't work. It would not pass data. So emailed Amazon and the sent a 2nd replacement. Having built at at least 30 computers I am not a rookie at it. Again I emailed amazon and the support guys are awesome. They refunded my money without question and were truly sorry for my troubles. I really wanted this to work because it is exactly what I need.

I purchased this laptop at Best Buy in March because it is solidly built and I like the size of the display and keyboard. My goal is to replace a 4 year old Gateway Windows 7 10.1" laptop, that has a 1 GHz single-core CPU and 2 GB of RAM, with a newer model that is at least as fast. Although this Acer Aspire has a 1 GHz dual-core CPU and twice the amount of RAM as my old Gateway, it's appallingly slow! For example, with the Norton 360 internet security, Firefox web browser, and Thunderbird email client running, the CPU occupancy spikes to 99%! During this scenario, the RAM and hard drive aren't close to their limits.

Unfortunately, there's a bigger problem with this Acer laptop! The battery abruptly dies without Windows first displaying the low battery power warning! Acer let me exchange the battery for a new one, but the new battery has the same problem! I found that I need to configure Windows power management to display the low battery warning at 50% battery power, because the battery dies at about 44%! With this setting, I get a 2 hour run-time.

Since this Acer laptop doesn't meet my performance expectations and the battery life is too short to make this device useful for me, I had to replace it with a Dell Inspiron 3148, even though the Acer is only 9 months old! This Acer laptop is all show and no go!
The stand up angle is not comfortable for Skype / Facetime. The iPad kept on sliding. we were disappointed with the purchase and bought a new cover. Paid more, but we're much happier.

2/12/13-UPDATE Well I just tried to use this device after re-installing software about two weeks ago and no luck. USB dongle is not responding and has solid blue light which mimics the issue when I had to uninstall/re-install as noted below. I'm giving up and Medialink is going into the garbage. While my fix below worked for one day, I have no intention of repeating these steps. Go with another brand of Bluetooth USB.

UPDATE 1/31/13-I had non-working Medialink Version 3.0 Bluetooth device in my hand to throw out when I remember someone else's review saying something about re-installing driver with a disc included with device. I still had original packaging and it does have (2) disc. I did not remember that (13) months after purchase. It seems most USB devices these days have software loaded in device itself. My wireless headphones and boombox installed their own driver software on this PC once I added them to the PC using this Bluetooth dongle, no disc needed.

I'm using this device with a Sony VAIO running Windows 7. So I uninstalled WIDCOMMM Bluetooth Software, Publisher Broadcom Corporation. Weird sold by Mediabridge, says Medialink on dongle and this is the software name. I re-installed this program and the Bluetooth device is now working again. I don't think you should have to uninstall/re-install any software in such a short period of time. Many people are not computer literate and would never have been able to do this.

Something else I forgot to mention is my device came apart at plastic end sticking out of USB drive. I used some Gorilla duct tape cut to size of end to put it back together many months ago. And even if your doesn't come apart you may tape something on it as the blue blinking light is very annoying if you are working in lower light environment.

I am doing another test of audio as I type. Running Slacker Radio on both PC and iPhone 5 and audio just sounds richer/fuller on the iPhone. The PC seems to befarther away. I am not using equalizer on either device so I would expect audio to be the same but in all fairness it could be the sound card installed in the PC causing sound to be slightly different compared to an iPhone. If you are not an audiophile, you may never notice difference but I am always comparing ear-buds to ear-buds to Bluetooth devices trying to get best sound out of whatever source I am using.

The total amount of time deleting my Bluetooth devices from PC, adding again, restarting PC numerous times trying to fix along with uninstall/re-install and updating Amazon review had to be at least (3) hours. I am only giving this device (2) stars for the reasons stated above. Minus (1) for coming apart/too bright blinking blue light in darker room & less rich audio. Minus (2) for time wasted rebooting PC/deleting devices then re-adding & uninstall/re-installing software just (13) months after purchase. Too much time wasted just trying to use this product. The iPhone takes about (15) seconds to add device and have Bluetooth up and running.

1/29/13-I purchased Version 3.0 device in 12/2011. This item worked initially for LG HBS-700 Bluetooth headphones and Logitech Wireless/Bluetooth Boombox but after not using it for several months, it no longer worked on my next attempt. And just (1) month past one year warranty. Both Bluetooth devices work flawlessly with the iPhone. Most importantly the audio quality is not the same as when using iPhone. I wasted hours trying to fix problem. I tried to download driver again and Medialink indicates you must purchase driver or it will not work after 40 days. What? Don't waste your money or time like I did. Complete absolute failure.

If you purchase this controller, look on the back of it and check out the sticker on the back. It says: 'Made in China'. That sums it up right there. My parents bought this controller for me many years ago because I was and still am a video game nerd, (bless them. They had no clue about how much of a piece of junk this thing is). Anyway. Even back in the day I hated this controller, even when I first held it in my hands. Made of cheap plastic, this thing is EXTREMELY cheap. The design of the controller felt very awkward for me. I didn't like the detachable thumb stick very much. It didn't seem to want to stay attached to the D-Pad hole that it snaps into. When I'd be playing a game, the stupid thing would fall out. Extremely annoying to say the least. So if you're looking for a great gaming controller. One that isn't a cheap piece of Chinese crap look to Logitech. This have great controllers.

I ordered this product to put in an older Mac Pro I bought.
Unfortunately, I was too busy to install these into my computer right away.

When I got around to installing the ram it crashed my computer.
I went through one by one to check the sticks and sure enough one of them was corrupt, right out of the package.
On top of that, my Mac Pro will only recognize these sticks if they are installed as pairs. So even though only one 4gb stick is dead, that means there are 2 sticks I can not use. So, I effectively paid $170 for 8 gigs of ram... Which to me is ridiculous.

Turns out the deadline to return the ram had passed before I installed it, so I'm stuck having paid for 4 sticks and only being able to use 2.

Is it wrong to assume something will work well right out of the package and not be DOA? I don't think it is.

Thanks for nothing, Komputerbay.

My previous (cheap) keyboard broke and I picked up this keyboard at Walmart because it was the cheapest, thinking that this would tide me over until I finally had the money to splurge on a mechanical keyboard. However, this keyboard is the worst. It takes a really long time to (sync? whatever it does with my computer on start up), so that even when the computer is booted up, I have to wait for the keyboard to start working before I can type in my password and log in. The graphics processor on this and many other HP laptop models runs so hot that over time it actually melts the low grade solder HP uses to construct these units. This causes the graphics processor to lose electrical connectivity with the mother board. The unit powers up (lights go on) but the screen stays totally black. There is a big class action lawsuit in the formative stages regarding this very issue. When you examine the motherboard from this model (and every other HP laptop since the Compaq/HP merger) one thing is striking...the motherboard thickness is about half that of any Sony VAIO model or Toshiba unit. HP engineers also elected to use a single heat sink to cool both the GPU and the CPU. The fix for this endemic HP laptop problem involves either reheating the GPU to readhere the solder to the motherboard or, better, removing the GPU, cleaning up the low grade solder, and resoldering the GPU with a higher grade solder that will not degrade at GPU operating temps. If the high temps and inadequate heat sinking has caused mother board warpage, you're looking at a new motherboard. When the computer is reassembled copper shims should be fabricated to place between the GPU, the CPU, and the heat sink. Use thermal conductive paste also. There are a number of YouTube videos that go through all this and the fixes in detail.

In summary, HP laptops seem to be steadily declining in quality. This is due to a combination of poor engineering and the use of inadequate quality materials. A laptop should last at least 5 years. These current production HP laptops often fail between one and two years. That is, right after the factory warranty runs out. Sony and Toshiba don't suffer from these issues near as often as HP, Dell, and even Apple does. The few dollars HP saves in producing these laptops costs the consumer hundreds down the road. Cost to fix the above problems ranges from $125 + shipping to $400 plus. Thus these repairs may not make economical sense. A new laptop purchase is mandated. The only vote the consumer has is with his/her wallet. Until HP fixes this endemic problem, consider purchasing your laptop from a different manufacturer.sense. A new laptop purchase is mandated. The only vote the consumer has is with his/her wallet. Until HP fixes this endemic problem, consider purchasing your laptop from a different manufacturer.

Like most people who buy a sub-$100 tablet, I was mostly attracted by the price. (So what if it's not great? I'm only out $100.) I've had the AGPtek 9-inch Android 4.0 tablet PC for about a week. First I found that the \\"user guide\\" in the box was worse than useless. It was poorly printed on pages of tissue-thin paper about 2x3 inches and contained many screenshots that were totally black. The downloaded version had legible pictures but was generally of not much help. It even contained inconsistent advice, such as admonishing the user to use the USB connection only for the transmission of data, but then on another page pointing out that it could be used for faster recharging (than the ac adapter). For the uninitiated Android user, a brief introduction to Android software might have been helpful, or at least a link to an Android tutorial. The worst problem I encountered was the tablet's poor wi-fi performance. The tablet consistently indicated that the signal from my home wi-fi network was \\"weak,\\" and sometimes too weak for the tablet to download anything. This is in spite of the perfectly normal performance of my aging LG telephone, my also aging netbook computer, and my even more remotely located Roku box under the TV. The only way I could get the tablet to operate through a wi-fi connection was to position myself about three feet from the wireless router, and even then the AGPtek would only show one or two arc-shaped bars, still indicating a very weak signal. In contrast, a signal strength app I have installed on my phone shows a \\"moderate\\" to \\"good\\" signal strength throughout the house. I can only conclude that the wireless transmitter/receiver function of the tablet is defective in either its design or its manufacture. The battery holds a charge only for a couple of hours or so, probably as a consequence of the perceived low signal strength of my home network. (The tablet probably ramps up it's receiver gain to the max in an effort to receive a better signal, andin so doing runs the battery down quickly.) My advice is to pay more up front and get a tablet with a brand name you can trust. Don't buy the AGPtek tablet. One way or another, this one is going back. I should probably give only one star and not two because most of the uses I had in mind for this device were online ones. But I suppose it's still possible to do a few things off-line, and it's always possible that you could use your \\"portable\\" tablet tethered to the router or to a wired network outlet. But that's not the way I would prefer to use a tablet PC. I think I just talked myself into dropping the rating to one star (I hate it).

I bought this scanner because I wanted to scan book pages from recipe books, music books, etc., some sizes larger than an 8.5 x 11.

I found that scanning books with smaller (.5) margins were impossible to scan without some excessive work at keeping the sensor on the page and any shift in position caused the scanner to start scanning at a different angle instead of straight. I also found that if you try to scan anything larger than letter-size pages, the scanner memory will run out before you've finished scanning the item, making stitching impossible because when it reconnects to the page, you find you have to start all over.

I agree with other reviewers about the cord. The cord is covered in rubber that grips the paper and moves it when you're trying to scan. Nothing can be done about it, other than taping the corners of the sheet to the table surface. It's a huge annoyance. The bad thing is, the cord is positioned level with the scanning surface, so it literally skips across the surface while you scan.

A better design would have been to make the cord position higher on the mouse so it doesn't skip across the page along with the scanner and to cover it with a smooth-gliding plastic rather than gripping rubber. Not sure which one of LG's rocket-scientists made that call, but it doesn't work, which is surprising for an LG product. Most LG products are great. This one is not.

Further on that subject, you will find NO support for this product on LG's U.S. site. You have to go to the UK site if you want any support or information on this product or to download the latest drivers and software for the product (if the autoupdate quits working within the software, which it does, sadly, leaving you to deal with failed installs.). For me, that kind of raises a skeptical eyebrow as to the reasoning behind the non-U.S. support.

If you are scanning flat sheets, it does an ok job, but then flat sheets can be scanned with a regular flat-bed or page scanner better and more efficiently, so why spend money on something like this (unless space is an issue)? If space is an issue, you better keep tape nearby to dock the paper to the surface so the cord doesn't move it. And forget about any type of book scanning. Flatbed scanning is more efficient despite the dark spine sides.

I bought this mouse not as a gaming mouse, but as a >3 button Bluetooth mouse for use with my MacBook Pro. Bear that in mind while reading this...

The first issue is that the mouse's firmware somehow communicates to the Mac that it's not only a mouse, but also a new keyboard. When sensing a new keyboard, OS X runs the user through a Keyboard Assistant application. Every time I connected the Orochi to my Mac, this Assistant would come up. And it happened with multiple Macs, too. The only real work around was to disable the Assistant.

The second issue I've been having is the application used to program the Orochi's buttons. I can't get it to reliably set the programming and *keep* it. Every time I'd connect the mouse, one or two of the programmed buttons would \\"lose\\" their settings.

I think the failure here is that the Orochi's button programs are being somehow saved to the mouse itself (perhaps some NVRAM in the unit?) The only way to set the mouse button programs is by having the Orochi connected via USB, which implies to me that they're writing something back to the mouse. There are probably better ways to do that...

Overall, I wouldn't bother with this one if given the choice. At least: not on a Mac.

The huge mac caveat first:

If you're running Mac OS X (10.9.x), the software drivers for this mouse WILL cause your entire computer to crash (kernel panic) daily. I've tested this for days. Razer's Synapse 2.0 software is well designed and feature-rich, but it simply breaks the OS in ways that are inexcusable. Until Razer comes out with an update for this, my rating will remain 2 stars.

***

First, some short info about myself:
- Male, 28 years old
- Software engineer & designer
- Starcraft I + II diehard
- Mac OS X 10.9.x

I've been searching for years for a worthy, wireless replacement to the mouse I've been buying for 10 years: The Microsoft Intellimouse Optical. Recently, old new stock of the Intellimouse has jumped in price and will continue to rise, and in general I've always wanted a worthy wireless solution. I don't like the heavily used, highly reviewed premium offerings from Logitech, specifically the MX series. The form is just too large, heavy, and doesn't fit my hand. I also have had bad experiences with the cursor tracking performance in daily use.

My criteria for the successor replacement:
* Similar form factor as Microsoft Intellimouse Optical
* 4-5 primary buttons, 8 buttons max
* Wireless
* Rechargeable
* Notched, "stepping-click" scroll wheel
* Gamer-caliber DPI resolution

The short review assuming Razer updates their Mac Synapse 2.0 software:

The Razer Mamba is an excellent mouse from a form and design perspective. It feels like a premium, "Darth Vader" Intellimouse in form-factor. The mouse feels great in the hand, the weight is perfect, and the cursor tracking phenomenal. The cable length is generous and the locking mechanism to switch between wired/wireless with the base station is well designed. I purchased this router and used it for one week before I finally decided to return it. The Linksys AC2400/E8350 router, while it is capable of delivering truly excellent throughput, suffers from too many flaws to justify my owning one. I conducted my tests using a MacBook Pro (mid 2013 model), an iPhone 6, an iPad Air, 2 Apple TV units, and an ASUS ZenBook UX31E. I did upgrade the router's firmware to Ver.1.0.01 (build 14) beforehand. I have substantial experience with networking in office and home environments, including client configuration, so I can assure you the flaws are not the result of user error, an atypical environment, or a strange home layout. My tests were conducted in my apartment, a rectangular shaped 2 bedroom 1500 square foot apartment with dry walls, single story, with the router situated in the center of the apartment, with no conflicting channels from neighbors’ routers. I was able to confirm the absence of channel conflicts using WiFi Explorer in OS X. I tested several different channels.

WHY I RETURNED THIS ROUTER:

This router was too slow in negotiating initial connection with any device. In addition, it was too slow or unreliable in reconnecting when taking my computer out of suspend or sleep mode, tasks that my prior router (a Cisco Linksys E4200) handled beautifully. These problems would even happen when my devices were within 8 feet or as far away as 30 feet of the router. The router's SSID on the laptop clients were properly configured to top priority. In addition, since I was the only person in the apartment when I conducted the tests, the load on the router from my various devices was light, to say the least.

To make matters worse, laptops and devices would lose connectivity several times a day (even though the DHCP lease was configured to 1 week). My old E4200 router, which I have used flawlessly in this environment for more than 4 years, performed much better in every respect, except for throughput.

I am returning the E8350 and have just purchased the E9200 and hoping it performs better.

By the way, the E8350 self-identifies as a Belkin router when I scanned it using WiFi Explorer in OS X. I have never considered Belkin a maker of excellent equipment, and this experience has not helped to improve my opinion of them. As it stands now, this is an overpriced, low-end router within its class. Look elsewhere until new firmware is released that resolves these problems.d have just purchased the E9200 and hoping it performs better. I tried so hard to like this mouse, first I got the MMO7 and returned it for a refund and then I went for the Rat7. I thought the MMO7 was defective, the mouse goes haywire after a while. Once I got the Rat7 I thought that all is well now, but no. Desperate for help and still hooked on this device I turned to Amazon first to look at reviews and found an email for someone at Mad Catz and told him my issues. He was very helpfull and quick with his replies. Turns out that it was lint, dust and microscopic fibers that gets in the lens area that causes all the problem. The mouse lens are just too sensitive and there is no easy way to physically clean the lens either. They suggest Q-tips, but most of time those will also leave lint in the lens area too. Well that being said, my Rat 7 will go back in its box and I will just hang on to it in case I move into a sterile environment where there are no lint's or dust. Maybe future drivers will fix this problems.

So, I will go back to optical mouse. Logitech G400 I think.

1. The hard drive is no longer held in by screws, but via 4 very cheap plastic \\"springs\\" that make it nearly impossible to get the drive in. Once in, you'll never get it out again!

2. There used to be a \\"sled\\" on which the drive was mounted, and the electronics were firmly attached to the sled. Now the electronics consist of a small circuit board with the connectors (data and power) connected to the end. I suspect that installing and removing a drive more than a few times will break off the connectors.

I ordered this based on the previous 3 reviews, 1 being 1 star and two others being 5 stars. Just received it today, installed perfectly and looks to be OEM. Booted up and battery was showing 57%. I kept it on battery power and encoded a video file in order to discharge the battery. Macbook powered off by itself around 13%. I then charged it up to 100% and have now been using it for the past hour and it hasn't dropped 1%. Very strange behavior. Coconut battery shows 1 cycle, now 2 since I charged it but current capacity remains at 100% since I've been using it for the past hour?

I'll try to update this post as the days go by. May consider returning and just spending the additional $30 to get it from apple and know it will work.

Update - After two days now of \\"conditioning\\" the battery, coconut battery reports design capacity of 93%. Yesterday it was 97%. After just 2 battery cycles the capacity has already dropped 7%, which is about 20-30mins of usage. After doing a PRAM and SMC reset (hold left side shift,ctl,alt + power while mac is shutdown and plugged in) the battery percentage in OSX is accurate. Only issue remaining now is capacity after multiple cycles.

Once upon a time I purchased the original Kindle--and I mean the original. The first one. The dinosaur. You know what? I loved the dinosaur. It was easy to read, easy to use, and easy to love. Because I didn't have any complaints about my Kindle, I never considered ordering any of the new models that have entered the market...until the Paperwhite. The new backlit screen and allegedly improved ease of use convinced me to trade in my dinosaur for the sleek new model.

I purchased the Paperwhite back in June, and a scant 4 months later I can report the dinosaur is back in my hands.

Yes, the backlit screen is lovely and easier to read. That's the beginning and end of the nice things I can say about this new Kindle. My daughter came over today to check out my Kindle Paperwhite because she's considering getting one herself. The Paperwhite, with incredible irony, chose that moment to not just be difficult, but refuse to work altogether. The screen is frozen and my books won't show up no matter how many times I restart it.

It's safe to say she's sticking to her dinosaur as well. Perhaps I have a renegade Paperwhite and I think Amazon should know the little beast cost has cost them a sale.

I bought this battery in October.  I figured that for the price, it couldn't be any worse than the original Dell battery.  I was wrong.  When I first got it, it seemed to be OK - charged quickly, held a charge pretty well, although I did notice that what the supposed life was (2.5+ hours when fully charged) never seemed to actually be that long.  But still, long enough to allow me to unplug for 20 minutes or so to get to another location, or work briefly in my car.  But starting about a month ago, the battery won't even charge.  It's plugged in, and it stops charging at 2%, of 5%, or 8% (I can't figure out why the difference), and immediately shuts down if I unplug from AC power.  I read some of the comments about it not fitting well and not hitting the pins.  I did notice that it was sliding around a little bit, so I put a couple of layers of duct tape on the side to get a better fit.  Now it will charge up to 22%, but still says \\"critical battery\\" as soon as I unplug it.  Of course, I can't return it because it's been too long.  I'm extremely unhappy with this battery, and next time will spend the extra money for a Dell.

Mediacom uses these units for HSI now and they are total junk. The modem is amazingbut that is irrelevant because It uses a belkin N450db router that constantly disconnects, overheats, and produces an extremely unstable signal barely capable of 72 Mbps @ 20 feet. Though it is branded and sold as a dual band unit it is not, it only operates on the 2.4Ghz band, with a max link speed of 14 mbps @ a 5 ft distance from the unit. No external antennas, and no High gain Internals, it's no wonder this under performs all around. As a network technician of over 15 years, I wouldn't wish this combo on the worst of enemies. The Motorola dedicated modem and a cheap net gear router will outperform this unit any day. Add DD-WRT to the equation and even the lowest end setup will far outperform belkin top end models easily. My best advice would be to throw it in the trash, without trashing as an option I would recommend disabling the wireless on the unit and using an external Netgear or Cisco/Linksys router.

I have been a Cisco / Linksys user for good 14 years but that may change soon. I bought this router to finally go from Wireless-G to Wireless-N and to also benefit from Gigabit Ethernet within my LAN, hoping both wired and wireless backups would be noticeabky faster. This was a replacement for my old, and now again current WRT54g Linksys router.

The initial set up was easy for both frequency bands and initially all seemed good. Then I tried to stream some music from my iTunes via AirPlay. All that happened was a router reboot. And several times. Had any backups or other critical traffic been going through at that point all would be lost. Cisco material did not provide much, offline or online. However, Googling revealed I was not the only one with this problem and various workarounds were suggested. Most meant sacrifices, including the loss of Wireless-N. That was not why I bought the router! One suggestion was disabling CTF, which should mean no trade offs in my situation. And I was happy for a moment again since AirPlay worked again and so did everything else.

However, next day page loads were slow, some pages would not load at all, others lacked styel sheets, one big mess. I rebooted the router but that did not help. At this point, I was losing my patience since my rule is that new things should simply work and not need excessive troubleshooting. I swapped the router back for the WRT54g. Since I modeled the settings based on it the swap was easy. And boom, everything was back to perfect and reliable.

Bottom line? I returned the \\"top of the line\\" product of 2012 and went back to the 54g that's been up and running non-stop for years. Glad I tried the switch when I did not have to since I had an easy way out. When I collect courage to try again, it will be a different brand. Sorry Cisco, but a router has to route! What are all the other fancy features good for if the basics fail?

This is a counterfeit card and will not hold more than 4GB of data! It was a defective 4GB card that should have been destroyed, but was instead reprogrammed to APPEAR to be 64GB. It will look fine in your computer, and will even appear to write 64GB of data to it just fine, but you will only ever be able to read the 4GB the card actually holds. Search for a site called SOSfakeflash for more info. If you suspect you have bought a fake card, use a free program called H2TestW to test it. The program writes 1GB files to the reported capacity of the card, then tries to verify the data. If it is a real card, it will verify fine, if it is FAKE, it will show errors starting after the real capacity ends (usually either 2 or 4 GB). Do not be duped! These sellers know what they are doing! They have been doing this scam on eBay for a while. They try to justify it by saying it is an "upgraded" card, but it is fraudulent to say it holds 64GB when it will never hold more than 4!

I bought this sad wretched device on eBay last year, and have watched it go downhill almost from day one. Just an incredibly poorly-built product, incomprehensible instructions, and more glitches than you'd think possible. The LCD screen quit working after about a month or two. Plus the SD card recording fails almost literally 50% of the time. Sometimes I'll go to eject the SD card to have my computer extract its contents as mp3/sound files, and it'll say the SD card is empty, that there's NO data saved! So 2 months of phone calls - BAM! gone - instantly! just like that. I can tell the device is recording (supposedly) and working clearly. But sometimes it stops for no reason, and I have to unplug & plug it back in, to get it to reset.

Here's the biggest red-flag that this is a poor-quality foreign-made product: there's no brand name! None. No manufacturer listed, either on the product itself, or the badly-mistranslated "instructions". No model # either - no way of identifying who made this or anything about it. Just a few weeks ago, my unit started making up its own dates to name the audio files, so now I get folders on the SD card that are labelled with the year 2049 and 2050 *sigh* and no way to fix it.

However, the worst flaw of this Mini-Telephone Recorder (something that I noticed instantly, which makes it a built-in design flaw) was that the volume of the other party on the line is much MUCH softer than your own voice. So when you go to open up the sound file and listen to a previously-recorded conversation, your own voice will be like CRAZY screaming loud, but the volume of the person you're talking to will be so soft you can barely hear them! And of course there's no way to manually adjust the recording volume control. I wish I could find a cheap simple device like this except built WELL here in America!

The price is excellent, but, unfortunately one seemingly gets what one pays for with these screen protectors.

There isn't a whole lot to say about screen protectors, but I will have 3 categories: ease of installation, appearance, and functionality.

Installation: these were a little bit trickier to put on that other brands I've used. I had to "redo" it several times to get the bubbles out, and, I'm generally quite good at installing these flawlessly. Of course, every time you have to re-situate the protector, you run additional risk of introducing foreign object (namely, dust and lint) into the picture. I would give these only a "2" in terms of ease of installation compared to other screen protectors I've used on phones, tablets, and laptops.

Appearance: No complaints here. They are crystal clear once you get all the bubbles out.

Functionality: Ok, here is where this product simply fails, and I have 2 screen protectors that I will probably never use now. After installing the screen protector, the touch screen of my 2nd generation Nexus is awful. Prior to putting a screen protector on, the Nexus touchscreen is about the best out there. After putting on the protector, I feel like I have a cheap tablet with an inferior screen. Just as an example, when playing Candy Crush and Solitaire, I have to sometimes swipe the screen 5 or more times to make a move. This is unacceptable, and it is clearly the result of the screen protector because I've used my tablet for 2+ years without a screen protector and it performed flawlessly. I just can't understand why a company would make a product that so drastically impairs the functionality of the touch screen it's meant to protect.

I would not purchase these. I would either get a case, or get a different brand of protectors. I've had good luck with 3M products, but they are much more expensive.

Summary:  A lot of the positive reviews are quite old.  The version of the product that shipped at that time (2002-2004) was GREAT and deserved 5 stars.  The version that is shipping now is a pale imitation of the original.  If you are considering one of these backpacks, do not rely on the early reviews because the product is NOT the same.    Detail:  Over the last 5-6 years I have owned 3 of these backpacks.  The one currently shipping (see \\"Version 3\\" below) is NOT as pictured.  Here's a quick recap:    Version 1:  My original backpack - purchased in 2002 or so - this version of the 15.4 Targus Gravity was well made and included both shoulder straps and a strap you could buckle around your waist.  Given the volume the bag holds, these were very nice features because a heavily loaded pack (in my case full of lots of books and a much heavier 2002-era laptop) was surprisingly comfortable to carry around.    Version 2:  When my original bag wore out (I'm pretty rough on them - no fault of Targus there) I wanted to buy the identical model.  I thought I had - they had the same model number after all.  Not so.  (This purchase was made in 2006 or 2007.)  The bag I received was otherwise identical to Version 1, but Targus stopped including the waist strap.  I was pretty annoyed at this, but eventually got over it as I was unable to find anything better.    Version 3:  In November 2009, my second backpack wore out.  As with before, I wanted to purchase the IDENTICAL laptop bag.  Hence, I searched for and bought the IDENTICAL model number - the Targus RG0318 15.4 Gravity.  Guess what, they changed the design AGAIN!  They removed one of the two zippered side pockets, leaving just the useless mesh holder that things will fall out of if you ever set the bag on its side, toss it into the back of a car, into the overhead bin of a plane, etc. etc. etc.  USELESS.  Also, the interior materials are much cheaper and have a mass produced quality to them.  They replaced the cool foldable document holder (that would keep papers nice and flat and out of the way) in the main compartment with a cheap velcro pouch.    The stock pictures you see listed are for what I call Version 2 above.  I.e. they are OUT OF DATE and do not show the current instance of this backpack.  If you buy the model now you will NOT get two zippered side pockets as shown, but only one.    Dear Targus: If you are going to change your product offerings, that's fine, do whatever you like, but DO NOT NAME THEM ALL WITH THE SAME MODEL NUMBER!  It's a huge difference to get rid of a belly strap and then get rid of one of the zippered side pockets on a product like a backpack.  These aren't mild cosmetic updates.  They are fundamental changes to the product's usefulness, and changes for the worse at that.

My husband purchased this with my new Kindle 2 so that I could have something to protect my Kindle's screen. I'm not real enthusiastic about it after having attempted to install this on my Kindle three times, attempting to remove the dozen or so specks of dust which are clinging to the sticky side of this product via the method recommended (using scotch tape) has been - shall we say - less than successful.

The product claims are as follows:

1. Maintain the anti-glare feature of your original Kindle 2 screen
2. Dust Repelling, Fingerprint Free, and Bubble-free Application
3. Sized to specifically fit the Amazon Kindle 2

My claims are as follows:

1. The anti-glare feature is fairly good, except if you get a bunch of dust under the screen protector. Dust causes bubbles, bubbles cause glare.

2. Dust repelling? I dunno. My Kindle is inside a cover when it's not being used. It does seem to resist fingerprints but there's no such thing as a bubble-free application of this product. A perfect installation with no bubbles would be possible only in a dust free environment. Most people don't have access to such an environment.

3. Yes the size is perfect... but unless your vision is also perfect, getting this item positioned on top of your Kindle screen in EXACTLY the position needed is time consuming... and with the sticky side of this product exposed to the air (and also the dust) for the length of time needed to get the product in the correct position... all I can say about that is bad... bad... bad.

In conclusion, I have to give this product an over-all rating of one star for the difficulty of getting a perfect installation.

I was forced to buy a Kindle Fire HD as the Kindle Keyboard 3G is no longer available. After my 2nd Kindle Keyboard died in less than six months (first one lasted two years) I was at the steps of Best Buy on a Sunday night because waiting 24 hours for a new eReader was unacceptable.

The Kindle Keyboard was the perfect Kindle, it was the best of both worlds, non-glare screen that could be read in full sun, and had speakers for text-to-speech enabled books (I have a one hour commute and I could listen where I left off). The low end Fire is the lowest priced 7\\" Kindle with speakers. Amazon touted that the Kindle Keyboard 7\\" was one of their best rated items of all time, then why did they stop making it!

If you are an AVID READER stick to the old school Kindles, Fires lose all of the things that make it easy to read, they are heavier, make even reading next to a lamp a pain (can you say eyestrain), and don't categorize your books easily (I have 1200 books dumped in the \\"Cloud\\"). If you need all the \\"extras\\" that go with a Fire (videos, apps, et. al.), buy a Samsung tablet and get a Kindle App. In the long run you'll be able to do all of the things that supposedly make a Fire great, and actually make it work for you in a business setting.

purchased this drive to rrplace a bad drive in my original wii. Went to the website and viewed the installation insttuctions. i would suggest getting 12 small containers for the steps involving removal of screws. I labeled the screw removal steps according to the instructions. This helps you when you are assembing back. I had some problems with the wiring disconnecting the wii front cover. I was really cover but ending snapping one of the wire from the front cover. I didn`t know what to do but i figured i would move on to the rest of the install. Anyways, got to the point to disconnect the old drive to install the new one. That went easier! I took the situation of another reviewer and plugged it in to test it was getting power. Well it was then i tried a game cd. Well it took the cd but was not spinning. I decideded that before i would proceed further, I would hook it up with the rest of the tv cords and sensor. Nothing! I took it apart again and installed my bad one. Plugged that in and tried game cd. This spun the disc. Checked the new one and what should i find inside? A freakin elastic hair band! How the hell did that get in there? Someone refurbishing this drive did not check if they lost a hair band! I removed the screws to remove the hair band. Installed , hooked everything up and plugged in to test. Would you know it, the game cd was spinning. Finished and hooked up finally and it is working. I would say that this is just a fluke but it sure I`m sure am curious how the hell a hair band got stuck in the drive.

Unfortunately, the product does not come with a Win2K driver.  This is odd especially considering that the most likely machines to need a USB-RJ45 port, are those old legacy machines that would be running Win2K.  When  I contacted Sentey they were as polite as they were unhelpful.  They claimed that there was no Win2k driver because it was a "security issue since even Microsoft does not support Win2k".  When I pointed out that MSoft no longer supports WinXP and the driver works for that OS, I received no reply.    Saying "Our goal is for you to be completely satisfied with this transaction. If this is not the case, we would appreciate it if you would give us a chance to address your concerns before leaving feedback."   is not enough.  It is not enough to make up a reason why a problem cannot be addressed; the solution is to address the problem.  Talk the talk -- very well -- Walk the walk -- not as good.  The reason I imagine that there is no Win2K driver is that nobody bothered to write one.  Furthermore, if anyone did bother it would not be a particularly risky piece of software, or a difficult endeavor.  So probably Sentey does not have anyone who can do it... I can't begin to describe the disappointment I've experienced with this product. Here's a quick summary of some of the issues I've had:

- Connectivity issues: I'd say about 30% of the time, this device does not appear in my Network Devices list. Restarting the device sometimes corrects this. Even worse, it randomly disconnects while I'm transferring files!
- Slow transfer speeds: My network isn't the fastest thing out there, but this device has EXTREMELY slow, inconsistent, transfer speeds. The primary reason I bought this device was to store the massive amounts of photos we take. The transfer speeds on this make me dread having to transfer my photos.
- File corruption: I've noticed that if I'm transferring a large amount of files, if the device loses connectivity, then regains it, some of the files being transferred at that time become corrupted. For example - I transferred several dozen photos tonight. Naturally, this thing loses connectivity prior to all the files being transferred. Once connectivity was regained, I glanced through the files which did transfer, and several of them appear to be cropped in half. Fortunately, I still had access to the originals. The same thing happened several months back; that time, I hadn't realized the file corruptions until I deleted the photos from my SD card!

I purchased this Acer XB270H monitor from Amazon. It failed two weeks after the 30-day refund/replacement period.
1. DSR is NOT the true game changer. I prefer it off because it does not actually look better and I feel it adversely affects game performance. DSR is nothing but hype.
2. G-Sync must be built into the games. No game supported G-Sync, NO G-Sync. G-Sync is nothing but hype.
3. Monitor is 1 ms response time. Less than 4 ms is Very Very Important.
4. Monitor is 144 Hz. Very Very Important. Makes G-Sync moot.
5. 27 inch display is very very important.
6. $500 price tag now? Look for monitors with 1 ms response time, 144 hz, and 27 inch or larger display for lower price and/or from a company better than ACER. Acer Customer Service Sucks. My monitor died on Feb 19, 2015. I purchased it on December 5, 2015. It last only 10 weeks before failure, GO FIGURE.
7. DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS MONITOR NOR ANY ACER PRODUCTS.

I ordered this case to build a music server. It seemed ideal for my needs and I loved the looks but when I received it, I was appalled at the poor quality manufacturing and the internal design seems ill conceived. Quality wise, it is not in the same league with Silverstone or Lian Li aluminum cases.

Specific issues:

1. The cover edges are very sharp and I cut my finger badly while removing it. You could argue this is my fault, but other aluminum case manufacturers manage to finish edges so they don't slice you.
2. My case had a strange dime size brown blemish I was unable to remove.
3. The welds for the rail that the cover attaches to are atrocious, worst I have ever seen in a PC case. No you cannot see them when the cover is on but it is part and parcel of a \\"home brew\\" feeling to this product.
4. The fit of the cover to the chassis is not precise. To reassemble it, I had to start the screws at an angle to pull the cover into alignment, stripping some of the screw threads. When assembled, the fit is uneven.
5. Inside, were all sorts of scratches or tool marks. Again, you won't see them with the cover on but you would never see this soppiness with a Silverstone or Lian Li aluminum product.
6. The case is supplied with an 80mm fan but it is attached on standoffs about 1 inch from the side vent -- not an effective design to vent air efficiently. The fan is a cheap design.
7. Because the last several mini ITX's cases I bought came with power supplies, I assumed this one did too, but it does not and it is only available separately from the distributor/seller (it is mentioned in the description).

The distributor was responsive and agreed to take the unit back but I'm out at least the non-trivial expense to return it from Hawaii.to return it from Hawaii.

I was looking forward to getting this laptop for a very long time because I really liked the Air form factor but really dislike the closed nature of the Apple ecosystem. The Asus is definitely a beautiful laptop and I liked its design a lot, but I think they got the basics wrong, which is shocking: wireless, touchpad, keyboard, and customer service.   First and foremost the wireless did not function correctly. At first I noticed that it went in and out even though I was sitting right in front of the router and none of the other people in the room with laptops experienced the same problem. Alone, I could live with this, but if you plan to stream a lot of content, be forewarned. Second, when I opened up my laptop after closing it for a bit, it couldn't find ANY wireless networks. I had to troubleshoot, at which point it told me that the network adapter had been turned off and asked me if I wanted to turn it back on again. This happened EVERY time I opened the lid - so, so much for your instant connect. I really just can't imagine any good reason for why any computer manufacturer would ever default the computer to disable the wireless without the user asking for that. I updated the WLAN driver, updated the BIOS, and also changed the power settings so that wireless would never be turned off to conserve power. I did everything, and nothing fixed these issues for me. I should add that I have a very nice, relatively new $160 router - it's not the router!  Second, even though I updated the driver for the touchpad, I kept experiencing problems with it. Scroll worked ok, but not as smoothly as on an Air. However, the special gestures just didn't work properly. I'd try to zoom in or out and it would zoom too much or too little and when I tried to rein it back, it just kept overshooting and it just wasn't usable. Likewise, every zoom in or out took a while to actually update, so you'd just be sitting in front of a frozen page while it tried to change the size of the page - it wasn't an instant experience like on the iPhone or the Air. I ended up disabling those features. Likewise, the touchpad insisted on zooming even when all I was trying to do was scroll. So....it's livable, but it's no improvement on the standard touch pad if the gestures are basically unusable.   Third, the keyboard just wasn't great. I'd type and it would miss every 5th key or so. I'd have to go back and retype everything. I feel like this is something I could probably get used to after a while and train myself to type harder, but it just seemed strange to be having such a basic issue on a very expensive, top of the line laptop, when even the cheapest netbooks had better keyboards.  Fourth, I called Asus customer support. I had registered my laptop and had become a member with the support stuff, but they insisted on taking my name and email and machine number, making me respell everything three or four times. I'm really not kidding - it took them 10 minutes just to get that info down and I don't know what the point of registering with the site was if I was going to be asked all this stuff again. I told them I had wireless issues and they didn't suggest changing power saver settings or getting the new WLAN driver (I read about that online), instead they suggested updating the BIOS. They sent me a link to their updates page and that was it. So, first of all, I feel like they didn't offer all available fixes. Second, when I went to the page there were three BIOS options and I had no idea which one I needed. I got all three, but then I couldn't open and install them! My friend figured out you had to go to a utility on the computer to get them updated. NOWHERE did it say how to implement these updates. We did use the utility, but then there was no feedback to say that anything had been updated, so who knows if it even worked. I called support back and they insisted that I give them all of that personal info again, even though I had a service number from the last time I called. So I had to repeat my name 5 times yet again! Don't they have all that info on file from the last call?? Why give a service number if you're going to spend 10 minutes asking me basic info AGAIN? So I gave him all that info and he started doing something and I was on hold for a while and we got disconnected. I called a third time, and they asked me for all of my info AGAIN. I told the person that I had already given info twice in the last hour and I didn't want to do it again, since clearly it was in front of him now that I had provided a service number and the info twice before. He insisted three times that he couldn't help me without me \\"verifying\\" that the info was correct. So, I gave up and hung up.   So, be forewarned, trying to get service is both unhelpful and frustrating.   In the end, I decided to send this back and I'm typing this review from an Air. Trust me, I waited for over a year to replace my laptop just so that I wouldn't have to buy an Apple, but dealing with the Asus truly drove me into Apple's arms. With the Air, none of those issues are a problem. If you ever need tech support, you show up at an Apple store and someone helps you instantly - no calls to Bangalore with people who are just reading from a script. Everything just works. There's no bloatware. In the Asus, you had both Asus and Windows utilities that seemed to conflict- like more than one manager for power and wireless. You might have fixed a problem in one and not the other. Plus, you get a nice backlit keyboard and pretty amazing gestures. Sure, it's more expensive, but if you're going to shell out over $1000 for a laptop anyway, don't you expect the most fundamental things to work?  As an aside for Asus's benefit, since you guys read this site, I think you sunk not just the Zenbook, but the entire ultrabook campaign. People really thought they'd finally get an Air alternative and then were sorely disappointed. Guess what? They did what I did - returned your computer and got anAir. Guess who won't be buying another laptop for another 2 years or so? All of the people who were disappointed with yours! But, that's not just bad news for the Zenbook, it's bad news for you because those of us whose first intro to Asus was the Zenbook now believe that you make half baked products. Likewise, you've proven yet again that no one can do it as well as Apple. This is all very unfortunate because many of us were rooting for an Apple competitor and many of us truly do believe that the more open approach to software development and platforms is the right way to go. But, by creating yet another crappy product, I think you're driving many people to believe otherwise. Problem is that once Apple gets you into their ecosystem with one product, they really make it appealing to then add other products or services to that ecosystem and the more people do that, the harder it will be for you to ever get them out of it. I think you missed a real opportunity to turn things around for yourselves.

I bought two of these for my home office. The first one broke before it was plugged in: the socket into which the USB cable would be plugged pushed into the device, making it impossible to plug in the cable. The second one functions in a very narrow technical sense; but unlike the several four-port unpowered USB expanders (not labelled), it produces such a steady stream of messages and warnings that it remains unplugged or unpowered most of the time. Furthermore, it is not very reliable at making and keeping logical connection with a device that is plugged into it. Not behavior that one would expect from a $4.00 USB extender, let alone one costing 11x that much.

I realize this experience is quite different from what is reported by other users; but I recommend against buying this device regardless of what your needs might be.

Forget also trying to read as you travel say in a car at night or on a plane in darkness, even with an additional light getting the angle right so you can see without being blinded by the reflection can and is tricky. It doesn't display all PDF's adequately.      -Not customizable - You can't even change the screensaver to a subject of your choice without voiding the warranty.    -Pointless 3G technology (3G works globally) - that's misleading advertising - Can't buy a book for your kindle if you are in a nation you are not registered in. Put simply if you travel forget the hype you won't be able to obtain some of the books you want through Amazon's Kindle Store.    The Kindle DX fall short on most of the claims. The dream of almost instant book purchases smashed just like the Kindle DX should be.     What's good?    Nothing!     It would be fine for an over 75 year old totally technology illiterate and wanting only to look at their old books that are now free because they are out of copyright. If you are under 65 perhaps you would like something of the current generation and not something designed in a bygone era long since forgotten then this Kindle isn't for you. If the dweebs that designed this don't change it, it could go theway of Betamax - well we can at least hope!    Take your money and spend it more wisely by investing in an iPad and simply add the Kindle app to it. Any other choice is a waste of money.    Some you love and some you hate - don't be a laughing stock buy something else.    REMEDIAL ACTION REQUIRED WITHOUT DELAY IF IT ISN'T TO BECOME ANOTHER BETAMAX TYPE FAILURE    Give the Kindle a full color touch screen and get rid of the pathetic keyboard and buttons. Up grade the processors and slim the software. Try adding an internal back lighting so it can be read comfortably in poor lighting or in a car at night. Make it clear that not every book will be available at most locations and include a communications package so that people who enjoy reading and want to discuss the books they have consumed can talk to each other over email or wirelessly over the Web.       Could have been great but falls short on almost everything. Sorry Amazon it's a lemon.

Get what you pay for... This is the first and only review I've ever written, but i feel my experience with this product warranted an immediate review. Bought this tablet for my daughter for Christmas and she loves it, but this is a terrible tablet. We have 4 children and have been through more than a few cheap tablets but this is by far the worst. Not enough battery to make it through one movie with the brightness set as low as possible. Takes longer to charge this thing than the amount of time you use it between charges... avoid this product at all costs, even if it was the last tablet in existence.

We have bought two DVD duplicators from Microboards. Never again! Oh, they work great for a few months and then slowly, one by one, the drives start failing, then the controller starts failing, then the firmware needs updating, and so Microboards sends out a firmware update, then a replacement drive, but then when the problems persist they want you to send the whole thing back. And then they fix it up and replace drives and send it back to you two weeks later and it works great for a few weeks and then one by one the drives start failing again...and the cycle goes on and on. So we decided to buy another duplicator from them so we would not be without a machine while the other one (which we thought was a lemon) was being serviced. Well, much to our frustration, the second duplicator started doing the same thing as the first (working great...then drives start failing...mail it in). We have sent our duplicators in four times in two years!    So frustrating. Never again. We will never by another Microboards product ever.     So I started talking to people this week, trying to figure out what other brand to go with, and everybody I talk to who uses other brands says, \\"Oh we never have any problem with ours.\\" Now, I'm not going to tell you what brands they are using. I do not want you to think I'm a salesman for another company. But I will give you this advice: Save yourself a major headache: avoid Microboards and go with another brand duplicator!

Pretty Garbage headset in my opinion. I read a lot of the 5 star reviews closely, and I believe a lot of them are fake and written by Plantronics themselves.  I have been using a Plantronics Gamecom Pro 1 from 2004. It finally died on me after 8 years of use in 2012, and I repaired it after a couple years and used it again. Then it died again, so I decided to go with Plantronics again because of how great that old headset was.  These are some things I noticed right off the bat:  -FRUSTRATION FREE PACKAGING? Want to know what this is? They take the bare headphones, throw them in a big spacious box with no padding, and then they ship it to you. No packaging around the headphones whatsoever.  -These things are extremely cheap feeling. It feels like nothing but hollowed out plastic.  -I have a small head, these things horribly clamp your skull and make your ears feel like they're broken after 10 minutes of wearing them. The ear cups are comfortable, except for the fact that your ears go straight to the actual earcup itself, which is only protected by a thin layer of fabric. It feels no different than shoving plastic on your ear with heavy force.  -They are designed to break after a year or so. Read all the other reviews around here and you will see a lot of mention of it. I am actually QUITE SURPRISED they DIDN'T SNAP the first time I put them on. There's cheap flimsy plastic above the cylinders on the ear cup, and you have to pull these vice grips apart really hard in order to wear them. The plastic turns white like it's being stressed after the first time you wear it. You may think you can tape it ahead of time, but looking at this, it looks like it will snap really hard one day.  -The cord is garbage as well. Really cheap flimsy cord. The quality of it is even worse than the 2004 Gamecom 1 cord. It constantly twists and it's literally impossible to uncoil some of the points. I tried with TOOLS and they refuse to uncoil. I have read that the cord eventually starts tosplit apart and break on its own after several weeks or months.  -The audio quality is "ok". It's surprisingly nowhere near as good as the 2004 Plantronics Gamecom Pro 1 I had. This was designed 10 years ahead of time and it sounds worse? Alright then.  - The mic is decent. Again, I did a lot of tests myself and while talking online to other people, and the headset on this sounds EXACTLY like the Gamecom 1. ONCE AGAIN, 10 years into the future, and this hasn't improved at all. Like many other reviews on here, people state the mic usually goes first, and a lot of people state it fails after about a week or so. It will start making static noises, and eventually buzzing, and eventually fail altogether. I've had this for about a week, and guess what? The static noises have started.  -The surround sound sounds like crap. All it sounds like is an echo effect. That's literally it. It sounds like I'm in a cheesy fake auditorium talking to people with voices bouncing off all the walls.  All in all, this product takes the early-mid 2000s Plantronics Gamecom Pro 1, makes it 100 times worse, and then resells it years later.  This headset is garbage, stay away from it, buy something else. I am returning this immediately.

There is some confusion about these speakers, do they get their audio via USB or just their power via USB?  The answer is that these speakers get their power via a USB but do not receive their audio via a USB. The speakers must be plugged in via your audio out or headphone jack in order to receive audio. More importantly the sound quality produced by the speakers is very poor, I would say that it's about the same as the internal speaker and my Mac Pro, only a little louder. These are cheap speakers, so I did not expect them to perform as well as my sound sticks, but I did expect better sound than the internal speaker in my computer.  The speakers are fairly small and portable so if you just need something for a laptop while you're on the road these might not be bad, but if you're expecting great sound quality you will be disappointed.

I am not happy with this laptop. It is the most laggy laptop I have ever used, even more so than the 6 year old Toshiba with the full hard drive that I was replacing. In fact while writing this review it has lagged twice, just from typing, with no other browser windows open. I have lost part of a work document I was writing because the computer froze and wouldn't do anything, even task manager wouldn't fix the problem, and I had to force shut down. Other times the computer has frozen and task manager won't even load, ctrl-alt-del just brings up a blank screen and a spinning mouse. I expected this kind of thing from my 6 year old computer that I had filled to the brim of it's hard drive, but I have only had this Asus for about 3 months and have barely saved anything to it's hard drive yet. It definitely feels like it can't handle too many activities at once, and sometimes it can't even handle one at a time. Also, this is something small, but I really miss my old computer's external volume dial. Especially with the lag, I find it hard to quickly adjust the volume on this Asus.

The only thing I really like about it is the touch screen, I like being able to zoom in closer on things that normally I could not, and I like swiping through pictures.

I ended up with the Cisco 2500...Not sure if I had a defective unit, but the Medialink went back to Amazon.
First I was sent the wrong cord so they sent an adapter for it. So of course that tiny piece went missing quick! And every time I plugged the cord in, the outlet would spark.

It was broken and didn't work. Tested all of the other parts and they worked individually so I figured this thing is to blame. Now I know why it was only $2.95 including shipping. Dump defective products, \\"sell\\" them for nothing so you can make your margin in the handling fee. Oh well...

Second take on their adapter...

The connector / converter did not work for me. They sell it as a way to connect older video cards to newer DVI only monitors, but the truth is not as simple as getting things connected. The monitor must also support the analog signals coming from the VGA era card, many new digital monitors do not. Better solution is to buy a cheep card that has a DVI output. Well at least now you know why it's only $2.95...

I bought three of these machines (AO751h-1401) they are indeed very impressive except for one very important thing.  After the first one or two days they started freezing; not like \\"take a long time to process something\\" freezing, but more like just completely inactive.  The monitor remains turned on but the harddrive light stops flickering (sign of inactivity), the mouse won't move and the keyboard won't work...or wake it up from inactivity.  Consequently, I was required to always cold boot the machines.  Most of the time the machines would freeze during windows updates or during some other software updates.  Often, also, the machines would freeze after being left on and then allowing them to go on standby or sleep mode; it was impossible to get them out of standby or sleep mode, so it always resulted in unwanted cold boots (with the power button or by removing the battery).  Apparently the problem is persistent through a range of Acer Notebooks and Netbooks; either way, it is a shame because the machines could have potential (when they work properly).  In the acer support site it asks that you update the bios to either 3206 or later (3208).  Doing so worked--for a while that is.  I managed to get the machines to not freeze during software updates, but I still can't get them to stop freezing after going into standby or sleep mode; I always end up having to cold boot the machine.  Everything else works great (once all software and system updates are installed, of course).  So, if you get one, make sure you get it from somewhere that will give you a refund if it does not work.

The order presented only the price with no mention of shipping costs. I expected standard shipping costs at most, but then the order I saw had expedited shipping. It cost as much as the cord, totaling about 18 dollars. Then after a week, the cord came and it turned out to be about two feet shorter than the actual cord I wanted. I checked the model number and the model is different than what was listed. For now, it is good to have a working power cord, but being misled by the model number was not an acceptable part of the process. I saw some of the other reviews about dysfunctional cords and fires. I've seen the other reviews, and fully expected to have an excellent experience w/ the optical mouse, but within 10 minutes I knew I had made a mistake.
I like to have a minimum of mouse movement, so I turn the sensitivity of my mouse up high. I'm used to having 2 inches of side to side mouse movement make the pointer cross my 19\\" 1280x768 screen. Hooking up the optical mouse, I found it very similar to my analog mouse - at first. But then I noticed that the pointer, while moving fine on strict horizontal or vertical motions, seemed to stutter on diagonal motions. Trying to move the pointer on a 45 degree angle across the screen, I could see the pointer shuddering slightly, but not making any real progress. Moving it faster would then make the pointer jump way beyond where I intended it to go. At this point I don't know if it was my mouse settings, the pad I was using (tried several), or the optical mouse itself, but I got very frustrated not being able to control it as precisely as I had before, so I returned it. I'm now the proud owner of 2 (2!) Logitech optical mice and love them...

Each tech used remote access to my laptop to try to install a wirless manager that worked. To no avail each told me that i purchased a piece of crap. So now instead of being out just the 35 dollars i am out almost 140. Please, Amazon, advertise properly or i will stop purchasing from your website.

**************************************************************************
FRAUD ALERT:

This computer was sold as new by EZ-Mart, but I just found out it was used. I had two preliminary indications. The first was the taping on the box. It wasn't as even as the original taping would have been.

The second was there was an tear on the keyboard box flap.

The third, and more damning was within a week of use, my father-in-law got a pop up from HP that said that the computer was registered Aug 18, 2012, and the warranty would expire Aug 18, 2013. Considering that I bought it in October of 2012, someone else had to have registered it in Aug, 2012. That means someone else has used it. I'm contacting Amazon to see what remedy I can get.

In fact, the name of the first owner is on the box. I'm not disclosing his name, because it wasn't his fault. I emailed EZ-Mart a week ago, and so far, no response. I will be contacting the appropriate attorney's general with respect to this retailer's fraud.

***************************************************************************

Also, it looks like it was a return, although it was sold as new. Still, it works fine, and is faster than the computer it replaced (my Father-In-Laws).

Setup was simple; the Windows 7 OS seems to be pretty similar to Win XP; and the HP Printer Driver installed simply, error free, and on the first attempt. The Windows version neeeded several rounds of update; the first round had 74 updates alone.

There is a lot of bloatware on it; I'll have to prune it sometime. That looks to be another evening, at least.

But, my father-in-law is happy. He was willing to settle for an Acer eMachine, but really wanted an HP. This wasn't that much more than an equivalent Machine, and we both felt more comfortable going with an HP.

I'd buy it again, just wouldn't be expecting it to be as fast as my quad core Intel processor powered Vista computer.

I bought a brand new 2TB drive.  Within 1 year the drive completely failed, without any prior indication  Seagate replaced the drive but 1.5 years later the new drive also completely failed. It was working perfectly and five minutes later, it completely failed.  Tried multiple PCs, and cables, and just could not believe that it suddenly completely failed.  Obviously am out of warranty.  The point is how can 2 drives completely fail so easily. I lost all my kids videos.  The video files were so huge that i did not have any additional comparable storage.  Should have bought another drive to backup.  I used the drives to backup personal files and kept it at home only.  Never moved it around, never took it out of the room!  I have Maxtor 300GB drive that i bought 6-7 years ago.  I had bought it used, but it is still going strong.  Unfortunately Maxtor was bought by Seagate in 2006 so am not sure of Maxtor's quality now.  So am unclear which drive to buy - but one thing is clear it will not be Seagate.

I've also had issues with my IP address being reassigned to other devices and windows telling me I have ip address conflicts (To hopefully fix this issue there is a setting in the router to assign a specific mac address to an ip address). We probably have about 10 or so devices connected to the router. And lastly, I bought a Western Digital USB Hard Drive and connected it to the router. The problem is, the drive appears to go into sleep mode and the router does not know how to keep it active or reawaken it so that feature is completely useless.  On a positive note, the signal strength of the 2.4Ghz 802.11n band is great and reaches all corners of the house compared with my old 802.11g router.
