The device's parental controls are intentionally crippled in order to steer parents into an (effectively required) $3 month subscription, on top of your current Prime subscription.

While you CAN use the built-in Kindle parental controls and Amazon Video Playback controls, there are a number of issues with this:

-Locked videos are still visible in the video lists
-Kids can still watch trailers for locked videos (seriously Amazon?? wft)
-Locked areas of Kindle are still on the top menu simply grayed out (how is this helpful to anyone?)

The only solution is to enable Amazon FreeTime without the subscription - and here's where the entire experience becomes a blatant money grab:

-You CANNOT add any Amazon Prime videos to the child's content list unless you PURCHASE them

That's right NONE of the content you're already paying for with your Prime subscription can be used, you have to additionally purchase this free content for your child to watch it.

It gets worse - by default this Kindle has sponsored ads on the lock screen:

-The ads (while possibly not adult) are certainly NOT age appropriate

Your only option is to pay an additional $15 to remove them.

So to sum up: you either have a completely empty device, or one with all the same kid unfriendly issues as the Amazon App on other tablets, OR you pay $15 plus an additional subscription simply to access content you've already paid for.

The real cost of this Kindle for parents is: $114 (based on the current $99 advertised price) + $3 month subscription on top of maintaining your existing Prime subscription. Use this when price shopping against other devices for your kids.

I got this drive as a replacement for a drive that was a replacement for a drive - all miserable failures. This drive actually worked for a few weeks before my PC started not recognizing it. Finally failed completely after less than two months use. Did I mention that it was a replacement sent from SimpleTech to replace the other two that failed before? SimpleTech actually upgraded the drive to a 2TB which is sitting on my desk as I type - can you hear that? That is the drive. All the way from New Mexico, you can hear it. I'm fixing on sending back the 'upgrade' soon, as after a week, I'm expecting it to fail miserably again. This is the fourth failed drive that I have received from SimpleTech to replace the original which was shipped with a screw loose. That's right - four drives, four failures. If not for the barely adequate customer service (did I mention that they have sent me a replacement four times over?) I would simply take this drive out and run it over with my 21 year-old Honda. That would be awesome! Did I mention that it is loud as heck? First time I started it up I thought my child was choking in a back room. Seriously, this thing is intolerably loud to start up, then kind of settles into a low drone which increases in intensity until it is unbearable and I've got to power it down. Crap. If this was the first drive that failed from SimpleTech, I'd not be so crass. But, after a 100% failure rate through four drives, I cannot sit idly by and let others waste their time and money on this company. I'm kinda bummed I have to give it a star rating, as I would much rather give it negative stars.

Used these on a TP-Link TL-WDR3600 router. Used android wifi analyser to measure signal strength. 3dBm signal reduction on 2.4MHz
1dBm signal reduction on 5MHz

I was really happy to find this module since there are few choices for LCD modules that can directly receive UART serial/RS-232 data.  I was willing to spend a few extra bucks for this feature over the countless other cheaper units out there. I bought this LCD module to work with an Arduino board thru the UART serial interface.  I connected it per instructions (by the way, no paper instructions are included you have to use the link in the description) and programmed up my board to use the LCD module's protocol.  The very first time, the unit was totally unresponsive and the backlight doesn't even come on.  The only sign of \\"life\\" I can observe is that the LCD pixels go full contrast when the module is powered.  I unsuccessfully tried \\"resetting\\" the module to different serial protocols to see if it would \\"wake up\\".  The return \\"window\\" had lapsed when I finally got around to this project, and it doesn't look like there is any manufacturer warranty.  STAY AWAY as far as I'm concerned.

All the Ports weren't recognized. If your looking for a Good 4 port PCIE 1X Card that has UASP Protocol (Which is 480% faster than a
USB 3.0 Card........Look for an Anker. You won't be sorry!!!!

No matter how many times I tried, I could not load the software successfully. Every time, somewhere along the line, there was an error message.
Then, as the prior reviewer noted, the two-button function seemed as usual for any other mouse. However, if I put it in 'pc' mode, it would lock up, or, if started there, would not even be recognized. Only by setting the switch to 'ms' mode would it recognize.
Like the prior poster, I could not make the middle button do *anything* - even though the setup page was quite complete with all the options shown, I could not make the button do anything.
The lack of documentation is appalling. Nowhere did I find any reference to how to make the scroll function work. The scroll button seems to be only a one-way (forward end moving, rear hinged) possibility, but the setup page refers to both axes - without any mention of how to engage it or reverse it.
It goes back tomorrow if I can't find their site to download a new set of drivers to test.
I *did* like the ps2 with serial adapter feature, as I have machines with both, and that's usually an extra-cost item...

My Old Review: It's a decent PC when it wants to work. Usually basic processes make the CPU reach 100% and the majority of the time it doesn't turn on completely. It will show the lights and all of that, but the monitor won't detect it. So I'll have to unplug the power cord from the PC and hold the power button for 20 seconds to make it work. It's really annoying.

And to add to that: This thing falls apart easily. Literally.

When this product was first announced, I was very excited because at the time, there was a dearth of covers for the back of the iPad 2 that matched the colors of the Smart Covers. As it turns out, there must have been quite a few people in the same position as the case was back ordered for months. I finally received it as a gift much later, and I have to say, after having used it for a few months, that I am very disappointed with the quality of the case given the price.

The biggest problem I've had is that the tiny plastic hooks that keep the iPad securely in place have snapped off on two corners. At the time, I did not remove and replace the case with any type of frequency that would cause them to snap off, just one day I noticed one of the corners was missing and it was starting to get a little loose, then one of the other corners snapped off and I was unable to keep the case in place period. I do not use the iPad outside of the house, nor do I let my children play with it.

The other problem is that the way the mold is cut, the corners of the case scrape against the iPad and leave scuff marks on the corners. This seems like a real production flaw and almost defeats the whole purpose of the protective nature of the cover.

Overall, it looks great on the back of the iPad and matches the Smart Cover well, but unfortunately, it just doesn't serve the purpose it was intended to very well.

You will read that there have been so many complaints for so many months, yet till today, Apple has not addressed it. I am shocked that any company could actually release such a lousy software that has memory management issue. This is not even intermittent issue. This is a broken software or maybe hardware.

Some decided negatives: flash player on websites dos NOT work properly, seizes up after a few seconds, sound goes on behind a static picture. Unacceptable. The Samsung book cover case, though OK by feel (far from the ingenuity of the iPad cover, though) has one appallingly bad design feature: when closed, the side edge presses on the on/off switch. It beggars belief that this could be allowed to happen. Plus, the tilt of the tablet, when used with the cover is with the 'top' pointing down and certain applications do not rotate 180 degrees to accommodate this. If you place the tablet the \\"wrong\\" way in the case, you solve that problem (and, ironically the one with the accidental on/off button press!) but the charging/USB cable is now on the inside, so you have to keep the case wide open to charge. Utterly idiotic.     I deliberately refuse to by i-somethings as I refuse to believe that one company should have a global monopoly on style and good design, so it is extremely annoying to see stupid oversights like these handing Apple on a plate the image of epitomy of cool design. Think, Samsung, think, damn it! You only had to try to use the thing to see it needs more work.

I was really excited at the idea of getting a tablet with these specs this cheaply, and for the most part it is functional. (I'm writing this very review on it in fact) but there are some problems I just can't get past.

1) Mine won't charge! It has the bothetsome issue of some mobile devices these days where you have to plug in the charger just so, or it won't connect and won't power the device. Very frustrating. I realize this problem wouldn't affect all tablets of this model, and I could get it replaced under warranty to fix this, but there's other things that make me not want to.

2) The tablet is pretty slow. Even turning all window animations off, this device chugs through even the most basic tasks, like browsing web pages or typing text. Not as responsive as I need.

3) The display quality is barely passable. When watching Youtube or Netflix, the video is plagued with these awful jagged edges that, if I saw the same in a video game, would make me want to turn anti-aliasing on.

You know what I think when using this device? This is baby's first tablet. It would be fine to give to a child, who doesn't mind the slowness or visual problems. The low price would make that an attractive idea. For an adult though, this thing is just below acceptable. I guess it's too soon to expect a really good tablet for this cheap.

Even though Microsoft Ergo is not illuminated, it is 10 times better than this keyboard mainly because the keys do not flow easy.  However, it would be a good keyboard if eyesight is a problem.  Keys not easy movement in my opinion.

I had high hopes for this keyboard, and the look of it when I opened the box only raised them further, since the keytop lettering is extremely nice. But it's way too poorly made. Some keys stick, others don't respond, the whole thing clatters in normal use (maybe to remind you how cheap it was), and the hard plastic wrist rest is pointless unless you also have hard plastic wrists -- and it's integrated with the keyboard, so you can't remove it to make room for a better one.

Unlike many of the positive commenters here I actually DO touch-type, and that probably means I'm not the target audience for this device -- which appears to be crotchety old grandpas still using one-finger hunt-and-peck. (And if you're wondering why a touch-typist would want a large-type keyboard, you probably aren't aware of how often a programmer uses the the non-alphabetic.) Bottom line: Nobody should have to use a keyboard where you suddenly find yourself inadvertently typing in CAPS because you didn't hit the Shift key just so, or worse yet, unintentionally selecting a big block of material because the Shift key stuck and you hit an arrow key for a legitimate reason.

One star is generous. It's trash. It's also just barely too cheap to justify the hassle and cost of return shipping. And yknow, recently I see lots of items like that for sale online -- vendors must realize they'd be swamped with returns if the items cost a bit more, so they price junky stuff just low enough to sucker you in and make you not bother demanding a refund. That way the extra volume puts them ahead regardless. Beware.

I am going to shatter this thing within the week, and it will be soooo satisfying. Your days are numbered you little gremlin.

I purchased this product solely because of its compatibility with Mac OS X, as my internal wireless card is \\"unpredictable\\" at best. However, I couldn't figure out which driver to use to install the Panda USB because the Mini CD that ships with the package is not readable by the internal CD/DVD drive found in my MacBookPro -- the drive doesn't have a retractable tray to which the mini disk can be coupled. Thus began my aggravations with the purchase of this adapter. The website for this product at [...] has the drivers for Mac, Linux, and Windows but no instructions to follow for installation. That's helpful. I was glad to download the driver over a 15k link if I could only tell what driver number applies to my wireless device. There is not a mention of the manufacturers model number anywhere on the adapter, on the packaging, or in the brief brochure that is included in the retail box. Once I am able to figure out that this card is RT3070 and download the software, the device remains unusable. The Ralink wireless manager software reports that the card is connected to my network, yet my ISR/access point does not show an association, and consequently an IP address isn't assigned to the device. However, there is no convincing the proprietary wi-fi manager that the adapter isn't actually associated. Lovely. Thinking that I may be able to use it on the Linux OS that dual boots on my laptop, I load up Fedora 11 and download the Linux driver from the RaLink website. Too bad that I cannot figure out how to get the installation going now that I have the driver. I don't know if it is not compatible with my distro or what. And where are the customers supposed to get the supposed one year technical support? The link from the manufacturers website immediately prompts the end user for username and password credentials without providing a link for one to use to create an account. I give up -- its a loss and a total waste of money. Had I known about the shoddy support and lack of documentation I would not have taken a chance on this product, let alone its inability to function in the Mac OS X environment. Caveat Emptor.

UPDATE:  I'm updating this to a one star after using it for almost a year now.  DO NOT BUY THIS!!!  1. It doesn't work with Windows Vista AT ALL  2. On the mac, the family shared drive is inaccessible about 95% of the time.  This is well documented in the Netgear Forums.  3. Getting the Stora to work on the Xbox doesn't work.  You can't even play videos stored on your Stora on your TV via the Xbox 99% of the time.  ===============================  I bought the Stora 1TB device in the hopes of consolidating our family's digital photos and music files in one convenient location.  I'm in a unique situation because we own an Xbox360, a MacBook, and three windows laptops running Vista and Windows XP.  Getting all of these to work with the Stora was EXCEPTIONALLY challenging. (UPDATE... Since posting this, I've never been able to get it to work with Windows Vista) It seemed that at every corner was a new unexpected challenge to over come.  Although I'll admit that getting it connected to the network was relatively straightforward.  Here were the challenges I faced:  Mac:    - Due to an incompatibility with the way MacOS accesses network drives, the browser fails to connect to your family shared drive.  - Drag-n-Drop on the browser doesn't work either because of this.    - Ultimately, this device doesn't work on a Mac.  (just google 'netgear stora mac issues' and you'll see a plethora of complaints with virtually NO solutions offered by Netgear)  Windows Vista:  - Every time I try to connect to the Stora with the desktop agent on my Vista laptop I get the following error message \\"\\"Local Connection to Stora Impossible. Do you want to try a remote connection instead?\\".  When you say, \\"yes\\" to the question, the system fails.  This is a problem because I cannot upload data to the Stora from my Vista laptop because of this.  I've tried every recommendation possible and there is no known solution to this problem.  - Basically, like the Mac, this doesn't work with Vista. Again, google 'Netgear Stora Vista Issue' and you'll also see a ton of unresolved problems.  XBox360:  -  Videos don't play with Xbox.  I have several videos from our wedding uploaded to the stora.  They are *.avi format.  When I try to play them on my Xbox 360, I got an error message that Xbox needs a special codec for this file format.  This may be an Xbox issue, but this is an advertised benefit of the Stora.  I've not found a work around for this.  -  Xbox does not see new files or directories on the Stora.  This is mostly an XBOX issue, really, but when you add new photos to the Stora and try to view them on the Xbox, the Xbox doesn't list them for a few hours or sometimes days.  It's as if the Xbox keeps a copy of the Stora directory structure locally and doesn't update is until it wants to.  You can reboot your stora and your xbox for hours and your files will not be visible on the xbox for a couple days, then POOF!!  The suddenly are there.  -  Xbox only works with Stora if you set up an entirely separate computer as a media server, connect it to the stora, and connect the Xbox to the computer, then it all works.  Why even buy a Stora then?  What's the point of advertising that the Stora works with the Xbox when it requires A WHOLE SEPARATE COMPUTER to work??!!!!!  I blame both Microsoft and Netgear for this.  - All your iTunes albums will play songs ONLY in alphabetical order on the Xbox.  You cannot rearrange the order of these songs.  I tried to create a playlist for one album (Charlie Brown Christmas) that ran in the correct order only to get an error message that the Xbox doesn't allow you to create playlists on external hard drives.  WindowsXP:  - I tried to use the backup options for the Stora displayed in the stora web page.  However, Stora's method of computer backups does not work with the built-in backup tools on XP.  You have to buy a separate software package to make this work.  I work in the technology industry and consider myself fairly savvy when itcomes to resolving these types of issues.  Despite my experience, I spent hours trying to fix these problems with few successes.  If you are not technically capable, I'd think twice before using this product.  ================  Summary - This thing is just a complete and total pain in the @ss to get to work correctly.

After researching for several months I decided to go with the brand new DELL XPS-15 Touch laptop at Christmas. Big mistake!  For spending over $1800 what I got was a laptop that was flaky and unreliable right out of the box. The first week it would open with a warning “Your PC needs to be repaired … critical files are missing …”; and then move on to open up Window 8.1  Over a three week period I sent three emails to Tech Support, and opened a chat session asking for help.  Even though I had paid for ‘premium’ tech support, NO one ever responded to help me with my issue. Finally, after the fourth week it woke up again with the ominous warning “Your PC needs to be repaired … files missing … contact your Manufacturer!”  and froze with the locked screen of death.  Eventually, I got someone to talk to me. Typically when you call the DELL 800 number for support you will get a message ‘We’re not available now leave a message, or call back in an hour or two”.  Finally they sent out a media to completely reinstall my operating system. It asked for me to insert another thumb drive to back up my files. Of course later I discovered it had actually saved none of my files, photos, S/W apps etc. It was then several days later that I discovered their so called ‘recovery’ disk had not bothered to install over a dozen Intel drivers that were missing. It also failed to reinstall the Windows Office software I had paid for. Interestingly, during those three weeks I did get a call from a very friendly lady offering me a 2 year warranty for the ‘bargain’ price of only ~$230 per year, for a ‘discount’ package of ~$460. DELL has very slow tech support, they have deficient quality control, … But they are really good at “marketing”.  By the way, Windows 8.1 is clunky to learn and use. It was designed for people who use a computer for entertainment, not for actually getting something done.

Price being one factor, I often try to give products from small companies a chance at my purchase. I bought this because there was a positive review about this memory in a W520 Thinkpad. But I had a very different result. My system has both SSD and HDD, one for my personal use and another for corporate use. My company forces a lot of junk in the name of security, group policies etc... slowing my system significantly. One day my system came up with \\"health check\\" dialog and corrupted both my hard disks. I thought it was my corporate security junk that ruined all my personal and corporate data. Lucikly I had backup of both, with a few exceptions. So I re-installed the OS on both HDD and got going again. But everytime I boot my system chkdsk would try to run. So after installing the OS for the third time, I was getting less optimistic of my Thinkpad. My display would also go blank (as you see during power save mode), and would not come back on. I thought it was bad power manager or bad video driver. I had to cold boot everytime I hit this issue. I changed my power settings to \\"never turne off display\\" and the problem still wont go away. I also noticed the wireless and bluetooth LED indicators would turn off along with the monitor. This gave me an indication it is not likely a power manager or video driver problem, I tried to think of all possible reasons. I blamed by SSD and Seagate HDD for this problem as usual. Got an RMA number for the Seagate HDD too. Ahhh... I replaced my memory too last week. So I removed the 16gb RAM and put back the old 8GB I had in my possession. After that I have been running fine with my old memory, display turns off and comes back on without any problem. So I think it is very likely a Komputerbay memory that has caused all this mess.

As for memory speed etc... I saw no difference whatsoever. I wish it worked in my W520, unfortunately it did not.

Amazon was kind enough to pay for return shipping and take it back. When Itried to get RMA number from Newegg for the Seagate HDD, they not only forced me to pay for the return shipping, they tried to print the UPS lable for me so they could make some money on it, they claimed it costs me less, but it costs just the same had I done it myself - I am sure they have a spectacular deal with UPS, I know this because I too work for a large corporation. Also I dont see Newegg offering great deals anymore, for some reason they are becoming more like CircuitCity. (BTW I never had to return my Seagate after I found the problem was with my memory).

This has got to be the dumbest \\"smart\\" cover ever. It doesn't do any of the things the Apple one does except fold over. Its cheap but if your looking of quality, this isn't it.

Don't Buy!!!
It sucks donkey nuts

INITIAL REACTION
The cover came packaged with just a clear plastic box and a small generic insert with the product name and the company. There were no instructions what-so-ever. It's pretty logical where the items should face (holes line up where ports are etc) and so the designers must have thought any idiot can put it on.

PUTTING IT ON
Hey it was a snap. It looked good and the macbook air closed without a problem. The item looked like it could withstand several scratches and a dink or two.

TAKING IT OFF
It is nearly impossible to take this thing off! While the tabs (there are six of them - two where the screen meets the keyboard and four along the edge closest to you) that holds the cover to the macbook in place very securly, it also causes a major problem for those who wants to take it off for whatever reason. It took me nearly 30 minutes to loosen ONE tab. At that point I got irritated and decided to cut the tabs off with my flush cutter...which surprisingly cut through the cover with ease.

I would not recommend this item unless you plan on never taking it off.

I'm a prety hard core gamer. When I first saw the Nostromo n40 Gamepad, I thought it would be the best thing for my gaming since the mouse. Installation was very easy to do - just plug it into the USB and insert the CD. The gamepad also felt very natural in my hand. It's also very easy to create different configurations for my games. It seemed prety great until I sat down and started gaming with it - it was then I found the reason why I never use this.
The gamepad only recognizes up to 3 simotaneous button pushes at a time. If you press 4 or more, the pad goes crazy unlike what would normally happen with a keyboard. Pressing 4 or more buttons might not seem like something you do much but you'll be surprized how much you do (especially in FPS games).
For instance, I was playing Medal of Honor with my Nostromo. I move diagonally right while crotched (a total of 3 button presses to do). While I'm doing this, I might press the \\"use\\" button. But because the nostromo goes haywire after 3 button preses, I would whip out a grenade and throw it at my feet.
Although the nostromo had great potential, it's one serious flaw prevented me from using it more than three times. It's now somewere behind my computer gathering dust.

I have Comcast which enables me to check my internet speeds on my computer and after installing this product my down load speeds went down from 50mbps to 8mbps and up load speeds went down from 12mbps to 3mbps. I called NetGear ans spent one hour on the phone with no results. I had four green lights and move it in three different spots and that also didn't work so I sent it back. What a waste of time! I fixed the problem by using a splitter and moved my modem/router under my TV and hard wired it with a Ethernet cable to my TV . I now have 5 bars and the TV works great when streaming.

Google may have taken over the internet, but they can't make a decent laptop (or Google Drive app... but that's a discussion for another time). Despite having received about three different chargers and the space of several months and having to send the laptop (if you can call a piece of metal and plastic that hardly works a laptop) in to have the hard drive fixed, it still refuses to charge. The customer service is better than other companies I've seen, but noting has changed. It stops charging after a couple of months. Also, the mousepad is one of the flimsiest things I've ever seen and it's pretty much broken, making navigating the internet a hassle. The battery life is pathetic. Don't believe Amazon, take it from a user. It's four hours and thirty minutes and it takes three times longer to charge. You can't take it to school to take notes on, it will die before then. You have to keep it next to an outlet to be able actually use it. Also, it takes about thirty minutes to connect to wifi and it will drop the connection a random times. I had to use a chromebook for a test once and it spent about ten minutes trying to 'reconnect' to the school's wifi. All in all, just stay away from these... things. It has huge defects that Google has been ignoring and you'd be better off just sticking to your phones and tablets. These laptops have nothing to offer that an iPhone or iPad can't. Honestly, it may be cheaper, but you'll spend more time calling Customer Service than actually using it.

-Proud Apple Customer

I got all excited to buy this 4 port KVM switch because it supposedly is easy to set up, comes with all connecting cords needed, and works with Mac minis. Hmmm....here's the system I am trying to hook up:

1 new Mac Mini Model A1347 (bought last year)
1 older Mac Mini intel core Duo Model A1176
1 old Mac Mini intel core solo Model A1176

When I tried to hook up the two older Mac Minis I realized their VGA pin portals were completely different than the IOGear KVM cords! The old minis have a configuration that I can only describe as 24 holds with a cross/4 hole shape to the right of that. The IOGear KVM cords have 14 pins and no cross thing and are much smaller plug.

There is probably an adaptor I can buy but I am not sure which one I need and if it will work with the IOGear KVM ( my experience is that sometimes when you add too many connectors- gobetweens it messes up a machine like the KVM).
Any experts out there want to weigh in on:

*What adaptors do I need to make this work?
*Should I just return the dang thing and get my money back?

Please email me directly in addition to posting here so I am sure I'll get your responses.
Thank you!
prqueen@mac.com

I need to preface this review based strictly on the comparison between my Paperwhite and this table. I LOVE my Kindle Paperwhite, I can read anywhere, in the dark, in the bright sun, any light, with or without my polarized sunglasses. I didn't think that when I upgraded to the (triple the price) tablet, I wouldn't be able to read when wearing my sunglasses. What a huge and total disappointment. I get screaming headaches in bright light and if I don't wear good polarized glasses, I can't be outside for any length of time. I had planned to use the tablet mostly for reading, on my deck, in airplanes, at the picnic table at work for lunch, etc., but will be limited to only indoor reading, which is my least favorite place to read. When I wear my polarized lenses, the screen is all blanked out, like when trying to sign the credit card screens with sunglasses.... not happening.

It's larger than my Paperwhite, and not as heavy or clunky as my 17" Dell laptop, but it's pretty useless as a reader. Also, the super shiny screen shows fingerprints galore, which is annoying as all get out. Truthfully, I may try to send it back and stick with a huge laptop and a reader that I can actually use for reading!

I bought a Dell after having some very bad customer service from them years ago and swearing to never buy a Dell again.
Well I read a review on the m4700 on PC Magazine and decided to take a chance. NEVER NEVER AGAIN!It has been a 5 month living nightmare. I was sent a m4800 as a replacement for a broken m4700. So this does include the M4800.
I bought the m4700 5 months ago and it was broken on delivery. They sent a tech guy out who replaced the screen, hard drive, video card and something else. 3 service calls the first week I had the new computer.
The computer shut down all the time and gave me copious blue screens. After hours on the computer with the remote repair they gave up finally. After 3.5 months of nothing but problems. Then 3 weeks ago they sent me a brand new m4800. After two weeks it totally broke. It is unfixable. The tech guy replaced the motherboard, video card, power source twice in a week and it is unfix-able. I asked for a refund. They refuse. I have documented all the phone calls and hours and I have spent over 30 hours and been hung up on over 25 times in 5 months. Or \\"disconnected\\" They bounce you from India, to the wrong dept, to this and that and no one takes responsibility for your case. It is so bad.
I have now been without a computer for another 10 days and it will be another 3-4 weeks before they can get me a replacement. Since I bought this computer I have not had one good day of use and yet they refuse to refund me. I hate Dell with every fiber of my being now. I run an online business so this has severely impacted me. I have had to move hard drives over 3 times. I spent the entire weekend moving my files that are a year old to an old laptop I had to borrow, since the entire reason I bought this Dell in the first place is my Acer was overheating all the time.
I am on hold now with a tech talking to his manager to reorder the next replacement and guess what? He swore he would not hang up on me, and the phone just disconnected. Do not buy a Dell. Do not buy a Dell. It is not worth it. Miracle, he called me back. He said they cannot replace it since the service tech said it was unfixable, but that does not mean it cannot be fixed! The tech rep I told me I had to take apart my computer on the phone with him first before I could get a replacement.
He refused to order me a replacement. I decided to try a different tech rep and the next one I got decided to actually help me and order me my 3rd computer. I am not waiting for my 3rd computer from my original order 5 months ago.
Nightmare, total total nightmare. I am in the small-medium business sector so that is better service than the consumer, so it it is this bad for me, if you buy not as a business I cannot imagine how bad it would be.

1. I have the \\"traditional\\" ipad car seat holder (the one in which the existing leather type ipad case sleeve, goes into the ipad car seat holder; I'm doing a poor job of explaining it, but search on amazon, you'll find it) and the problem with that one is that you can't really adjust the viewing angle.

2. This ipad car seat holder is really a nice product in concept but is poorly built. Here's the bottomline:
a. In terms of ease of use and flexibility; it's awesome. It fits on the car seat and is rock steady. Huge caveat: you obviously need a car seat headrest that will actually come off. Most compact cars have this feature, but many larger cars / SUVs don't and thus won't work with this unit. The ipad fits perfectly and with ease into the casing and it is solid. Furthermore, you can move the viewing angle up / down / right / left; most excellent if you have two kids in the back.
b. Ok, so the above is great and it is. The problem is that the folks that brought you this item didn't put as much thought into the quality of product as they did the engineering of it. ie, with the weight of the ipad and the stress via being the car (ie road bumps etc...), the cheap cheap plastic joint spontaneously broke after around... 6 months of sporadic use. Now if they could make this same product with a metal type arm, that would be awesome, until then, definitely pass on this item because it will not last.

Description is a lie.
The screen is not IPS. It is a crappy screen with washed out colors when you look at it from a slightly high, low, or side angle. After using it for about an hour, my eyes started to hurt from the screen's colors constantly changing depending on how I slightly shifted my head when i was looking at it.
There isn't 1GB of ram. I used two system apps to check the specs and they both said there's 850MB of ram.
I am so sick of these tablet makers lying about the specs. Why do they think nobody can find out?
Which reminds me, it's not a 1.5Ghz quad-core. The spec apps say it's a 1.34Ghz quad-core.

Other things:
The box is not branded "Shamo's," neither is the little pamphlet inside with tiny writing.
Speakers were really good though.
If you press the back just a little bit with your fingers, you can create distortions on the screen.
A screen protector comes in the box.
The box wasn't sealed.

After reading the positive reviews on this tablet, I had relatively high hopes.  Now, based on the price I know I shouldn't expect much, but I thought my expectations were reasonable.  Just gave my 7-year old this for his birthday yesterday.  Right out of the box, my initial thoughts are this thing is slow and clunky and it doesn't even have any programs, apps, etc. really running on it.......  I figured 'Zoodles' would already be installed, but it appears I need to install it.  I have spent almost 1 hour trying to install it and it still appears to not be fully installed??  It says it cannot install Adobe AIR?  I don't know, I am not much of a Techie, but for a kids tablet, it should be pretty straight forward.  My son was super excited when he got this, as this is an upgrade from his LeapPad2 tablet, which doesn't do much.  I was able to get him on the internet to play some basic games.  He was very excited, love the green cover and was overall happy.  Today is day 2 with the tablet and after he got home from school he played with it a bit more.  It was freezing and acting slow (you tap something on the screen and it takes a few seconds to respond).  Also, it appears the screen needs to be calibrated, because it doesn't pick up the correct location where you touch.  After a little while, my son asked if there was a way to return this and get one that worked.....ugg!  Well, I am thinking I need to return this to Amazon.  The question is - should I try another Dragon Touch - maybe I got a bad one?  I am still seeing so many positive reviews, even recent ones.......Or should I just go with a Kindle Fire and call it a day?  Can't beat the price at $60, but for $40 more I can get a Kindle Fire.  Appreciate hearing any comments or feedback.  Update, 5/20/2015:  Okay, so I just dropped this off at UPS to return to Amazon.  my son hasn't used it because it is painfully frustrating to use.  looking at the reviews this morning, I must have gotten a bad one?   I can't believe all the rave reviews on this tablet.  I am not a techie, I don't have all the latest gadgets.....so it is not like my expectations were too high.  This thing reminded me of a four year old laptop you get handed down at work......well, the search continues for a replacement for my son.

This desktop has decent performance, especially for the price, however, I found the fan noise unacceptable.   I realize that this CPU/GPU combination needs a lot of cooling, but I have not heard computer fans this loud outside of a server  room. My first thought was that one of the fans was defective, but after doing some research I found that this is a common  complaint of the HP Pavilion line.    If you are purchasing this for use in a loud office environment, the excessive noise might not be an issue, but if you  plan on sitting next to this unit in a quiet bedroom or home office, you might want to think about buying something else.  (At least go to a retail store and listen for yourself.)    I returned my unit after only one day.

At the same time I bought a Logitech Webcam C210 for around the same price.  It was a night and day difference. They are quoted as having the same stats but WOW the Logitech was much better.

Bought this guy off newegg.  First one froze occasionally.  After about a month it would only post about 1 out of 4 times when hitting the power button.  Set up an RMA and asrock replaced it with a new tested motherboard.  I only had to pay shipping to send it to them.  New motherboard got here with two bent pins where the power button connector goes and one completely broken off pin that is unused next to the bent ones.  I did not need the broken pin and the motherboard ended up powering fine with the pins bent so I kept it to avoid the hassle of another RMA and another month without my new machine.  Will not buy asrock again.  Decent motherboard but you would think they would have better quality control...

Quite useless. I think this is actually a reasonable research project, but to market this as an actual product is misleading. It aims to be a 3D manipulation device, but I could not find any task - 2D or 3D that it could do at all reasonably. The simplest thing I could think of - scrolling - does not work. It does not reliably capture your engagement with scrolling, the motion is very inaccurate, and it does not reliably capture disengagement, so you continue to scroll when you don't want to. It is so painful to use, I could not do it for any length of time inspite of the coolness factor. Perhaps one would learn to scroll reliably, but that's a lot of work for very little benefit! (I'm not sure I'd want to scroll with my hand in the air even if I could, but at least that would be working as advertised).

What makes things worse is that the hype requires the device to attempt to be even fancier (there are 'media' controls and a host of 'apps' and 'games'). Given that no single action worked reasonably, you can imagine what the 'games' were like - exercises in patience!
It is fine to buy if you are a grad student working in this area or looking to do a (carefully rehearsed) demo, but is otherwise a waste of money.

HOWEVER, the Ethernet port NEVER worked and when connecting through it today, no bueno, so to UPS the refurb goes...And fingers crossed on the new one tomorrow...

UPDATE: Jan 2016
Unfortunately, a couple months ago I went to transfer a 90GB virtual machine to it and it overheated and disconnected right before finishing. Thought perhaps it was a one-off. But no, tried again now and same thing happened. Sigh. Worked great while it lasted. I still have data on it and as long as you don't do sustained throughput it appears to be working fine, but you can't have issues with something as important as a drive.

--

I am extremely pleased with this drive.

Bought the 512GB version and the speeds on it are phenomenal. In fact, the speeds came out so well testing with BlackMagic that I thought something was wrong with the app: 295MB/s write and 433 MB/s read. This is faster than my SSD on my 2013 rMBP and has twice as fast reads and writes than another Samsung 840 256GB drive that I have in a Gauntlet2 USB 3.0 external enclosure (which is also 6x the size of the tiny MyDigitalSSD enclosure). A very small, reliable, and fast package that I would easily buy again; highly recommended for anyone else in the market for an USB 3.0 connected fast drive.

Was disappointed with this purchase.  The time it takes to process the print command was about 10 seconds -- a delay that I couldn't accept.I was using a brand new Windows 7 32-bit machine with i3 processor so I don't believe the delay was due to the machine.  Unfortunately I believe this is a case of old technology not playing well with new technology.  I returned the product.

Pro's: It was easy to unpack. It was also easy to repack when I returned it.  Con's: 1. All of the social media sharing, more than 3 user accounts, and access across the internet all require the purchase of a premium account from [...].  2. Registration on [...] is mandatory in order to use the device. Your device name must be unique (if another user has the same device name, you have to pick another name)  3. Device needs to be restarted too frequently as it loses its network configuration  4. Video streamed from device is sub-par on a 1000MBPS connection  5. While its OS is Linux based, you cannot access it through any means  6. Configuration issues caused set-up to take in excess of 90 minutes  7. Poor offshore support  8. Firmware update bricks device requiring a hard reset  9. Device does not, as stated on the packaging, work with any SATA HDD  10. Attaching USB HDD to USB port according to instructions is problematic  11. Does not work with any uPnP device as claimed  12. Barely works with Linux (Fedora and Ubuntu distro's)  13. storage cannot be mapped as a network drive    This was the single most useless piece of hardware I ever used. Netgear has permanently lost me as a customer because of the lack of support and poor quality of this device. I would sooner revert to a typewriter than use another one of these Stora devices again.

Mounting this fan as an exhaust fan blowing upwards is a sure way to destroy the bearings in the Fan within couple weeks and accordingly, destroying this fan. Unsure if this is due to the modal vibrations which may be seen with a high speed camera while mounted in such horizontal orientation or whether the bearings are poorly designed. Regardless, if the bearings and/or the fan itself is not designed for certain orientation or application, then properly label the product for the designed/intended orientation (e.g., vertical orientation). However, based on the product description, the product is currently defective.

Please note that other sleeve bearing fans do not appear to exhibit the issue discussed above.

This mouse is as great as everyone says it is. Unfortunately if you use this mouse to travel with do not expect 2 AA batteries to last you an entire trip. I just got back from vacation and used the computer to tie up loose ends at work. I used the mouse/computer for less than 12 hours and I turned it off after every use and the batteries were dead after one week.

In my opinion a week of battery life after less than a 2 full \\"work days\\" is unacceptable for a laptop travel mouse. The battery in the Microsoft mouse I replaced with the Logitech Anywhere mouse would last for at least 5 months before it needed changing. If you use this Logitech mouse a few days a week for a year and you turn it off after every use you will go through 104 batteries.

The mouse really is perfect in every other way just like the Logitech Performance Mouse MX I own however they both need batteries weekly rather than a couple times a year like Microsoft mice.

Pros: The shape off the mouse is good for small hands and the buttons are within reach at a decent price. It is smooth and decent for gaming that does not require too many skill buttons.

Cons: The software does not work since window 7 does not recognize the mouse for the software to work. After plugging it in a couple of times, windows recognized the mouse but the software accompanied with the mouse does not. After searching online for answers to this problem, I realized it is a huge problem that hasn't been resolved. After contacting logitech with no answers, I gave up and was too lazy to return the mouse. Logitech has problems with customer service. I contacted Microsoft for answers and they stated it is an issue on Logitech's end. Another problem I encountered was if I unplugged the mouse after the computer is off, it will fail to detect it the next time the computer is turned back on. I would have to go through the process of installing, restarting windows again. Also contacted HP for help but they could not resolve the issue.

I bought this based on my Gateway laptop being mentioned in the description.  It did NOT fit my laptop and was, in fact, the wrong wattage.  I have since sold the laptop as is and threw this adapter in the junk pile.

This seemed like the device I always wanted - a simple, inline ad blocker that could replace all the browser extensions throughout my house. Something I could just plug in between my router and modem and not think about every again.

Unfortunately, I was very disappointed and have submitted the device for a return / refund.

The biggest annoyances for me are video pre-rolls (e.g. YouTube, Hulu, etc.) I had hoped this would block most, if not all, of the video ads but it did not (a large part of this is due to TLS being used by default by most services these days). In fact, I noticed more ads with the device than I did before using the AdBlock extension.

Beyond that, it created a double NAT between my home network and my ISP that caused big headaches with port forwarding. It was essentially not worth the hassle of confutation, plus the expense, to get only margin blocking effectiveness.

Ads may just be a part of life these days ... either way, this device does little to remove them.

Other times, the setup would drop and you'd have to do the whole thing over again - which is easy but definitely time consuming and not convenient.

The software is designed to show everything available through the freetime program, which encourages kids to run new apps, which would be great except that the storage management is quite possibly the worse implementation ever. Very little storage is available to begin with, and rather than swap out/off apps when space is needed for a new one (the others can always be re-downloaded on next launch, right?) the tablet runs out of space about 3 times a week on average.

When storage is limited, does the kindle THEN auto-remove or archive items? Of course not, it instead DISABLES WIFI. This is a great solution, as now, even things like netflix, which simply stream (and or course use some buffering space) won't work either. So the tablet then can't download new apps/games, and also can't use any wifi requiring applications.

Since it's a kid's tablet, you then have to put in the parental password, go to settings, clean up applications, and then re-enable wifi. Then, you get to do it again in 1-3 days.

This is probably the single biggest tech mistake purchase I've ever made, but we wanted them in time for x-mas and the had just been released. My kids mostly end up on our normal tablets anyways, as these (I was dumb enough to buy two) are constantly in a state of lock-down from storage usage.

Don't make the same mistake - get a 'normal' android or apple tablet, and then get a child-proof case.

To begin this review I should mention that I am a heavy Kindle user and previously owned the Keyboard Kindle. On this older Kindle I had a great cover. It had a magnetic tab closure to hold the cover closed. when you flipped the cover completely open, that same tab could flip around and hold the cover open. You could then slide your hand into the inside pocket to hold the Kindle with one hand. Either Hand. And you could easily use the hand holding the device to change pages with ease.

This Paperwhite cover is beautiful. It feels like heavyweight cardboard with a plastic back case. The Kindle fits very well. And there is a fun feature that wakes your Kindle when you open the case. Fun, but far less necessary than the missing features. The case snaps closed, but won't remain open. There is no pocket or loop on the inside of the case to slip your hand into. Ultimately, there is no comfortable way to hold the Kindle in this case in one hand and turn the pages.

I'm very disappointed, especially since I pre-ordered this case and paid full retail price for it. Without these features the only advantage that this case provides is to protect the Kindle when it's in my handbag, and I can get a $15 case later to accomplish that.

I've used this for about 2 years now. Before the first year was out, one half of it stopped working. It just stopped sending the signals from one machine. There was a warranty so I called to have it replaced and it cost me about 1/3 of the entire original to ship the bad one to them. Still, I figured it was cheaper than a new one so no big deal...hardware goes bad sometimes. Today, just now, the new one went bad (it has been another year give or take a month). That is enough for me. It's not so much the cost, which is cheap as far as KVMs go, as the hassle.

In addition, with this KVM, to switch between machine you press the scroll lock key twice and then either an up or down arrow. Not a big deal unless you switch a lot. Doing computer support in a consulting role for a living I've come across many KVM switches. Most of them are just too expensive for the normal home user but one I've used quite a bit is the IOGEAR GCS62 MiniView Micro KVM Switch. It has never failed and you scroll lock twice and it switches machines. It is about the same price...My recommendation is to buy that instead. I just did. =)

P.S. A couple people mentioned that they'd have to unplug and replug everything because it loses it's signal. That has also happened to me many times and a few times unplugging didn't do it. I had to shut down both machines and then restart them both so the KVM could \\"figure itself out\\".
It was poor quality with all device and wires. It worked for first 2 days and 3 day it died. Thanks to amazon I got money back. It is and giving me 1080P quality.

Update: Closing in on 1 year owning this laptop and I have NEVER owned or worked with a machine that has had more inexplicable issues.  It has been sent back twice--working on the third as I type this. The screen had dead pixels.  Half the usb port drivers died.  For several weeks now, when powering on, sometimes it powers on, other times it just sits there with the screen backlit but no one home.  Essentially, I have to system wipe it every 3 months or it doesn't work.   Occasionally, the NVIDIA card won't be detected by the system and hence no drivers will work or install.  Don't think Razer has solved the heat dissipation issue and the video cards are flaky. And I think there's a short somewhere in my system.  I'm a pretty experienced computer person and this one has driven me crazy.     Pretty much everything positive you've heard about this laptop is true.  I bought it for the screen pretty much alone.  It doesn't get 5 stars because the amount of HF noise on the adapter line is ridiculous.  I'm going to try a few different plug configurations, but when it is charging (and it's plugged into a pretty high quality power filter so I don't think it's that), there is a fairly unacceptable amount of noise that enters the system from the AC charger.  I have a pretty complex setup and In my case, it travels through a KVM (only plugged into usb for key/mouse at the moment on the laptop) I have set up and through the sound output which is why it's so bad--I can't listen to music through either system when it's plugged in.  Toroid coils also haven't helped but I was just using ones I had around the house.  Everything is plugged into that power filter, but it still could be the KVM (it's a good one, but when a system like that has so many plugs in proximity, the cross-talk is going to be bad regardless).  So I don't know.  Razer, you have any thoughts on the AC noise? Not sure it can be fixed...  <<Update>> Bypassed the sound from the KVM direct to a different stereo input and it's reduced the noise significantly at the expense of flipping more buttons to change sources.  Tweaking the gain on each device suppresses the noise, but it's still there.  Gets an additional star since I got it working, but could be a problem for serious audiophiles...

Pros:  This laptop performs at a level that will exceed the requirements of most users.  Games run at high settings with little trouble.  The full 1080p screen is vibrant, and leaves little to be desired.  Plenty of processor power.  Ton of Ram  Minimal useless bloatware  Cons:  In the 3 months since purchasing this computer, I have had several issues with it.  First, it gets hot, those vents on the back aren't just for show, they move some air. Expect something akin to the exhaust coming out of the tail pipe of your car. This is easily remedied by picking up a cooling mat, preferably something with a little elevation, especially if your going to have it sitting in your lap.  Second, 3 weeks after receiving the laptop, The user files on the HDD were corrupted, rendering the computer useless. The only solution was to do a clean install of Windows 7.  Third, the DC charging pin attached to the motherboard broke off into the charger. This rendered the laptop unable to be charged up at all.  Other thoughts:  Battery life isn't the greatest, but anyone surprised by that should probably read the specs on the computer again. It doesn't sip power, it chugs through it like a desktop, even in battery saving, low power mode.
Only lasted a few months. Invest a little more and buy a quality charger with a longer cord.

The Kindle Fire HDX 7" was ordered by my children as a gift for my husband while he was in the hospital, to be followed by an extended recovery period at home.  We were told that it was chosen because of its claim to "senior friendliness" and ease of use, aided by the Mayday button, should he - or we - run into any difficulty with it.  My son, in particular, who is a computer engineer, suggested that it would be more frustration-free than Netflix or other readily available entertainment sources.  None of the above proved to be true.  The first device involved an array of problems that led to the conclusion that it was defective.  When my son visited for several days, he reached this conclusion despite all his expertise and attempts at help from Mayday.  He arranged to have a replacement sent.  Regardless of numerous attempts at help from Mayday for the second one, we lost all the programs that had been downloaded on the first one,  as well as the trial membership to Audible Books. Now we are even having trouble with confusion over our prime account and a notice that it has been canceled.  The recovery and rehab period are closer to the end than the beginning, but my husband has been unable to get any use out of this device.  The Mayday feature has been worse than useless - just one more source of frustration. It has been a total dud and a complete disappointment.  We would recommend it to no one.

I have had the Belkin pre-N router for quite some time and it has performed flawlessly. My two year old recently decided to remove the antennae so i thoght I would try the new draft n products. Belkin hadn't released the N1 so I began with the Netgear Rangemax 240. This was a dismal failure and support was atrocious. Undeterred, I then tried the Netgear Next. Equally poor result. Finally after weeks of waiting, I got my hands on the Belkin N1. Easy setup,and blazing speed-when it works. It loses connection with my Motorola surfboard modem at least once a day(seven days in a row). The N1 laptop card crashed my computer twice. In the mean time I'm using a very dependable Belkin super G router-no problems whatsoever. I ordered a new Belkin pre N today. If it ain't broke ,don't fix it! I love the Belkin product. Documentation and support are superb. Setup is a snap. I just think that wireless n is just not there yet. I was looking at this mouse for a while and finally decided to buy one.  I also bought a wired Corvette mouse as a gift for someone else. It worked right out of the package and there were no installation issues at all.  It actually worked surprisingly well......for two weeks.  Then a plastic headlight came loose and it started acting sporadic.  I thought it may be out of battery since it came with low quality batteries ,but when I removed the battery cover, I noticed the batteries were not seated properly.  When I removed the batteries, one side of the battery contacts fell into the void in the mouse.  I could not get it to reseat in the battery compartment so it will no longer work.      I was willing to live with the cheap feel and the less than comfortable shape since it was such a unique mouse, but I'm not willing to pay this much for a plastic \\"model\\" to sit on my desk since it no longer works.  Hopefully, the wired mouse will last longer than the wireless did.

I like products that Belkin makes, especially for portable devices. Past reviews have borne this out. However, while this product does most of what it claims to, it falls very short in one critical area.

But first, the good points.

For any dock or base that is going to accept a phone or tablet (especially a full-sized iPad), stability is key. Fortunately, this item has that handled, but just barely. It's width of just over 3.25" is very proportional for iPhones but it's a little on the narrow side for an iPad. That difference makes the dock dependent upon its weight to keep the iPad from tipping. If not disturbed, it can do so, but if the iPad were to be bumped (such as brushing up against it or fumbling for something on a nightstand) I think it might be at risk for sending the whole works for a ride. The rear support for each of the two devices that can be plugged into it is suitable to hold both iPhones and iPads from tipping over backwards.

There is an adjustable dial for each docking bay that the instructions say will help adjust the Lightning plug at the base for a variety of devices, whether they are in cases or not. While a good idea in concept, the execution leaves something to be desired, and it's this execution that causes this product to get no more than a rare 2-star rating from me.

The Lightning plug is embedded in a piece of black plastic that is roughly the size of the old 30-pin connector that was used on Apple products before the Lightning connector was introduced and became standard across Apple's new portable designs.

I would imagine that doing this made some sort of sense from a tooling or manufacturing perspective, but that plastic base prevents the Lightning plug from being able to make a solid connection with devices that are in most cases that I have, including one made by Belkin for the iPhone 5. I also tried an Otterbox Commuter case for the iPhone 5, as well as an Otterbox Symmetrycase for the iPhone 6. All of those cases do not have a port hole wide enough to accept the wide plastic base on this dock, and no amount of adjustment with that dial is going to change the fact that the plastic base won't fit into a case port hole that is made for the much smaller Lightning connector.

I contacted Belkin customer support for assistance, but that was Wednesday morning, and it's now Sunday night, and I never received a response, or even a confirmation message that they received my inquiry and were looking into the issue and would get back to me.

Given the fact that this dock advertises itself to work with devices in cases and that it has what I consider a design flaw that would prevent it from doing so, and that I contacted Belkin and haven't heard a response even after 3 business days, I can't give this item more than a 2-star rating.

If that plastic base were to be replaced with something much smaller, I would be happy to give it a 4-star rating. If you have cases that will fit that large base or that are so shallow that it won't matter (like most iPad cases), then it's a decent product. For me, it's pretty useless unless I take a Dremel and see if I can remove that extra plastic myself. No one should have to do that, especially for a device with this price tag.

So I had a number of G5 towers sitting around after a transition to Mac Pro's.  Decided one of them could be repurposed as a backup machine if only I could squeeze some more disks in there to get the storage.  Searching around for ways to add more disks to the G5 tower, I came across the Sonnet G5 Jive, purportedly able to add three additional drives to your G5.  I did my research, found all good reviews, checked out Sonnets page for the G5 Jive ([...] and confirmed it should be a go.  I even bought Western Digital drives as recommended on their page - and thinking about how smart I was being, I bought their Green drives which are supposed to pull more power than regular drives.  I should note I bought TB disks - they are cheap enough and common enough now that it made sense.    I installed it all - easy enough - and went to power it on.  The G5 hummed for about 2 seconds before powering down.  Huh.  Checked all my connections and then tried again.  Same hum, same powering down.  Disconnected the Jive, then tried again - all okay, powered up.  So, it was the Jive.  Maybe I'd made bad connections, so I disconnected then reconnected everything.  Same problem, two seconds of power, then gone.    Called Sonnet.  They always seemed to be a good company in my mind.  After some hold time I got on the phone with a fairly gruff sounding guy - no niceties here!  After explaining what had happened, and giving him all my info, he put me on hold again to chat with a colleague.  And then came back on and confirmed that I was using TB drives.  Yes.  Well there, apparently, is the problem.  When developing the Jive, Sonnet claimed that there were only 500GB & 750GB drives to test with and that they had never tested with 1TB drives.  Never?!  Nope...decided not to test them when 1TB drives became commonplace either.  Turns out, 1TB drives pull too much power.  And they acted like it was my fault for even trying to use TB drives!     So now I am stuck with 5 1TB drives, a Sonnet G5 Jive and a Sonnet Tempo SATA X4i PCI card - well over $1k worth of kit - and can't use it.  I told the support guy they need to keep testing their products and updating their product pages as they find information out like this.  We'll see how quickly they fix this.  It's messed up I tell ya.  So...if you are hoping to use this to expand your G5 with some modern hard drives - don't.  It just doesn't work :-/  Sonnet has now become 'The Worst Company Ever' in my book.

I take road trips and I thought it would be great.  Let me tell you, there is no way you would be able to hear the narrator in a moving car, with or without earphones. Also some movements cause the Kindle to advance pages without even touching the screen.  This machine is being returned and exchanged for a different model. I am not ready to totally give up on Kindle, there are too many good comments, but this particular model needs more work.

For starters, my battery only lasted for about 1.5 hours brand new.  I have an HP dv6000, and like most notebook owners, my computer performance is fast, but not spectacular, lying somewhere in the middle.  The HP battery monitoring system (i.e., little battery icon in the system tray) grossly OVER-estimates the charge level.  The battery holds charge for about an hour, then rapidly descends off a cliff.  THE ANNOYING THING is that my battery slips past the HP power management system, which is configured to give me a warning when I have 10% power remaining.  The result: my laptop unexpectedly and ungracefully blacks-out in the middle of operation!      Taking a closer look at the design, the shape of the battery pack casing (with its glorious external row for extra life) looks like it contains rechargeable AA cells.  It's hard to believe that this battery is a Li-Ion, or maybe it is of cheaper quality; so much so, that it is apparently foreign to my HP power management system.  The previous battery that I purchased (for $90) was not great either, lasting only a year, but was recognizable enough that my system was able to accurately estimate the remaining charge level.     So I regret to say that it may be worth shoveling out the extra cash on a certified HP battery.  Sometimes the peace of mind and quality is worth the added cost (at least to me).  With the money I have wasted over the past year, I could have already purchased an HP battery which lasted me 2 years.
